Thornburgh's aides said the attorney general had not authorized Ayer's letter. Other officials, however, said Ayer's letter merely expressed a longstanding department policy now being questioned by the White House. An FBI investigation ordered by Thornburgh into the unauthorized leak of information about a criminal probe involving the office of Rep. William H. Gray III, D-Pa., identified Runkel as a ``secondary source'' of the news story. While Thornburgh defended his longtime aide, the disclosure of Runkel's role in the episode was a political embarrassment.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Max Woodbury got an invitation to dine with fat cats at a GOP fund-raiser attended by the president. But Max will probably stay home _ maybe snooze in the sun, play with a ball of yarn or toy with a mouse. The 2-year-old cat somehow wound up on the mailing list for the President's Dinner, scheduled for June 12 in Washington. Jennifer Woodbury said she and her husband are Democrats who never sent a dime to either political party, so she has no idea how Max Woodbury got an invitation. ``The only thing I can think of is they got it off a mailing list,'' she said. ``I sent away for dry flies from a mail order company and put it in Max's name'' so the the flies could be a surprise gift for her husband. Liz Hamel of the National Republican Congressional Committee said Monday that all invitations for the annual event are sent to GOP contributors. ``Either Mr. Woodbury's cat is on a mailing list, or somebody's playing a joke,'' she said. But if Max wants to attend, he can, she said _ providing he makes the $1,500-a-plate contribution.

It's baaaaaaack. The Return of the Two-Headed Calf. The public's fascination with a mounted two-headed calf has led a museum to put the oddity back on display beginning today. The calf died at birth in 1922 and its heads were mounted and displayed at the West Overton Museum from about 1930 to 1987, said director Kimberly Bringe. The oddity was popular among museum visitors, especially children. Still, Ms. Bringe thought no one would notice when she put the calf away because it was deteriorating. She was wrong. Parents who had seen the calf as children repeatedly asked about its whereabouts and several people offered to buy it. ``I think people are naturally attracted to oddities,'' Ms. Bringe said. ``Of the thousands of displays and artifacts we have here, people always want to see the two-headed calf. ... It's like a shrine. I call it the divine bovine.'' The calf, reconditioned by a taxidermist, is being put on display in the children's area. Each year, about 3,000 people visit the museum.

DOC.HEAD: Dubcek Says He Did the Right Thing
DOC.TEXT: Alexander Dubcek says he is satisfied he did the right thing in pressing ``Prague Spring'' reforms that brought on the 1968 Soviet-led invasion and a generation of hardline communist rule for Czechoslovakia. ``I wouldn't have done it differently. ... I can face the people in the public squares today,'' unlike now-discredited leaders swept out of power in his and other East European countries the past year, Dubcek said at a news conference Monday. Dubcek, Czechoslovak Communist Party chief at the time of the invasion, was restored in Prague's peaceful revolution last winter to the post of federal assembly president after living for two decades in political oblivion. After the news conference, Dubcek gave Vice President Dan Quayle his suggestion how Lithuania and other Baltic republics should handle their quest for independence for Soviet rule. They should engage Moscow in prolonged negotiations and take pains to avoid provoking the Soviet military, he was quoted as saying by a Bush administration source who spoke on condition of anonymity. The talk with Quayle concluded the first visit to North America by Dubcek, who was returning home aboard a special Czechoslovak government plane. Asked if he felt the 1968 invasion was triggered by reforms being too bold or too cautious, Dubcek said his 1968 policies ``derived from reality, and were not dependent on personal approach.'' Czechoslovak traditions of democracy and scientific and industrial skills made it ripe for change in 1968 although ``we attempted something not possible for us to reach at that time,'' he said. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev deserves help and understanding in his reform efforts, Dubcek said. He appealed for understanding of ``Gorbachev's difficult legacy'' of economic, domestic and foreign relations problems. ``It is necessary to alter views about the Soviet Union and not be against everything there,'' he said, adding that ``the Soviet Union needs help in many fields: diplomatic, economic and political first of all.'' Czechoslovak and Soviet conditions are very different, he said, but the two countries today share aims of democratization, decentralizing their economies and easing divisions between the people and the state. Dubcek he said he is against ``collective guilt,'' apparently meaning ousted communists should be judged by specific actions, not party membership. He said measures are being taken to recover wrongly diverted public funds. Efforts are being made to identify those former comrades who signed the letter inviting Warsaw Pact armies to intervene in Czechoslovakia, Dubcek said. But he added that ``it doesn't really matter how many signatures there were'' because ``nothing can justify the invasion, which was the doing of the respective countries ... a decision of the governments of the participating countries.'' Czechoslovakia was invaded by units from Poland, Hungary, East Germany and Bulgaria in addition to the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Woman Admitted to Partnership
DOC.TEXT: The accounting firm Price Waterhouse is being required to give a partnership and back pay to a woman who argued that she was denied the promotion because she was not sufficiently ladylike. The decision Monday by U.S. District Judge Gerhard Gesell could mean Ann Hopkins will become a partner in the firm on July 1 and receive up to $400,000 in back pay, according to James H. Heller, one of her attorneys. ``She's won her case,'' Heller said. ``If they will take her back, that's what she wants to do.'' Heller said he believed this to be the first time a federal judge has ordered a firm to make someone a partner. Ms. Hopkins, formerly a senior manager at Price Waterhouse, left the firm in 1984 and has worked as a consultant to the World Bank. Price Waterhouse has not indicated whether it will appeal, Heller said. The case already has been to the Supreme Court, which ruled 6-3 last May that employers must bear the burden of proving they did not discriminate illegally once there is evidence bias played a part in personnel decisions. Gesell earlier had decided that there was evidence that Price Waterhouse discriminated against Ms. Hopkins, but he also found that the firm had other reasons which could have been grounds for denying her the promotion. The Supreme Court decision sent the case back to Gesell for further hearings based on the altered standard of proof.

DOC.HEAD: Workers Strike at Hyundai Motor Plant
DOC.TEXT: More than 27,000 Hyundai workers demanding higher pay and a shorter work week struck the country's largest auto plant today, halting production at the facility in the port city of Ulsan. The walkout came only a week after the plant, 200 miles southeast of Seoul, reopened at the end of a weeklong strike. That work stoppage was in protest of the April 28 police crackdown on strikers at the nearby Hyundai Heavy Industries Co. shipyard. Union and company officials at the plant, which produces 2,600 vehicles a day, said about 22,800 workers showed up at the plant for a solidarity rally and followed the union's decision the previous night to launch an indefinite strike. The remaining 4,200 workers on strike worked the night shift and would be staying home today. The action shut down production at the plant, which employs a total of 29,000 workers. Officials of Hyundai Motor Co. threatened to seek punitive legal action against union leaders and charged that they launched the latest strike without going through required legal procedures. However, the union leadership denied the charge and said the strike was called to press union demands after failing to reach agreement with the management despite 22 rounds of negotiations since Feb. 13. Hyundai workers demand, among other things, an 18.95 percent raise in their average monthly pay of $621 and a reduction from 44 to 42 hours in their work week. The company has offered a 5.95 percent wage increase. Hyundai Motor Co. sold 589,000 vehicles, including cars and trucks, in 1989. Annual sales included 200,000 vehicles, mostly subcompact cars, in exports, company officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Plans Test Of Vaccine To Protect Unborn From AIDS Virus
DOC.TEXT: A synthetic version of an AIDS virus fragment may be tested later this year to determine whether it can protect unborn babies from developing AIDS. Dr. Arye Rubinstein, professor at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York, said Monday that studies in his lab have shown that mothers infected with human immunodefiency virus (HIV)that causes AIDS will not pass the disease to their unborn if their immune system develops a particular type of antibody. Rubinstein said the body's immune system makes this antibody in response to a specific protein found in the gp120 molecule, which is part of the surface of the HIV virus. In a paper published in the May issue of the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, Rubinstein said his laboratory was able to correctly identify infants who would become HIV-infected by assessing the level of this PND antibody in their blood of their mothers. In a talk Monday at the Town Forum on AIDS sponsored by the Institute for Advanced Studies in Immunology and Aging, Rubinstein said his group plans to conduct trials later this year of a vaccine that uses a synthetic version of the PND protein.
DOC.HEAD: Ambassador Says Free Trade Agreement Can Be Reached With Mexico
DOC.TEXT: A free trade agreement with Mexico could take less time to negotiate than the one with Canada, says the Mexican ambassador. ``We can go faster. I think the key issues are going to be fewer,'' Gustavo Petricioli, Mexico's ambassador to the United States, told the Border Trade Alliance on Monday. ``If we can agree on the fundamentals, the basis of our positions on both sides, we can move very, very fast.'' Members of the alliance, a loose-knit group of business leaders and government officials from Texas, New Mexico, Arizona and California, said Petricioli's message was another sign Mexico is serious about doing away with trade barriers.
DOC.HEAD: NRC Staff Recommends Start for New York Nuclear Plant
DOC.TEXT: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission staff says the Niagara Mohawk Power Corp. had shown it can effectively manage and operate its Nine Mile Point Unit 1 nuclear power plant. The NRC staff said Monday it saw no impediment to restarting the reactor, on the shore of Lake Ontario, near Oswego, N.Y. It has been out of operation for more than two years.

DOC.HEAD: Six Bombs Explode in Santiago; Guard Wounded at U.S. Consulate
DOC.TEXT: Bombs exploded at the U.S. Consulate and five other sites in the capital, causing some damage and injuring a Chilean security guard at the consulate, authorities said. The bombs, which exploded during a 90-minute period late Monday night, also went off at a Jewish community center, the city's main Mormon church, an army parking lot, and the offices of two foreign-owned companies. An anonymous male caller to a Santiago radio station claimed responsibility for the army parking lot bombing on behalf of a previously unknown group calling itself the December 14 Commando. The bomb damaged a van in the lot. The caller said the group was demanding the resignation of Gen. Augusto Pinochet _ the country's former right-wing president _ as commander of the army. Police said no individual or group immediately claimed responsibility for the other bombings, including the one at the U.S. Consulate. The state-run television reported that the bomb at the consulate had been planted in a car parked in the rear of the compound. A police guard on duty at the U.S. Consulate said the blast damaged a parked car. He said an ambulance took a Chilean security guard from the scene, but his injuries were not considered serious. Bombs went off at the United Fruit Co., a joint U.S.-Arab company, and TNT International Transportation Co., an Australian firm, police said. Both companies have been the targets of bomb attacks by leftist guerrillas in the past. The pro-Communist Manuel Rodriguez Patriotic Front, a leftist urban guerrilla group, has claimed responsibility for bombing and shooting attacks on military and police targets. In recent years, another radical leftist group, the Lautaro Commando, has staged dozens of attacks on Mormon chapels in Chile, saying the Mormon Church is ``a tool of U.S. imperialism.'' The group takes its name from an Indian chief who fought the Spanish conquerors in the 16th century. Pinochet, who led the bloody 1973 coup that toppled Marxist President Salvador Allende, handed over the presidency in March to Patricio Aylwin, the civilian who won the Dec. 14 presidential election. But the general has stayed on as army commander under a constitutional provision adopted when he held power that bars any president from replacing him until 1998.

DOC.HEAD: Georgian Communist Chief Rejects Baltic-Style Independence Moves
With PM-Soviet-Baltics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Georgia's Communist Party leader rejected nationalist demands for immediate independence, saying such a move would jeapardize democratic reform introduced by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The party's stance toward independence is expected to be a key issue at the Georgian Party Congress which opens today, just 13 months after 20 people died in clashes between Soviet troops and pro-independence demonstrators in Tbilisi, the republic's capital. Givi Gumbaridze, who became the Georgian party leader after the April 1989 clashes, said he opposed calls for independence similar to declarations recently made by the Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. He has advocated more autonomy for the southern Soviet republic, but not immediate independence. Gumbaridze, in an interview published Monday by the national Communist Party newspaper Pravda, said those who sought an immediate political and economic break with the Soviet Union could only upset the process of democratization, known as perestroika, initiated by Gorbachev. ``Political boldness and political rashness are absolutely different things that exclude each other,'' he said. ``Some people are eager to seize power by means of `ultra-patriotic' calls for immediate independence,'' Gumbaridze said. Elsewhere, he said, some top officials refuse to give up privileges and allow the party to renovate itself. The only way to real independence and economic prosperity ``is to build a new, genuinely democratic society without renouncing everything already achieved,'' Gumbaridze said. Gumbaridze said the Communist Party should still be viewed as the leading political force in the republic, even though the Georgian Supreme Soviet in March removed the constitutional article that granted the party a monopoly on political power. ``Some people are forgetting that it was the Communist Party that stopped the sliding of our country to a catastrophe, gave the green light to perestroika, and opened the way to glasnost and democracy,'' Gumbaridze said. Gumbaridze said the Congress would set the party on a course that will provide Georgia with ``political and cultural growth and a moral revival of the people.'' But Mamuka Tsagareli, a spokesman for the radical Party of National Independence in the republic, said Georgia's Communist Party ``ought to disband.'' ``The Communist Party of Georgia is a criminal organization which has utterly discredited itself for the 70 years of the Communist regime in Georgia,'' Tsagareli said. Tsagareli said his group, which advocates Georgian independence from the Soviet Union, was not planning any action today because it does not want to interfere with the actions of another political party and it is too busy preparing for its own congress on May 23.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Down
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 31,997.04 on the Tokyo Stock Exchange on Tuesday, down 45.61 points, or 0.14 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Reformers Condemn Bill Making it a Crime to Insult President
With PM-Soviet-Baltics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Reform-minded legislators condemn a newly approved bill making it a crime to insult or slander the Soviet president, saying the measure could be used to terrorize and persecute government opponents. The Supreme Soviet passed the measure ``protecting the honor and dignity of the president'' on Monday, less than two weeks after an unofficial May Day protest in Red Square that saw thousands jeer President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other leaders. Alexander N. Yakovlev, a close aide to Gorbachev, has said the Soviet leadership was insulted by the demonstration. The new bill provides for a fine of up to 3,000 rubles (about $5,000 at the official exchange rate) or two years in a labor camp or three years in jail for slandering or insulting the president. An offense conducted with the help of the news media could be punishable by a jail term of up to six years, Tass said. It said a newspaper, radio or TV station carrying such material could be fined up to 25,000 rubles (about $41,600) and be suspended from broadcasting or publishing. ``It is not aimed at the protection of the president's dignity and honor; it opens up a possibility to persecute undesirable citizens,'' said progressive Deputy Sergei Belozertsev. ``I am afraid a wave of terror and repressions set off by this unfortunate law will sweep the country in the near future.'' The bill has an accompanying resolution, expected to be passed today, stating remarks critical of the president and his policies should not be confused with insults or slander, Belozertsev said. But it remains unclear how legitimate criticism will be separated from insults or slander in a country that has a long history of laws to stifle dissent. ``Who is to decide what is an insult?'' asked Belozertsev, who opposed the measure he called ``ignorant and reactionary.'' Ilmars Bisers, deputy chairman of the Council of Nationalities, said the law places the interpretive powers into the hands of local judges. Gorbachev, who on March 15 was elected to a more powerful presidency, has said he wants to use the office as a unifying force for the entire country. But criticism of his policies and pressures from several republics for autonomy or outright secession have become even more acute since Gorbachev took the post.

DOC.HEAD: East German Defense Chief: Warsaw Pact Seems to be Breaking Up
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's defense and disarmament minister says the future of the disintegrating Soviet-led Warsaw Pact could be decided at a meeting of the alliance next month. ``It now appears as though the Warsaw Pact is in the process of dissolving itself,'' said the minister, Rainer Eppelmann. ``Whether it has a military-political future depends on the meeting of the disarmament and defense ministers on June 7.'' He did not specify where the meeting will be held. Eppelmann, a Lutheran pastor, was named East Germany's defense and disarmament minister last month in the country's first non-Communist government. He said other Eastern European countries were questioning their role in the Warsaw Pact. ``The Hungarians have signaled that they want to leave the Pact, the Czechs want to let it stagnate, and with the Poles, it's not clear,'' Eppelmann said. The minister said he told his Soviet hosts on a recent visit to Moscow that a ``German republic'' cannot belong to the Warsaw Pact. Eppelmann's remarks, carried by East Germany's official ADN news agency, were some of the most pointed comments to date from within the seven-nation Warsaw Pact. Bulgaria and Romania are the two other members. Questions have been increasing about the continued existence of the military alliance since a democratic upheaval swept Eastern Europe last year. Facing growing pressure at home, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has been yielding control over Moscow's longtime allies in Europe. East Germany was one of the Soviet Union's staunchest allies under the German state's former hard-line Communist leaders. Eppelmann said it will be necessary to hold the Warsaw Pact together as a ``political alliance at least for an interim period.'' He said he was pressing for a ``total European'' solution to defense issues. Moscow officials already have proposed the breakup of the opposing military alliances, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact. But those proposals have been met with skepticism in Washington. Europeans in recent months have been talking increasingly about a continental solution for security issues as the various nations come closer together. The question of military alliances and allegiances is a major point in the continuing German unification talks. Moscow says a united Germany cannot remain in NATO. The United States, West Germany and their allies insist on such a membership. West Germany's foreign minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, has offered to let Soviet troops stay in what is now East Germany for a limited time during the unification process. In addition, the Bonn government is now negotiating a possible takeover of some of the costs of maintaining the 380,000 Soviet troops in East Germany, once the West German mark becomes the currency for both countries on July 2.

DOC.HEAD: Arizona Takes Up New King Holiday Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Hearings begin noon EDT; lead prospects uncertain.
DOC.TEXT: Hoping to deflect charges of racism against Arizona, Gov. Rose Mofford has called the Legislature into special session to create a new Martin Luther King holiday. The bill would designate both King Day and Columbus Day as paid holidays for state employees. It would wipe out a bill signed by Mrs. Mofford last year to create a paid King Day by making Columbus Day an unpaid holiday. The King-for-Columbus bill so angered King opponents and Columbus supporters that they joined forces and gathered nearly twice the needed signatures to have the law suspended pending a referendum this November. A Senate committee was to hold a hearing on the new measure today. While legislative leaders predicted passage before week's end, opponents vowed to gather at least 43,350 signatures and force a referendum after all. Among those pressing for a referendum is former Republican Gov. Evan Mecham, who was removed by impeachment in 1987 and is running for governor again. Forty-seven states have some sort of official holiday honoring King. Arizona has an unpaid holiday for him proclaimed by Mecham, the third Sunday in January. The other states without official King holidays are Montana and New Hampshire. Mrs. Mofford, Mecham's successor, been pushing for the new bill. She said lawmakers should settle the issue rather than put it on the ballot for all Arizonans to decide. ``We've never voted on a holiday before,'' she said. Addding a King Day to the holiday list rather than swapping it for Columbus Day would cost the state an $500,000 to $3.5 million, but Mrs. Mofford said the cost was worth it to avoid bad publicity over the lack of a King holiday. ``I would trade that any time for the amount of money it could cost us in the end,'' the Democrat said, citing possible sports and convention boycotts. ``I'm embarrassed because we're being referred to as a racial state.'' Controversy over a King holiday has dogged the state's politicians for years. Democratic Gov. Bruce Babbitt declared a holiday by executive proclamation as he was about to start a presidential bid in 1986. But Republican Attorney General Bob Corbin called it an illegal encroachment on the Legislature's role and Mecham rescinded it days before it would have taken effect. The ensuing uproar included marches, tourist boycotts and convention cancellations. The furor also fueled a recall drive against Mecham, but he was removed by impeachment on other grounds before the recall vote could be held. Last year's bill was ``a mistake that the Legislature made,'' Mrs. Mofford said. Asked why she had signed it with such ceremony last year if she considered it such a mistake, she replied, ``You don't veto a moral issue. I never thought that it would come to this.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Off Sharply, Stocks Gain
DOC.TEXT: The dollar dropped sharply against the Japanese yen Tuesday, and share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell moderately. The dollar closed at 151.30 yen, down 2.05 yen from Monday's close of 153.35 yen. After opening at 151.82 yen, the currency ranged between 150.15 yen and 152.15 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues shed 45.61 points, or 0.14 percent, to close at 31,997.04 points. The Nikkei index started slightly lower, but posted a moderate gain with 73.34 points at the end of morning session before closing lower. In the bond market, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 88.13 points as of 3:00 p.m. (4 a.m. EDT), up from Monday's close of 87.86. Their yield stood at 6.930 percent, down from the previous day's close at 6.985 percent. Currency dealers said the dollar's retreat followed its overnight decline in New York, where the U.S. currency ended at 152.50 yen, down from 152.70 yen last Friday. ``The yen strengthened against the dollar following yen-buying against the West German mark,'' which accelerated the dollar's slide, said a dealer of Fuji Bank, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The dealer said the yen-mark trading was an adjustment following the considerable buying of the West German mark over the past several weeks. ``The market's dollar-selling mood results from investors' expectations of a slow-down in the U.S. economy ahead of the release of major U.S. economic indicators,'' said Masato Hayashi, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo. Major U.S. indicators to be released this week include industrial production for April later Tuesday, the consumer price index and housing starts in April on Wednesday, and March trade figures on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Distraught Man Wounds American in Stabbing Incident
DOC.TEXT: A distraught man stabbed a retired American serviceman at a nightclub near the U.S.-run Subic Bay Naval Base, police said today. The victim was drinking with three other Americans at the nightclub Monday night when the unidentified assailant armed with a 7-inch knife stabbed him in the right shoulder, said Lt. Col. Nicanor Daos, chief of police. Daos identified the victim as Richard Rhodes, a retired U.S. serviceman on vacation. No details on Rhodes' personal background were immediately available. Daos said the attacker escaped after the stabbing and Rhodes was rushed to a hospital, where he was declared out of danger. A 26-year-old man believed to be high on drugs was arrested early today in connection with the stabbing, said the police chief of this city 50 miles west of Manila. The man, Alvin de Guzman, 26, told reporters that he attacked the American because he was irked by the buzzing of low flying jets. ``The (jets') noise was hurting my ears,'' de Guzman said. ``In my irritation, I attacked the American. The Americans own the jets, right?'' Authorities blame leftist guerrillas for the killings Sunday of two U.S. airmen near Clark Air Base, 50 miles north of Manila, a day before talks began on renewing the lease on U.S. bases in the Philippines.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Chief Backs Love Canal Resettlement
DOC.TEXT: The Environmental Protection Agency has pronounced most of the abandoned Love Canal neighborhood safe for people to move back in. EPA Administrator William Reilly endorsed a 1988 study of the virtual ghost town, removing the last federal barrier to the sale of 236 homes, or two-thirds of the homes evacuated in the '70s because of an underground leak of toxic chemicals. Reilly said Monday the study by the state and the EPA was legally and scientifically sound and should not be overturned as neighborhood and environmental activists had requested. ``There is no undue health risk to buying homes and raising children,'' he said. New York's Love Canal Area Revitalization Agency plans to sell 60 to 75 homes a year for three years beginning this summer, said James Carr, the agency's planning director. About 200 people already are signed up t buy homes. Among them is Philip Palmisano, a retired bar owner who lives in nearby North Tonawanda with his wife and son. ``I'm no scientist or chemist, but you have to take somebody's word on it,'' he said. ``The government wouldn't let us move in there if it wasn't safe, would they?'' The homes to be sold are in a ring around a huge dump in the middle of the neighborhood. All are two or more more blocks from a six-block-long pit left over from a canal project where tons of PCBs, dioxin and other toxic chemicals were dumped by Hooker Chemical Co. in the 1940s and early '50s. In the 1950s, the canal was covered and homes and an elementary school were built nearby. The federal government declared the neighborhood a disaster area in the 1970s, and more than 2,500 residents were evacuated. The homes probably will be sold by bid for $50,000 to $60,000, or 10 percent to 15 percent below market price in the area, Carr said. Lois Gibbs, a former Love Canal housewife who led the fight for federal aid to residents, said no adequate assessment of the health risks to future residents has been made by the state or the federal government. ``The law states specifically that they must do a risk assessment and they haven't,'' Gibbs said Monday from her Arlington, Va., home. She said she and the Natural Resources Defense Council will sue to block resettlement. In January, Gibbs and other environmental activists had met with Reilly to ask that Love Canal be turned into a hazardous waste research center. If the area is resettled, ``Love Canal will become the precedent for resettlement of other areas,'' said Gibbs, now executive director of the Arlington-based Citizens Clearinghouse for Hazardous Waste. Advocates of resettlement stress that state health officials have ruled the area safe. Sewers have been cleaned and so have nearby creeks, officials said. ``I think there's a strong perception in Niagara Falls that Lois Gibbs was a lot of hot air,'' Carr said.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``It's almost too good to be true yet. ... I didn't believe it at first. The Russians are coming.'' _ Minnesota Gov. Rudy Perpich, who said the White House notified him that Mikhail Gorbachev is considering a visit to his state.

``Even if all Soviet armed forces return to the U.S.S.R. and conventional arms control moves forward, the Soviet military will retain forces many times larger than those possessed by any other single state.'' _ Secretary of State James Baker III, promising to keep American troops in Europe, regardless of arms control agreements with the Soviet Union.

``I even had a woman last week that opened my front door and threw her check inside and got in her car and drove off and wouldn't even come inside.'' _Florist Bill Grealis, on about rumors he has AIDS and how people in Belle, W.Va., have almost driven him out of business.

DOC.HEAD: 5.3 Billion To Triple In Century Without More Family Planning
DOC.TEXT: The world's population of 5.3 billion may nearly triple in the next century and pose a serious threat to the environment unless family planning efforts are redoubled, according to a U.N. report released today. ``The next 10 years will decide the shape of the 21st century. They may decide the future of the Earth as a habitation for humans,'' said Dr. Nafis Sadik, executive director of the United Nations Population Fund. Only six years ago, the report said, population growth appeared to be slowing everywhere except Africa and parts of South Asia and world population seemed likely to stabilize around 10.2 billion toward the end of the next century. ``Today, the situation looks less promising,'' it said. ``Progress in reducing fertility rates has been slower than expected.'' ``If fertility reductions continue to be slower than projected, the mark could be missed yet again. In that case the world could be headed toward an eventual total of up to 14 billion people,'' Mrs. Sadik said. She told a news conference that ``the best and quickest way to reduce population growth'' is to invest in improving women's status, access to education, health and access to family planning. The U.N. Population Fund report recommended that spending on family planning in developing countries be doubled to $9 billion by the end of the century. Mrs. Sadik said she hoped the United States will resume support for the fund's activities. Last year, she said, the U.S. Congress voted to contribute to the fund but President Bush vetoed the bill. U.S. abortion opponents had charged that because the U.N. agency operates in China, which has a one-child-per-family policy, the money would have indirectly supported forced abortions. Every year during the 1990s, the population will increase by 90 million to 100 million people, roughly equivalent to the current population of Eastern Europe or Central America, the report said. Over the decade, a billion more people will inhabit the planet, equivalent to an extra China, it said. ``The 1990s will see faster increases in human numbers than any decade in history,'' Mrs. Sadik said. ``The choices of the next 10 years ... will decide whether world population trebles or merely doubles before it finally stops growing. They will decide whether the pace of damage to the environment speeds up or slows down,'' she said. World population growth continues to be grossly out of balance, with 90 percent of the increase in developing countries, and the biggest growth in the poorest of them, said the State of World Population 1990 report. ``At the start of the 1990s the choice must be to act decisively to slow population growth, attack poverty and protect the environment. The alternative is to hand on to our children a poisoned inheritance,'' it said. According to the latest U.N. projections, the report said, the world has overshot 1984 targets and is on course for a total nearer 11 billion than 10 billion. In 15 countries, 13 of them in Africa, birth rates rose between the early 1960s and 1980s and in 23 more countries, they fell by less than 2 percent, it said. In China, the world's most populous nation, Mrs. Sadik said family size still increased from 2.3 to 2.5, partly because of the age structure of the population and rural couples having more children. She said countries in which women had the lowest status and participated least in society tended to be the ones with the highest birthrates and countries with sustained political support for population programs achieved the best results.

DOC.HEAD: Taiwan Wants To Establish Unofficial Mission In China
DOC.TEXT: Taiwan wants to establish a mission in China to promote trade and other unofficial ties, a government spokesman said today. Although the Nationalist government is the sworn enemy of Communist China and has refused official contact with Beijing, hostility has thawed in recent years, leading to rising trade and other exchanges. Government spokesman Shaw Yu-ming said the mission would be a ``positive measure'' that could ``help solve the many problems arising from exchanges (with China) and will contribute to the stable and peaceful development across the Taiwan Straits.'' He said the government ``should fulfill its obligations to assist our businesses in trading (with China) instead of taking a hands-off attitude.'' Although the mission would be considered unofficial, it would receive government funding, officials said. Under the plan, China would be allowed to set up a similar office in Taiwan. But Shaw noted that Beijing has shown some suspicion about the plan if the two offices are to have equal status. The Nationalist government retreated to Taiwan in 1949 after losing a civil war to the Communist forces in China. Although the Nationalist government still claims to be the sole legitimate rule of all of China, Beijing considers Taiwan a runaway province. Shaw said government Mainland Affairs Committee proposed today to sanction any Taiwanese indirect investments in China other than high-technology products or projects that could harm national security. Taiwan authorities only allow investment in China if it is channeled through companies in third countries. Indirect investment totaled an estimated $1 billion last year. Many of the island's largest entrepreneurs want to directly set up factories in China to utilize cheap labor and land.

DOC.HEAD: Taxing Air Not a Well-Grounded Idea, Court Rules
DOC.TEXT: Slapping a tax on air isn't a well grounded idea, Vermont's Supreme Court says. The ruling Monday ended a legal tussle over air space between the cities of Winooski and Burlington. Fed up with noisy planes from Burlington's airport, Winooski a few years ago sent Burlington a $90,222 property tax bill for use of Winooski air space. William Wargo, who argued the case for Winooski, said the airport noise lowers the smaller city's property values. But the Supreme Court ruled in Burlington's favor, upholding a judge's ruling that the tax couldn't be imposed on an ``imaginary surface.'' The court said federal law recognizes certain ``imaginary surfaces'' above the Earth's surface extending from runways, but they are not subject to taxation. Moreover, the court said, the surfaces encroaching on Winooski's air space are established by the federal government, not by the city of Burlington. The ruling eased a bit of tension in the Clavelle family. Burlington Mayor Peter Clavelle grew up in Winooski and is the son of Raymond Clavelle, Winooski's longtime collector of delinquent taxes. ``In my heart I didn't feel it would pass, but with the judicial system you never know,'' the elder Clavelle said. His son lauded Winooski for its creativity. ``But I would have been real surprised if they would have prevailed,'' said the Burlington mayor. ``And we would have had a big hole in our budget if they would have prevailed, so I'm very pleased.''

DOC.HEAD: Baker Heads to Moscow for Arms Control Talks
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts grafs 11-13, ``Baker's first xxx to update with new details of Baker's schedule in Moscow
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III is on his way to Moscow to try to work out arms control agreements with the Soviet Union for signing at the fast-approaching Washington summit. Baker's aides are not predicting success. ``By the end of the week we should know a lot more,'' a senior U.S. official said before takeoff Monday. The four days of talks are Baker's last chance to work out agreements with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze for signing during the May 30-June 3 visit of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The two sides are in disagreement on several key issues. Gorbachev's problems at home also could get in the way. ``The general assumption is that he has increasingly acquired more of the formal power,'' said the senior official, who demanded anonymity. ``On the other hand, his difficulties with the economy and nationalities, and the general level of dissatisfaction have, perhaps, limited his ability to use that power.'' Other topics Baker will take up with Shevardnadze starting Wednesday include the restive Baltic republics and outbreaks of anti-semitism in the Soviet Union as well as accords on space, the environment and trade being prepared for the summit. On his way, Baker stopped in New York to make a speech, promising to keep American troops in Europe even if the treaties are concluded. ``Even if all Soviet armed forces return to the U.S.S.R. and conventional arms control moves forward, the Soviet military will retain forces many times larger than those possessed by any other single state,'' Baker said. He said the North Atlantic Treaty Organization would not dissolve, either. ``To prevent war, we must continue to deter aggression and contain the residual threat,'' Baker said. He suggested the Western alliance take on more of a political role, however, and consider holding ``a solid political and military dialogue'' with the Soviet Union and the countries of Central and Eastern Europe. Baker's first meeting in the Soviet Union will involve the Middle East. He will see Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, who is visiting Moscow, Wednesday afternoon. Administration officials said last week Baker does not plan to overhaul his strategy for getting stalled talks going between Israel and Palestinian Arabs. Mubarak has been acting as a middleman between the Bush administration and the Palestinian Liberation Organization. Right after the Mubarak meeting, Baker holds his first round with Shevardnadze. He is to see Gorbachev Friday morning, and is scheduled to wind up his stay in Moscow with a news conference Saturday. The most dramatic candidate for a summit signing _ a treaty declaration to reduce long-range nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines _ is far from complete. U.S. and Soviet negotiators have been wrangling for weeks over ballistic missiles with multiple warheads and over cruise missiles packed on jet fighters. Baker, in a concession, is prepared to inch closer to the Soviet position on cruise missiles, limiting their range to 500 miles instead of 625 miles, but is looking for something in exchange, said a U.S. official who spoke on condition of anonymity. A separate treaty to reduce troops, tanks, airplanes and other non-nuclear arms in Europe is moving slowly in negotiations between NATO and the Warsaw Pact in Vienna. That treaty is designed for signing at a 35-nation summit before the end of the year. But President Bush and Gorbachev would like to report progress when they meet here. The biggest obstacles are which airplanes and helicopters to limit and how compliance would be ensured. ``We will be making our best effort, within our interests, to get the treaties done,'' the senior official said. Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said, ``We have always said we hoped we could conclude a START (Strategic Arms Reduction) treaty this year, and that we hoped to be able to resolve all major issues in START by the summit.'' ``If we do accomplish all that, so much the better. If we do not, we will keep working at it,'' she said. Bush last week offered to halt production of U.S. chemical weapons if the Soviets set a schedule for demolition of their stockpiles and accept other U.S. demands. Baker will follow up the offer with Shevardnadze, but an agreement depends on the Soviets accepting Bush's demand that the two sides be allowed to retain small stockpiles of poison gas until 40 nations agree to a global ban and implement it. Shadowing Baker's trip is the unrest in Lithuania and the partial economic blockade Moscow has imposed on the Baltic republic to try to diffuse a drive for independence. The Bush administration has urged the two sides to settle their differences through negotiations. Otherwise, Baker told Congress recently, pressure could build to impose U.S. economic sanctions against Moscow. Congressional sentiment is strongly on the side of the Lithuanians. Bush and Baker have publicly supported independence but also stressed the importance of maintaining good U.S.-Soviet relations.

DOC.HEAD: Mohawk Charged With Murder in Reservation Violence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to ADD innocent plea.
DOC.TEXT: SALABERRY-DE-VALLEYFIELD, Quebec (AP) _ A Mohawk newspaper editor was behind bars today on charges of murdering a fellow Indian in a gun battle over casino gambling on the St. Regis Indian Reservation. Doug George, an outspoken, 35-year-old opponent of gambling, pleaded innocent Monday in Quebec Provincial Court in the May 1 slaying of Harold Edwards, 31. The slaying of Edwards and another Mohawk the same day prompted hundreds of New York and Canadian police to break with their hands-off policy toward Indian matters and enter the 28,000-acre reservation to keep the peace. George was being held without bail on charges of second-degree murder, which carries a life sentence with parole eligibility in 10 years. His brother, David George, 42, pleaded innocent to dangerous use of a firearm and was released on his own recognizance. Authorities have yet to file charges against three anti-gambling Mohawks who also were arrested Sunday in Edwards' slaying. The 9,000-member reservation straddling the U.S. border has been torn by violence for nine months over whether to allow gambling on the reservation. The reservation's six casinos attract busloads of gamblers, providing jobs and revenue. But opponents say gambling also brings drugs, money and prostitution and undermines traditional Mohawk ways. Members of the pro-gambling Warriors Society, a self-appointed security force, said Edwards was neutral on gambling. Authorities gave no motive for his slaying. An investigation also continued into the shooting of Matthew Pyke, 22. Pyke was opposed to gambling. An estimated 5,000 rounds of ammunition were exchanged in the shootout that caused the first fatalities of the casino dispute. Doug George, managing editor of two newspapers on the St. Regis Indian Reservation, the Indian Times and Akwesasne Notes, regularly used the papers to tout his anti-gambling views and to criticize the Warriors Society. Eli Tarbell, owner of the Bear's Den general store, said George used his position to ``control the media'' and lay the blame for the unrest on the Warriors. ``He's a primary candidate in the whole thing,'' he said. New York Gov. Mario Cuomo's chief negotiator, Henrik Dullea, said he wasn't sure if the developments in Quebec would have any effect on the state's attempt to begin negotiations to end the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Seeks Authority to Force Down Drug Planes
DOC.TEXT: U.S. military pilots could force suspected drug smuggling planes to land for inspection rather than simply wait for them to do so, under a Bush administration proposal. Pilots who disobey orders to land would face up to five years in prison under the proposal, contained in the administration's new anti-drug bill, the Los Angeles Times reported today. The proposal would let the Customs Service, Coast Guard and the military do ``everything we can short of shooting the bad guys down,'' an unidentified administration official told the newspaper. Authority to shoot down planes has been proposed by Sen. Mitch McConnell, R-Ky. But the administration said that option posed an unnecessary risk to innocent pilots. Currently, U.S. pilots who intercept suspected drug smugglers over American airspace have no authority to force planes to land. They can only follow them until they land, when a search is permitted. Authorities have complained the restriction allows smuggler pilots to drop drugs into the United States with little fear of prosecution. The administration bill, which is to be unveiled Wednesday, has generated concern that authorities could force innocent pilots to land and submit to searches. ``We're all for efforts to stop drugs, but you have to be reasonable,'' said Cheri Farha of the 300,000-member Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association. The Customs Service has devoted 100 planes to drug interdiction, the military 50 planes and the Coast Guard 10 aircraft.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Seeks To Tone Down Environmental Proposals
DOC.TEXT: U.S. delegates at an environmental conference sought to soften tough European proposals, including a timetable for stabilizing carbon dioxide emissions. The United States came under sharp criticism Monday at the U.N.-sponsored meeting for opposing a new environmental aid fund for developing countries, and for refusing to endorse stricter anti-pollution measures. ``We are a country with a thick skin,'' said John A. Knauss, the chief U.S. delegate, in response to the criticism. Delegates at the 34-nation conference were discussing the text of a final conference declaration to be issued Wednesday. The debate found the United States at odds with many of its Western European allies. ``I think we'll find a wording that is acceptable to all,'' said Knauss, head of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. Another U.S. delegate, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Washington opposed the proposal for a Third World environmental aid fund because it did not want to create a new bureaucracy to perform a task that could be handled by the World Bank. The first day of the ministerial-level talks on Monday was marked by discord. Environmentalists protesting outside the conference hotel in this Norwegian port city voiced fears that the final declaration might end up being too vague. Carlo Rita Di Meana, the environment commissioner for the European Community, expressed concern about the U.S. stance. He said ``the United States appears to be deserting us'' at a time when industrial nations are acting together to protect the environment and developing countries are starting to become aware of environmental concerns. The main point of contention in the draft declaration is a proposal by European nations that calls for stabilizing emissions of carbon dioxide by the year 2000. Carbon dioxide is among the so-called ``greenhouse'' gases believed to contribute to global warming. The United States has objected to imposing expensive requirements on industry to combat what it considers unproven environmental hazards. Only Britain and the Soviet Union have given unofficial support to U.S. efforts to move back the timetable for reducing carbon dioxide emissions. The United States is also objecting to another provision in the draft declaration that says precautionary preventative action should be taken to protect the Earth, even if scientists disagree on its value. A U.S. delegate, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Washington did not object so much to the contents of the draft declaration proposals, but rather to their timing. The delegate said the United States wants first to study a U.N. report on climatic change due out this fall before entering in any new environmental agreements. He added that the United States was willing to compromise on any proposal, except for one calling for new funds for environmental research. Washington expects to spend about $1 billion on climate research in 1991, he said. Knauss refused during a news conference to be drawn out on specific issues under negotiation. But he said evidence is still lacking on how the emission of carbon monoxide and other ``greenhouse'' gases will effect global temperatures. Scientists agree that emissions of man-made pollutants, especially the release of carbon dioxide from burning fossil fuels, is causing heat to be trapped and will result in a warming of the globe. But the extent of the warming and how specific regions of the Earth will be affected is not clear. The Bergen conference, called Action for a Common Future, is a regional follow-up session to consider environmental protection recommendations following the 1987 release of a report by the U.N. World Commission on the Environment and Development, chaired by Norway's former prime minister Gro Harlem Brundtland.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Steady in Europe After Drop Against Yen, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was steady in European trading today after a drop in Asia overnight caused by the sale of U.S. Treasury bonds. Gold fell slightly. Currency traders said the dollar was under pressure because of uncertainty about interest rates in the United States. The release of new U.S. consumer price figures on Wednesday and trade figures on Thursday also were likely to keep investors cautious pending their release, traders said. ``The uncertainty about what the Federal Reserve is going to do has sparked a flow of capital toward the yen,'' a trader in Milan said. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 2.05 yen to a closing 151.30 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 150.95 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: _ 1.6433 West German marks, unchanged _ 1.3912 Swiss francs, down from 1.3952 _ 5.5355 French francs, down from 5.5430 _ 1.8475 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8472 _ 1,207.00 Italian lire, down from 1,209.75 _ 1.1791 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1767 In London, the dollar fell against the British pound and was quoted at $1.6865, compared with $1.6817 late Monday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $367.80 an ounce, down from $369.75 bid late Monday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $367.85. In Zurich, the bid price was $367.50, down from $368.75 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 26 cents to close at a bid $369.36. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.06 an ounce, from Monday's $5.09.

DOC.HEAD: Philippines Serves ``Notice of Termination'' Of Bases Agreement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with guerrillas claiming responsibility for killing two U.S. servicemen, ADDS Enrile comment on bases. Pickup 9th graf `Critics of...'; ADDS 3 grafs of details at bottom.
DOC.TEXT: The Philippines formally told the United States today that the lease for U.S. military bases expires in September 1991. U.S. and Filipino officials said the move does not prevent a new accord from being reached. The ``notice of termination'' was presented today by Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus during the second day of talks on the future of the installations, including Clark Air Base, the Subic Bay naval base and four smaller installations. Police arrested about 50 people today after they staged a motorcade to demand the bases be closed. Forty-two people were arrested during anti-bases protests when the talks began Monday. Communist guerrillas opposed to the bases shot and killed two U.S. airmen near Clark on Sunday and claimed responsibility for the slayings in a statement today. Although largely symbolic, the serving of the ``notice of termination'' highlighted differences between U.S. and Philippine officials over when the lease on the six installations actually expires. Manila believes the 1947 Military Bases Agreement allows the installations to remain until Sept. 16, 1991. The United States, however, maintains they could stay one year longer. ``The government of the Philippines hereby notifies the government of the United States of America that the 1947 Philippines-United States Military Bases Agreement ends on Sept. 16, 1991 and cannot be extended,'' the notice of termination said. Today's announcement of termination also gave the government of President Corazon Aquino a way to display its own people its independence from the United States. ``In my opinion, the Aquino administration still wants the bases to remain but they are putting up a drama because there are many demonstrators and there are problems,'' said opposition Sen. Juan Ponce Enrile, a former defense minister who now says he opposes the bases. Critics of the bases have accused the government of caving in to American demands by agreeing to discuss a new bases treaty. Such criticism mounted after U.S. jets from Clark flew air cover for government forces during a failed coup which almost toppled Mrs. Aquino. ``Today, 15 May 1990, marks an historic moment for all Filipinos,'' said Philippine panel spokesman Rafael Alunan. ``We have taken that first step in terminating an agreement that was executed in 1947 during the days of lingering U.S. colonialism in the Philippines.'' Alunan told The Associated Press that the notice, given by Manglapus to chief U.S. negotiator Richard Armitage, did not rule out a new bases agreement. ``Our constitution mandates is to be open to new ideas, to lead us to a new negotiation for a new treaty,'' Alunan said. ``It does not preclude new negotiations for a new treaty.'' Stanley Schrager, spokesman for the American panel, said the move brought out longstanding differences between the United States and the Aquino government on the termination date. In 1966, the two governments agreed that the bases agreement would extend for 25 more years subject ``to termination upon one year's notice by either government.'' According to the U.S. interpretation, the Philippines would have to wait until Sept. 16, 1991 to give one year's notice. But in 1986, a few months after Mrs. Aquino took office, the constitution was rewritten to state that ``after expiration in 1991 of the agreement ... concerning military bases, foreign military bases, troops or facilities shall not be allowed in the Philippines'' unless provided for under a new treaty. ``The timing was not anticipated but the serving of the notice was expected,'' Schrager said of the announcement. U.S. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they hoped a new agreement could be negotiated and ratified before September 1991, making the difference of opinion on the expiration moot. The claim of responsibility for the slayings of the two U.S. servicemen came in a signed statement by Jay-ar Sigua, spokesman of the communist New People's Army regional. ``This incident serves as a warning to the U.S. government and its local puppet regime,'' Sigua said. ``We will not stop until all U.S. bases and all American occupational soldiers are kicked out of our country.'' The assailants shot and killed Airman John H. Raven, 19, of Delta Junction, Alaska, and Airman James C. Green, 20, of Craig, Colorado, outside a hotel near Clark Air Base outside Angeles City, about 50 miles north of Manila.

DOC.HEAD: `Pretty Woman' and `Driving Miss Daisy' Earn Pretty Penny
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `3. Tales...', to correct Darkside to one word.
DOC.TEXT: The Cinderella story ``Pretty Woman'' is still sitting pretty at the box office eight weeks after release. The film, starring Julia Roberts as a hooker who finds love with a rich businessman played by Richard Gere, was No. 1 for the third consecutive weekend at the nation's box office. The weekend take pushed both ``Pretty Woman'' and the Oscar-winning ``Driving Miss Daisy'' over the $100 million mark. ``Pretty Woman'' earned almost $7.6 million last weekend, followed by ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles'' with $3.7 million and ``Tales from the Darkside,'' in third place with $2.9 million. May is considered one of the flattest times of the year in the movie business, with weekends filled with high school proms, graduation parties and commencements. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Sunday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``Pretty Woman,'' Disney, $7.6 million, 1,794 screens, $4,233 per screen, $101 million, eight weeks. 2. ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles,'' New Line, $3.7 million, 2,267 screens, $2,047 per screen, $110 million, seven weeks. 3. ``Tales From the Darkside,'' Paramount, $2.9 million, 1,535 screens, $1,920 per screen, $9.3 million, two weeks. 4. ``The Hunt for Red October,'' Paramount, $2.2 million, 1,323 screens, $1,670 per screen, $105 million, 11 weeks. 5. ``Spaced Invaders,'' Disney, $2.0 million, 1,776 screens, $1,119 per screen, $11.0 million, three weeks. 6. ``The Guardian,'' Universal, $1.8 million, 1,544 screens, $1,185 per screen, $12.7 million, three weeks. 7. ``Q & A,'' Tri Star, $1.5 million, 917 screens, $1,650 per screen, $7.9 million, three weeks. 8. ``Wild Orchid,'' Epic, $1.2 million, 760 screens, $1,582 per screen, $7.2 million, three weeks. 9. ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' Warner Bros., $1.04 million, 914 screens, $1,143 per screen, $100 million, 22 weeks. 10. ``Short Time,'' 20th Century Fox, $1.0 million, 574 screens, $1,757 per screen, $2.6 million, two weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Four Killed in Shooting at High-Stakes Dice Game
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf with two grafs to UPDATE with police estimate of amount involved in dice game, investigators searching car; INSERTS one graf after 13th, `The bar ...' to UPDATE with amount found on a victim. Pick up 14th graf, `Two people ...'
DOC.TEXT: Three masked men who shot four people to death in a police-style raid on a high-stakes dice game left thousands of dollars behind _ and still managed to scoop up ``quite a lot of money,'' police say. The men wore ski masks and camouflage clothing when they broke into the game at the Glass Key Cafe, shouting, ``Task force!'' early Monday. Three people were wounded in the attack, one critically. Capt. Randy Ely said the robbers fled without taking some cash on the gaming table, and investigators found other money in the pockets of some of the victims. ``This all happened rather quickly,'' he said. ``We're still certain they got away with quite a lot of money.'' Police gave no estimate of the amount taken but said as much as $400,000 was involved in the dice game. Investigators today searched a stolen car believed to have been driven by the men. The car was found by police about five miles from the dice game. Police Chief Thomas Windham said as many as 15 people were inside. Some scrambled into a back room and others ran outside to escape the gunfire. ``It appears to have been a robbery of a gambling game,'' Windham said. ``We have information that it was an extremely high-dollar gambling game with tens of thousands of dollars involved.'' On Oct. 2, several men hid inside the cafe and opened fire during a gambling game, Ely said. One man was killed. No arrests have been made and police said they could not say for certain that the latest attack is related. ``Essentially, you've got three blacks wearing ski masks that raid a dice game. That's the similarity at this point,'' Ely said. ``At this point in time, we just don't have more to go on than a generalized description.'' Police said three men went inside the cafe and a fourth man stayed outside. In the earlier attack, the men did not identify themselves as police, Ely said. The bar, in a poor neighborhood, is home to gambling, drug deals and violence, Windham said. Lt. Don Gerland, a vice officer, said gambling is widespread in the city, but the amount of money in Monday's game was unusually high. One of the victims had $60,0000 in cash in his pockets and wore a bullet-proof vest, police said. The man died of a gunshot wound to the head. Two people were killed inside; another was dead on arrival at a hospital and a fourth died in surgery. One man was listed in critical condition with a gunshot wound to the chest. Another man was reported in fair condition, and cafe owner, Albert Huey You said he was nicked in the ear with a shotgun pellet.

DOC.HEAD: Holy See and Romania Re-Establish Diplomatic Relations
DOC.TEXT: The Vatican and Romania today re-established diplomatic relations broken by the former hard-line Communist regime 40 years ago. With the move, the Holy See has completed the restoration of official ties with all countries that had cut relations after the Communists came to power in Eastern Europe after World War II. Pope John Paul II's native Poland, which is predominantly Roman Catholic, restored ties last July. Hungary did so in February and Czechoslovakia followed suit in April, two days before the pope paid a historic visit to the country. The Vatican reported it had reached agreement with Romania on restoring ties two weeks ago after a visit to the country by Archbishop Angelo Sodano, the Holy See's foreign affairs chief. After coming to power, the Romanian Communists adopted harsh measures against organized religion that included suppressing the Eastern rite branch of the Catholic church. In July 1950, relations with the Vatican were cut when the government gave the papal envoy three days to leave the country. With the fall of Communist regimes over the past year, the Vatican has moved quickly to expand its influence in Eastern Europe. Two months ago the Vatican made a major breakthrough in Romania when the pope appointed 12 bishops to restore the church to the strength it enjoyed before the crackdown on religion began. The move also revived the Eastern rite branch.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Delays Progression of HIV Infection
DOC.TEXT: The onset of AIDS in people with mild infections of the HIV virus can be delayed with early treatment of AZT and makes it ``almost a whole new drug,'' a leading researcher said. A study released Monday in the May 15 issue of the Annals of Internal Medicine said people who took AZT were more than twice as likely not to develop AIDS or AIDS-related complex than those who received a placebo. That study and a similar one last month in the New England Journal of Medicine prompted the federal Food and Drug Administration in March to allow physicians to prescribe the drug for patients with the virus who have not developed AIDS symptoms. ``It means we can recommend intervention to prevent serious illness just as we would for mild hypertension to prevent stroke or heart disease,'' said Dr. Margaret Fischl, lead author of the study in the Annals of Internal Medicine. ``The data shows remarkably that if you give zidovudine (AZT) orally before someone's immune system is severely damaged or they are severely ill, you will delay development of AIDS,'' she said. Because AZT is ``licensed for almost all phases of HIV infection,'' she said, it represented ``a quantum leap in treatment intervention.'' She said the study also showed ``the drug was well-tolerated, with minimum side effects.'' Only 1 percent of those getting the minimum dose experienced serious side effects, she said. AZT is the only drug definitively shown to at least slow the usually fatal course of acquired immune deficiency syndrome. The latest study examined 711 people with mild symptoms of human immunodeficiency virus type 1 infection, or HIV, the precursor to AIDS. A placebo was given to 351 people while AZT was given to 360. Of those getting the drug, 15 developed AIDS or AIDS-related complex within about 11 months. Of those who did not receive the drug, 36 developed AIDS or AIDS-related complex. The results were more conclusive for those with more advanced HIV infection. The illness is measured by the concentration of CD4 T lymphocytes, a cell important in forming antibodies. The lower the count, the more advanced the illness. Among those whose CD4 T lymphocyte count fell between 200 and 500 per square millimeter, 34 subjects who received the placebo developed AIDS or AIDS-related complex, compared with 12 who received AZT. Among those whose CD4 T lymphocyte count fell between 500 and 799, two subjects who received the placebo developed AIDS or AIDS-related complex, compared with three who received AZT. In an editorial, researchers from the University of British Columbia cautioned treating patients with counts between 200 and 500. ``The available data do not address the question of whether early intervention ... prolongs life or improves its quality,'' the editorial said. ``Whereas the selective use of zidovudine in such persons should be endorsed for the present, we eagerly await the results of ongoing trials that will help resolve these important issues,'' the editorial said.

DOC.HEAD: Christians Battle Each Other in East Beirut, Moslems in West
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces ignored a church plea for a cease-fire today and kept up the shelling duels that have scorched their enclave. Police said 18 people were killed and 42 wounded. In west Beirut, street gun battles broke out between Moslem factions loyal to Iran and Syria, killing six more people and wounding 15. The artillery bombardment that raged into a seventh day in east Beirut and the surrounding Christian hinterland worsened the plight of thousands of trapped residents. Today's deaths raised the casualty toll in the Christian fighting to at least 1,022 dead and 2,726 wounded since Jan. 30, when army Gen. Michel Aoun moved against militia chieftain Samir Geagea to seize control of the Christian enclave north of Beirut. Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir, spiritual head of the Maronite Catholic sect, issued a cease-fire appeal before midnight, urging Aoun's troops and Geagea's Lebanese Forces militiamen to disobey their commanders and lay down arms. But the bombardment raged past daybreak. Aoun and Geagea are both Maronite Catholics. ``They simply opted to disobey the patriarch, not their commanders,'' said a police spokesman who cannot be named under standing rules. ``It seems they can't stop fighting.'' Police said Geagea's mobile 40-barreled rocket launchers spread along the enclave's coastline poured fire on Aoun's 155mm howitzer batteries in the upper Metn mountains at a rate of one round per second through most of the night. Flames leaped through the night sky. Fires burned out of control in scores of devastated apartment buildings, fuel storage tanks and filling stations. Marlene Kenaan, a 27-year-old secretary reached by telephone at her home in the mountain resort town of Brummana, said she spent the night with her parents in the underground wine cellar. ``We felt the door of hell has been flung open and we were roasting under merciless bombardment,'' Ms. Kenaan said. ``Wine bottles danced all night and we kept drinking them to shore up our spirits,'' she quipped. The Moslem fighting started at midnight and pitted the fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, Iran's main Lebanese ally, against the Syrian-aligned secular Amal, Arabic for hope. The factions have been struggling on and off since 1987 to control the 1.2 million Shiites who make up Lebanon's largest sect. The latest casualties brought the overall toll to 1,041 killed and 3,076 wounded in three years. Police said Hezbollah fighters hurled grenades and fired jeep-mounted 106mm guns in an attempt to expel Amal from west Beirut's old Jewish quarter. Amal stopped the assaults with rocket-propelled grenades and armor-piercing rockets. Syrian troops in charge of west Beirut's security ringed the low-income neighborhood to contain the fighting, which ease at midmorning. Shopowners removed glass shards and debris under the watchful eyes of helmeted Syrian troops toting automatic rifles and shoulder-fired rocket launchers. Dozens of wrecked cars smoldered amid heaps of smoke-blackened burned fruits and vegetables. ``Go ahead and take pictures,'' a veiled woman cried as photographers reached the scene of the fighting. ``Show the world how brutal are our men.''

DOC.HEAD: Florist Being Driven Out of Business Over AIDS Rumor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `There are...', to restore dropped word `of.' SUBS 12th graf, `Grealis said...', to add that he has wife, daughter. Note contents of 7th graf.
DOC.TEXT: A rural florist says rumors he has AIDS are driving him out of business, and he's even posted a clean bill of health in his shop to convince those who have shunned him, threatened him and trashed his van. On Monday, West Virginia's attorney general stepped in on Bill Grealis' behalf. ``We will have some investigators up and down this hollow until we are satisfied that this nonsense is going to stop or until we can find out who's doing it,'' Roger Tompkins said. ``When we do, we'll prosecute them.'' Grealis, 41, said he doesn't have AIDS and has medical tests to prove it: Results are taped to a showcase in his small flower shop in Campbells Creek, a mining hollow of about 350 outside the capital of Charleston. Rumors that he has AIDS began in December after he was hospitalized for prostate problems and lost more than 50 pounds. Since then, he said, he has been the target of threats, and business is off 80 percent at Christy's Floral. ``There are a lot of mean boys here in Campbells Creek,'' said Robert Elliot, a local resident. ``They're rowdy. They get into a lot of stuff. I've seen a lot of things happen here in Campbells Creek that ordinarily shouldn't happen.'' Three tires on Grealis' van were slashed last week and its windshield smashed. ``AIDS'' and ``fag'' were scrawled in black paint on the truck's side. A scribbled message on a paper bag left on the shop's door said: ``If you don't get out now, you may wind up in the hospital or in the funeral home.'' ``I even had a woman last week that opened my front door and threw her check inside and got in her car and drove off and wouldn't even come inside,'' Grealis said. ``I've had people who have seen me in the grocery store coming down the same aisle and turn around and go the other way _ people that I've known up here for 22 years.'' A friend, Joyce Lawrence, 41, said few people have been willing to help. ``I knew he didn't have AIDS. Besides, you don't get AIDS by buying a flower from somebody,'' she said. ``The ignorance of these people is destroying him.'' Grealis, who is separated from his wife and has a 14-year-old daughter, said he should never have been tested for AIDS, ``but they worked on my mind so bad that I actually began to think there was something wrong.'' He said will fight for his business. ``I need the rumors to stop,'' he said. ``I need to get back financially where I was to hold my head above water.'' West Virginia ranks 43rd in the nation with 144 AIDS patients since 1984, 87 of whom have died, according to the state Health Department.

DOC.HEAD: Three Killed In Shootout At Indian Frontier
DOC.TEXT: A gunbattle between Indian and Pakistani soldiers in the disputed state of Kashmir left three soldiers dead and another wounded, a Defense Ministry spokesman said today. A Pakistani soldier was killed late Monday when Indian troops opened fire on him and other troops as they repaired a bunker on Pakistan's side of the cease-fire line, the spokesman said. Pakistan retaliated, killing two Indian soldiers, the spokesman said on condition of anonymity. Border gunfights between the two armies occur regularly, the Defense Ministry said. ``This is nothing very unusual,'' he said. ``They keep exchanging gunfire and sometimes there are casualties.'' Pakistan and India have been waging a war of words since January when militant secessionists launched a bloody indpendence battle in the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir. India regularly accuses the majority Moslem nation of Pakistan of training and arming Moslem militants, who want either independence or union with Pakistan. Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's government denies that charge. India's state of Kashmir is the only one with a Moslem majority. Most of India's 880 million people are Hindu. Kashmir was divided between India and Pakistan at the end of British colonial rule in 1947. The two neighbors have gone to war three times. In 1948 and 1965 they fought over Kashmir. In 1971 they fought over Bangladesh, then East Pakistan. Ms. Bhutto arrived today in the holy Iranian city of Mashhad to begin a Middle East tour, and the dispute in Kashmir was expected to be high on the agenda of her talks with Iranian officials. In London, meanwhile, the House of Commons on Monday welcomed Pakistan back into the Commonwealth, a 49-nation association of Britain and its former colonies, with a plea for a non-violent solution of the Kashmir dispute.

DOC.HEAD: Communists Say They Killed Two U.S. Airmen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts lead, fixes overline.
DOC.TEXT: Communist rebels today claimed responsibility for the weekend murder of two American airmen, and they threatened further attacks until all U.S. military facilities shut down. Jay-ar Sigua, spokesman of the Communist New People's Army regional, made the claim in a signed statement sent by courier to The Associated Press. ``This incident serves as a warning to the U.S. government and its local puppet regime,'' Sigua said. ``We will not stop until abuses by American officers and soldiers have ceased. We will not stop until all U.S. bases and all American occupational soldiers are kicked out of our country.'' Today the Philippines formally told the United States that the agreement allowing U.S. bases expires Sept. 16, 1991. U.S. and Filipino officials said the move did not preclude a new accord. On Sunday, suspected Communist assassins gunned down Airman John H. Raven, 19, of Delta Junction, Alaska, and Airman James C. Green, 20, of Craig, Colo., outside a hotel near Clark Air Base outside Angeles City, about 50 miles north of Manila. Another American serviceman escaped unhurt. The killings brought to eight the number of Americans killed since April 1989, when guerrillas gunned down U.S. Army Col. James ``Nick'' Rowe, a heavily decorated Vietnam war hero, on his way to work at the Joint U.S. Military Assiatnce Group in suburban Quezon City. Sigua said the American servicemen were ``punished'' because American troops, CIA agents and other U.S. spies have increasingly participated in the government's counter-insurgency campaign. However, the two victims were not stationed at Clark. They were among 280 airmen and support personnel assigned to the 8th Aircraft Generation Squadron on temporary duty from Kunsan Air Base in South Korea. On Monday, U.S. officials canceled off-post leaves for the 40,000 troops, military dependents and Defense Department civilians at all six U.S. bases in the country. Aside from Clark, the United States maintains Subic Bay Naval base and four other smaller military installations. The guerrilla statement did not mention the May 4 killing of U.S. Marine Gunnery Sgt. John Fredette near Subic, 50 miles west of Manila. Fredette, 34, was on temporary duty from a Marine Air Station at El Toro, Calif. In Angeles, Lt. Col. Julius Yarcia, police chief, said today they have identified the five assassins involved in Sunday's incident and intelligence agents were in pursuit of the suspects.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Will Visit U.S. for Bush Meeting, Ticker Tape Parade
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with De Klerk visit; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: South African President F.W. de Klerk will meet with President Bush at the White House several days before black leader Nelson Mandela, for talks on dismantling their country's racial segregation system. U.S. officials said today de Klerk will visit the White House on June 18 in the first official call by a South African president in more than 30 years. Mandela, who will tour six U.S. cities and be honored with a ticker tape parade in New York City, arrives in the United States about June 20 and will meet Bush about a week later, officials of his African National Congress said Monday. Bush issued the invitations to both men last February, as soon as de Klerk released Mandela from prison, where he served 27 years for plotting to overthrow the South African government. De Klerk's decision to free Mandela and lift a ban on the ANC opened the way for talks between the white minority government and the black majority on rewriting the country's constitution to grant blacks political power. U.S. officials said the decision to schedule de Klerk's visit before Mandela's was dictated by the two men's busy itineraries and did not signal a preference for either leader. But organizers of the Mandela visit, a coalition of labor and black civic groups, were angered especially because they had objected to Bush's invitation to de Klerk in the first place.
