Randall Robinson, head of the TransAfrica organization, said inviting de Klerk to the White House before Mandela was ``insensitive'' in light of the South African government's oppression of blacks and its lengthy imprisonment of Mandela. Joseph Lowery, president of the Atlanta-based Southern Christian Leadership Conference, said Mandela is expected to meet with Atlanta business and civil rights leaders and lay a wreath at the tomb of the late civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. Mandela, 71, will address a joint meeting of Congress to thank U.S. leaders for their support during his incarceration and for their efforts to obtain his release. But he is also expected to warn that despite some reforms adopted by the white government of President F.W. de Klerk, ``the impression that apartheid is gone is wrong, it remains firmly in place,'' said the ANC's Washington representative, Lindiwe Mabuza. Mandela will urge U.S. leaders to keep intact the economic sanctions imposed by Congress in 1986 so that pressure is maintained on the South African government to carry through with the reforms, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Official Says Cost of Losing Most-Favored Status High
DOC.TEXT: China stands to lose nearly one-fourth of its total exports and most of its sales to the United States if Washington cancels its most-favored-nation trade status, the vice minister of trade said today. ``We are very concerned that the good economic and trade relations the two countries have established over the past 10 years could be destroyed,'' the minister, Shen Jueren, said in an interview with American journalists. He estimated China would lose about $10 billion worth of exports annually, an even greater loss than U.S. analysts have estimated. China exported about $43 billion worth of goods worldwide last year, including about $12 billion worth to the United States, mostly garments, shoes and toys. The U.S.-China Business Council in Washington has estimated that Chinese exports to the United States would fall 50 percent. Shen said some Chinese workers would lose their jobs, especially in export-oriented coastal provinces, but did not provide any figures. ``China is a large country and we can bear the burden if we have to,'' Shen said. China and the United States have given each other most-favored-nation trade status since 1980, entitling each to the lowest available tariffs on exported goods. Without it, the average tariff on Chinese goods would jump to more than 50 percent from the current 9 percent, the U.S.-China Business Council estimates. China's status must be renewed each year, with June 3 the deadline for a decision. President Bush is expected to support renewing the special trade status but may face stiff opposition from congressmen who believe China should be punished for last June's crackdown on the student-led pro-democracy movement. As early as April, Chinese officials began warning that suspension of most-favored-nation status would set back political and cultural relations as well. An article in the official China Daily said suspension would be shortsighted and chided, ``China has never yielded to pressure from outside.'' Shen, however, avoided polemics and instead appealed on behalf of China's reformers. ``Many friends in the United States say they want China to continue its reforms and opening to the outside world. But if MFN is canceled, this will create difficulties for the reform and opening up. This is a contradiction,'' he said. Shen said China in return would suspend most-favored-nation treatment for U.S. goods but refused to say whether other retaliation was possible. The United States sold about $5.7 billion worth of goods to China last year, led by wheat, airplanes and parts, and fertilizer. Asked if the trade ministry was pressing the government to make concessions on human rights, he said: ``I think our government has done quite a lot in this regard.'' In the past two weeks, China has ended martial law in Lhasa, Tibet, and announced the release of 211 people who took part in last year's massive pro-democracy protests. Both moves were widely seen as intended to counter congressional criticism of its human rights record. However, hundreds of protesters remain jailed, many still without formal charges. Many of those released have lost their jobs. Chinese leaders also have refused to express regret for ordering the army to open fire on protesters in Beijing, resulting in hundreds and possibly thousands of deaths. Only a few countries, including Albania, Cuba, Vietnam and some Soviet bloc states, do not receive most-favored-nation from the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Police Say Attack on Vietnamese Not Related to Grocery Boycott
DOC.TEXT: Police say the beating of a Vietnamese man was a bias crime but it was not related to a black-led boycott of two Korean-American groceries blocks away. A man and a girl who allegedly took part in the attack were arrested Monday. Both live in the Flatbush neighborhood of Brooklyn, near the scene of the assault early Sunday. Tuan Ana Cao, 36, suffered a fractured skull in the attack. He was listed in guarded condition at Kings County Hospital. Originally, police had linked the beating to the nearby grocery store boycott, saying the attackers had yelled anti-Korean slurs at Cao. But officials said Monday that the attack began with an argument over a broken window. The incident contributed to racial tensions in the city, already on edge as two juries continue deliberating in the Bensonhurst racial attack case. Two white youths are charged with murder in the death of a black teen-ager killed by a mob he encountered in the Bensonhurst neighborhood last summer. The grocery boycott began Jan. 18, after a black woman allegedly was roughed up by workers in one of the stores because she had refused to let them look in her purse. Though boycott organizers insist it isn't racially motivated, pickets outside the stores have shouted anti-Korean slurs. Because of the slurs allegedly uttered during the beating, Sunday's attack was classified as a bias assault, but Police Commissioner Lee Brown said it was neither premeditated nor related to the grocery boycott. Ulner Alsaint, 18, was charged Monday with felonious assault and possession of a dangerous instrument, a claw hammer that was recovered, Brown said. Alsaint allegedly hit Cao over the head, fracturing his skull. He told police he struck Cao in self-defense. A 13-year-old girl was charged as a juvenile with criminal mischief. At a news conference Monday, Brown provided this account: Shortly after 2 a.m. Sunday, a group of teen-age boys left a neighborhood party and met a group of younger teen-age girls coming from another party. The 13-year-old threw a bottle, shattering a ground-floor window in a nearby apartment building. Some Vietnamese men in the apartment went outside ``to find out what happened and a dispute erupted,'' Brown said. The attack was classified as bias-related because some in the group screamed, ``Koreans, get out of America!'', police said. But they also yelled other anti-Asian slurs. The 13-year-old girl said she threw the bottle to be ``one of the group,'' and did not aim for the window, according to Brown. Police said Monday that the initial confusion over the attack on Cao stemmed in part from the difficulty of interviewing him through a translator when he was still disoriented from his injury. Police had originally said Cao was the victim of a robbery attempt shortly before the beating, but now say this was not the case. In a televised speech Friday, Mayor David Dinkins he called for an end to bigotry and hate. He said Monday he had not expected his words to deter all bias-related crimes.

DOC.HEAD: College Graduate Leaves Impression Again and Again
LaserPhoto LWRX1
DOC.TEXT: Carol Jong put her best face forward in her college yearbook _ again and again and again. She managed to get herself shown as a graduate seven times in the 1990 yearbook at the University of Kansas, using different names and looks. There's Buffi J. Baker in Business. Or Bertha Heffer in Engineering, wearing studious spectacles. Even Violet Couleur in Fine Arts. And how about Anne (U.) Rissom in Allied Health and Dorrie N. Collum in Architecture. Or Kacey Starr in journalism, an apparent play on the name of The Kansas City Star newspaper. Some of the aliases were tailor-made for particular schools while others ``just fit the stereotypes,'' Ms. Jong said. Ms. Jong's roommate joined in the prank, but all of her fakes were caught. The roommates are part of the 1990 graduating class of 5,200. ``We wanted to leave our mark at KU,'' said Ms. Jong, a senior graduating Sunday from the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences. ``Since we're not athletes or student presidents or anything, we wanted to be remembered for something special.'' She spent $27 last fall over five weeks to get nine different pictures taken for the yearbook. She changed her hair and clothes each time and sometimes spoke with foreign accents. The yearbook's editors weren't amused. ``I mean, it's a great joke as far as she's concerned,'' said Jeannine Kreker, assistant editor of the Jayhawker. ``But as far as Kansas alumni and everybody who's going to look at this book years from now is concerned, it makes us and the university look pretty silly.'' Not all of Ms. Jong's fakes slipped through. There's no Penny Sylan in Pharmacy. Or, for that matter, no Anna L. Gesik, one of her roommate's names.

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu to Apologize for Japan's Wartime Aggression in Korea
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said today he will apologize for Japan's wartime aggression when he meets South Korea's president next week, but the government is less willing to have the emperor make a similar statement. ``I think I should express frank regret about our mistakes in the past and apologize for them,'' Kaifu told Parliament. He was responding to an opposition question about news reports that South Korean President Roh Tae-woo expects an apology from Emperor Akihito. Kaifu did not comment on whether the emperor would make an apology during Roh's three-day trip to Japan, which begins May 24. Japan ruled Korea as a colony from 1910 to 1945, and Koreans have bitter memories of harsh treatment under the Japanese, along with the legacy of their country's division since the war's end. Leaders of Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party expressed strong opposition to a royal apology. ``We should not use the emperor for political purposes,'' Ichiro Ozawa, secretary general of the party, told a news conference. The matter is delicate for the Japanese, touching on the nature of the emperor's role under the postwar constitution and recalling unresolved questions about how much responsibility the late Emperor Hirohito had for Japan's wartime actions. Six years ago, Hirohito told then South Korean President Chun Doo-hwan that he sincerely regretted the unfortunate past between the two countries. Japanese media quoted Roh Monday as saying Korea was unsure whether Hirohito's statement was an apology or not, and that he expected a definite apology from Emperor Akihito. Akihito succeeded to the throne after Hirohito died in January 1989. Roh said it was clear from history which country had been the aggressor and which had been the victim, and that Japan and Korea needed to have a proper understanding of history to be able to cooperate in the future, news reports added. Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe said the wording of what the emperor would say had not yet been decided. He stressed that while the constitution prevents the emperor from taking a role in politics or government, the prime minister would speak ``sincerely and honestly'' about the past. Watanabe said he was confident the situation would improve and Japan and South Korea could move toward greater cooperation. He indicated that Roh's visit would be used to announce new joint projects between the two countries. He declined to give details but said there would be cooperation in the areas of technology, culture and exchange visits.

DOC.HEAD: 6-Month-Old Baby Killed By Random Bullet
DOC.TEXT: A 6-month-old girl was shot in the head and killed by a bullet randomly fired on a city street, police said. The baby's mother, Claudia Flowers, was pushing her daughter in a stroller about 10 p.m. Monday on the city's South Side when she heard what she thought were firecrackers, said Police Sgt. Dalia Padgurskis. ``She looked at her child and noticed she had been injured,'' said Padgurskis. ``The bullet apparently entered one side of the head and exited the other.'' Rashonda Flowers died at Michael Reese Hospital and Medical Center about 5 a.m., a nursing supervisor said. Padgurskis said the neighborhood has been the scene of frequent incidents of people firings guns from the upper floors of public housing high-rises, and there were reports of random shootings earlier Monday night.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Orders Check of Oil Strainers in Wake of Destroyer Fire
DOC.TEXT: The fatal fire aboard the guided missile destroyer Conyngham has prompted the Navy to examine the possibly faulty installation of a fuel oil strainer aboard its ships. A statement Monday from Atlantic Fleet Headquarters said the ship's strainer, used to separate fuel oil from water so contaminated fuel can be recycled, is among the possibilities that caused the fire. The May 8 fire killed one crewmen and injured 18 others while the 27-year-old Conyngham was on a training missing 80 miles off the North Carolina coast. The fire was extinguished in about two hours with the help of two other ships. But the Navy cautioned no conclusion has been made on the cause of the fire. Various methods of replacing the strainer, or repairing it, were given to ships and their maintenance officers in a message that was sent to all Navy ships. ``It is practice to issue instructions as quickly as possible when potential problems are identified after an incident,'' the stament said. ``USS Conyngham has a fuel oil strainer like the one described in the message.'' The message said the strainer could have caused the fire and outlined proper strainer installation. It added that a quarter-inch-thick stainless steel shaft has shown evidence of cracking in the past. Cmdr. William R. Williams, captain of the Conyngham, said Friday that a fuel oil leak apparently started the blaze that swept up the middle of the ship from a forward fireroom on the right side of the vessel. The fire quickly rose through passageways, burning through decks and sending smoke through berthing spaces, he said. The decks were red hot, with fireballs periodically exploding out of hatches, he said. The Conyngham, which was scheduled for decommissioning next year, is now docked at Norfolk Naval Station awaiting a decision on whether it will be repaired.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Troops Leave Mongolia
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union today began the second phase of its troop withdrawal from Mongolia, the official Soviet news agency Tass reported. Tass said a ceremony took place to see off a Soviet air squadron in Nalayha near Ulan Bator. Another farewell ceremony for Soviet military units was held in Choira in East Gobi Aimag. Tass did not say how many troops were involved. The Soviet Union has announced that by 1992 it will withdraw all its troops from Mongolia, a sparsely populated country on the Chinese border. Western specialists estimate the Soviets had 60,000 troops in Mongolia before the pullout began.

DOC.HEAD: Texans Jittery About Dam Releases, More Evacutions in Louisiana
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with record release from dam, add background on murder-suicide, recast; picking up at the 10th graf pvs, `Damage to Texas...'. SUBS last graf to capitalize `Cokes.'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos HT2, XTRK2
DOC.TEXT: River managers today released record amounts of water from a dam to unburden the foaming, bloated Trinity River, forcing thousands of Texans from their homes downstream. Residents vented their anger with threatening calls. Sirens blared Monday each time dam operators opened huge steel gates to increase the flow of water into Lake Livingston, about 60 miles northeast of Houston. Below the dam, an estimated 7,000 people were urged to evacuate. ``What's scary is what we know is coming,'' said Alanna Shaver, whose family left its Hardin home in favor of a trailer next to a Red Cross shelter. As the water has risen, so have the tempers of those in the way of the water. The Trinity River Authority said it has fielded numerous threats. ``We're very security conscious and we obviously have some unhappy campers out there,'' the authority's John Jadrosich said. ``They're not satisfied that we've released too much water or not enough.'' Livingston Dam operators today released water at a record rate to keep up with the high water reaching the reservoir from torrential rain two weeks ago hundreds of miles to the north. The release rate was up to 77,000 cubic feet per second and officials said that is expected to increase throughout the week; the previous record was 75,000 cfs in June 1973. ``There's not a whole lot that can be done at this point,'' Jadrosich said. ``It's a giant flood _ a Texas-size flood.'' Flooding since April 15 has claimed 12 lives in Texas and one in Oklahoma, where the danger was mostly over. The flooding also may have led to a murder-suicide by a Louisiana farmer, a neighbor said. DeSoto Parish farmer James McMullen, 58, shot his 58-year-old wife, Billie, and himself Sunday, said sheriff's Capt. Marvin Melton. The threat of losing all of his crops may have been too much for McMullen, said neighbor and close friend Tommy Dugan. McMullen's 300 to 400 acres of wheat and 800 to 900 acres in cotton were threatened by flooding. Damage to Texas agriculture has been estimated at between $500 million and $700 million since heavy rain fell in Oklahoma and Texas two weeks ago. Scores of people remained out of their homes in Louisiana because of the rising Red River. It was expected to flood 600 square miles there, including 200 square miles of cropland, said Maj. Jack Scherer of the Army Corps of Engineers. The Red subsided slightly in parts of Arkansas, but the threat of flooding near Garland remained. National Guardsmen and volunteers sandbagged levees in the town about 20 miles from Texarkana. ``What they're doing now is placing sandbags at the base of the levee to clamp down on the areas where it's seeping under, like you'd bend a water hose to cut off the water,'' said John Upton, secretary-treasurer of the levee district. In Washington, Sen. David Pryor of Arkansas asked the General Accounting Office to look into the way the Corps regulates water levels in the region. Some farmers and others have blamed the Corps for some of the flooding. ``The Corps has been criticized for not releasing enough water from some of the facilities in advance of the heavy rains to provide for additional flood storage capacity,'' Pryor wrote. ``I am unsure as to whether or not these standard operating procedures are the best procedures we could be using to protect life and property.'' Jadrosich said earlier releases from Lake Livingston would not have made much difference. ``This is the kind of flood you can expect to see every 100 years,'' he said. ``This will become known as the Flood of 1990.'' As the level of the 90,000-acre, 55-mile Lake Livingston rises, dam operators open the 12 flood gates a little wider. The releases depend on hourly reports from about a dozen inspectors, who report gauge readings upstream. Beer and ``nerve medicine'' were big sellers at Romayor Grocery, 15 miles below the dam, said Kimbel Lambert, a clerk whose father owns the store. Hordes of sightseers converged on the combination grocery-gasoline station. Residents leaving the area also stocked up there. ``We have a kitchen in the back and all. Well, nobody's cooking _ it's just kind of eat and run. So they're buying snacks, Cokes, beer _ mainly beer, nerve medicine, y'know,'' Lambert said.

DOC.HEAD: Rehnquist Urges Streamlining of Death Penalty Appeals
DOC.TEXT: The nation's top judge today urged Congress to streamline death penalty appeals so long delays will be eliminated. ``The system at present verges on the chaotic,'' Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist told the American Law Institute, a group of lawyers and judges. ``The system cries out for reform.'' Noting that the average time between sentencing and execution is seven or eight years, Rehnquist said, ``The eight years ... is consumed not by structured review ... but in fits of frantic action followed by periods of inaction,'' he said. More than 2,200 death row inmates across the nation are awaiting execution, but through the 1980s no more than 25 have been put to death in any one year. Rehnquist said Congress should change how federal courts review capital punishment cases from state courts in ways recommended by a committee he appointed two years ago. That committee, headed by retired Supreme Court Justice Lewis F. Powell, recommended last September that death row inmates be limited to one chance to attack their state court sentences in state appellate courts and one chance in federal courts. Currently, inmates may file several challenges in federal courts, usually after several unsuccessful appeals in state courts. ``The result is that at no point until a death sentence is actually carried out can it be said that litigation concerning the sentence has run its course,'' Rehnquist said in criticizing the current system. The Powell committee's report was denounced by civil liberties lawyers. Rehnquist last October sent the Powell committee report directly to Congress rather than refer it to the U.S. Judicial Conference, the federal courts' policy-making body which he heads. Fourteen of the Judicial Conference's 27 members wrote Congress to request hearings on the conference's recommendations _ which differ significantly from those of the Powell committee. The Judicial Conference's proposals were hailed by the same civil liberties lawyers who had panned the Powell committee's report. Rehnquist today criticized the Judicial Conference's recommendations, along with bills introduced by Sens. Joseph Biden, D-Del., and Strom Thurmond, R-S.C. The chief justice said Biden's proposal ``would actually exacerbate the delays and repetitiousness of the present system.'' He said Thurmond's proposal, which would eliminate most federal court review of death penalty cases, is not yet needed. ``While this approach might commend itself some years hence, it does not do so at the present time,'' Rehnquist said.

DOC.HEAD: Operation Rescure Protesters Enter Clinic, Defying Supreme Court Order
With PM-Abortion Protests
DOC.TEXT: Operation Rescue anti-abortion protesters entered an Atlanta abortion clinic today, defying the U.S. Supreme Court's decision to uphold an order barring them from going within 50 feet of such clinics. There were no immediate arrests, but police were called to the Atlanta Surgi-Center, said a clinic spokeswoman who declined to give her name. The high court on Monday upheld a Georgia judge's ruling that ordered the anti-abortion group to stay at least 50 feet away from the property line of any Atlanta facility where abortions are performed. Operation Rescue had asked the court for emergency help to block the ruling, but the court refused on a close 5-4 vote. Operation Rescue spokesman Bob Jewitt said at least five people went inside the Atlanta Surgi-Center this morning, and the clinic spokeswoman confirmed that protesters were inside. She declined to give any other details. In their appeal to the Supreme Court, Operation Rescue members had argued that the Atlanta injunction violated their free speech rights. Jewitt called Monday's action ``a little stumble along the way,'' adding, ``We feel we'll be victorious in the long run.'' Lynne Randall, who operates an Atlanta clinic that has been a frequent target of the protests, welcomed the action. ``We have to balance women's right to privacy with people's right to protest,'' she said. Since July 1988, when Atlanta hosted the Democratic National Convention, city police have arrested 1,320 demonstrators at Operation Rescue sit-ins. Many of the protesters barricaded abortion clinics, blocking patients and employees from entering or leaving.

DOC.HEAD: Hezbollah To Kidnappers: Keep Your Captives Until Israel Frees Prisoners
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1 graf for final graf to CORRECT number of Arab prisoners held by Israel.
DOC.TEXT: The main group overseeing Moslem factions holding Western hostages told the kidnappers not to free any of their remaining captives until Israel releases Arab prisoners. Hezbollah, or Party of God, sponsored a women's sit-in Monday at a south Beirut house belonging to the United Nations peacekeeping force in Lebanon. ``We ask the hostage-holders not to release any more of the foreign captives until all our loved ones are released from the Zionist jails,'' chanted Umm Ahmed, who refused to give her full name. About 50 other women echoed her chant. Umm Ahmed said she has heard nothing about her 21-year-old son Ahmed since he was captured during the 1982 Israeli invasion of Lebanon. The women involved in the protest were relatives of Shiites and Palestinians held prisoner by Israel or its predominantly Christian militia ally in south Lebanon. The commander of the South Lebanon Army militia, Gen. Antoine Lahd, said Sunday he was ready to swap some of his detainees for the remaining Western hostages, three Israeli servicemen and several of his men held by Shiite Moslem factions. Hezbollah withheld public comment on Lahd's offer. But the Communist-run Voice of the People radio station in Beirut quoted an unnamed Hezbollah source as replying: ``Israel and its puppets must free all the prisoners unconditionally.'' One of the unarmed Hezbollah activists sponsoring Monday's sit-in said the protest was ``our initial reaction to the agent Lahd.'' In another development, Irish Ambassador Antoin Mac Unfraidh appealed today to the kidnappers of Irish hostage Brian Keenan to release him for humanitarian reasons. ``Mr. Keenan does not belong to an imperialist country. He comes from a poor and small country that had its share of war,'' Mac Unfraidh said at a news conference at the Irish consulate in west Beirut. He said he had met with Sheikh Hussein Fadlallah, the spiritual guide of Hezbollah. Keenan, 39, of Northern Ireland, was an English teacher at the American University of Beirut when he was kidnapped April 11, 1986. He holds British nationality as well. No group has claimed responsibility for Keenan's abduction. Recently freed U.S. hostage Frank Reed has said he was held with Keenan and British journalist John McCarthy during much of his captivity and that both of them were in good physical condition. Reed, 57, was freed after 42 months in Shiite hands April 30. Eight days earlier, Robert Polhill, 55, of New York, was released from a 39-month captivity. Their release leaves 16 Western hostages, including six Americans, in Lebanon. The hostage held longest is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was seized March 16, 1985. Hezbollah has demanded a reciprocal gesture from the United States for Polhill's and Reed's releases, saying the release of Shiite prisoners by Israel and the SLA would help resolve the plight of the kidnapped Westerners. Israel has said that any prisoner swap must include the three Israeli soldiers captured in Lebanon in 1986. Israel holds about 9,000 Arabs in its jails. There are also about 300 Shiites held by the SLA in the Khiam detention camp in Israel's self-designated ``security zone'' in south Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Radical Students Battle Police, Declare Week of Protest
DOC.TEXT: Radical students fought police with rocks and firebombs in three cities today, declaring a week of protests to mark a 1980 anti-government uprising, news reports said. Meanwhile in Ulsan, more than 27,000 Hyundai workers demanding higher pay and a shorter work week struck the country's largest auto plant today, halting production. The government, led by President Roh Tae-Woo, has said it would crush any illegal labor protests. On April 28, police firing tear gas rushed into the nearby Hyundai Heavy Industries Co. shipyard to put down a strike. About 6,000 students joined the protests in Seoul and the southern provincial cities of Kwangju and Chonju, shouting ``Punish Roh Tae-woo!'' The police responded with tear gas, the Yonhap News Agency said. There were no reports of injuries or arrests. The National Council of Student Representatives, a nationwide radical student group, designated the week beginning today a period of anti-government struggle to mark the 1980 uprising in Kwangju. The council, which has led many violent anti-government demonstrations, said it would organize nationwide rallies on Friday, the anniversary of the uprising. By official count, about 200 people were killed and more than 1,500 others injured when the military cracked down on the 10-day Kwangju uprising, the worst in modern Korean history. Dissidents say the death toll was much higher. Radical students and dissidents usually mark the Kwangju anniversary with anti-government protests. In Seoul, about 2,000 radical students rallied or clashed with riot police on at least nine campuses demanding Roh's ouster. In Kwangju, an opposition stronghold 150 miles south of Seoul, 3,500 students throwing rocks and firebombs, fought police for several hours around four schools, Yonhap said. ``Punish the criminals of the Kwangju massacre!'' the agency quoted protesters as shouting. Students planned to mark the anniversary with major anti-government rallies and memorial services, expected to attract some 100,000 people, Yonhap said. In Chonju, another opposition stronghold, about 500 students, hurling firebombs, fought police, Yonhap said. The students said they would mark the Kwangju anniversary with protests, it said. Roh was an army general when tens of thousands of Kwangju citizens revolted against the central government on May 18, 1980, demanding democratic reforms. The military crushed the uprising 10 days later. Roh's government is under mounting public fire for economic failures that have triggered inflation and pushed up housing costs. Roh's popularity is at an all-time low. Students want Roh to disband his giant new ruling party. They want a public vote on the coalition, formed earlier this year by Roh's old ruling party and two opposition groups. In southeastern Ulsan, operations of the Hyundai Motor Co., were quiet today. The Hyundai workers voted to walk out after negotiations with management bogged down. The Hyundai workers were demanding an 18.95 percent raise in their average monthly pay of $621 and a cut in the work week from 44 to 42 hours. The company offered only a 5.95 percent wage raise. The car plant, a subsidiary of the giant Hyundai group, produces 2,600 vehicles a day. It exported about 200,000 cars to the United States and other countries last year.

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana Supreme Court Turns Down Killer's Last Minute Appeal
DOC.TEXT: The Louisiana Supreme Court has again refused to stop the execution of Dalton Prejean, condemned to die for killing a Louisiana state trooper at the age of 17. Since his conviction for the 1977 murder of Trooper Donald Cleveland, Prejean, now 30, has received 10 stays of execution and spent more than 10 years on death row in the Louisiana State Penitentiary at Angola. He is scheduled to be executed early Friday. Cleveland was killed in Lafayette after stopping Prejean's car on a routine traffic charge. That murder occurred soon after Prejean was released from a juvenile detention center, where he had been sent for killing a cab driver when he was 14. By a vote of 5-2 Monday, the state Supreme Court denied a claim that the psychiatric evaluation administered before Prejean's 1978 trial was inadequate and the jury therefore never learned that Prejean was retarded. The U.S. Supreme Court last summer rejected the argument that Prejean should be spared because he was only 17 when the murder was committed. Other motions have argued that the black man should not be executed because he is mildly retarded, because an all-white jury convicted him, and because the jury was never told he had been was abused as a child. Prejean's lawyers prepared to turn to Gov. Buddy Roemer and the federal courts again to win another reprieve. ``We've just been sweating this one out,'' said lawyer Sam Dalton. ``I don't think we have time for anything else other than another telegram to the governor telling him to do the right thing this time. I'd like to try again, but I don't know that we can.'' ``We're very disappointed, but we're committed to pursuing this until the end,'' said attorney Andrea Robinson. ``I hope the U.S. Supreme Court agrees with us and agrees with him.'' The governor said he had discussed the case with his legal counsel. ``Our plans are to proceed with the execution. I'm never happy with these things but I do not, as a representative of the people, have a choice,'' Roemer said Monday. Roemer said he would be willing to discuss the case with defense attorneys, but he has twice spurned a State Pardon Board recommendation that Prejean's sentence should be reduced to irrevocable life imprisonment. Several courts have suggested that Prejean's attorneys have been filing repetitive appeals aimed mostly at delaying the execution. Last fall, the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals criticized defense lawyers for what the judges called an abuse of the appeals process. The judges said Prejean's lawyers were intentionally filing motions just before the scheduled execution dates so that judges, with no time to review the paperwork, would have to issue stays.

DOC.HEAD: Helms Seeking to Block AIDS Relief Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with cloture vote. Picks up 6th graf pvs `The bill...'
DOC.TEXT: The Senate voted overhwelmingly today to limit debate and proceed with a bipartisan bill providing $600 million to states and cities hit hard by AIDS. The Senate's 95-3 vote to limit debate was necessary to begin considering amendments after an opponent, Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., erected procedural roadblocks in the way of the bill. Helms had acknowledged that his lonely objection was futile and that the Senate would ultimately approve the two-year spending authorization. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, responded today to Helms' assertion that money was being spent on a disease spread through ``immorality.'' Mitchell said the government provides money through Medicare to treat people whose smoking caused lung cancer or heart disease, or whose reckless driving caused injury _ and should do no less for people with AIDS. ``The Congress doesn't refuse to care for these people because it is their behavior which led to the disease,'' Mitchell said. ``As is the case of smoking and lung cancer, we can do no less for those American men, women and children with AIDS,'' he said. ``We must act now to provide emergency support to our nation's cities and towns who continue to struggle to meet the overwhelming needs of AIDS patients.'' Helms said Monday that the bill was a result of AIDS ``hysteria'' and neglects the ``role immorality has played in this crisis.'' ``I've never heard once in this chamber anybody say to the homosexuals, `Stop what you're doing,''' Helms said. ``If they would stop what they're doing there would not be one additional case of AIDS in the United States.'' The only senators joining Helms in voting against the debate limitation were Sens. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H., and Steven Symms, R-Idaho. The bill has 65 Senate cosponsors, more than enough for passage, said one of the sponsors, Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass. A bipartisan group of supporters described the measure as emergency relief for communities and public health systems overburdened by people suffering from AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome. ``The time has come to recognize AIDS as a national disaster that is disproportionately affecting certain areas of the country,'' said Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif. ``They cannot be expected to cope with this crisis alone.'' Under the bill, 13 metropolitan areas would qualify for $300 million: Atlanta; Boston; Chicago; Dallas; Houston; Los Angeles; Miami; New York; Newark, N.J.; Philadelphia; San Francisco; San Juan, Puerto Rico; and Washington, D.C. Those areas have reported 60 percent of the nation's AIDS cases, sponsors said. The money would be used to care for AIDS patients and to bolster support programs. Another $300 million would go to states to develop comprehensive AIDS care programs, especially services to small cities and rural areas. Opening debate Monday pitted Helms against a fellow conservative Republican, Sen. Orrin Hatch of Utah. Hatch disputed Helms' assertion that ending homosexual behavior would halt the disease, saying the AIDS-causing virus continues to be transmitted through other means. ``It is foolish to say it just all comes because of high-risk homosexual conduct,'' he said. Hatch said the lifestyles of AIDS sufferers shouldn't matter and cited federal estimates that as many as 1 million to 1.5 million people may be infected with the virus, including as many as 25,000 children. ``Are we going to hold it against these children because their mothers are (intravenous) drug users?'' Hatch asked. ``This is a bill to try to alleviate pain and suffering,'' he said. In a speech and an exchange with Hatch on the Senate floor, Helms charged that homosexual activity was to blame for the disease and called the bill ``another legislative flagship for the militant homosexual'' lobby. He said money for research into cancer and other diseases was ``drying up'' while spending increased for AIDS.

DOC.HEAD: Demanjuk's Attorney Assails Photo Lineups Used in Trial
DOC.TEXT: An attorney for retired Ohio autoworker John Demjanjuk today challenged the admissibility of two photo lineups used to identify Demjanjuk as a sadistic death camp guard and convict him of Nazi war drimes. In his appeal before a five-judge Supreme Court panel, defense attorney Yoram Sheftel also attacked the trial court for failing to halt prejudicial press coverage of the trial. A three-judge panel in April 1988 found Demjanjuk, 70, guilty of committing crimes against humanity and crimes against Jews, and sentenced him to death. The trial judges accepted the testimony of survivors who identified the Ukrainian-born Demjanjuk with the help of photographs as ``Ivan the Terrible,'' who operated gas chambers at Treblinka death camp in Nazi-occupied Poland. More than 850,000 Jews perished there in 1942-43. Demjanjuk claims he is a victim of mistaken identity and that he was incarcerated in German POW camps after being captured while serving in the Soviet Red Army. Sheftel began the appeal Monday by challenging the Israeli court's jurisdiction to try an extradited suspect for war crimes and accusing the trial judges of being biased. He expanded on the bias argument today, blaming the judges for the emotional atmosphere surrounding the trial, including a Dec. 1, 1988, attack in which a Holocaust survivor threw acid in Sheftel's face at a funeral. Sheftel suffered an eye injury and still wears dark glasses as a result. He said the assault followed a spate of inflammatory press accounts of the trial. He cited an article that questioned his credibility and readiness as a Jew to defend an alleged Nazi collaborator. ``This was a bloodletting report,'' Sheftel said. ``The court didn't intercede or say anything. After such reports, the message is that such an action (attacking Sheftel) would be heroic.'' He also disputed the admissibility of two photograph lineups. Aided by the photos, eight Treblinka survivors singled out Demjanjuk as the notorious guard ``Ivan.'' Sheftel displayed a poster containing blowups of the lineups and said there were seven flaws in the identifiction process. One lineup involved a page containing eight photographs, including a 1951 shot of Demjanjuk that he had filed with his application for a U.S. immigration visa. The second included a disputed picture of Demjanjuk from a 1942 identity card that the Soviet Union supplied to Israel. It purportedly is from the Trawniki camp, which trained death camp guards. Sheftel has claimed the Trawniki document is a forgery. He said today the photographs were improperly shown to the survivors. Demjanjuk, for example, was never called for an in-person lineup, Sheftel argued. He noted rulings in both the United States and Israel that a suspect should participate in person in criminal indentificaton procedures. Only if a suspect refuses should photographs be used, Sheftel said. Another flaw, Sheftel said, was that none of the other head shots in either lineup resembled Demjanjuk. Hair color, shape and size of faces were clearly different. ``It is like putting a photograph of a black suspect among seven white men. Where have you heard of such a thing?'' Sheftel said. Demjanjuk, wearing a brown prison uniform, sat flanked by two police guards and listened grim-faced to the daylong proceedings. His wife, Vera, and his son, John Jr., watched from the front row. Asked about the appeal's chances, John Jr. said he was hopeful. ``They have the courage to make a decision based on the facts and the law, and the conviction will be overturned.''

DOC.HEAD: Four Palestinians Killed, One Shot By Jewish Settler
DOC.TEXT: The bodies of three slain Palestinians, including an Israeli-appointed village leader, were discovered today in the West Bank, and a 14-year-old Arab died of wounds after being shot earlier by a Jewish settler. Throughout the Israeli-occupied lands, Palestinians staged a protest strike to mark the 42nd anniversary of the founding of Israel, which led to the displacement of hundreds of thousands of Palestinians. Israel was founded May 15, 1948. Israelis mark Independence Day on April 30 according to the Hebrew calendar. The army clamped curfews on about 200,000 Palestinians in five Gaza Strip refugee camps to prevent clashes during the anniversary. The army spokesman said the bodies of three slain Palestinians were discovered in the West Bank villages of Balaa, Rafat and Assira al-Shamaliya. The villages are far apart. He said the army was investigating the deaths, which apparently were unrelated. The victim in Balaa was identified as Farid Saleh Yassin, a 60-year-old village leader appointed by Israel. Arab reporters said six masked men abducted Yassin from his home Monday and stabbed him to death before dumping his body on the outskirts of the village. A leaflet distributed in the village accused Yassin of being a collaborator. Arab reporters said the decomposing body of Ziad Ahmed Yassin, 25, no relation to Farid, was found near his home village of Assira al-Shamaliya. Residents said Ziad, a laborer, was abducted Friday night by four masked men as he was returning home. Residents in Rafat told reporters they were unable to identify a body found today that was badly battered and mutilated with stab wounds. At least 213 Palestinians have been slain by fellow Arabs during the 29-month uprising, most on suspicion of cooperating with Israel. The army says only a small number actually did cooperate. Also today, Israeli hospital officials confirmed the death of Sameh Ahmed Abu Sheikh, 14, of Qalqiliya. Arab reporters said he suffered bullet wounds in the neck and face Sunday when an Israeli settler fired on stone-throwers. His death raised to 687 the number of Palestinians slain by Israeli soldiers and civilians. Forty-three Israelis also have been killed. In other developments, State Comptroller Miriam Ben Porath said top army commanders share the blame for negative news coverage of Israel's handling of the uprising because they sometimes delay or withhold information. Long delays in getting out the army version of events which have already been reported promptly by Arab sources have damaged the credibility of the army spokesman, her report said. An army official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said ``no one denies that sometimes in order to achieve reliability, you have to sacrifice speed.'' The comptroller also criticized the Housing Ministry for offering special financial incentives to lure ultra-Orthodox Jews to the West Bank settlement of Betar, southwest of Jerusalem. The report said the ministry offered each family willing to buy an apartment in Betar an interest-free mortgage of $42,000 and an additional grant of $7,000. About 8,000 housing units are planned in Betar. The comptroller said the enticements were offered in violation of standard criteria, such as granting preferential mortgage conditions only to army veterans. Many ultra-Orthodox Jews receive exemptions from army service to study. Also today, Israeli legislator Yossi Sarid demanded the Defense Ministry reveal details of five cases of alleged brutality by soldiers against Palestinians. In four of the cases, troops reportedly seized Palestinians, took them to out-of-the-way places and beat them until their arms and legs were broken, Sarid said. In the fifth incident, Palestinian detainees were left tied up for hours outside an army lockup in freezing temperatures.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Discovers Torn Filter on Valve
DOC.TEXT: NASA technicians today removed a faulty valve that forced the agency to delay the launch of the space shuttle Columbia from this week to the end of May or beginning of June. A filter on the valve was torn, allowing debris to enter Columbia's cooling system, said Lisa Malone, spokeswoman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. ``We're pretty glad we did find the problem,'' Malone said. ``Now we'll be on the right track of putting everything back together.'' Columbia had been scheduled to lift off Wednesday or Thursday with seven astronauts and the $100 million Astro observatory, capable of examining sources of ultraviolet and X-ray radiation. Last week, however, engineers spotted a problem with the valve and NASA postponed the mission two to three weeks. Technicians working on a makeshift platform in Columbia's payload bay, about 10 feet above the covered observatory, began draining toxic Freon refrigerant from the shuttle's cooling system Friday. They completed the work late Monday, then cut out the valve, about the length of a hand, and some attached plumbing. It was the first time such a procedure had ever been performed at the launch pad. Replacing the bad valve is expected to take nearly three days, Malone said. The cooling system then will be refilled with Freon and the entire system will be tested. NASA is expected to set a new launch date early next week. Columbia's nine- to 10-day flight will be the first Spacelab mission since 1985 and the 36th shuttle mission. The faulty valve was sent to a nearby Rockwell International service center for analysis. Rockwell built Columbia and the other shuttles.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Pleads Innocent on Six New Drug Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material, editing throughout to add background, further comment.
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry pleaded innocent today to six new drug charges alleging he used cocaine over a five-year period. ``I feel fantastic today. I got a great defense team,'' Barry said outside the courthouse after entering his plea. Barry lawyer R. Kenneth Mundy told U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson that ``we enter a plea of not guilty'' to a 14-count indictment handed up last Thursday against the mayor. The new charges accuse Barry of five misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession and one misdemeanor count of conspiracy. The mayor took drugs as far back as 1984, the new indictment alleges. Barry previously pleaded innocent to eight charges brought Feb. 15 alleging that he lied to a federal grand jury and possessed cocaine on five occasions. The new indictment includes all 14 charges. ``I am anxious to get this trial on by June 4 if it can possibly be done,'' said Jackson. Mundy said ``the last thing we want is a continuance'' pushing back the starting date of the trial. The judge brought up the possibility that Mundy might ask to sever the new charges into a separate case. Mundy did not indicate if he would take that approach ``Even if all Soviet armed forces return to the U.S.S.R. and conventional arms control moves forward, the Soviet military will retain forces many times larger than those possessed by any other single state,'' Baker said. He said the North Atlantic Treaty Organization would not dissolve, either. ``To prevent war, we must continue to deter aggression and contain the residual threat,'' Baker said. He suggested the Western alliance take on more of a political role, however, and consider holding ``a solid political and military dialogue'' with the Soviet Union and the countries of Central and Eastern Europe. Baker's first meeting in the Soviet Union will involve the Middle East. He will see Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, who is visiting Moscow, Wednesday afternoon. Administration officials said last week Baker does not plan to overhaul his strategy for getting stalled talks going between Israel and Palestinian Arabs. Mubarak has been acting as a middleman between the Bush administration and the Palestinian Liberation Organization. Right after the Mubarak meeting, Baker holds his first round with Shevardnadze. He is to see Gorbachev Friday morning, and is scheduled to wind up his stay in Moscow with a news conference Saturday. The most dramatic candidate for a summit signing _ a treaty declaration to reduce long-range nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines _ is far from complete. U.S. and Soviet negotiators have been wrangling for weeks over ballistic missiles with multiple warheads and over cruise missiles packed on jet bombers. Baker, in a concession, is prepared to inch closer to the Soviet position on cruise missiles, limiting their range to 500 miles instead of 625 miles, but is looking for something in exchange, said a U.S. official who spoke on condition of anonymity. A separate treaty to reduce troops, tanks, airplanes and other non-nuclear arms in Europe is moving slowly in negotiations between NATO and the Warsaw Pact in Vienna. That treaty is designed for signing at a 35-nation summit before the end of the year. But President Bush and Gorbachev would like to report progress when they meet here. The biggest obstacles are which airplanes and helicopters to limit and how compliance would be ensured. ``We will be making our best effort, within our interests, to get the treaties done,'' the senior official said. Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said, ``We have always said we hoped we could conclude a START (Strategic Arms Reduction) treaty this year, and that we hoped to be able to resolve all major issues in START by the summit.'' ``If we do accomplish all that, so much the better. If we do not, we will keep working at it,'' she said. Bush last week offered to halt production of U.S. chemical weapons if the Soviets set a schedule for demolition of their stockpiles and accept other U.S. demands. Baker will follow up the offer with Shevardnadze, but an agreement depends on the Soviets accepting Bush's demand that the two sides be allowed to retain small stockpiles of poison gas until 40 nations agree to a global ban and implement it. Shadowing Baker's trip is the unrest in Lithuania and the partial economic blockade Moscow has imposed on the Baltic republic to try to diffuse a drive for independence. The Bush administration has urged the two sides to settle their differences through negotiations. Otherwise, Baker told Congress recently, pressure could build to impose U.S. economic sanctions against Moscow. Congressional sentiment is strongly on the side of the Lithuanians. Bush and Baker have publicly supported independence but also stressed the importance of maintaining good U.S.-Soviet relations.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Military Team Goes To Laos To Excavate Warplanes
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. military team flew to Laos today to excavate two U.S. warplane crash sites that may yield the remains of American servicemen missing in action from the Vietnam War, a U.S. official said. After the two- to three-week excavation in southern Laos, the team will survey other sites and then cooperate with the Laotians in a joint field investigation to try to resolve some ``discrepancy cases,'' said Jim Williams, spokesman of the U.S. Embassy in Bangkok. ``Discrepancy cases,'' which the United States considers of highest priority, are those in which U.S. officials say the Laotians should have information. They include cases of airmen who were known to have survived crashes but were never heard from again. The 17-member U.S. team is from the Joint Casualty Resolution Center and the Central Identification Laboratory, both based in Honolulu and entrusted with accounting for America's wartime missing personnel. Williams said these would be the fourth and fifth excavations jointly conducted with the Laotians this year. Joint surveys of the two crash sites in March 1989 and in January this year ``found evidence that the sites may yield the remains of Americans missing in action,'' he said. He said a total of 2,303 Americans are listed as missing in action from the Vietnam War, which also involved fnam. Williams said a March 1989 joint excavation resulted in the accounting for seven missing Americans. A joint excavation in January this year recovered remains that are still being analyzed, he said. No remains were found in the most recent dig in March.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Says Authors Forced to Censor Themselves
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet author living in the United States said today that writers in both superpower countries are forced to censor themselves. ``Inner censorship also exists in the American literature even though there is no such thing as the ideological totalitarianism in this country,'' Vassily Aksyonov told the House subcommittee on the Interior Department and related agencies. The subcommittee is conducting hearings on a request for $175 million in fiscal 1991 for the National Endowment for the Arts, the government arts-funding agency. This year's appropriation was $171 million after funds were sequestered for the Gramm-Rudman budget-balancing bill. Future funding has been threatened by a controversy surrounding a pair of photographic exhibits. The exhibits included graphic depictions of homosexual acts and images considered by some to be sacrilegious. Aksyonov said that totalitarianism created the atmosphere in which Soviet writers learned to censor themselves by hewing to the requirements of ``partymindedness, populism and ... Socialist realism.'' In the United States, he said, the inner censorship ``looks subtler, less imposing ... since it was created not by Big Brother, but rather by our generous Big Sister, Mrs. Market. ``On the surface, everything looks logical and harmonious if one doesn't take into account that the public taste had been meticulously developed by the market itself rather than by literature,'' he said. Aksyonov was the first in a series of witnesses, including Oscar-winning actress Jessica Tandy of ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' to testify. Others scheduled to appear were cellist Yo-Yo Ma; writer George Plimpton; folklorist Alan Lomax; actresses Jane Curtin and Jane Alexander; theatrical producer producer Joseph Papp, who refused an NEA grant because of strings attached to funding this year; and artists Robert Rauschenberg and Roy Lichtenstein. Aksyonov, who teaches literature and writing at George Mason University near Washington, D.C., was exiled from the Soviet Union in 1980. His best-known work is ``Searching for Melancholy Baby.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs MOSCOW-dated item to CORRECT age of Kirilenko to 83, sted 84.
DOC.TEXT: Andrei P. Kirilenko, a former Politburo member who once was thought to be in line to succeed Leonid I. Brezhnev as Soviet leader, died Saturday at age 83. The official news agency Tass said he died of a ``grave illness.'' Kirilenko, a full member of the Communist Party's ruling Politburo for 20 years, dropped from sight in 1982 and his retirement became known a month later. After Kirilenko retired, Yuri Andropov succeeded Brezhnev on his death in 1982, and Konstantin Chernenko took over from Andropov's death in 1984. Although Kirilenko's fall from power officially was attributed to ill health, reports circulated that his fall actually occurred because his son defected to the West.

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Backs More Prison Space, Alternative Sentences
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material, editing thruout
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh today encouraged state and local drug war officials to provide both prison space and alternative sentences for drug law violators. ``As a former governor, I'm well aware of the resistance that you face,'' Thornburgh told the officials gathered at a conference called by the Office of National Drug Control Policy. He described that response as ``not-in-my-backyard _ the knee-jerk, so-called NIMBY response.'' Yet, Thornburgh said, citizens should be aware of the obvious alternative. ``Would they rather have dangerous felons at large in their own back yard or have them incarcerated in their neighborhood? The answer and choice are clear.'' He noted that the federal government is spending $1.4 billion this year to build more federal prisons and that $376 million seized from drug traffickers is helping to pay for new federal prison cells. Thornburgh said that seizures of such assets and the federal government's ability to share seizures with state and local officials sends ``a crystal-clear message to those who might dabble in the drug business. Simply put, as we say to the drug profiteers, `You make it. We take it.''' He also said that alternate means of punishment are available and should be expanded and that such options will be explored at a conference after Labor Day called in Washington by the National Institute of Justice. That conference will feature officials who are running such programs as boot camps, intensified supervised probation and electronic monitoring, in which prisoners stay home and their whereabouts are monitored by use of an electronic bracelet, said Harri J. Kramer, a Justice Department spokeswoman. Thornburgh spoke a day after Louis Sullivan, the secretary of health and human services, told the conference that the government has hard facts, not ``smoke-and-mirrors projections,'' showing a steep decline in cocaine-related medical emergencies in the United States. Sullivan said reports from the Drug Abuse Warning Network showed a drop of nearly 20 percent in cocaine emergencies in the fourth quarter of 1989 after several years of increases. ``Now, this decrease represents just one data point in an ongoing series of reports, so we cannot describe it as a trend,'' he said. ``But let me say this: the results I am reporting today are not smoke-and-mirrors projections, assumptions, extrapolations or hunches, like some you've heard recently.'' ``Today's results are hard and fast data, reflecting actual, reported incidents of cocaine-related medical emergencies,'' Sullivan said. ``As such, they confirm what several surveys have indicated over the past year: that we are making significant headway in our efforts to establish a drug-free America.'' Dr. Edgar Adams, director of the epidemiology division of the Health and Human Services Department, said the Drug Abuse Warning Network, which reports on 431 emergency rooms in 21 cities, listed 2,300 cocaine-related medical emergencies in the first quarter of 1985. He said the number increased steadily to 10,200 in the second quarter of 1988 and then leveled off at around 11,000. In the fourth quarter of last year, the reports declined to 8,627, Adams said. He said the number of cases was down in 19 of the 21 metropolitan areas and remained stable in the other two.

DOC.HEAD: Actor George Hamilton Granted Immunity to Testify in Marcos Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 2 grafs with morning testimony; SUBS 3rd graf to update with earliest Hamilton appearance this afternoon.
DOC.TEXT: A judge granted immunity to George Hamilton to compel the actor to testify at Imelda Marcos' fraud trial. U.S. District Judge John F. Keenan said in his Monday order that prosecutors sought immunity because Hamilton had indicated he would invoke his Fifth Amendment right not to answer questions that might incriminate him. Hamilton, who has been named as an unindicted co-conspirator in the case, could testify as early as this afternoon. With immunity, he cannot be prosecuted for any wrongdoing but must tell the truth or face perjury charges. An unindicted co-conspirator is someone who prosecutors claim took some step that advanced a conspiracy but is not charged with a crime. Hamilton, who played a vampire in the movie comedy ``Love at First Bite,'' is a friend of the former Philippine first lady. Mrs. Marcos, 60, is accused of helping her late husband, former Philippine President Ferdinand E. Marcos, loot their nation's treasury of more than $220 million to secretly buy four New York buildings and artwork. Marcos, who also was indicted, died in exile in Hawaii in September. He was ousted as president in a popular revolt in 1986. Hamilton was mentioned in testimony as having accompanied Mrs. Marcos to view an art collection in New York that the Marcoses allegedly purchased with stolen funds. Mrs. Marcos is charged with racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction. Her co-defendant, Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi, is charged with fraud and obstruction for allegedly helping the Marcoses hide their ownership of the four buildings and art. The first witness called to testify today was Carmen Gomez, an accountant who was a long-time employee of Mrs. Marcos' friend, Gliceria Tantoco. Mrs. Tantoco, who owns a department store in Manila, was charged with Mrs. Marcos but is a fugitive. Mrs. Gomez said that Mrs. Tantoco's son, Bienvenido Tantoco Jr., told her in the spring of 1984 that his mother was in charge of four New York buildings owned by ``F.L.'' She testified that ``F.L.'' stood for ``first lady'' and referred to Mrs. Marcos.

DOC.HEAD: Vandals Paint Swastikas on Buildings; Thousands Protest Anti-Semitism
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with swastikas painted on buildings; Picks up 3rd graf, `Trade unions ...'
DOC.TEXT: Swastikas were painted on a Communist Party office and several public buildings in two towns, and four youths were arrested for spray-painting neo-Nazi slogans in two other communities, police said today. The incidents were reported a day after President Francois Mitterrand and Holocaust survivors joined with tens of thousands of other people in silent protest of anti-Semitism and the vandalism of Jewish cemeteries. Police in northern Seclin said swastikas and six-pointed stars were painted in red overnight on the town library, the tax collector's office, a reception hall and several monuments. In Gardenne, near Marseille, swastikas and racist slogans were painted on the local office of the French Communist Party, police said. Four youths were arrested Monday in southwestern Perigueux in connection with recent incidents in which neo-Nazi slogans were spray-painted on a World War II monument in Perigueux and a synagogue in Bordeaux. One of the slogans said, in German: ``We will return and conquer.'' The march Monday came hours after swastikas were found painted on Jewish graves in suburban Clichy-sous-Bois, stirring anew the national outrage that followed last week's desecration of 34 Jewish graves and mutilation of a corpse in Carpentras in southern France. Trade unions, anti-racism groups, religious leaders and all mainstream political parties called on the nation to make a ringing statement against a growing tide of racism in the country. Extreme right-wing leader Jean-Marie Le Pen, who once called the Nazi gas chambers ``a detail'' of history, did not urge his followers to participate. His deputy, Bruno Megret, accused mainstream politicians of trying to capitalize on the desecrations. Le Pen, whose National Front party was supported by 15 percent of those questioned in recent opinion polls, frequently utters anti-Semitic remarks and favors expelling France's 3.4 million Moslem immigrants. Police said about 80,000 people were in Monday's march, but organizers claimed as many as 200,000 attended the rally. The major French television networks carried live coverage of marchers jamming a mile-long route from the Place de la Republic to the Place de la Bastille. Many marchers wore yellow Stars of David similar to those the Nazis forced Jews to wear during World War II. The bells of Notre Dame cathedral, normally silent on Monday, sounded in mourning in sympathy with France's 650,000-strong Jewish community. Roaring cheers greeted Mitterrand, whose attendance was not announced in advance. It was the first time since World War II that a French president joined a public demonstration. ``The mission of justice and the police is to guard the rights of everyone,'' Mitterrand said before the march. ``Respect for the living depends on respect for the dead.'' ``I've come here about my roots,'' said Armand Volkas, 38, a San Francisco therapist whose parents were deported to Auschwitz from France for joining the Resistance. ``My mother is suffering from Alzheimer's disease, so the idea of a concentration camp survivor losing her memory is an odd metaphor,'' he said. ``I'm here to help remember.'' The marchers were mostly peaceful, but angry youths verbally abused politician Simone Veil when she tried to stop them from breaking windows at a cafe where extreme right-wingers recently toasted Hitler's birthday. Mrs. Veil, a Holocaust survivor and former president of the European Parliament, was protected by Jewish youths who stopped the pillaging, the restaurant management said. She was uninjured. The march cut across religious lines, as Moslem leaders and several Roman Catholic bishops joined in. At the request of Jewish leaders, the country's six main TV networks agreed to broadcast ``Night and Fog,'' a documentary about Nazi death camps, Monday night. At Carpentras, 55 miles north of Marseille, police last week found 34 desecrated graves and the unearthed body of an 81-year-old man impaled on an umbrella. On Monday police in the Paris suburb of Clichy-sous-Bois, where Le Pen's National Front posted strong showings in a by-election in March, found 32 graves vandalized at a Jewish cemetery. Several were marked with swastikas in red paint, markers were toppled and inscriptions defaced. Interior Minister Pierre Joxe had said Le Pen must take some responsibility for the crime. But Le Pen denounced the desecration as barbaric and said it was likely a sham staged to disgrace him and his party.

DOC.HEAD: Funeral For Cardinal O Fiaich
DOC.TEXT: Ireland's Cardinal Tomas O Fiaich was laid to rest today at a funeral that saw British and Irish officials seated alongside their avowed enemies in the Irish republican movement. O Fiaich, spiritual leader of the Roman Catholics of Ireland and Northern Ireland, died a week ago at age 66 after suffering a heart attack while on pilgrimage to the shrine of Lourdes in France. Prominent figures from around the world were among the mourners who packed the 1,500-seat St. Patrick's Cathedral in Armagh, O Fiaich's headquarters as Roman Catholic primate of All Ireland. Attending the requiem Mass were Charles Haughey, prime minister of the Irish Republic, and Peter Brooke, Britain's chief minister in its province of Northern Ireland. They sat a few yards from Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness, leaders of Sinn Fein, the legal political wing of the Irish Republican Army which is outlawed in both Ireland and Britain. The IRA is fighting to rid Northern Ireland of British rule and unite the Protestant-dominated province with the mainly Catholic Irish Republic. But at today's service, the emphasis was on O Fiaich's efforts to reconcile feuding Catholics and Protestants. Bishop Cahal Daly reminded the mourners of O Fiaich's frequent denunciations of the IRA's campaign of violence. ``May those committed to violence listen at last in death to this plea from the heart of that good Irishman who was Cardinal Tomas O Fiaich,'' he said. ``He will be remembered as a people's prelate, a man with the common touch, a happy man who spread happiness around him; a warmhearted man whose love was without frontiers and who was greatly loved,'' Daly said. Thousands of mourners listened to the Mass on loudspeakers outside the church. It was broadcast live throughout Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic. Among the mourners were New York's Cardinal John O'Connor, Cardinal Bernard Law of Boston and Cardinal Francis Arinze, president of the Vatican's council for inter-religious dialogue. Two other cardinals, 50 archbishops and abbots from Irish monasteries also attended, along with Patrick Hillery, the Irish state president. Security in and around the cathedral was tight, with dozens of armed detectives keeping watch in bulletproof cars.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Welcomes President of Tunisia
DOC.TEXT: President Bush welcomed the president of Tunisia to the White House today, hailing him as an ally and advocate of peaceful settlement to the Arab-Israeli conflict. Zine El Abidine Ben Ali was greeted with a formal welcome to the White House that included military bands and colorful honor guards on the South Lawn. ``Your visit continues a tradition of high-level discussions, demonstrating that our relations _ dating back to 1797 and close since Tunisian independence in 1956 _ are still sound and growing,'' Bush said. Ben Ali planned to ask Bush for debt relief and to express the Arab world's alarm over growing Soviet immigration to Israel. The Tunisian leader also was expected to protest what Arab countries view as unjustified U.S. and British attacks on Iraq for its alleged attempts to develop nuclear weapons. Praising Tunisia as an intermediary between Arab countries and the West, Bush said, ``It's been an example of pragmatism, stability and progress in the Middle East. ``And Tunisia has consistently supported a peaceful, negotiated resolution to the Middle East issues, including the Arab-Israeli conflict,'' Bush said. He said Tunisia's record is impressive in other areas, as well, since it has the highest literacy rate in North Africa and consistently has honored its debt obligations. Ben Ali thanked Bush for U.S. assistance. ``We are pleased to say that we are committed as firmly as you are to the ideals of democracy, human rights and free market economy, for such are our fundamental choices,'' Ben Ali said. ``And we are confident that you will continue supporting and strengthening these options,'' he said. Ben Ali, who arrived Monday for a three-day state visit, was to meet with administration officials, lawmakers, leaders of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, and attend a White House dinner. Ben Ali, a former military officer, assumed the presidency in 1987 after a panel of doctors declared the former president, Habib Bourgiba, senile. Ben Ali wants a change in Tunisia's interest payments on its $5.6 billion debt, said Tunisia's Ambassador Abdelaziz Hamzaoui. The most pressing issue on Ben Ali's agenda is the settlement of Soviet Jews in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and in the disputed eastern sector of Jerusalem. Ben Ali was quoted recently as saying he wants to tell Bush that Iraq was only acting in self-defense when it warned recently that it would attack Israel if Israel attempts to bomb Iraqi facilities as it did in 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Minister Demands Payment By Italy for Seized Parts
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's foreign minister today demanded that Italy compensate Baghdad for nearly 100 tons of steel parts seized on suspicion they were to be used to build a giant gun capable of firing shells hundreds of miles. Minister Tariq Aziz's visit to Italy began shortly after police blocked export of the material, most of which was about to be loaded at a Naples dock for transport to the Middle East. Police said the parts, ordered by Iraq and manufactured in Italy, were thought to be components of giant artillery. Aziz today reiterated Iraq's contention the material was destined for petrochemical projects. Officials at the state steel company, which made the parts, have said the design provided by Iraq raised no suspicions among technicians. They said Iraq paid about $4 million for the material. During his visit, Aziz was to meet with U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar about stalled Iran-Iraq peace talks. But he also met Monday with Italian Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis over the parts' seizure. Iraq on Monday said it would take legal action against Britain, Italy, Turkey, Greece and any other countries that take ``illegal'' measures to stop exports of equipment ordered by Iraq. Britain, Turkey, Greece and West Germany have all seized material meant for Baghdad and suspected of being weapons' components. Aziz said today that while he made no threats in his meeting with De Michelis, he said Iraq would demand compensation for material that was paid for but not delivered. Future trade and other deals could be jeopardized, he said. ``If Italy insists on not giving Iraq the material, then they have to pay the sum paid by Iraq,'' Aziz said. The Iraqi said De Michelis told him the matter was under investigation by magistrates, who will decide the outcome. Italy bans arms sales and deliveries to Iraq, as well as to Iran, Libya and Syria. Aziz said in a news conference that if Iraq had built a ``super gun'' Iraq ``would show it off to everybody.'' ``It's a lie. Iraq's arms are known. ... I've said the story of a `super cannon' is an invented story and we deny it completely,'' Aziz said. He also reiterated accusations that the suspicions were part of an Israeli propaganda campaign. Aziz was asked about Gerald Bull, the Canadian arms designer who helped Iraq develop missile research. Bull was assassinated in Brussels in March. ``Like you, I read about Bull in news reports that he had something to do with Iraqi firms. But I cannot confirm and I cannot deny that,'' Aziz said.

DOC.HEAD: `Silver Spoons' Actor Dies of AIDS at 37
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 6th graf, `The Public ...,' to CORRECT spelling of show to ``Hill Street Blues.''
DOC.TEXT: Franklyn Seales, a stage and television actor perhaps best known as the finicky business manager on the ``Silver Spoons'' TV series, has died at age 37. Seales died Monday at his family's home in New York City of complications from AIDS, his sister, Deborah Richardson, told the Los Angeles Times. Born on the Caribbean island nation of St. Vincent, Seales studied at John Houseman's Acting Company in New York in the early 1970s. Houseman enrolled Seales after spotting him at an audition for ``Romeo and Juliet,'' at which Seales was only helping a friend. Between 1982 and 1986, Seales played business manager Dexter Stuffins on the NBC-TV sitcom ``Silver Spoons,'' in which the late Houseman played a stoic grandfather. The Public Broadcasting Service television drama, ``Trial of the Moke,'' proved to be Seales' first big break. His other television appearances included ``Hill Street Blues'' and ``Amen.'' Among his motion picture credits were ``The Onion Field'' and ``Southern Comfort.'' He is survived by his mother, three sisters and three brothers.

DOC.HEAD: Dalai Lama Pleased With Government Reforms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with Dalai Lama comments; Picks up penultimate graf.
DOC.TEXT: The Dalai Lama said today he was pleased with progress over the past two days in reforming his increasingly ineffective government-in-exile despite conservative opposition to change. ``Up to now everything has depended on me, but I am getting older,'' the 54-year-old Buddhist monk said in an interview. ``A democratic system of government is more important than an individual person.'' On Monday, 368 representatives of the 120,000 Tibetans overseas elected for the first time the government-in-exile's Kashag, or Cabinet, which has headquarters in the northern Indian town of Dharmsala. Previously they were nominated by the Dalai Lama. But only three of the seven seats were filled in two rounds of balloting. Conservative opponents of the Dalai Lama's plan to separate himself from the day-to-day governing of the Tibetan movement handed in blank ballots and dropped out of the race for Cabinet seats. With a laugh, the Dalai Lama said he would be happy to work with a Cabinet of three. ``That is what the people wanted. We are on the road to democracy,'' he said. The Dalai Lama, who won the 1989 Nobel Peace Prize for his advocacy of non-violence in Tibet's struggle against Chinese rule, ordered the changes Friday when he dissolved the Kashag and the Assembly of Tibetan People's Deputies, or parliament. The spiritual and temporal leader of the world's 6 million Tibetans said he wanted his movement to become more democratic. Many Tibetans oppose the reforms because they fear the responsibility that democracy entails, said Tenzin Namgyal Tethong, a newly elected Cabinet member. ``In the past they thought the Dalai Lama would handle everything; now the people realize that their participation is also important,'' said Tethong, the Dalai Lama's chief representative in Washington. ``The Dalai Lama is telling us to get involved in the movement again. It is a challenge.'' Tethong is joined in the Cabinet by the Dalai Lama's younger sister, Jetsen Pema, known for her work with Tibetan children and in education, and Kelsang Yeshi, a former minister for culture and religious affairs. Another reason for opposition to reforms is that many Tibetans revere the Dalai Lama as a living god and feel his authority should not be challenged by a government outside his control. ``I am just a monk, maybe a popular one, but just a monk,'' the Dalai Lama said with a chuckle. Tethong said the next step will be to reform elections and the parliament. He said a new, expanded body will be elected by the end of the year and will better represent the exiled Tibetan community. Tethong, and later the Dalai Lama, said the reform was necessary to rebut charges from Beijing that Tibetans live in a backward, feudal society dominated by conservative monks and superstition. The Dalai Lama said changes in Eastern Europe have convinced him of the fragile nature of Chinese communism. He said he believes that within 10 years Tibetan exiles will be able to return to their mountainous homeland. The government-in-exile also has been criticized for not taking advantage of pro-independence protests in Tibet in which scores died over the past two years. On May 1, China lifted martial law in the Tibet capital of Lhasa after more than 13 months. Communist China claims Tibet has been part of China since the 13th century, but Tibetans claim their land has been an independent nation since antiquity. Chinese Communist troops marched into Tibet in 1950. Nine years later, Chinese security forces brutally crushed an uprising, forcing the Dalai Lama to flee with 80,000 followers to India where he set up his government-in-exile.

DOC.HEAD: Government Complaint Alleges Supremacists Planned Bombings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `A third...', to CORRECT third suspect's name to Proctor J. Baker sted James P. Baker.
