DOC.TEXT: Two Idaho men with ties to the white-supremacist movement planned to bomb Korean businesses, a synagogue and bars popular with blacks and gays, an FBI agent says in a government complaint. The two were arrested Saturday near a motel south of Seattle just hours before they planned to detonate a bomb at a popular gay club, Thomas Trier, FBI special agent stationed in Tacoma, said in an affidavit. John Winslow, 29, of LaClede, Idaho, and Stephen E. Nelson, 35, of Hayden Lake, Idaho, appeared in federal court Monday for a bond hearing. The hearing was continued until Thursday at the government's request. A third man, Proctor J. Baker, 57, of Coeur d'Alene, Idaho, was arrested Saturday in Coeur d'Alene and appeared in court there Monday. Details of Baker's involvement were not disclosed. All three men were associated with the white supremacist group the Church of Jesus Christ Christian (Aryan Nations), based in Hayden Lake, Idaho, federal authorities said. Trier said in his affidavit that some information obtained by the FBI came from legal electronic surveillance and that Nelson and Winslow were followed by federal agents from the Aryan Nations compound in Idaho to the Seattle area. Trier said Winslow talked of plans with Nelson to bomb several black bars in Tacoma, several Korean businesses in south Tacoma and a synagogue in Seattle. ``Winslow agreed that their intended targets were in Seattle because they were sure to get maximum impact due to the upcoming Goodwill Games,'' Trier said, referring to the Olympic-style athletic event planned for July and August in Seattle, Tacoma and other cities in the state. Trier also said Winslow stated ``they wanted to make a major impact to `get the movement clicking,''' an apparent reference to the white-supremacist movement. Winslow and Nelson were charged with conspiring to bomb the Neighbours Disco after traveling to Seattle from Hayden Lake and buying materials to make a bomb. They also face charges of possession of firearms and bomb parts. The government charged Baker with possession of two pipe bombs. He was held without bond and scheduled to appear in court again Wednesday. Winslow and Nelson were taken into custody as they emerged from a van parked at a motel south of Seattle. A search of the vehicle turned up a 6-inch pipe with caps for both ends, smokeless gunpowder, a coil of primer fuse, a propane cylinder, a 12-gauge pump-action shotgun, a .38-caliber revolver, a ``stun gun,'' knives, hate literature and other items, the FBI said. FBI agents used federal warrants to conduct a simultaneous search at the Aryan Nations compound and other locations in Idaho. Aryan Nations has been a center for white supremacist activities the past decade. Its leaders advocate establishment of an ``Aryan homeland'' in the Northwest.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Coming to Visit Minnesota During Summit Trip, Governor Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with governor saying visit confirmed. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `Richard Bohr...'.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gorbachev Tour, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will visit Minnesota on June 3 while he is in the United States for the summit meeting, Gov. Rudy Perpich announced today. In a statement from his office, the governor said he was officially notified of the visit this morning by Yuriy V. Dubinin, Soviet ambassador to the United States. Dubinin told Perpich that the Soviet leader would stop in Minnesota from 1 p.m. to 7 p.m. June 3. Gorbachev would like to meet with representatives of the business community and agricultural leaders in the state, Perpich said in the statement. The statement didn't indicate whether Gorbachev's wife, Raisa, would accompany him. ``President Gorbachev's visit to Minnesota is a tremendous compliment to the people of Minnesota,'' Perpich said. Earlier, before the plans for the visit were confirmed, Perpich had pronounced the prospect of a visit from Gorbachev ``bigger than the Super Bowl'' and said he'd like to take the Soviet leader to meet his parents. ``It's almost too good to be true yet,'' said the governor, who extended the invitation in a Feb. 26 letter. `I didn't believe it at first. The Russians are coming. Can you imagine?'' ``I think it's bigger than the Super Bowl,'' he said. The Super Bowl comes to Minneapolis in 1992. Business leaders, meanwhile, savored the opportunity to forge closer ties to the Soviet Union in such areas as high technology and food processing. Gorbachev is to arrive in Washington on May 30; the talks are to conclude by June 3. When asked the one place he would take Gorbachev, Perpich said, ``What comes to me almost immediately is Hibbing, to visit my father and mother.'' Perpich's 90-year-old father, a retired miner, immigrated from Yugoslavia, in 1920 and his mother, 78, is the daughter of immigrant parents. Richard Bohr, executive director of the Minnesota Trade Office, said the invitation to Gorbachev may have been kept alive in part by the Soviet leader's ``fascination'' with Nikita Khrushchev's visit to Iowa in 1959. Albert Eisele, a former Control Data Corp. employee who said it was his idea to invite Gorbachev, said the Iowa trip generated good publicity for Khrushchev. But he said a visit to Minnesota would have economic purposes as well. ``Minnesota has high technology, health care, food processing, packaging and distribution and education _ everything the Soviets need,'' said Eisele, a lobbyist in Washington. ``For that reason we would very much want him to come and establish a closer relationship.'' Robert Schmidt, a former executive of Control Data, said the Twin Cities business community will propose a forum to meet with Gorbachev. ``There are lots of things going on here in the state of Minnesota that I always thought would be of interest to Gorbachev,'' Schmidt said. From 1969 to 1979, when trade was interrupted by the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, Control Data sold more than $150 million worth of computers to the Soviets, Schmidt said. Schmidt said the Soviets have colossal agricultural problems that could be solved with the technology of Minnesota companies. Geo. A. Hormel & Co., for example, is interested in modernizing food packaging, storage and distribution in the Soviet Union, he said. Many Soviet farm products spoil before they reach the market, Schmidt said. Vern Freeh, vice president of international affairs for Land O'Lakes Inc., said the dairy cooperative is trying to open an agricultural operation south of Moscow. Other Minnesota companies doing business in the Soviet Union include automated controls maker Honeywell Inc. and grain merchant Cargill Inc. Freeh said Gorbachev's decision to extend his stay in the United States is the mark of a ``very astute politician.'' ``If he says, `I want to see the middle of your country and the West Coast,' people will say, `Hey, there's quite a guy,''' Freeh said.

DOC.HEAD: Crocodile Kills Two Hunters
DOC.TEXT: Two young men tracking a crocodile with spears were killed when the animal attacked them, according to a report Tuesday. The South African Press Association said the two were killed over the weekend when they went after the crocodile because it had eaten several goats and cattle from their herds. Nearby villagers who rushed to the scene attacked the crocodile after it killed the hunters, and a man with a gun killed it, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Charged With Ordering Demolition of Mosque
DOC.TEXT: A town mayor was charged with interfering with religious freedom for ordering the demolition of a wing of an abandoned factory that was being used as a mosque. Gerard Dezempte, mayor of Charvieu-Chavagneux in eastern France, maintained his innocence during Monday's court hearing in Lyon. He said he assigned a bulldozer to demolish the north wing of the building, and that it accidentally razed the south wing. Five people were sleeping in the wing when the bulldozer arrived August 16 at 7 a.m. and began the demolition. One of the occupants was slightly wounded. The local Moslem community accused Dezempte of racism and rejected his claim that the demolition was accidental. Interior Minister Pierre Joxe sided with the Moslems, expressing the Socialist government's disapproval of the mayor. Dezempte is a member of the conservative Rally for the Republic party. The manager of the demolition company, Felix Deschanoz, and his son, Franck, who drove the bulldozer, also were charged Monday with complicity in the unlawful destruction of property and interference in the practice of religion. Shortly after the demolition, the bulldozer was set afire, and fires later broke out at the mayor's office and a municipal gymnasium. Dezempte, who had opposed the establishment of a mosque in the town, described the fires as ``terrorist attacks.'' In late August, the mayor and the head of a local Islamic cultural association signed an accord providing new premises for a mosque. The case against the mayor was adjourned until next month.

DOC.HEAD: Campaign Promises Complicate Farm Bill
DOC.TEXT: Election-year promises bumping against the constraints of deficit reduction are complicating the 1990 farm bill. As negotiators from Congress and the White House start their budget summit today, the House and Senate Agriculture committees continue efforts behind closed doors to write their big-money commodities programs. Staffers say the Senate committee's proposals could make it into the open by Wednesday for a vote by the panel. The House, however, is moving more slowly as a task force composed of agriculture subcommittee chairmen and ranking Republicans review the promises made at subcommittee level. ``We have promised policies we do not have money for,'' Rep. Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, chairman of the committee, has said. The House Agriculture Committee also is getting pressure from a small group of lawmakers who say they'll attack the farm bill on the floor if its price support programs are too protective of farmers with high incomes. That group, led by Reps. Richard Armey, R-Texas, and Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., represents a problem agricultural interests in the House have with congressmen who don't need farmers to get elected. The entire House and the one-third of the Senate is up for election this fall. In the Senate, where every member has a farm constituency, the money is a little looser, though the budget summit may change that. The talks are aimed at finding enough savings to hold next year's federal deficit to no more than $64 billion, the target set by the Gramm-Rudman balanced-budget law. White House budget chief Richard Darman has said that $60 billion to $100 billion in deficit reduction might be necessary. Republicans said Monday that among their chief goals will be reductions in domestic spending, including farm price supports. The bill the Senate Agriculture Committee has been working on was introduced by the so-called ``prairie populists'' led by Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., and including Sens. Thomas Daschle, D-S.D.; Tom Harkin, D-Iowa; Kent Conrad, D-N.D. and James Exon, D-Neb. ``Their proposal, while not quite living up to the fiery language of the group's press conference, calls for higher loan rates and target prices, as well as an optional bushel-base supply management program _ all paralleling the most progressive concepts still alive on the House side,'' said the National Family Farm Coalition.

_greater than WASHINGTON (AP) _ The Agriculture Department announced Monday that the Soviet Union is purchasing an additional 150,000 metric tons of corn and 100,000 more metric tons of soft red winter wheat. The department also announced that 30,000 tons of U.S. soybean oil are being sold to Pakistan. Sales to the Soviet Union this marketing year now total 19,345,700 tons of corn and wheat _ 3,561,500 tons of wheat and 15,784,200 tons of corn. The marketing year began Oct. 1, 1989. Under government agreement, the Soviet Union can buy up to 22 million tons of the two commodities until the year ends Sept. 30.

Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn., is introducing legislation to quicken the speed at which health-threatening pesticides are removed from the market. The bill, which is cosponsored by Sens. Harry Reid, D-Nev., and David Durenberger, R-Minn., also would: _ Expand the definition of certified and private applicators to include anyone who uses registered pesticides. _ Ensure that a pesticide's effects on children be reviewed before it is registered. _ Require applicators to be proficient at integrated pest management and other low or nonchemical forms of pest control. _ Put a nine-year life on the registration of all pesticides to ensure that they are re-evaluated regularly. _ Require applicators and dealers to keep records of sales and applications. _ Require a pediatrician and scientist trained in public health to sit on the scientific advisory panel and forbid anyone from being appointed to the panel who does business with a pesticide company.

DOC.HEAD: Names of Eight Suspected Nazi Collaborators Given to New Zealand
DOC.TEXT: Nazi hunters said Tuesday that the New Zealand government has been given the names of eight Nazi collaborators who are believed to be hiding in New Zealand. Ephraim Zuroff, Israel director of the Los Angeles-based Simon Wiesenthal Center, said the suspects were five Lithuanians, two Latvians and one Serb. He said all the individuals listed were ``involved in the commission of murder.'' He refused to give the names. Zuroff said suspects included a former police chief of Bazilionai, Lithuania, who was accused of killing several hundred Jews in 1941, and a Lithuanian vigilante who was responsible for the deaths of 140 Jews on July 29, 1941. The list was turned over to the New Zealand ambassador to the United Nations, Ann Hercus, on Monday, Zuroff said.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Suggests All-Germany Elections to Boost Momentum for Unification
An AP News Analysis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with West German gov't calling for early elections as soon as possible. Pick up 8th pvs, `Moscow's flat...'
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl has found that the road to German unification is paved with obstacles and marred by an occasional pothole. The latest trouble is a state elections setback that pushed Kohl to suggest joint German voting a year earlier than planned, to regain his party's momentum. Kohl and his coalition allies agreed today that elections for a united German government should occur as soon as possible. That brought immediate criticism from the opposition Social Democrats. The chancellor conceded a ``bitter defeat'' in Sunday's elections in two West German states. The Social Democrats defeated his conservative Christian Democratic Party and won control of the upper house of Parliament, the Bundesrat. The Social Democrats have opposed Kohl's plans for a quick unification, proposing a more cautious approach. Hans Klein, the chief government spokesman, said today that all sides were unanimously agreed there should be all-German elections ``at the earliest possible date.'' He was not more specific. But Alfred Dregger, parliamentary leader of Kohl's Christian Democrats, said he favors either replacing the Dec. 2 federal elections with all-German ones, or holding the all-German vote when the current legislative period ends Jan. 13, 1991. Finance Minister Theodor Waigel said he believes an all-German vote will occur this year. The lower house, the Bundestag, is the actual lawmaking body, but Bundesrat approval is needed for legislation that has direct consequences for the finances of West Germany's 11 states. Kohl's defeat was just one of a growing list of obstacles that are plaguing Kohl's ambitious plans for a rapid unification. These include: _ Moscow's flat refusal to budge from its position that a united Germany may not belong to the NATO alliance. _ Poland's call for a formal guarantee that a united Germany will have no claims to its Western border. _ The threat by East Germany's Social Democrats to pull out of the government if unification does not provide strong social benefits. _ The strong disagreement between East Germans and West Germans over how much property West Germans will be able to buy in East Germany. That disagreement also reflects East Germany's strong fear of economic domination by the larger and economically more powerful West Germany. ``The whole thing is going to quickly, and just hasn't been thought through,'' said one woman during a demonstration of shopkeepers Monday in East Berlin. East German tenants are banding together to fight what they predict will be skyrocketing rents as a result of unification. Others fear the ever-growing number of West Germans coming back to claim property they abandoned while fleeing the Communists after World War II. East German women are demanding a retention of their nation's liberal abortion law, rather than West Germany's more restrictive regulations. In West Germany, anxious citizens are worriedly pointing to the astronomical costs of unification that could run into hundreds of billions of dollars. They are also concerned over predictions of high inflation similar to the huge price increases that preceeded the Nazi era. West German voters took their dissatisfaction to the ballot box on Sunday, leading to a resounding defeat for Kohl's Christian Democrats. Strong support for Christian Democrats in East Germany would help Kohl if all-German balloting were held in December, but such an election would likely spark outcry from the rival Social Democrats and raise eyebrows throughout Europe. Kohl promised his European Community colleagues at a summit meeting in Dublin last month that an all-German election would take place late next year, not this year. In West Berlin, where Kohl met with East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere, the chancellor told reporters that unification would proceed ``step-by-step'' and added that no date for elections had been discussed. ``The work is enormous,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Awards $971 Million Rocket Motor Contract To Lockheed
DOC.TEXT: NASA has awarded a $971 million contract to Lockheed Missiles and Space Co. for 20 new solid fuel booster rocket motors to help propel space shuttles into orbit. Morton Thiokol Inc., which produced the faulty booster blamed for the Jan. 28, 1986, Challenger disaster, did not bid on the contract, NASA spokesman Jerry Berg said today. The new 125-feet ``motors,'' actually the main body of the booster, could increase the payload capacity of shuttle flights by six tons. NASA has an option to order up to 88 motors, or 44 shuttle flight sets. That additional production option could be worth up to $1.3 billion. Lockheed, located in Sunnyvale, Calif., is teamed with Aerojet Space Boosters Co. of Sacramento, Calif., as its principal subcontractor. The first set of the new rocket motors is to be delivered in 1995 and NASA plans to phase them in over three years.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Rebels Say They Killed Airmen
LaserPhotos MLA7,11
DOC.TEXT: Communist rebels claimed responsibility Tuesday for the weekend slaying of two American airmen and threatened more killings until all U.S. military members leave the country. Also Tuesday, President Corazon Aquino's government formally told the United States that the lease on the six U.S. military bases here expires in September 1991 and cannot be extended. The move was largely symbolic, and U.S. and Filipino officials said it does not rule out a new accord. Police arrested about 50 people Tuesday after they staged a motorcade to demand the bases be closed. In a statement to news organizations, the central Luzon command of the New People's Army said it ``punished'' the two Americans _ airmen John H. Raven, 19, of Delta Junction, Alaska, and James C. Green, 20, of Craig, Colo. _ because of U.S. ``aggression and intervention in the internal affairs of our country.'' The two were shot Sunday with .45-caliber pistols at close range while waiting for a ride near Clark Air Base, 50 miles north of Manila. A companion, Airman 1C Randall Moore, escaped uninjured. ``This incident serves as a warning to the U.S. government and its local puppet regime,'' the statement said. ``We will not stop until abuses by American officers and soldiers have ceased. We will not stop until all U.S. bases and all American occupational soldiers are kicked out of our country.'' U.S. authorities banned the 40,000 troops, Defense Department civilians and military dependents from leaving their bases in the wake of the killing. Those living off-post were ordered to stay home when off duty. The statement did not mention the May 4 killing of U.S. Marine Gunnery Sgt. John Fredette near Subic, 50 miles west of Manila. U.S. officials believe the rebels were also responsible for killing Fredette. The Communist rebels fighting the Philippine government for more than 21 years have repeatedly threatened to kill Americans. In 1989, rebels gunned down U.S. Army Col. James ``Nick'' Rowe, a decorated Vietnam War veteran. In October 1987, rebels killed two enlisted airmen and a retired U.S. Air Force sergeant near Clark. U.S. and Philippine officials began the second day of talks in Manila to decide whether to enter formal negotiations on a new bases agreement. Although there is growing opposition in the Philippines to the U.S. bases, many Filipinos support them because they pump an estimated $1 billion into the economy every year. In a surprise move, Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus, the chief Philippine delegate, presented a formal ``notice of termination'' for Clark Air Base, the Subic Bay naval base and the four smaller U.S. installations. ``The government of the Philippines hereby notifies the government of the United States of America that the 1947 Philippines-United States Military Bases Agreement ends on Sept. 16, 1991 and cannot be extended,'' the notice said. Rafael Alunan, spokesman for the Philippine panel, said the notice, given by Manglapus to chief U.S. negotiator Richard Armitage, did not rule out a new agreement. ``Our constitution mandate is to be open to new ideas, to lead us to a new negotiation for a new treaty,'' Alunan said. ``It does not preclude new negotiations for a new treaty.'' Although largely symbolic, the move underscored differences between the two governments over when the bases must close if no new agreement is reached. The Philippines maintains the current agreement allows the bases to remain until Sept. 16, 1991. The United States claims they could stay one year longer. The 1947 Military Bases Agreement allowed the United States to maintain installations here for 99 years. In 1966, the agreement was amended so that the pact would remain in force for 25 more years subject ``to termination upon one year's notice by either government.'' According to the U.S. interpretation, the Philippines would have to wait until Sept. 16, 1991 to give one year's notice. In 1986, a few months after Mrs. Aquino took office, the constitution was rewritten to state that ``after expiration in 1991 of the agreement ... concerning military bases, foreign military bases, troops or facilities shall not be allowed in the Philippines'' unless provided for under a new treaty. Philippine officials say the new constitution supersedes the 1966 timetable. Stanley Schrager, spokesman for the U.S. panel, said American negotiators were surprised by the timing of the Philippine notice. He said the U.S. hopes a new agreement can be reached before September 1991, making the difference of opinion on the expiration moot.

DOC.HEAD: 20th Anniversary Of Jackson State Slayings Passes Quietly
DOC.TEXT: The 20th anniversary of two slayings during protests at Jackson State passed unobserved this morning on a quiet, sunny campus where a handful of students and staff handled between-semester business. The shootings were ``something that hit the news real fast ... and sort of got real hushed,'' said Cass Parker, an assistant chemistry professor and former student at Jackson State. ``The students' interest has changed tremendously. There seems to be a resurgence in student interest, but it's not the same _ I guess it's a little subdued.'' There was no observance of the day James Earl Green and Phillip Gibbs were shot to death, mainly because school was out, said Parker, a Jackson State student from 1971-1975. Classes ended May 12 and will resume June 12. On May 2, about 300 people attended a convocation and held a candlelight vigil at a marble memorial dedicated to Gibbs and Green. At about 12:05 a.m. on May 15, 1970, law enforcement officers opened fire on students at then-Jackson State College during a protest on the Vietnam war and civil rights issues. The barrage of rifle and shotgun fire lasted about a minute. Killed were Gibbs, a 21-year-old pre-law major from Ripley who was taking part in the protest, and the 17-year-old Green, a Jackson high school student who was walking through the college campus on his way home from work. The shootings followed by less than two weeks the deaths of four students at Kent State University in Ohio during an anti-war protest there. Author and poet Margaret Alexander Walker, the featured speaker at the May 2 ceremonies, chided students for not turning out in greater numbers to remember the dead. However, school officials noted later that classes wern't dismissed for the day's events. The school had about 3,700 students in 1970 and has about 7,150 today, 93 percent of them black. ``Students were not discussing (the convocation),'' said Parker. ``It was just another something else that happened.'' Tracie Archie, a 20-year-old political science student, was showing a friend around campus this morning and stopped by the memorial briefly. ``They had it in the paper, but a lot of students didn't know about it,'' she said. ``There wasn't much talk about (the shootings). My mother told me about it.''

DOC.HEAD: French Worker Dies in Channel Tunnel
DOC.TEXT: A construction worker died Tuesday after he was hit by a truck in the partly completed tunnel under the English Channel, officials said. The project's death toll is now eight. The worker was identified by management as Rene Saint-Georges, 56, of Calais. He was the second French worker killed since construction began in 1986. Six workers on the English side have died, the most recent May 7. The tunnel will contain two rail lines and is scheduled for completion in June 1993. The total cost is estimated at $13 billion. About half the tunneling on the 31-mile project has been completed.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Finds Couple Guilty In Beating Adoptee Son To Death
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to restore dropped first reference to prosecutor Keenan.
DOC.TEXT: A woman was convicted of manslaughter and assault today in the beating death of her newly adopted 2-year-old child, and her husband was found guilty of assault but acquitted of the more serious charge. Monroe County Judge Donald Wisner found Bernice Kittelberger, 32, guilty of second-degree manslaughter and second-degree assault in the death last August of Maurice West, who died just eight weeks after coming to Rochester from a Cincinnati foster home. Wisner found Gerald Kittelberger, 30, innocent of the manslaughter charge, but convicted him for second-degree assault. The couple had waived a jury trial and did not testify in their own defense. The judge allowed the Kittelbergers to remain free without bail until sentencing July 25. The manslaughter conviction carries a maximum sentence of 15 years in prison, and second-degree assault has a maximum sentence of seven years. The trial was attended by Maurice's former foster parents from Cincinnati, Jan and Dale West. The Wests had wanted to adopt Maurice but were turned down because they were white and the child was black. The Wests have criticized adoption officials for placing Maurice with the Kittelbergers, who are black, arguing there was inadequate investigation and follow-through. Monroe County Medical Examiner Dr. Nicholas T. Forbes testified that he believed Maurice's death was a direct result of repeated and severe beatings. He said he could not, however, say exactly what caused the child to die. Witnesses testified that Maurice's face, legs, buttocks, and genitals were severely bruised and swollen, and that there were partially healed burns on the palms and backs of his hands. In a statement to police, Mrs. Kittelberger said Maurice died after choking on oatmeal. Both Kittelbergers told police that they had beaten the child with a belt, a paddle and a stick wrapped with tape to punish him for resisting toilet training. Defense attorneys argued that medical experts had been unable to pinpoint the specific cause of Maurice's death and asked that the charges be reduced to third-degree assault, a misdemeanor. Thomas Cocuzzi, who represented Mrs. Kittelberger, acknowledged that she had used inappropriate force on Maurice. But ``that is not enough for you to convict her of either of the counts,'' he argued. Alvita Eason, Kittelberger's attorney, said her client was not home the morning Maurice died, at the time Forbes suggested the child received a fatal injury. But Richard A. Keenan, assistant Monroe County district attorney, said Kittelberger had beaten Maurice himself and knew his wife was beating the child.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Say Production Level Shows Weak Manufacturing Sector
DOC.TEXT: Industrial production fell 0.4 percent in April in what analysts called a sign of continuing weakness in manufacturing. The Federal Reserve today attributed the drop to a 14 percent decline in production of cars and light trucks. ``Industrial production excluding motor vehicles and parts was unchanged in April and has shown little movement since January,'' the nation's central bank reported. Cynthia Latta, an economist with DRI@McGraw-Hill, a Lexington, Mass., forecasting organization, said the report was ``in line with all the other signals that we have had that the industrial sector is the weak link right now in the economy.'' Industrial production had risen 0.5 percent in March and 0.9 percent in February. The advances were revised from increases of 0.7 percent originally reported for March and 0.8 percent for February. Output had fallen 1.0 percent in January. ``Last month, people were talking about accelerating growth,'' said Thomas Runiewicz, an econmist with the WEFA Group in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. ``This kind of brings us back to our senses. When you discount the auto sector, it really shows the economy is flat.'' Ms. Latta said the drop in auto production ``was not as bad as it looks.'' ``If the auto industry was producing full tilt,'' she said, ``it would have to cut back sharply'' because of slow sales. That, in turn, would produce further job losses. Indeed, Richard W. Rahn, chief economist with the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, said the weak 0.1 percent growth in industrial production in the last 12 months has been accompanied by a loss of 280,000 factory jobs. Output at factories producing both durable and non-durable goods fell 0.6 percent in April. Durable manufacturing was off a full 1.0 percent, while non-durable output slipped 0.1 percent. Mining production, however, rose 0.9 percent while utility output gained 0.6 percent. The Fed said its industrial production index in April stood at 108.7 percent of its 1987 base, down from 109.1 percent in March. The Fed also reported the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities _ which usually move in tandem with industrial production _ dipped 0.5 percentage point to 83.0 percent in April. The operating rate measures not only output but also changes in productivity levels. The overall manufacturing operating rate fell 0.7 points to 82.2 percent. The rate at factories producing durable goods fell a full percentage point to 80.7 percent, while the rate at plants making non-durable goods slipped from 84.6 percent in March to 84.3 percent last month. The operating rate at mines rose 0.9 points to 88.3 percent, while it jumped 0.5 points to 86.6 percent at utilities.

DOC.HEAD: Agreement On Fairness Media Time, Free Elections Signed
DOC.TEXT: Government and opposition negotiators worked late into the night to sign agreements early today on guarantees of free elections, media time and campaign funds and fairness. The first postwar multiparty elections will be held June 10. A runoff will be held a week later. The final election accords were expected to be signed last week, but were delayed by procedural haggling between the opposition and the ruling Socialist Party. Almost 40 parties and alliances are registered to contest the first free multiparty elections since World War II. No more than five or six are expected to win seats in a new parliament that will work on a new constitution before new elections are held in about 18 months. Petko Simeonov, leader of the election campaign of the Union of Democratic Forces, said that on June 10 Bulgaria will prove that it has always stood for democracy, the state news agency BTA reported. The opposition Agrarian party Nikola Petkov, which is part of the UDF, said in a separate statement that there are no conditions for holding ``free, honest and democratic elections in Bulgaria.'' According to BTA, the Nikola Petkov party urged the present government of former Communists to resign and be replaced by an interim coalition able to ensure democratic preparations for free elections. The party said it would contest the June 10 elections, but leveled harsh accusations against the Socialists, who govern alone and dominate national politics. The Socialists reject blame for the imprisonment, torture, murder or repression of hundreds of thousands of people in the Stalinist 1950s, the Nikola Petkov party charged. It also claimed that the former Communist Party's functionaries have weapons, that voters are being threatened and that there are cases of physical violence.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in Upper Plains; Flood Waters in South Texas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with storms today, picking up at the 3rd graf pvs, `In the Rockies...'.
DOC.TEXT: Fast-moving thunderstorms dumped heavy rain and hail on the central Plains early today, causing local flooding and downing power lines, and record releases from a swollen lake in Texas threatened to flood thousands of homes. Thunderstorms battered parts of Missouri and Kansas today, with more than 7 inches of rain in places flooding streets and closing some rural roads. An industrial area of northeastern Kansas City, Mo., was evacuated because of flooding along the Big Blue River. The area also had storms Monday. Clifford Clark, administrator of the Greene County, Mo., highway department, said his crews had closed 20 farm roads in the county today because of high water. ``The water is very swift in a lot of the areas, and the roads could be washed out too,'' he said. High water forced cars off roadways north and south of Emporia, Kan. String wind battered southwestern Missouri along with the storms, uprooting trees and knocking down power lines. Nixa was completely blacked out and Springfield had scattered outages. In the Rockies, showers were reported early today in Salt Lake City and rain fell over Montana. Temperatures were to soar into the 90s in the desert of Arizona, western Texas and the Gulf Coast of Florida. The rest of the Sun Belt was to have mostly temperatures in the 80s. Showers were forecast to today across Montana, the Dakotas, Iowa and Missouri and Illinois. Rain was to move into the upper Midwest by late tonight. More rain was also expected today in Texas and Oklahoma. Almost continuous monthlong flooding in the region has caused 13 deaths, ruined millions of dollars in crops and damaged hundreds of homes. A dam today at Lake Livingston in Texas approached record releases of water as torrential rain two weeks ago hundreds of miles to the north finally reached the lake about 60 miles north of Houston. An estimated 7,000 people were urged to evacuate. Severe thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front on Monday that moved across southwestern Texas through Oklahoma and into Kansas, spilling more water into the flooded Red and Trinity rivers. Thunderstorms over northern Texas Monday spawned a tornado at Tuxedo, causing some damage and injuries. Another twister was reported northwest of Guthrie. The nation's high Monday was 104 degrees at Lajitas and Presidio, Texias.
