Marie 47 foggy; San Antonio 76 cloudy. _West: Albuquerque 64 fair; Anchorage 47 cloudy; Boise 43 fair; Casper 47 cloudy; Fairbanks 57 partly cloudy; Great Falls 42 rain; Honolulu 74 fair; Las Vegas 70 windy; Los Angeles 58 partly cloudy; Medford 46 fair; Pendleton 48 partly cloudy; Phoenix 80 fair; Portland, Ore., 51 partly cloudy; Reno 52 fair; Salt Lake City 44 showers; San Diego 61 cloudy; San Francisco 52 partly cloudy; Seattle 47 fair; Spokane 45 cloudy. _International: Calgary 37 partly cloudy; Montreal 55 partly cloudy; Ottawa 54 partly cloudy; Regina 50 windy; Toronto 54 partly cloudy; Winnipeg 45 fair; Mexico City 66 fair; San Juan 77 partly cloudy.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Top Issue in Pa.; Nebraska and Oregon Also Hold Primaries
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS in 3rd graf that Hatfield has one primary opponent.
DOC.TEXT: Pennsylvania voters today settle primary contests for governor dominated, oddly enough, by an anti-abortion Democrat and a pro-choice Republican. Nebraska Democrats choose among seven men bidding for a chance to oust Gov. Kay Orr. In Oregon's primary for governor, Attorney General Dave Frohnmayer is favored to win the GOP nomination to replace retiring Democratic Gov. Neil Goldschmidt. Secretary of State Barbara Roberts is unopposed on the Democratic side. In Senate races, two-term Democrat James Exon of Nebraska has no primary opposition and former Republican Rep. Hal Daub is favored to win the nomination to challenge him. Oregon Sen. Mark Hatfield's bid for a fifth term is opposed by one long-shot challenger in the GOP primary. Six Democrats are seeking their party's nomination, including businessman Harry Lonsdale, who criticizes Hatfield's anti-abortion views. In Pennsylvania, Gov. Robert P. Casey's opposition to abortion is at odds with prevailing political stands. Nationally the Democratic Party favors abortion rights, and the GOP seeks to ban abortion. Casey, who in November signed a tough anti-abortion law, is being challenged in the primary by lawyer Philip S. Berg, who has based his underdog campaign on that issue. ``I believe that this primary election will be decided by voters who will choose to reaffirm individual rights,'' Berg said. Casey, who is seeking a second term, has asked voters to look beyond abortion to his administration's efforts to clean up the environment, tackle drugs, boost economic development and increase aid to education. ``I think this election is going to be a referendum on my record,'' Casey said. On the Republican side, pro-choice Auditor General Barbara Hafer is challenged by Marguerite ``Peg'' Luksik of Johnstown, who opposes abortion. Hafer has the endorsement of the Republican State Committee. ``I would say I'm a long shot, but anybody on the ballot is viable and I'm on the ballot,'' Mrs. Luksik said. ``Win or lose, I think it's been good for the state.'' In the Democratic lieutenant governor's race, former state party chairman Edward Mezvinsky launched a late challenge to incumbent Mark S. Singel, who opposes abortion. ``We've put together a textbook campaign in response to a very odd, submerged opponent,'' Singel said. Three Democratic congressmen from western Pennsylvania face tough primary races. Rep. John Murtha, chairman of the House Defense appropriations subcommittee, is under attack from Kenneth Burkley, a lawyer, for relying on political action committees and for voting for the congressional pay raise. Rep. Austin Murphy is accused of ``immoral conduct'' by challenger William Nicolella because he fathered an illegitimate son nearly two decades ago. Murphy said, ``I respect and care ... for all my children.'' And Rep. Joe Kolter is challenged by Frank Clark, who held the seat for 20 years until he was unseated in 1978. Clark, part-owner of a gas and oil company, says the incumbent hasn't done enough for the district's economy. Clark lost a previous comeback bid in 1986. Mrs. Orr, who four years ago became the first Republican woman elected governor of any state, is expected to overcome a primary challenge from Omaha businessman Mort Sullivan. Democrats are optimistic about their chances in November. A recent Omaha World-Herald poll showed her approval rating at 39 percent, partly because of lingering resentment over a state tax hike early in her administration. ``It's a targeted race for us,'' said Mark Gearan, executive director of the Democratic Governors Association. ``Kay Orr is one of the most vulnerable incumbent Republican governors. And we have a very good group of opponents.'' Four candidates in the crowded Democratic field were considered to have the best shot at nomination: Mike Boyle, former mayor of Omaha; Lincoln Mayor Bill Harris; Omaha lawyer Ben Nelson, and Bill Hoppner, a former aide to Sens. Exon and Bob Kerrey. Late last week Kerrey reversed a pledge to refrain from backing a candidate and disclosed he had cast his absentee ballot for Hoppner. Residents of Eugene, Ore., will vote on a measure to toughen an ordinance that bans the local manufacture of nuclear weapons and their components. Some say the existing ordinance has stifled economic growth. Citing the pending ballot measure, Rohr Industries earlier this year decided to build a $15 million factory for jet engine parts in San Marcos, Texas, rather than Eugene. With it went 250 jobs.

DOC.HEAD: Bailiff, Suspect Wounded in Courtroom Shooting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Name Ptomey is correct.
DOC.TEXT: A court bailiff and a man being arraigned on a traffic charges were wounded in a courtroom struggle today after the man pulled a gun, a spokeswoman said. The shooting occurred in the courtroom of Monroe County Judge William Ptomey, who was hearing misdemeanor traffic cases. Peter Anderson, 22, of Miami was to be arraigned on drunken driving and related charges, but when his name was called he handed a dead flower to Assistant State Attorney Leo Bueno, said sheriff's spokeswoman Becky Herrin. When asked why, Anderson allegedly said the charges were ridiculous and pulled a .38-caliber revolver from inside his waistband. Bailiff Ron Dowmond, 62, attempt to grab the gun, but it went off, wounding the bailiff in the hand and grazing Anderson's neck and cheek. Anderson was jailed on charges of attempted murder, aggravated battery, carrying a firearm in a courtroom and reckless display of a firearm. The bailiff provided the only security for that courtroom. Sheriff Allison DeFoor ordered that everyone entering courthouse now be searched or checked with a portable metal detector until permanent security measures can be installed. Dowmond was to be taken to a hospital for treatment of his hand, Ms. Herrin said.

DOC.HEAD: Pa. Governor Faces Abortion Rights Challenge as 3 States Hold Primaries
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Polls close at 8 p.m. EDT in Pennsylvania; 9 in Nebraska and 11 in Oregon; Matter below the dash will stand.
DOC.TEXT: Pennsylvania Gov. Robert P. Casey faced a long-shot primary challenge Tuesday from a Democrat who attacked his opposition to abortion. In Nebraska, seven Democrats competed for a chance to run against Republican Gov. Kay Orr. Oregon Attorney General Dave Frohnmayer was a strong favorite to defeat six rivals for the GOP nomination to replace Democratic Gov. Neil Goldschmidt, who declined to seek a second term. Secretary of State Barbara Roberts was unopposed on the Democratic side. In U.S. Senate races, Oregon Sen. Mark Hatfield's bid for a fifth term drew one minor challenge within the GOP. In a six-candidate Democratic field, businessman Harry Lonsdale, who criticized Hatfield's anti-abortion views, was considered the likely victor. Two-term Democratic Sen. James Exon of Nebraska had no primary opposition, and former Republican Rep. Hal Daub was favored to win the nomination to challenge him. Casey, who signed a tough anti-abortion law in November, was challenged by pro-choice lawyer Philip S. Berg. On the Republican side, pro-choice Auditor General Barbara Hafer was challenged by abortion foe Marguerite ``Peg'' Luksik of Johnstown. Hafer had the state GOP endorsement. The abortion issue also dominated Pennsylvania's Democratic lieutenant governor's race. Former state party chairman Edward Mezvinsky launched a late pro-choice challenge to incumbent Mark S. Singel, who opposes abortion. In western Pennsylvania, Democratic U.S. Reps. John Murtha, Austin Murphy and Joseph Kolter all faced primary battles. Murtha was criticized for supporting congressional pay hikes; Murphy for having a son outside his marriage. Kolter was challenged by former Rep. Frank Clark, who said the incumbent wasn't doing enough for his district's economy. Mrs. Orr, who four years ago became the first Republican woman elected governor of any state, has suffered in popularity polls since Nebraska increased taxes. She was challenged in a primary by Omaha businessman Mort Sullivan. The Democratic race shaped up as a four-way scramble among Mike Boyle, former mayor of Omaha; Lincoln Mayor Bill Harris; Omaha lawyer Ben Nelson, and Bill Hoppner, a former aide to Sens. Exon and Bob Kerrey. Hoppner received a late boost when Kerrey disclosed he had cast his absentee ballot for him. Previously, Kerrey had said he would remain neutral. In the college community of Eugene, Ore., voters decided whether to amend the city charter to guarantee the city's status as a nuclear free zone where manufacture of nuclear weapons and their components is prohibited.

Pennsylvania provided a twist to conventional political wisdom on the abortion issue. Nationally, the Democratic Party endorses abortion rights and the GOP platform seeks to ban abortion. Casey, bidding for a second term, asked voters to look beyond abortion to his administration's efforts to clean up the environment, tackle drugs, boost economic development and increase aid to education. Nebraska Democrats are optimistic about their chances against Mrs. Orr, who drew only a 39 percent approval rating in a recent Omaha World-Herald poll. ``It's a targeted race for us,'' said Mark Gearan, executive director of the Democratic Governors Association. ``Kay Orr is one of the most vulnerable incumbent Republican governors. And we have a very good group of opponents.'' Mrs. Orr acknowledged that she has smarted under polls that indicate a flagging job performance rating and said she was eager to get on to the general election campaign. Eugene voters already have approved an ordinance calling for a nuclear free zone, but proponents of the charter amendment said it was needed to force the city council to accept the will of the people. Opponents said the ordinance has stifled economic growth. Citing the pending ballot measure, Rohr Industries earlier this year decided to build a $15 million factory for jet engine parts in San Marcos, Texas, rather than Eugene. With it went 250 jobs.

DOC.HEAD: Defendant in Landmark Supreme Court Ruling Back in Jail
DOC.TEXT: The defendant in a landmark 1968 Supreme Court case that led to police being allowed to stop and frisk some suspects has been arrested on a charge of breaking into a pharmacy. John Wesley Terry, 43, of Charleston, was arrested May 7 and was being held in the Wayne County Jail on $25,000 bond. In 1968, the U.S. Supreme Court in Terry vs. Ohio established the right of police officers to stop and frisk people they believe are armed and dangerous. ``In law enforcement circles he's a real celebrity,'' said Wayne County Deputy Sheriff Mark Bradshaw. ``Whether he knows it or not, he has helped us a lot.'' The 1968 case came after Terry and some other men were stopped by an officer who suspected they were planning a robbery. The Supreme Court decision upheld Terry's conviction on a charge of carrying a concealed weapon.

DOC.HEAD: New Kansas City Newspaper Hits the Streets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 3rd graf, `I'm thrilled...', to UPDATE with first-day sales total. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `Media analysts...'.
DOC.TEXT: The sole investor in Kansas City's new afternoon newspaper says he hopes to buck a national trend and attract enough readers for a profit. Analysts say that's going to be tough. The first edition of The Kansas City Evening News rolled off the press Monday. ``I'm thrilled. It looks really good,'' said Steve Rose, president of a family-owned chain of 18 suburban weekly papers and owner of the new 50-cent tabloid. Rose said the paper sold about 22,800 copies Monday and planned to print about 30,000 copies today. Media analysts contend the newspaper will face tough times, especially with advertising revenues going through what one called ``the worst cycle I've seen in years.'' Rose said he can make a profit through low costs, small circulation and street sales. The newspaper will not be delivered to homes. He said he's not trying to compete directly with The Kansas City Star, a morning paper with daily circulation of 297,000. Rose said he got the idea for a newspaper in March, when the Kansas City Star Co. stopped publishing an afternoon edition and merged it with the morning newspaper after years of declining afternoon circulation. ``I don't want and I don't need 50,000 to 100,000 readers,'' Rose said. ``If we start down that path, suddenly all the economies change. That's exactly where Ralph Ingersoll ended up.'' Ingersoll started the tabloid St. Louis Sun to compete with The St. Louis Post-Dispatch for morning readers, but the Sun shut down last month after only seven months. Ingersoll cited home-delivery costs and inadequate street sales. Rose's newspaper, unlike the much larger St. Louis Sun, has an editorial staff of four. It will consist mostly of news from wire services. The Monday-through-Friday paper shares a press, building and other equipment with Rose's weeklies. Startup costs have been under $1 million, he said. Ken Berents, an analyst for Alex Brown & Sons Inc. in New York, said starting a new newspaper in a town with a monopoly newspaper like Kansas City is ``running uphill'' with ankle weights on.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Upholds Injunction on Anti-Abortion Protests
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 6th graf pvs, However in ... to UPDATE with five arrested
DOC.TEXT: The anti-abortion group Operation Rescue spent more than $50,000 for November demonstrations that kept women out of Washington-area clinics in violation of a court order, a federal judge was told today. Attorney Larry Eisenstein, who represents the National Organization for Women and Planned Parenthood, said Operation Rescue and its leaders should be found in contempt of a Nov. 8 order that prohibited blockades of abortion clinics. He asked that they be fined ``a large enough figure to deter them from returning in the future.'' Police arrested more than 700 protesters during a Nov. 17 demonstration on charges that they violated a new District of Columbia law. Today's hearing in U.S. District Court came one day after the Supreme Court, by a vote of 5-4, turned down Operation Rescue's request for emergency help. The court let stand a Georgia judge's injunction that keeps members of the group at least 50 feet away from any Atlanta facility where abortions are performed. However in Atlanta today, Operation Rescue protesters defied the Supreme Court decision and entered an abortion clinic. Police said five persons were arrested after they entered the Atlanta Surgi-Center and chained themselves together. There are similar legal challenges to Operation Rescue demonstrations at abortion clinics in other states. At today's hearing before U.S. District Judge Louis F. Oberdorfer, Eisenstein showed videotapes of three November demonstrations in an effort to prove that Operation Rescue, Project Rescue and their leaders violated Oberdorfer's injunction. NOW and Planned Parenthood name five individuals as defendants along with the two organizations. Only one, Clifford Gannett, was in court today. Eisenstein said he would present witnesses to show that Gannett was active in the blockades Nov. 11 and Nov. 17 at the Hillcress Women's Surgi-Center and the Washington Surgi Clinic in violation of the order. Eisenstein also said he would show that Organization Rescue, which says it is in debt, spent ``well in excess of $50,000 and maybe well more than $100,000'' on the November operations He said that 1989 donations to the two organizations exceeded $700,000 and that they deposited more than $1.1 million in bank accounts. The high court Monday rejected an emergency request by Operation Rescue members who said the Atlanta injunctin is violating their free-speech rights. Operation Rescue spokesman Bob Jewitt called Monday's action ``a little stumble along the way,'' adding, ``We feel we'll be victorious in the long run.'' Lynne Randall, who operates an Atlanta clinic that has been a frequent target of the protests, welcomed the action. ``We have to balance women's right to privacy with people's right to protest,'' she said. Since July 1988, when Atlanta hosted the Democratic National Convention, city police have arrested 1,320 demonstrators at Operation Rescue sit-ins. Many of the protesters barricaded abortion clinics, blocking patients and employees from entering or leaving. Operation Rescue members Michael Hirsch, Gina Robertson, William Haynes, Steve Britt and Pamela Sekulow said in the court appeal that the Atlanta injunction deters them ``from engaging in prayer, picketing, leafleting and other forms of peaceful expression on public forum streets and sidewalks.'' The state judge who issued the injunction is considering a request to modify it, and a formal challenge to the injunction is before the Georgia Supreme Court. Operation Rescue founder Randall Terry, who spent time in jail until a contempt of court fine for violating a similar injunction in New York was paid, called Monday's court action ``an outrage.'' ``Our rights are being denied because we're pro-life Christians. If we were homosexuals, does anyone really think that we would be denied access to a public sidewalk?'' Terry said.

DOC.HEAD: Precede LOS ANGELES
China Backs Out of Fighter Pact with United States
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 8 grafs new with State Department announcement; picks up 4th graf pvs, The Chinese Embassy.
DOC.TEXT: China has canceled a $550 million deal with a U.S. defense contractor to modernize its F-8 fighter jets, the State Department said today. Under the 1986 deal, Grumman Corp. was to equip the planes with sophisticated electronics and navigation and radar equipment. ``The Chinese government has decided not to proceed beyond the development phase at this time,'' said Richard Boucher, the State Dpartment's deputy spokesman. Boucher declined to speculate on the reasons for the decision or the employment impact at Grumman. He said the development phase of the project will be completed this fall. But a U.S. official, who commented on condition he not be identified, said the Chinese apparently were concerned about rising costs and the fact that immediate delivery of the sophisticated gear is barred by the ban on military exports imposed by the United States after the crushing of China's pro-democracy movement. ``We have not made any deliveries and we will not make any until circumstances change,'' Boucher said. ``They made the decision they didn't want to proceed with the production phase,'' Lt. Cmdr. Edward Lundquist, a Pentagon spokesman, told the Los Angeles Times earlier. The Chinese Embassy in Washington would not comment on the decision. However, the Times quoted unidentified defense industry sources as saying the Chinese had expressed concern over cost overruns on the project. Dubbed Peace Pearl, the agreement ranked among the largest of its kind reached between China and the United States in the 1980s. The deal was touted at the time as the basis for strategic cooperation against the Soviet Union. Under Peace Pearl, the Chinese Air Force and Grumman, based in Bethpage, N.Y., were to upgrade 55 planes at $10 million each. But one unidentified industry analyst told the Times the cost overruns could total $200 million. Mariam Reid, a Grumman spokeswoman, referred questions about the deal to the Pentagon. The Bush administration suspended U.S. military sales and deliveries to China last year after the government crushed the pro-democracy movement. The administration also expelled 40 Chinese officers assigned to the Peace Pearl project at Grumman in Bethpage and at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base near Dayton, Ohio. But it allowed long-term military programs such as Peace Pearl to continue, and eventually allowed the Chinese officers to return to the United States. The arms modernization pact was signed in 1986 after then-Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger offered the idea during a 1983 trip to Beijing.

DOC.HEAD: Widow Settles Biographer's Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: The widow of singer Harry Chapin has settled for $65,000 a lawsuit in which a writer accused her of interfering with publication of a biography of Chapin. Sandy Chapin's lawyer, Tony Curto, who had maintained in court that there was no interference with the book, described the agreement Monday as settlement of a nuisance. The writer, Peter Coan, sued the Chapin estate for $9 million in 1984, alleging that the biography he contracted to write for Pedigree Books three years earlier was suppressed because the estate threatened legal action. The book was published in 1987 by Ashley Books of Long Island. Coan said he accepted the settlement because pursuing the case would have cost much more in time and money. Chapin was killed in a car crash on the Long Island Expressway in 1981. His widow lives in Huntington Bay.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Will Visit Minnesota, California After US Summit
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 5 grafs White House announcement; picks up 3rd graf pvs, ``It's almost ...
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will turn into a tourist after summit talks with President Bush, hopscotching to Minnesota and California from Washington early next month, the White House announced today. Gorbachev's destinations are Minneapolis and San Francisco, White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said. He said the Soviet leader would arrive in Washington on the evening of May 30, meet with Bush at the White House on May 31 and June 1 and then accompany Bush to the presidential retreat at Camp David on June 2 for informal talks. The two leaders will meet again on June 3 at the White House for a morning news conference, and then Gorbachev will set out on his tour. Gorbachev will spend about about six hours in Minnesota, visiting with business and agricultural leaders, and then head for San Francisco. ``It's almost: 3rd graf

DOC.HEAD: As Talks Open, Think Tank Says What's Missing Is Leadership
With AM-Budget Talks Bjt
DOC.TEXT: As White House deficit negotiations got under way Tuesday, a Brookings Institution report disputed President Bush's inaugural speech assertion that the nation has ``more will than wallet.'' What's lacking, it said, is not wealth but leadership. ``The question is not whether America has enough wallet, but whether it has the will to use its abundant wealth to solve the problems that it faces,'' wrote Henry Aaron, a senior economist with the liberal research organization. The country has plenty of wealth, the report said. ``The United States is a nation blessed with the highest per capita income. Its national product is 2{ times larger than that of the second-largest economy,'' the report said. ``It is enjoying its longest peacetime expansion.'' Facing no military threat or economic crisis, the United States ``can muddle through without absolute decline,'' Aaron said. ``Yet Americans cannot escape the reality that decisions taken during this decade will determine whether the chronicle of growth at home and influence abroad continues or flags,'' he said. The report, ``Setting National Priorities'' by nine Brookings researchers, is intended to take a ``centrist'' stance toward problems on the budget, foreign policy, defense, trade, global warming, education, health care and political paralysis. It was a coincidence that the book-size report came out the day talks were opening between Bush and congressional leaders on ways to take as much as $100 billion out of the projected deficit. Bush, who said on inauguration day that the United States cannot solve all the world's problems because ``we have more will than wallet,'' has consistently opposed a tax increase to reduce the deficit. But a tax increase could emerge from the budget talks even though both parties have shied away from advocating one. The talks are expected to last for weeks and could drag on throughout the summer. Writing about the political impasse that has made deficit reduction difficult, political scientist Thomas E. Mann said, ``The most striking and unsettling feature of American politics ... is the stark contrast betweeen the extraordinary pace and scope of change occurring outside the country and the political immobilism within.'' Mann said Bush was unlikely to adopt daring solutions to the nation's economic problems and was almost sure to prefer to stick with a political strategy that, barring a deep recession, ``is very likely to lead to his re-election in 1992.'' But, Mann argued, by accepting ``a modest increase in taxes weighted toward those high-income households that reaped most of the economic benefits of the 1980s,'' the president could help the country and enhance his own re-election prospects. Such a course, he said, would ``eliminate the deficit, lower interest rates, increase investment, fuel economic growth and, not incidentally, neutralize efforts by the Democrats to mount a populist critique of the GOP.'' ``These presidential initiatives could break the policy logjam, help the country begin to deal with its long-term challenges and put the Republican Party in a position to increase its strength at all levels of elective office,'' he said. He said, however, that it was doubtful that either party would adopt unconventional strategies to deal with the nation's problems. Aaron labled the problem ``a psychosis of poverty and helplessness.'' He blamed it on ``an extended consumption binge'' arising from the country's refusal to save more and to cut both personal and government spending or to tax itself enough to scale down the deficit. ``Depressed saving slows growth of worker productivity,'' he said. ``It is conventional wisdom that because of the deficit the United States cannot afford to solve serious problems of health care, education and infrastructure. ``In fact, failure to attack these problems and the deficit simultaneously stems from a deeper common source: American leaders have been unwilling or unable to try to persuade the people of the need to cut spending, to raise taxes or to take other controversial actions.'' In a proposal to convert the deficit into a modest surplus by 1995, economist Charles L. Schultze raised the possibility of cutting or taxing Social Security benefits; raising taxes by 1 percent of the national income; cutting spending on such ``middle class subsidies'' as the farm program, school lunches for middle class children, disability compensation to veterans with low disability ratings; and subsidies for merchant vessels He also raised the possibility of imposing user fees for grazing on federal lands and raising interest rates for rural electrification loans. ``That the nation can muddle through, sustaining large budget deficits without a cyclical crisis, does not mean that deficits do no harm and can be ignored,'' Schultze wrote. ``A successful economy ought not only to avoid recession and inflation, but also to provide for future growth.''

DOC.HEAD: Commission Recommends Preparation For Military Strikes Against Terrorists
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 5 grafs after 9th graf pvs, Members of, to include White House and victims' families' reaction.
DOC.TEXT: The United States should consider military strikes against air terrorists and conduct covert operations if direct action is not possible, a presidential commission investigating the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 recommended today. The seven-member commission also called for notification of passengers when there is a credible bomb threat. And it recommended major changes in the Federal Aviation Administration's security operations. ``The U.S. civil aviation security system is seriously flawed and has failed to provide the proper level of protection for the traveling public,'' the report said. ``This system needs major reform.'' The report also called for a halt to the FAA's order for widespread installation of sophisticated plastic explosive detection devices, saying the machines likely would not have detected the bomb that blew up Flight 103. The commission called the FAA an agency that simply reacts to disasters and doesn't do enough to prevent them. The seven-member panel headed by former Labor Secretary Ann McLaughlin spent nine months investigating the Dec. 21, 1988, bombing, which killed all 259 people aboard the jetliner and 11 people on the ground in Lockerbie, Scotland. The panel's budget was $1 million. Despite the commission's sharp criticism of government efforts, FAA Administrator James Busey said he welcomed the report. Busey said an FAA group would meet with the independent commission's staff to ``implement those recommendations that meet the FAA's one essential criterion: to help eradicate airline terrorism.'' ``The commission's recommendations are a welcome contribution to our efforts of the last year to enhance aviation security and to attack the global threat of terrorism in our skies,'' Busey said. Members of the commission, which included four members of Congress and two former military figures, handed a copy of the report to President Bush and victims' family members this morning. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said, ``We certainly agree that we need to be as aggressive as necessary to fight terrorism.'' But he declined comment on the report's specific recommendations. Bush told the commissioners they had done ``an excellent job,'' Fitzwater said. ``The president said we'll take it and get right to work on the problems.'' Paul Hudson, whose 16-year-old daughter Melina died on the flight, said the report appears to validate and document the belief of victims' relatives that ``flawed aviation policies and procedures... permitted the Pan Am 103 bombing to kill our loved ones in the worst terrorist attack in U.S. history.'' Victoria Cummock, whose husband John died in the bombing, called the report ``a very good first step.'' ``The philosophy of aviation security has got to change. It's got to take hearings, legislation and action,'' she said. ``The destruction of Flight 103 may well have been preventable,'' the report said. But it said ``it is impossible to say whether the failure of any specific security procedure was directly related to the sabotage of the flight.'' ``The United States should pursue a more vigorous counterterrorism policy, particularly with respect to nations sponsoring terrorists,'' the report said. The commission recommended planning, training and equipping the military for ``direct, preemptive or retaliatory military actions against known terrorist hideouts in countries that sanction them.'' It also called for public support of actions to punish terrorists. ``National will _ and the moral courage to use it _ is the ultimate means to defeat terrorism,'' the report said. Commission members gave Bush a private briefing on the report two hours before the president met with families of those killed in the bombing. Among other key recommendations in the 182-page report: _Congress should create the office of assistant transportation secretary for security and intelligence. _The federal government should directly manage security at domestic airports and conduct a study to assess the safety of U.S. airports from terrorists. _The State Department, rather than airlines, should conduct negotiations with foreign governments to meet security standards at airports used by U.S. carriers. _Victims of terrorist attacks aimed against the United States government should qualify for special financial compensation. _The State Department should take steps to ensure that family members of victims are given ``prompt, humane and courteous treatment and services in overseas disasters.'' Rep. John Paul Hammerschmidt, R-Ark., a commission member, said ``a lot of improvements have already been made (in airport safety) just because the Pan Am 103 incident was so dismaying and shocking.'' But he added: ``We were a little dismayed in the way FAA had handled security back then. Let me emphasize that isn't true right now, I think, just because of what's happened since Pan Am 103.'' Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., also on the commission, said despite recent improvements there is still ``a great vulnerability'' to terrorism in the aviation industry. ``Terrorism is a new kind of warfare ... that we're going to have to be prepared to deal with,'' D'Amato said. The commission held five public hearings in Washington and traveled to Europe for interviews with aviation and airline officials in France, West Germany and Britain. Flight 103 originated in Frankfurt and switched to a different airliner in London before leaving for New York.

DOC.HEAD: NBC Reshuffles Slumping `Today' Show, Brings Joe Garagiola Back as Co-Host
DOC.TEXT: In a surprise move aimed to revived its slumping ``Today'' show, NBC said today that Joe Garagiola, a familiar face from the show's past, would join Bryant Gumbel and Deborah Norville as a co-host. NBC also hired Faith Daniels, co-anchor of the ``CBS Morning News'' and news segments of ``CBS This Morning,'' to anchor ``NBC News at Sunrise'' and the news segments of ``Today.'' Garagiola was a host of the show from 1969 to 1973. He will return to the show in June. The network also announced that Dick Ebersol, who played a leading part in changes that preceded the ``Today'' drop into second place, is giving up his job as senior vice president in charge of ``Today.'' He will stay as president of NBC Sports, the network said. Ebersol came into the turbulent ``Today'' picture last year, and is widely held responsible for the controversial shift in which Norville succeeded 13-year veteran Jane Pauley as the show's host in January. Since then, the once-dominant program has run second in ratings to ABC's ``Good Morning America.'' The new shifts come just three weeks before NBC executives are to face the network's affiliates at NBC's annual convention in Washington, where NBC News president Michael Gartner likely will hear complaints. ``It is no secret that in recent months `Today' has been through some trouubled times,'' Gartner said in a statement today. He said the latest moves were designed ``to expand the cast and build on the strengths of the program.'' The network also said that correspondent Katie Couric will become a full-time correspondent for ``Today'' in Washington, D.C.

DOC.HEAD: Two Killed at Dormitory Shooting at Montana State
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Boyer identified...', to CORRECT spelling of Boeder sted Boder, CORRECT home state to Minnesota sted New York, add hometown, other detail.
DOC.TEXT: UPDATES thoughout with suspect, victims identified, still no word on motive. No pickup.

A Montana State University student armed with a shotgun killed two other students early this morning at an MSU dormitory, authorities said. Brett D. Byers, 19, was charged with two counts of deliberate homicide, felony criminal mischief and reckless driving after he was arrested in East Helena following a high-speed chase. Bozeman Police Chief Dick Boyer said officers were called to Langford Hall on the MSU campus at 2:20 a.m., where they found two students who had been shot more than once. The victims died later at Bozeman Deaconess Hospital, he said. Boyer identified the victims as freshmen James Clevinger, 19, of Billings, and Brian Boeder, 19, of Plymouth, Minn. The shootings occurred in Boeder's room, he added. Authorities did not immediately release any information on a possible motive. MSU spokesman Allan Smart confirmed that Byers and the victims were all students at the university, which has an enrollment of about 11,000. Byers, who turned 19 last Friday, said nothing as Justice of the Peace Wallace Jewell read the charges. The frail teen-ager, handcuffed and wearing gray jail coveralls, was later transported to Bozeman by officers from the Gallatin County sheriff's office and Bozeman Police Department. A witness identified Byers in the hallway after the shooting, said Lewis and Clark County Attorney Mike McGrath. Bozeman police alerted authorities in Helena, 90 miles to the northwest, to watch for Byers' pickup truck. McGrath said authorities surmised Byers might be heading for Great Falls, his hometown, and would drive through Helena. The truck was spotted by a Lewis and Clark County deputy sheriff at 4:50 a.m. on U.S. Highway 12 near East Helena, Sheriff Chuck O'Reilly said. A high-speed chase followed, and the suspect was arrested after he crashed through a highway fence and into a gas pump and two power poles at a Circle K store parking lot, the sheriff said. ``We'd requested assistance from the Helena police; he probably saw them coming, turned off the highway and went through the fence,'' O'Reilly said. Byers suffered only minor injuries, and was treated at a Helena hospital before being taken to court, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: `My Country is Bankrupt,' Chamorro Cables Bush
DOC.NOTE: EDs: UPDATES throughout with administration considering short-term loan; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said today it is considering a short-term loan to Nicaragua following an urgent plea from President Violeta Chamorro, who declared, ``My country is bankrupt.'' Mrs. Chamorro, in a letter to Bush, asked for a $40 million short-term loan because Congress has not yet acted on a $300 million aid package that Bush is seeking for Nicaragua. ``We are looking into possibilities of doing something along the lines of what she requests,'' White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said. ``If we can't get something fairly quickly, we are taking a look to see if there are some kind of loans or something that can help her out in the short term,'' he said. House Speaker Thomas Foley says he wants to bring the aid package to a floor vote this week. Mrs. Chamorro said the loan money was needed ``to avoid a critical situation that may be looming in the very near future.'' A copy of the cable was obtained today. Her request came as food supplies for thousands of Nicaraguan rebels based at demobilization camps are expected to be exhausted by the end of the week. U.S. officials are concerned that the peace process in that country may unravel. The Bush administration has been sharply critical of Congress for its delay on the aid package, which also includes another $420 million for Panama. ``My country is bankrupt,'' Mrs. Chamorro told Bush. She said that the Sandinista party of former president Daniel Ortega ``is taking advantage of the situation to create instability.'' ``Today we face a general strike of the public sector. But we are determined to struggle on,'' she told Bush in the cable, dated May 11. She said that Nicaragua's reserves ``are insufficient to fulfill our obligations coming due in the next 30 days.'' She also cited a 70 percent per month inflation rate. The State Department considers the food issue to be crucial because, once food deliveries to the camps end, the Contra rebels will be forced to look elsewhere for their needs, raising the possibility of armed encounters with Sandinista soldiers. At present, the rebels are stationed in ``security zones'' which are off limits to the Sandinista army. The zones were established as part of an agreement reached among the contending Nicaraguan factions after the election of U.S.-backed President Violeta Chamorro in February. The U.S. role in the process is to ensure a continuing supply of food to the camps as well as additional assistance to enable the Contras to disarm and return to their homes. But Congress has yet to approve an aid package that includes $30 million for these purposes. Officials of the Organization of American States officials who are overseeing the process told the Bush administration on Monday that only five days' supply of food remains, said U.S. officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Bush telephoned Foley, D-Wash., on Monday to relay his concern over the situation after receiving a message from Mrs. Chamorro in which she outlined what she described as a deteriorating situation, the officials said. ``Food must be ordered immediately to prevent a gap in food supplies,'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said. ``If the Nicaraguan resistance must provide their own food, its members might have to leave the security zones, risking fighting with the Sandinista Army. This could mean the unraveling of the demobilization process.'' The aid bill before Congress has become bogged down by scores of amendments, including one relating to federal funding for abortions in Washington, D.C. ``The economic aid package ... contains the necessary funds to feed the Nicaraguan resistance. It is urgent that Congress pass this package quickly if the achievements of the bipartisan accord and the Nicaraguan election are to be preserved,'' Ms. Tutwiler said.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Forces Duel with Shells
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces ignored a cease-fire call by the church and dueled with shells Tuesday as Moslem factions fought street battles in west Beirut. Police said 24 people were killed and 61 wounded. In Christian east Beirut and the surrounding countryside, the battle between Gen. Michel Aoun's troops and Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces raged without letup for a seventh straight day, leaving 18 dead and 46 wounded, police said. The clashes brought the casualty toll to 1,022 dead and 2,730 wounded since the battle for control of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave broke out Jan. 30. Police said six people were killed and 15 wounded in gunbattles between the pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem Hezbollah, or Party of God, and the Syrian-backed Amal militia in and around west Beirut's old Jewish district of Wadi Abu Jamil. Police said bearded Hezbollah fighters, attempting to expel Amal militiamen from Wadi Abu Jamil, tossed grenades and fired 106mm recoilless guns mounted on jeeps. Amal gunmen thwarted the attacks. The hostilities, which began at midnight, stopped at midmorning when Syrian troops deployed in Wadi Abu Jamil separated the combatants. The area was abandoned long ago by its original Jewish inhabitants. Shopowners removed glass shards and shattered shutters from narrow alleyways under the watchful eyes of helmeted Syrian troops toting automatic rifles and shoulder-fired rocket launchers. Dozens of wrecked cars smoldered amid heaps of blackened fruits and vegetables. ``Go ahead and take pictures,'' cried a veiled woman as photographers reached the scene. ``Show the world how brutal our men are.'' The Moslem factions have been fighting each other intermittently since May 1987 for control of Lebanon's 1 million Shiites, the country's largest sect. The latest casualties brought the toll to 1,041 killed and 3,076 wounded in three years. In the Christian sector, fires blazed out of control in apartment buildings in residential neighborhoods in east Beirut, and in villages in the highlands of Kesrouan and pinewoods of the Metn mountains northeast of the capital. The hostilities kept all roads blocked for a seventh straight day between the Aoun-controlled Metn mountains and the rest of the enclave under the authority of Geagea's militiamen, tightening the noose on thousands of already trapped residents. Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir, spiritual head of the Maronite Catholic sect, issued a cease-fire appeal before midnight, urging Aoun's troops and Geagea's militiamen to disobey their commanders and lay down arms. But the bombardment continued past noon Tuesday before it dwindled into sporadic exchanges of machine gunfire. ``They simply opted to disobey the patriarch, not the commanders,'' said a police spokesman, who cannot be named under standing rules. ``It seems they can't stop fighting.'' Both Aoun, 54, a U.S.-trained artillery officer, and Geagea, 38, a former medical student, are Maronites, the community that dominated power since Lebanon gained independence from France in 1943. Aoun's 19,000 army troops have failed to overpower Geagea's 6,000 street fighters, hardened by 15 years of civil war. Geagea, whose forces control two thirds of the Christian enclave, promised in a statement broadcast by his Voice of Free Lebanon radio station to oust Aoun within four or five weeks. Marlene Kenaan, a 27-year-old unmarried secretary, said from her home in the mountain resort town of Brummana Tuesday that she spent the night with her parents in the underground wine cellar. ``We felt the door of hell has been flung open and we were roasting under merciless bombardment,'' Ms. Kenaan said. ``Wine bottles danced all night and we kept drinking them to shore up our spirits,'' she quipped.

DOC.HEAD: Study of Home Movies Finds Possible Warning Signs of Schizophrenia
DOC.TEXT: Psychiatrists and psychologists who viewed old home movies usually were able to identify children who would be diagnosed with schizophreia as adults, a researcher says. The study supports the view that the disease follows an early brain abnormality, said psychology professor Elaine Walker of Emory University in Atlanta. ``There may be early subtle signs of vulnerability to schizophrenia,'' Walker said Monday. The project involved home movies that portrayed five infants and children up to age 5 who were later diagnosed with schizophrenia as young adults. Thirteen psychologists and psychiatrists were shown the films, which also included at least one sibling. The mental health professionals were asked to guess which one later was diagnosed as schizophrenic. Their performance was much better than one would expect by chance, which suggests they were able to spot clues, Walker said. The observers said the signs included delayed development of motor skills, awkwardness, and unexpected emotional responses shown in the face. Now, researchers plan to analyze the movies with objective measures of motor development and facial expression to see if those factors tend to identify pre-schizophrenic children, Walker said. Walker presented her results at the annual meeting of the American Psychiatric Association. The study has been accepted for publication in a scientific journal, she said. The clues the raters spotted were ``amazingly predictive,'' Dr. Stephen Oxley of Duke University in Durham, N.C., said after Walker's presentation. While the results are very preliminary, they suggest there may be ways to spot children at risk for developing the disease, he said. Other research also has pointed to possible early brain disturbances in schizophrenia, he said. If children at risk can be spotted early, perhaps steps can be taken to prevent the disease, he said. Further research also might give clues about what part of the brain is involved, which might guide research into treatment, he said. Schizophrenia is marked by a loss of touch with reality, called psychosis, and hallucinations, delusions, disordered thinking and inappropriate emotions.

DOC.HEAD: Sikh Militants Kill 7 Hindus, 4 Others in Punjab
DOC.TEXT: Sikh militants impersonating government security troops shot and killed seven Hindus after luring them out of their homes in the northern state of Punjab, police said Tuesday. The killings occurred late Monday in Darrowali, 42 miles north of the Sikh holy city of Amritsar. Local police chief Jagdish Kumar said five armed Sikhs wearing uniforms of the paramilitary police arrived in the village and told residents they had come to protect Hindus from Sikh terrorists. ``They asked Hindu residents to assemble in the village square and later told them they should go out of the village and hide as there was a report of an imminent attack,'' Kumar said. Nine Hindu men left. The militants followed the nine, overpowered them and tied them up, Kumar said. The gunmen then shot eight of them at close range, Kumar said. One man survived the shooting and another escaped, he said. In three other attacks across the northern farming state, Sikh militants shot and killed four people, United News of India reported. Their identities were not immediately known. The latest killings brought the deaths blamed on the militants in the state this year to 814. Sikh militants are campaigning for an independent nation they want to call ``Khalistan,'' or ``land of the pure'' in the Punjabi language. The militants claim that Hindus, the country's religious majority, discriminate against Sikhs, who make up 2 percent of India's 880 million people. Hindus form 82 percent of India's population, but Sikhs have a slight majority in Punjab.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Grounds H-46s
DOC.TEXT: The Navy has grounded its fleet of H-46 Sea Knight helicopters to correct a problem in the rear transmission of the twin-rotor chopper, the Pentagon said Tuesday. The decision to ground the fleet was made after an investigation of a H-46 accident earlier this month, said spokesman Pete Williams. Seventeen Marines were injured at the Marine Air-Ground training center at Twenty-Nine Palms, Calif., when their chopper made a rough landing during an air-assault exercise. Williams said the Navy had found a problem that could lead to a loss of drive in the rear rotor system. The Navy is trying to devise ways for the choppers to be repaired in field units rather than returning them to maintenance depots, Williams said. There are 342 choppers in the fleet, with 261 assigned to the Marine Corps and 81 to the Navy. Sea Knight choppers have a crew of three and have been used since the Vietnam War. The 84-foot long helicopters built by Boeing Vertol and have been out of production since 1971. There are various versions of the aircraft. The UH-46 and CH-46 are used by the Navy, while the Marines use the CH-46 version. The HH-46 is used by both services as a search and rescue aircraft.

DOC.HEAD: de Klerk Visit To Precede Mandela's, ANC Leaders Angered
DOC.TEXT: South African President F.W. de Klerk will pay a historic visit to the White House in June, officials said Tuesday. Black leaders called the de Klerk invitation ``a slap on the face'' to Nelson Mandela, who will call on President Bush a week later. U.S. officials said de Klerk will visit the White House on June 18, the first official visit by a South African president in more than 30 years. But White House and State Department spokesmen declined to confirm the dates. Bush invited the two men as soon as de Klerk freed Mandela, leader of the African National Congress, last February after 27 years in prison. The invitations were designed to boost a process, begun in talks earlier this month between De Klerk and Mandela, to grant political rights to South Africa's disenfranchised black majority. U.S. officials said the decision to have de Klerk's visit before Mandela's was dictated by the two men's schedules and not a preference for either leader. But the ANC, which represents many of South Africa's 28 million blacks, said the administration's decision to invite de Klerk for a visit, especially prior to Mandela's, was an insult. ``It is a slap on the face,'' said Mendi Msimang, the ANC representative to Britain who participated in a news conference announcing details of the Mandela visit. ``It is not too late for the administration to take corrective measures.'' The ANC said it had not been formally apprised by the administration of the de Klerk visit. ANC officials said that despite Mandela's release from jail and the legalization of their organization, blacks are still jailed and denied basic political rights by de Klerk's white government. They noted that de Klerk, who took office last year, still opposes giving an equal vote to all blacks and wants to maintain veto powers by the country's 5 million whites. A coalition of anti-apartheid threatened to organize protests around the United States unless the de Klerk visit is cancelled. The ANC announced Mandela would arrive on June 20 in New York City, where he will be recognized with a ticker tape parade and possibly address the United Nations General Assembly. He will travel to Washington on June 24 for two days. At the invitation of labor groups, predominantly black colleges and civic leaders, he probably also will stop in Boston, Atlanta, Miami, Detroit and Los Angeles. Mandela will thank those groups for their support during his incarceration and for the pressure they exerted on Congress and the business community to impose economic sanctions against the South African government since 1986. But Mandela will also appeal to Americans ``to maintain the sanctions and intensify the sanctions,'' said Tebogo Mafole, the ANC representative at the United Nations. He urged those who would reward de Klerk for his recent gestures to keep in mind that they were brought about through pressure. ``Yes, there have been some steps. However, they fall far short'' of political equality for blacks, he said. Mandela is also expected to ask Americans for money to help the ANC bring its members back from their enforced exile and to build up the organization in South Africa now that it is legal again. Mandela has asked the international community for $20 million.

DOC.HEAD: Grounded Rocket's Next Mission Scheduled for Summer
DOC.TEXT: Europe's Ariane rocket, grounded since a failed launch in February, is expected to make its next mission this summer, a senior aerospace official said Tuesday. Launches might be resumed by the end of July or beginning of August, said Frederic d'Allest, president of Arianespace which commercializes the rocket. The 37th mission would propel into orbit two telecommunications satellites, one French and one German, D'Allest said at the International Air Show in Hanover, West Germany. His remarks were made available in Paris. The 36th mission exploded shortly after liftoff Feb. 22. D'Allest reiterated that the problem was due to ``mishandling'' of the rocket's first stage, which most likely occurred before it was shipped to the launch site in French Guiana. A board of inquiry concluded in April that the first-stage engine's water supply line was blocked by a rag.

DOC.HEAD: Typical First-Time Home Buyer Still Short of Needed Income
DOC.TEXT: The typical first-time home buyer had just 73 percent of the income needed to purchase a typical starter home in the first quarter of 1990, the National Association of Realtors said Tuesday. ``Increasing home prices, tapped-out savings accounts and mortgage rates above the 10 percent mark put the squeeze on housing affordability'' for first-time buyers, the Realtors said Their first-time home buyer affordability index for the first quarter was down from 74.3 in the last three months of 1989. The index was 75.2 after the first three months of last year. The Realtors' composite index, which measures housing affordability of all buyers, stood at 104.4 in the January-March period. That was down from 105.7 in the fourth quarter and 106.5 in the third. The median income of ``prime first-time home buyers'' _ renter families with wage earners aged between 25 and 44 _ was $23,123 during the first quarter. That was $8,532 less than the $31,655 needed to qualify for conventional financing covering 90 percent of a median-priced starter home costing $81,500, the Realtors said. The median means half of the buyers had greater incomes and half less, or that half of the homes cost more and half less. ``A 10 percent down payment on a $81,500 home would amount to $8,150, leaving the typical first-time buyer during the first quarter with monthly mortgage payments of $659,'' the Realtors said. Despite the gap between income and the amount needed to buy a starter home, first-time buyers are finding ways to shift from renting to owning, according to Realtors chief economist John A. Tuccillo. ``Condominiums, alternative mortgage instruments, help from parents with deep pockets and even lease-options and equity-sharing arrangements are among the methods entry-level buyers are employing to make that first home purchase,'' Tuccillo said.

DOC.HEAD: Numerous Sticking Points Hold up Arms Agreements
With AM-Arms Summit Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here, in brief, are the main points of disagreement in arms control negotiations as Secretary of State James A. Baker III begins four days of pre-summit talks in Moscow. _Strategic Arms Reduction Talks: The two sides disagree on range limits for nuclear cruise missiles deployed on aircraft and naval forces. Also, the Americans are resisting a Soviet demand for a legally binding limit on future deployments of sea-launched cruise missiles. Other points of dispute include limits on mobile land-based intercontinental ballistic missiles and anti-cheating measures. _Chemical Weapons: The Soviets are resisting a U.S. plan to retain about 500 tons of poison gas, or about 2 percent of its stockpile, after signing a global ban on the weapons. As a precursor to such a ban, the superpowers are negotiating a bilateral deal to rapidly reduce their stockpiles to 5,000 tons, but the two sides have disagreed over a timetable for carrying out the weapons destruction. _Conventional Forces in Europe: The two main obstacles are defining limits on aircraft and personnel. Work also remains on four other weapon categories: tanks, armored combat vehicles, artillery and helicopters. Anti-cheating provisions are in an early stage of discussion, and the virtual dissolution of the Warsaw Pact has opened new debate about how the treaty would be applied to individual nations. _Open Skies: These NATO-Warsaw Pact negotiations to allow unarmed aircraft of each alliance to fly over the territory of the other are snagged on quotas for such flights and what types of sensors would be allowed on the aircraft. The purpose of the flights would be to reduce suspicions about threatening troop movements. _Nuclear Testing Talks: Highly technical and relatively minor disagreements remain, and settlement is expected in time for signing at the U.S.-Soviet summit that begins May 30. The aim is to set verification measures for two existing but unratified treaties that set limits on the yield of nuclear tests.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Official Says Review Will Likely Have Little Effect on Purchases
DOC.TEXT: A major review of Navy programs will likely have no effect on the Defense Department's planned purchase of an attack submarine and guided-missile destroyer in 1991, a top Pentagon official said Tuesday. Gerald Cann, an assistant secretary of the Navy, told a Senate panel that he doubts the Pentagon will propose a cut in the number of Seawolf SSN-21 submarines or Arleigh Burke DDG-51 destroyers after the review is completed. President Bush's $303 billion military budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 calls for $3.6 billion for five destroyers and other expenses, and $3.5 billion for two submarines and additional costs. ``No, I don't see any changes in 1991 at all,'' Cann said during an appearance before the Senate Appropriations subcommittee on defense. Following a major review of aircraft programs earlier this year, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney proposed reducing the Pentagon's planned purchase of B-2 stealth bombers, C-17 transport planes and other sophisticated aircraft. Cheney's action came in response to the lessening Soviet threat and increasing congressional sentiment for a reduction in defense spending. But Cann, an assistant secretary for research, development and acquistion, said he does not expect the naval review, scheduled to be completed this summer, to produce the same results as the aircraft review. ``I'm personally confident that when we're through with this that both the SSN-21 and the DDG-51 will be validated as proper ships to be built,'' Cann told the panel. The assistant secretary also assured the panel that he is confident the Seawolf will work although half of the funds for the nearly $35 billion program will be appropriated before operational tests have been completed. ``I have relatively high expectations that once we put the Seawolf together ... it will do very well,'' Cann said. Vice Adm. D.L. Cooper, the assistant chief of naval operations for undersea warfare, said a study by the CIA and Defense Intelligence Agency concluded that the submarine in the fleet in 1995 will be superior to the best threat it might face in the year 2005. The intelligence study was completed earlier this year.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Pleads Innocent to New Drug Charges
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry pleaded innocent Tuesday to six additional drug charges alleging that he used cocaine and conspired with others to get it during a five-year period. ``I feel fantastic today. I got a great defense team,'' Barry said outside the courthouse after entering his plea. U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens and Barry lawyer R. Kenneth Mundy said they hoped to begin the trial June 4, but Mundy said the new charges _ part of a superceding 14-count indictment returned against Barry last Thursday _ might make it difficult to meet the original start date. ``We will not be deterred,'' Mundy said after the five-minute hearing. ``We want to show the public and the court that we will not drag our feet. ... It will not be the defense that stalls.'' Stephens said the government was prepared to go to trial as scheduled. ``It is important for the case to be resolved expeditiously and fairly,'' he said at a brief news conference. U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson also said he hoped to start the trial on time. The new charges accuse Barry of five misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession and one misdemeanor count of conspiracy. The indictment alleges that the mayor took drugs as far back as 1984. Barry earlier pleaded innocent to eight charges brought Feb. 15 alleging that he lied to a federal grand jury and had cocaine in his possession on five occasions. The new indictment includes all 14 charges; the three perjury charges are felonies. The new charges add to Barry's legal problems in the face of the Sept. 4 mayoral primary. Barry has not announced that he will seek a fourth term, but he has been making a series of campaign-style appearances around the city. One of the drug-possession counts stems from Barry's arrest Jan. 18 in an FBI undercover sting operation. Prosecutors say that Barry was videotaped smoking crack cocaine in a downtown hotel. Mundy complained at Tuesday's hearing that the government's refusal to turn over a list of witnesses might hamper his trial preparation. The government is not required to disclose the names of witnesses who will testify against a defendant, said Assistant U.S. Attorney Richard Roberts. Roberts said hotel records and job applications had been produced for the defense. He did not elaborate. Judge Jackson said the defense ``is entitled to know who alleged co-conspirators are.'' A hearing on pre-trial motions will be held May 25, Jackson said. Outside the courthouse, Barry urged reporters not to question him about his legal difficulties. ``I'm not going to have anything to say,'' he said. ``I'm going to leave here and go back to the district government. If convicted on all 14 charges, Barry could face a maximum of 26 years in prison and $1.85 million in fines.

DOC.HEAD: Survivors Say Government Massacred Civilians
DOC.TEXT: INSIDE REBEL-HELD LIBERIA (AP) _ Government troops massacred at least 32 people before fleeing advancing rebel troops, according to survivors who showed reporters a pile of 15 bodies. The survivors said Monday that soldiers of President Samuel Doe rounded up people in six villages and shot many before fleeing the rebels April 9. At that time, the soldiers were about 30 miles north of the strategic port of Buchanan, about 60 miles southeast of Monrovia, the capital. The 15 bodies displayed Monday deep inside rebel territory were in a freshly dug grave that had not been filled in because villagers fled to avoid the fighting, the survivors said. They were interviewed in a hospital on the Liberian Agriculture Corp. rubber plantation, an American-owned operation. The survivors said dozens of people were wounded by the government troops. They said they knew of 32 killed and it was likely there were additional dead that had been dumped in the bush. Doe's forces have been accused of slaughtering civilians in an effort to defeat rebels of former civil servant Charles Taylor, whose men invaded Liberia from neighboring Ivory Coast on Dec. 24. International organizations say Doe's troops have killed hundreds of civilians, and the U.S. Congress passed a resolution condemning the president. No comment was immediately available on the survivors' statements. Doe has denied his men have committed atrocities. He said the rebels often do not wear uniforms, making it difficult for soldiers to identify them. International groups say the rebels have killed members of Doe's ethnic Krahn group in apparent reprisals for attacks on members of their ethnic groups. Doe seized power in a bloody coup on April 12, 1980. He initially threatened to kill all the insurgents but later offered them the opportunity to surrender. The U.S. government has called on him to negotiate an end to the fighting. The Liberian president has said he is willing to talk, but not with Taylor himself. Meanwhile, an independent newspaper carried a report Tuesday quoting the British Broadcasting Corp. as saying rebels had taken the mining center of Yekepa in Nimba County in the east. The government had no comment on the report and took no immediate action against the Standard newspaper. Doe has said that journalists who make any false claims about the rebels will themselves be treated as rebels. Workers at the Yekepa iron ore mine, interviewed by the BBC, said government forces fled into neighboring Guinea when the rebels attacked. The mine workers, who also went to Guinea, said the soldiers crossed the border, which is adjacent to the mine, when they ran out of bullets. The port of Buchanan is the outlet for iron for the mine, and it also is near the country's major airport at Robertsfield. Before the government took over the iron ore mine last year from a private company, it had provided 70 percent of the country's foreign exchange earnings. No recent figures are available. Since invading, the rebels have pushed out of Nimba County to the south into River Cess County, to the southwest into Grand Bassa County and to the west into central Bong. Nimba County, the second-largest in population in the West African nation, produced more than 20 percent of the country's food. But more than 80 percent of its 350,000 people have fled to Ivory Coast, Guinea and other parts of Liberia, which was founded by freed American slaves in 1847. The rebels largely control Nimba County, home to the Gio and Mano tribes that are their ethnic base.

DOC.HEAD: Department Seeks Public Comment on New Food Regulations
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department said Tuesday it wants public comment about designing new food safety regulations for some refrigerated meat and poultry products. Products that would be covered by the regulations include ready-to-eat, uncured, perishable meat and poultry packaged in a variety of sealed containers. The labels indicate the food is ``perishable'' or carry instructions to ``keep refrigerated.'' Examples include soups, sauces, pastas, salads and entrees found in refrigerated cases in delicatessens and grocery stores. Frozen foods or those that consist entirely of cured meat or poultry are not included. Lester M. Crawford, administrator of the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service, said consumer demand for fresh convenience foods ``has greatly increased the variety of these products on the market.'' ``These products are perishable and if improperly processed or handled, they may pose unique health risks to consumers,'' he said. ``We are asking for public comments, information, scientific data and recommendations to help determine what additional regulations are necessary to ensure the safety of these products.'' Crawford said the new refrigerated food products differ greatly from traditional meat and poultry. Although processed and packaged to destroy or retard the growth of harmful organisms, they don't receive the thermal heat processing used to kill all bacteria in traditional canned goods. Comments may be sent by July 13 to: Policy Office, Attention Linda Carey, Hearing Clerk, Room 3171-South, Food Safety and Inspection Service, USDA, Washington, D.C. 20250.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Johnny Carson, the king of late night television for 28 years, has signed up for another year. ``I'm still enjoying this after all these years. As long as I'm having fun, I'll continue,'' the 64-year-old Carson said in a statement Tuesday. Carson begins his 29th year as host of NBC's ``The Tonight Show'' on Oct. 1. He'll continue on a Wednesday, Thursday and Friday schedule, said spokesman Charlie Barrett. Financial terms weren't disclosed. During some of Carson's vacation periods, which average 12 weeks a year, guest host Jay Leno will fill in, Barrett said. Carson has remained on top despite challengers to the late-night TV throne over the years, including Alan Thicke, Pat Sajak, Dick Cavett, Merv Griffin, Joey Bishop and Joan Rivers. ``He's remained No. 1 all these years and he averages 12 million viewers a night. That's quite a record,'' said Barrett. Since his debut on Oct. 1, 1962, Carson has led more than 7,000 hours of discussions and introduced more than 20,000 guests to ``Tonight Show'' audiences. In addition to celebrities, Carson has featured bird callers, child spelling champs, tree climbing dogs and a potato chip collector.

The world rights to Nelson Mandela's memoirs have been acquired by Little, Brown and Co., the company said Tuesday. Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress, was released from a South African prison three months ago after nearly 28 years in jail. A week and a half after his release, he met at his home in Soweto with William D. Phillips, vice president and editor in chief of Little, Brown, the company said. Mandela's lawyers, the London firm of Meer, Care and Desai, then negotiated on Mandela's behalf to conclude the agreement. Phillips said in a statement that the book, not yet titled, will be a political memoir about his fight against apartheid and a personal story. It is planned for publication in 1992. ``We don't know how or where this book will end,'' said Phillips. ``This is not a man in retirement.'' The statement did not say how much Mandela would receive for the memoirs.

Jane Pauley will take a shot at the newsmagazine format this summer, but she says she'll have lots of help. ``It's not going to be `The Jane Pauley Show,' '' the former ``Today Show'' host said in the May 19 issue of TV Guide. ``We're going to take advantage of NBC correspondents. I'm not going to be the sole talent.'' The unnamed show will premiere on NBC June 27, with a summer run of five shows. If it becomes a regular series, January 1991 would be the earliest for a regular time slot, she said. NBC anchor Tom Brokaw won't be one of those on the show, Ms. Pauley said. ``Tom pointed out that his plate was pretty full,'' she said. ``So he couldn't make an additional commitment to our show.'' She laughed off rumors that she would join Brokaw on ``The NBC Nightly News'' as co-anchor. ``It doesn't look to me like `Nightly' needs any help,'' she said. ``As far as I'm concerned it's moot _ as delicious as that prospect might sound.''

A used car lot downtown is attracting a lot of attention this week as star-watchers try to get of glimpse of Jessica Lange, Tommy Lee Jones and Powers Boothe. They're in town for the filmming of ``Blue Sky,'' a movie about life on an Army base in 1962. ``Blue Sky'' is the first movie to be filmed in Selma since ``The Heart is a Lonely Hunter,'' the 1968 Alan Arkin film that attracted Academy Award nominations. For the first scenes, former Police Lt. Jim Rutledge rounded up dozens of cars made in 1962 or earlier. They were lined up on a lot that was turned into a used car business just for the film. Crowds gathered, trying to catch a glimpse of Miss Lange. Later, filming will move to Craig Field, a former Air Force base five miles east of Selma. For the movie, it will become ``Fort Mitchell.'' City officials threw a reception for the film crew Saturday night at a restored antebellum mansion.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Striking Workers Paralyze the Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with striking workers paralyzing government; Political confrontation with Sandinistas; Pickup 3rd, `Public school...'
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of striking workers paralyzed the government today and Vice President Virgilio Godoy said the opposition Sandinistas were ``trying to overthrow President Chamorro.'' It was the most serious threat to the 19-day-old government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, who defeated the leftist Sandinistas at the polls Feb. 25. Riot police fired tear gas into the Foreign Ministry building to disperse workers who occupied the building, but state employees retook the premises immediately and pushed out the police. Strikers ignored threats of massive firings from the government. It was just one of several government buildings occupied by strikers. Mrs. Chamorro's whereabouts were not immedidately known. At most buildings, police merely stood outside. There was no sign of any army presence. Telephone, telegraph and telex communications went dead, cutting off Nicaragua from the rest of the world. Workers threatened to cut off electricity to the city in the afternoon, to be followed by the water supply. Both electrical and water ministries were occupied by strikers. An angry mob rushed Foreign Minister Enrique Dreyfus and a group of Nicaraguan ambassadors who were standing in the porch of a restaurant across the ministry parking lot. Police protected them from the mob. The strike was for higher pay, but it became increasingly clear the stoppages were a political confrontation between the government and the Sandinistas. In addition to their economic demands, the strikers issued a new demand that the U.S.-backed Contra rebels immediately demobilize. Tires were set ablaze in front of about six government buildings, while loudspeakers at the gate blared Sandinista revolutionary slogans against Mrs. Chamorro and her government. ``Violetta, start packing your bags!''; ``The people own the government, not the beaugois!'' and ``Not one step back!'' were some of the slogans chanted by strikers at government buildings. Public school teachers and communication workers joined the striking public employees pressing for a 200 wake hike to compensate for skyrocketing inflation, now estimated at 70 percent a month. The government employees, a majority of them Sandinistas put there by the previous leftist government, were also demanding restoration of a public service law that provided them with job security. A commentator on Radio Sandino, the Sandinista party broadcasting station, demanded that Mrs. Chamorro, who took office April 25 for a six-year term, step down. ``She should pack her bags and leave the country,'' the radio said. Vice President Virgilio Godoy accused the Sandinistas of trying to overthrow Mrs. Chamorro's government by encouraging a general strike. The strike broke out last Wednesday when Mrs. Chamorro devalued the currency for the fourth time since taking office and ordered a 60 percent pay raise for government employees. The government workers rejected the raise, saying it was too little. The government declared the strike illegal Monday and threatened to fire those who failed to return to work by today. Presidential spokesman Danilo Lacayo said about 10,000 public workers out of 150,000 nationwide were on strike. Mrs. Chamorro appealed to President Bush for $40 million in emergency aid. ``My country is bankrupt,'' Mrs. Chamorro said in a cable to Bush. She said the Sandinista party of former president Daniel Ortega ``is taking advantage of the situation to create instability.'' Mrs. Chamorro said the emergency funds are needed to tide her country over until Congress enacts a $300 million aid package requested by the administration. She said the money was needed ``to avoid a critical situation that may be looming in the very near future.'' A copy of the cable was obtained today. ``Today we face a general strike of the public sector. But we are determined to struggle on,'' she told Bush in the cable, dated May 11. ``We are looking into possibilities of doing something along the lines of what she requests,'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said today. ``If we can't get something fairly quickly, we are taking a look to see if there are some kind of loans or something that can help her out in the short term.'' The Bush administration also said it would respond to an appeal by Mrs. Chamorro, who described a deteriorating situation in food supplies for thousands of Nicaraguan Contra rebels based at demobilization camps. Sandinista labor union leaders said they are ready to paralyze the country with strikes if government does not back off its threat to dismiss strikers. They said they would shut down telephone service, public transportation, schools and banks today. Attempts to contact Managua today from New York and Mexico City were unsuccessful. ``There will be an escalation of the strikes, and we hope we don't have to paralyze the country, because we have the capacity to do it,'' Lucio Jimenez of the Sandinista Workers Central told reporters Monday. Jimenez said a lawyer was petitioning the Supreme Court asking that the Labor Ministry decree declaring the strikes illegal be revoked. Workers are demanding either a 200 percent raise or a minimum monthly salary equivalent to $150. They also are demanding that a law guaranteeing their rights be reinstated, and that the government guarantee that there will be no retaliation against the strikers. The average wage in Nicaragua is the equivalent of about $30 per month. Unemployed Nicaraguans said they would be glad to take the jobs of the striking public workers. With Nicaragua's high unemployment, it is unlikely the strikers could shut down the system for long. Estimates of the unemployment rate run as high as 45 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Strikes Down Federal Drug Testing Program
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Tuesday declared unconstitutional mandatory drug testing for attorneys applying for jobs in the Justice Department's antitrust division. The ruling by U.S. District Court Judge Gerhard Gesell came in the case of Carl Willner, who filed suit after the Justice Department tentatively accepted him for employment and then asked him to submit to a urine test. Gesell said testing Willner would infringe on the right of any citizen not to be searched without a reasonable basis of suspicion. The antitrust division requirement ``offends the Fourth Amendment,'' Gesell said. The case is the first major federal decision on applicant drug testing involving government agencies, said Arthur Spitzer, an attorney for the American Civil Liberties Union who argued on behalf of Willner. A one-time mandatory pre-employment drug test is required of all attorneys accepted for positions in the Justice Department's Offices, Boards and Divisions component, which includes the antitrust division.
