Gesell pointed out that Willner would not have access to Top Secret classified information and was not a prosecutor in drug cases. The U.S. Court of Appeals has upheld random testing for existing employees in the department in those sensitive positions. But the appeals court has rejected the department's plan to require drug tests for all criminal prosecutors and all employees with access to grand jury materials. The judge said in essence that applicants ought to be treated the same as existing employees. In the Willner case, the Justice Department had argued that the expectation of privacy is less for an applicant than for an existing employee singled out for random testing. The judge enjoined the department from requiring pre-employment drug testing for antitrust division applicants if there are no grounds for suspicion. ``Just as a beautiful sand dune crumbles if continuously eroded by ocean waves, said Gesell, ``so will this essential, precious right become a victim if it is modified at times of stress.'' The judge said applicants who would be exposed to Top Secret information could be tested. Gesell said Willner lacks standing to challenge all pre-employment drug testing for the entire department or for the entire Offices, Boards and Divisions component. In court arguments April 24, Justice Department lawyer Peter Robbins pointed out that the applicant test is a one-time event. ``You don't want somebody enforcing the law turning around and violating the law,'' Robbins said. Gesell's decision would ``cut severely into the government's ability to conduct widespread applicant testing,'' said Spitzer. Spitzer said Willner, now in private practice in Washington, is scheduled to start his Justice Department job in July.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Democrats Compete for Nomination In Governor's Race
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Polls close at 9 p.m. EDT; matter below dash should stand
DOC.TEXT: Seven candidates for the Democratic nomination for governor awaited the verdict of voters Tuesday, and Gov. Kay Orr was virtually assured of the Republican nomination for a second term. The state's first woman governor and the first Republican woman elected to a governorship, Mrs. Orr, 51, faced token opposition from Omaha businessman Mort Sullivan. The four Democratic front-runners were former Omaha Mayor Mike Boyle, 46; Lincoln Mayor Bill Harris, 50; Bill Hoppner, 40, a former aide to Sens. Jim Exon and Bob Kerrey; and Omaha businessman Ben Nelson, 48. Exon, seeking a third term, was unopposed in the Democratic primary. Republican Hal Daub of Omaha, a former congressman, was expected to defeat Otis Glebe, an Omaha landlord, for the GOP nomination.

Recent newspaper polls indicated the Democratic gubernatorial race appeared to be a dead heat. Boyle, who was recalled during his second term as Omaha mayor in 1987 and who lost a comeback bid for that office in 1989, surprised many observers when his low-budget campaign brought him into contention for the nomination. Nelson led the Democratic hopefuls in spending, using television ads to get his name and his message to voters. An attorney and former state insurance director, he was criticized for connections with companies connected to fallen junk-bond king Michael Milken. Nelson dismissed such shots as ``neo-McCarthyism'' and said his activities had been above-board. Harris, a former state senator, said polls showed he was the Democrat who could beat Mrs. Orr in November. Hoppner supporters had hoped a last-minute endorsement from Kerrey would help his cause. Each of the Democratic front-runners contended through the campaign that he could provide better leadership than Mrs. Orr, who has smarted from newspaper polls which indicate a flagging job performance rating.

DOC.HEAD: West German Call for Joint Elections Draws Angry Response
DOC.TEXT: West Germany on Tuesday called for united German elections as early as December, and the proposal drew angry responses from opposition politicians in both German nations. Markus Meckel, East Germany's foreign minister and head of the East German Social Democrats, said he feared early joint elections could result in East Germans being ``dominated in an all-German state.'' The East Berlin government announced that it plans to hold state elections Dec. 2, the same day as the West German national elections. It was not clear whether the announcement from Eberhard Stief, the No. 2 official in the East German Interior Ministry, was designed as an intermediary step on the way to plans for joint national elections in both countries. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl met with his own coalition partners Tuesday to look over a draft treaty that will seal the economic merger of the two Germanys on July 2. Kohl's coalition partners gave their approval to the treaty during the session, but a few details remain to be worked out. The planned economic merger wasn't the only topic at the closed-door meeting. Hans Klein, Kohl's chief spokesman, said all participants ``spoke out unanimously for the soonest possible date for all-German elections.'' He did not give a possible date. But Alfred Dregger, parliamentary leader of Kohl's Christian Democrats, said he favors either replacing the Dec. 2 federal elections with all-German balloting or holding the all-German vote when the current legislative period ends Jan. 13, 1991. Finance Minister Theo Waigel said he believed an all-German vote would be held this year. After the meeting, Kohl said he had not discarded the idea of holding federal elections Dec. 2. But he again left open the possibility the German states could hold a joint federal election that day. Kohl said that question ``must be decided in the Parliament'' of East Germany. The chancellor said all-German elections could not occur until conclusion of the so-called ``two-plus-four'' unification talks involving the two German nations and four World War II victors _ the Soviet Union, the United States, Britain and France. The six nations are trying to iron out the international complexities of unification, such as the military attachments of a united Germany. Kohl said he is confident those talks can be concluded this year. Kohl suffered a major setback earlier in the week after losing control of Parliament's upper house to the opposition Social Democrats through two state election defeats. Earlier this month, the chancellor had said he did not see all-German elections occurring before the fall of 1991. But now Kohl, possibly sensing he would have a better chance of winning all-German elections than the federal vote Dec. 2, has left open the possibility of the joint elections before next year. Hans-Jochen Vogel, head of West Germany's Social Democrats, lambasted Kohl for his new position, accusing the chancellor of ``misusing the German unity process'' to try to further his political career. Vogel's East German allies also warned Kohl against being too hasty. Meckel said he was worried East Germans could become ``dominated in an all-German state'' if joint elections were this year. Klein, the West German government spokesman, said Kohl and his coalition allies Tuesday determined the economic merger will take effect on July 2 as planned. Klein said a ``few important details'' remain to be worked out, but that Kohl was confident that would occur during a meeting between the German finance ministers in Bonn on Thursday. He said one of the problems was the lack of information about East Germany's current economic situation. The economic merger would involve a drastic overhaul of East Germany's embattled economy in exchange for massive West German assistance. Under the draft economic treaty, East Germany would turn over all currency matters to West Germany's central bank, and bring its economic policies in line with those of its Western neighbor.

DOC.HEAD: 73-Year-Old Woman in Fight for Life With Computer
DOC.TEXT: Reports of 73-year-old Rose Marie Posey's demise were greatly exaggerated, but the fight to regain her life goes on. Declared dead in March by a U.S. Treasury Department computer, Mrs. Posey found that efforts to correct the error prompted more official buck-passing than resolution. ``I'm so mad about this I just shake,'' Mrs. Posey said. ``I know I'm not dead, but I don't feel so good because of all this.'' She learned of her ``death'' in April when she didn't receive her $871.13 monthly pension check. The mistake was supposed to have been fixed, but it lingers in government computers. On Thursday, Mrs. Posey got a letter from Medicare saying the national health insurer had denied a $25 payment for minor foot surgery done March 16. ``The date of this service was reported to be after the date of death,'' said the computer-generated letter addressed to her. ``I just want to take a hammer to all these computers,'' Mrs. Posey said. Last week, Mrs. Posey complained to the Railroad Retirement Board, which pays her pension, and to Travelers Medicare, the insurer that handles the board's Medicare payments. But on Monday the Medicare computer still listed her as dead. ``Our computer shows her date of death as 12-31-89,'' said Debbie Petersen, a Travelers Medicare spokeswoman in Salt Lake City, Utah. She blamed the Railroad Retirement Board. ``We just pay the claims. Railroad Retirement handles the computer system,'' she said. ``We can just look at the screen from our end, we can't change anything on it.'' But Bob Lehrke, the board's district manager in Springfield, blamed Travelers Medicare. ``Travelers should already have updated and corrected their records,'' he said, adding that he was unaware the insurer couldn't make computer changes. ``Once it leaves the Railroad Retirement Board, I don't know the process of what happens to it,'' he said. ``But our end is clean, so obviously it's something they should correct.'' Meanwhile, Mrs. Posey's mistaken death is taking its toll. ``My nerves are just about ready to blow sky high,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Frohnmayer Hoping for Big Victory in Primary
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Polls close at 11 p.m. EDT; matter below the dash will stand.
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dave Frohnmayer hoped for a big victory in Tuesday's Republican primary as a boost for his fall campaign for the governorship. Six other contenders were on the ballot but Frohnmayer, one of Oregon's best-known political figures, was expected to easily emerge as the winner. Secretary of State Barbara Roberts was unopposed for the Democratic nomination. Oregon's senior senator, Republican Mark Hatfield, was challenged in his bid for nomination to a fifth term by environmentalist Randy Prince, a political unknown. Six Democrats, including Harry Lonsdale, a high-tech businessman from Bend who financed his own campaign, were seeking the right to oppose Hatfield Residents of the college town of Eugene voted on a measure to toughen an ordinance that bans the local manufacture of nuclear weapons and their components.

Opponents of the existing ordinance have called it a symbolic gesture that has driven away potential economic investment in Eugene. The expected general election matchup of Frohnmayer and Roberts in the governor's race was created when the incumbent Democrat, Neil Goldschmidt, decided not to seek a second term because of marital problems. Lonsdale spent his primary campaign taking shots at Hatfield, saying the incumbent should be replaced because he has done nothing to stop logging of old growth trees and is opposed to abortion.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Envoy to Express Concern Over Kashmir Strife
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will send a special envoy to India and Pakistan this weekend to encourage both countries to calm the escalating strife in the Kashmir, the White House said Tuesday. Bush has urged both sides to restore ``calm and security'' to the troubled region, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. He said the mission of deputy national security adviser Robert Gates is ``a reflection of (Bush's) deep concern'' about the deteriorating situation in the region, which has been at the center of two Indian-Pakistani wars. Gates' May 19-21 trip is designed to convey Bush's message firsthand to the leaders of both countries and ``gain a firsthand appreciation of the situation,'' Fitzwater said. Accompanying Gates will be Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly and Richard Haas, the National Security Council's top expert on the region. Gates, the deputy to national security adviser Brent Scowcroft, will travel from Moscow, where he has been with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. The Kashmir is the only state with a Muslim majority in predominantly Hindu India. Two Indian soldiers and a Pakistani soldier were killed in a gunbattle in the disputed state Monday night, according to the Pakistani Defense Ministry. Tensions flared in January when militant secessionists launched a bloody independence battle in the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir. Pakistan denies India's claims that it is training and arming Moslem militants in the region. Kashmir was divided between India and Pakistan at the end of British colonial rule in 1947. The two neighbors fought wars in 1948 and 1965 over Kashmir; in 1971 they went to war over Bangladesh, then East Pakistan. Fitzwater said: ``The United States deeply regrets the current violence in Kashmir. We call on all sides to take steps to restore calm and security and to allow political dialogue to address the problems of Kashmir.''

DOC.HEAD: Va. Governor Orders South African Divestiture
DOC.TEXT: Gov. L. Douglas Wilder, who has been under fire for neglecting concerns by fellow blacks, ordered state agencies Tuesday to sell their nearly $1 billion holdings in companies tied to South Africa. Wilder, the nation's first elected black governor, said he wanted his executive order to be implemented as soon as possible, although details have yet to be worked out. ``The time for action is now and we can develop a policy,'' he told reporters. ``It's not going to be that difficult. It's not going to be unworkable.'' Virginia is the 27th state to order divestment in companies that do business with South Africa to protest its apartheid laws requiring racial separation. Wilder ordered no new investments in the companies and said state agencies and institutions should begin divesting from companies with ``substantive interests'' in the country. Since he announced the plan Saturday during a commencement address at Norfolk State University, he has been praised by blacks but criticized by conservatives who had been pleased with his tight fiscal policies. ``I'm very pleased he's taking this step. I would hope and expect more progressive actions,'' said Charles E. Jones, an Old Dominion University associate professor who had joined other black scholars in criticizing Wilder's ``New Mainstream'' conservativism. ``It could be a costly process, depending on how they handle it,'' said state Sen. Hunter B. Andrews, a conservative Democrat who has frequently tangled with the Democratic governor. Wilder's order affects nearly $1 billion in state investments, primarily by the state employees' pension fund and several colleges and universities. The governor said he would like to see divestiture completed before his term ends in January 1994. He insisted that Virginia would not face the same problems as other states such as New Jersey, which lost as much as a $500 million by divesting $4.2 billion in South African-linked holdings in three years. ``Ours will be prudent and I can say to you that I wouldn't necessarily mirror the example of New Jersey with reference to how they went about handling that matter,'' he said. Wilder said he set the South African policy because university board members had asked his administration what they should do about such investments. He said ``it's a valid question'' whether the state should divest from companies doing business in other countries that violate human rights, such as South Korea, but that South Africa's system is more oppressive than other nations'.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Say U.S. Agent Slain Because He Cost Drug Barons Billions
DOC.TEXT: U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena was tortured and murdered because his work had cost a Mexican drug cartel more than $5 billion, a prosecutor said Tuesday in opening arguments in the trial of four men. The defendants included the brother-in-law of a former Mexican president. Assistant U.S. Attorney John Carlton said the defendants were involved either directly or indirectly with drug trafficking, and participated in actions that led to the slaying of the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agent in Mexico. The motivation was drug smugglers' anger at devastating raids on marijuana plantations, Carlton said. ``The cartel's anger and frustration became increasingly focused on one DEA agent,'' he said. He said there were meetings in which there was talk of ``taking care of agent Camarena.'' ``From May of 1984 to February of 1985 the cartel suffered a series of devastating losses, which it blamed on the DEA,'' Carlton said. ``The seizures cost the cartel over $5 billion ... and the cartel began a series of retaliatory actions.'' On trial are Ruben Zuno Arce, the brother-in-law of former Mexican President Luis Echeverria; Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros, a convicted Honduran drug kingpin; Juan Jose Bernabe Ramirez, a former Mexican police officer; and Javier Vasquez Velasco, who is accused of murdering two American tourists in an apparent mistake killing. Carlton said Vasquez and other drug traffickers mistook Albert Radelat and John Walker for DEA agents when the two walked into a celebration dinner that drug lords were holding in a restaurant. Carlton said much of the prosecution's case would depend on the testimony of confidential informants as well as physical evidence including hairs found at the house where Camarena was slain. The mention of hair evidence led to a motion for mistrial by the attorney for Matta. Attorney Martin Stolar has disputed that the hair found at the murder scene was Matta's and has asked for further scientific examination before it is admitted in evidence. He said the prosecutor should not have mentioned it, but Judge Edward Rafeedie denied the motion. The 31-year-old Camarena was kidnapped off a street in Guadalajara, Mexico, in February 1985. Testimony at the trial of three other men in 1988 showed that the agent was taken to a house where he was tortured and interrogated by drug lords before being slain along with his pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar. Their bodies were found a month later on a ranch 65 miles outside Guadalajara. The DEA has promised to capture every person involved in the slaying. So far, 22 people have been charged in this country and more than 20 convicted in Mexico. Among those arrested was a Mexican doctor who allegedly monitored Camarena's medical condition while he was interrogated, and administered drugs to revive Camarena so that the interrogation could continue. The arrest last month of Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain enraged Mexican officials who said he was unlawfully abducted from his Guadalajara office on April 2 and turned over to U.S. authorities in El Paso, Texas, the next day. Mexican authorities say a former policeman arrested in connection with Alvarez Machain's abduction told them the DEA was involved, an allegation denied by DEA officials.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinians Kill Suspected Collaborators
DOC.TEXT: Palestinian activists killed three Arabs they accused of collaborating with Israeli authorities, hammering nails through the hands of one of the victims, Palestinian and army reports said Tuesday. In other developments, Jewish settlers rampaged through Arab villages on the outskirts of Jerusalem, and a 14-year-old Palestinian boy died of wounds he suffered when he was shot by a settler in an earlier incident. Throughout the occupied lands, Palestinians staged a protest strike marking the 42nd anniversary of the founding of Israel. The army clamped curfews on about 200,000 Palestinians in five Gaza Strip refugee camps to prevent clashes during the anniversary. Jews mark Independence Day on April 30 in accordance with the Hebrew calendar. The body of a slain Palestinian was discovered in each of the villages of Balaa, Rafat and Assira al-Shamaliya, an army spokesman said. He said the army was investigating the deaths, which apparently were not connected. The victim in Balaa was identified as Farid Saleh Yassin, the 65-year-old village leader appointed by Israel. Nails were hammered through his hands, a military official said. Six masked activists abducted Yassin from his home Monday and stabbed him to death before dumping his body on the outskirts of the village, Arab reporters said. A leaflet distributed in Balaa accused Yassin of being a collaborator. The decomposing body of a 25-year-old man who was abducted Friday was found near Assira al-Shamaliya, and a 48-year-old land dealer's body was found covered with stab wounds, the Arab reporters said. The deaths brought to 215 the number of Palestinians known slain by fellow Arabs during the 29-month uprising, most on suspicion of cooperating with Israel. Israeli hospital officials on Tuesday confirmed the death of a 14-year-old boy from Qalqiliya. He was shot Sunday when a settler fired on stone-throwers, the reporters said. No arrests were made in the case. At least 687 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers and civilians during the uprising. Forty-three Israelis have died. Before dawn Tuesday, hundreds of Jewish settlers from Maale Adumim near Jerusalem hurled stones at Arab houses and cars on the outskirts of the city to protest frequent stone-throwing and firebomb attacks on their vehicles. The protest occurred after a firebomb was thrown at a bus, apparently by a Palestinian. Five Arab workers from the daily Al-Fajr newspaper were slightly injured by broken glass when their van was stoned by the settlers, a witness said. Another Al-Fajr employee said some 50 settler attackers shouted: ``Kill the Arabs.'' Several policemen were injured trying to protect the settlers. In political developments, caretaker Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir asked parliament's Finance Committee to approve the transfer of $20.5 million for settlement needs in the occupied territories. Shamir spokesman Avi Pazner said the sum would not be used for any new projects. But Israel army radio said the sum included $4.5 million for new settlements. Pazner said he did not expect renewed friction with the United States, which views settlement in the occupied territories as an obstacle to peace, since the move was a ``routine annual request.'' In recent weeks, the government has started construction of two new settlements in the West Bank and Gaza. It also has admitted it secretly funded a settlement in the Christian Quarter of Jerusalem's Old City.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Considers Short-Term Loan to Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said Tuesday it was considering Nicaragua's urgent request for a $40 million short-term loan. ``My country is bankrupt,'' President Violeta Chamorro said in a Friday cable to President Bush. Nicaragua's reserves ``are insufficient to fulfill our obligations coming due in the next 30 days,'' said Mrs. Chamorro, citing a 70 percent per month inflation rate. A copy of the cable was obtained Tuesday. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the administration was ``looking into possibilities of doing something along the lines of what she requests'' as the push for passage of Bush's entire $300 million Nicaraguan aid request continued. ``If we can't get something fairly quickly (from Congress), we are taking a look to see if there are some kind of loans or something that can help her out in the short term,'' Fitzwater said. The comments came as thousands of striking workers in Managua paralyzed Mrs. Chamorro's 19-day-old government. Vice President Virgilio Godoy said the opposition Sandinistas were trying to overthrow Mrs. Chamorro, who defeated President Daniel Ortega in the Feb. 25 election. ``It is unfortunate that the Sandinistas, despite their promises to work with the Chamorro government to achieve economic reconstruction and national reconciliation are engaging in what appear to be politically motivated strikes,'' said State Department spokesman Richard Boucher. As arrangements for a Treasury Department loan were being considered, there were indications from Capitol Hill that lawmakers were preparing to act on Bush's original aid package. But there was no telling when funds would actually reach Nicaragua. House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., said he wanted a House vote Thursday on an authorization bill that would provide $300 million for Nicaragua and $420 million for Panama. However, House-Senate negotiators had to resolve their differences over the spending package, which has been muddied with billions of dollars of tack-on issues. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said Tuesday that Mrs. Chamorro has been treated unfairly. ``We were telling her ... that if she was elected she could count on us,'' Dole said. ``The final result is Congress is still playing games and she doesn't have anything to show for it.'' Mrs. Chamorro told Bush that she needed the loan to cover a dire economic crisis and ``to avoid a critical situation that may be looming in the very near future.'' She accused the Sandinistas of ``taking advantage of the situation to create instability.'' The aid also is needed to feed 14,000 Contra rebels in temporary camps where they are disarming under the auspices of the Organization of American States. Their supplies are expected to run out by the end of the week, U.S. officials said. ``Congress is playing with fire'' by holding up the aid package, which includes $30 million for the rebel camps, Assistant Secretary of State Bernard Aronson said Tuesday. He said he didn't know whether Mrs. Chamorro would designate any money for Contra camps if the $40 million loan was made. ``The demobilization process is in grave danger because of the shortfall,'' said another administration official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``Hungry men with weapons aren't exactly going to be lying down.'' Both the House and Senate have approved $720 million in emergency aid for Panama and Nicaragua. Final approval has been delayed in conference committee where the bill is bogged down by scores of amendments, including one relating to federal funding for abortions in Washington, D.C. The aid package also had been linked procedurally to a Democrat-driven proposal to use aid to El Salvador as leverage to bring about a negotiated peace in that country. Dole said it was wrong to include El Salvador and other add-ons in the Panama-Nicaragua package.

DOC.HEAD: Private Group Calls For Reductions In Toxic Releases
DOC.TEXT: Nearly two-thirds of the nation's toxic industrial waste is produced by 100 corporations and the chemical industry accounts for almost half, a private group said Tuesday. Washington-based Citizen Action criticized the chemical industry for not moving quickly enough to curb toxic releases. The group said 42 percent of all such pollution comes from chemical plants and four of the top five polluters are chemical companies. However, a spokesman for the Chemical Manufacturers Association said the organization's members already are committed to making signficant reductions in hazardous releases in the coming years because of public concern. Citizen Action based its analysis on statistics released last month by the Environmental Protection Agency. The EPA figures, widely reported at the time, showed that 4.6 billion pounds of hazardous chemicals were released by factories into the air, water and ground in 1988. Citizen Action said its examination of the data showed that 10 companies released about 26 percent of the toxic chemicals into the environment. Seven of the 10 are members of the Chemical Manufacturers Association. Robert M. Brandon, vice president of Citizen Action, chastised the chemical industry trade group for an advertising campaign as part of recent Earth Day observances that promised to ``continuously improve our performance in health, safety and protecting the environment.'' ``The public shouldn't be fooled,'' said Brandon, arguing that the EPA data shows that industry has not done enough to curb toxic emissions. ``It's time for polluters to take responsible action.'' He said the chemical companies should make a commitment to cut toxic releases in half within five years. Spokesman Jeffrey Van said the 170 Chemical Manufacturers Association member companies are committed to reducing toxic releases. He said the volume of chemical industry releases was reduced 10 percent from 1987 to 1988, despite an 8 percent increase in productivity. ``The public has spoken. People say the numbers are too high and they want them down,'' Van said. The spokesman said he could not provide an industry-wide estimate on reduction goals, but said some large companies are planning emission cuts substantially greater than 50 percent. Glynn A. Young, manager of environmental and community relations for Monsanto Co. in St. Louis said the firm plans a 90 percent reduction in air emissions of toxic chemicals within two years and a 70 percent reduction in all toxic releases by the end of 1995. Monsanto was the second largest polluter of toxic chemicals, releasing 202 million pounds in 1988, the citizens group said. Du Pont Chemical released the largest volume _ 338 million pounds _ in 1988, the group said. Du Pont spokesman John McAllister said the company plans to cut air emissions of toxic chemicals by 60 percent by 1993 and all emissions by 35 percent this decade. Citizen Action said other companies among the top 10 and the amount of emmissions they produced in 1988 are: American Cyanimid, 189 million pounds; Shell Chemical Co., 173 million pounds; BP Chemicals, 151 million pounds; Freeport McMoran, 150 million pounds; AMAX, 113 million pounds; Allied Signal, 100 million pounds; ASARCO, 98 million pounds; and Vulcan Chemicals, 93 million pounds.

DOC.HEAD: Pennsylvania Anti-Abortion Governor In First Post-Law Test
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Polls close at 8 p.m. EDT; matter below the dash will stand.
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Robert P. Casey, facing his first election test since signing a tough anti-abortion law, met a pro-choice challenger in Tuesday's Democratic primary. His endorsed running mate, Lt. Gov. Mark S. Singel, also drew a primary opponent hoping to tap into pro-choice sentiment. Opposing Casey was attorney Philip S. Berg of suburban Philadelphia. Edward Mezvinsky, a former Iowa congressman and former Pennsylvania Democratic Party chairman, ran against Singel. On the Republican side, Auditor General Barbara Hafer, who is pro-choice, had party leaders' backing in her contest against an anti-abortion challenger, Marguerite ``Peg'' Luksik. Incumbent Democratic congressmen John Murtha, Austin Murphy and Joseph Kolter, all of western Pennsylvania, were in contested primaries. Murtha was criticized for supporting congressional pay raises, Murphy for having a son outside his marriage, and Kolter for not doing enough for his district's economy. Abortion also figured in a legislative race pitting Republican Stephen F. Freind, architect of the state's anti-abortion law passed in November, against newcomer Ellen Fisher, a businesswoman who supports abortion rights, Freind has represented a suburban Philadelphia district in Delaware County for 14 years. Another race tested the local prestige of Rep. William Gray III, the House majority whip. He supported Democratic state Rep. Louise Bishop, who was challenged for renomination by ward leader Carol Ann Campbell. All three are black. Democratic Committee Chairman Bob Brady, a white, supports Campbell. Gray accused Brady of ``plantation politics'' _ hand-picking Campbell because he controls her. Brady and Campbell denied the allegation.

Casey ignored Berg and reminded voters of his efforts to bring jobs to Pennsylvania and clean up its toxic waste sites, trash and drinking water problems. ``It's not a case of writing him off,'' Casey said in a recent interview. ``It's simply a case of following our game plan, which is the same no matter who is in or out of the race.'' Casey said abortion was important but not the only issue. Mezvinsky, who still owes Casey's campaign $50,000 from an unsuccessful race for attorney general in 1988, bucked the governor to challenge Singel. ``Our party should not have leadership that's out of step,'' Mezvinsky said of Casey's and Singel's opposition to abortion, a stand that runs counter to the national Democratic Party's position. ``My candidacy is a bridge. It allows Democrats to have a home.'' Hafer, a fast-rising Republican making her sixth run for office in 13 years, looked beyond her opponent and aimed her attacks at Casey. She questioned his management of the state's budget and prisons. The budget is slipping towards red ink and the Camp Hill prison erupted in three days of riots in October. Pennsylvania's new law includes a ban on abortions after 24 weeks of pregnancy, except where the mother faces death or irreversible harm, a 24-hour waiting period, spousal notice, and requirements that doctors explain to the woman the likely age of the fetus and the risks of and alternatives to abortion. The waiting period and spousal notice have been blocked by federal court while appeals are decided.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Buy More U.S. Corn
DOC.TEXT: Private exporting companies have sold the Soviet Union an additional 150,000 metric tons of U.S. corn for delivery this year under a long-term supply agreement, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. Orders since Oct. 1, the beginning of the agreement's new year, total more than 15.9 million tons of corn, 3.6 million tons of wheat, 342,300 tons of soybeans and 1.2 million tons of soybean meal. Sales of barley total 7,300 tons. In 1988-89, sales were a record of more than 21.7 million tons, including more than 16.3 million tons of corn and nearly 5.4 million tons of wheat. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 39.4 bushels of corn or 36.7 bushels of wheat or soybeans.

DOC.HEAD: House Resolution Accuses Cuba of Human Rights Violations
DOC.TEXT: The House overwhelmingly approved a resolution Tuesday accusing the Cuban government of human rights abuses. ``It appears that the Castro regime is not impressed by the movement worldwide to promote basic human rights,'' said Rep. Chris Smith, R-N.J., sponsor of the resolution. The resolution, approved 391-2, says Cuba has ``engaged in a consistent pattern of gross violations of internationally recognized human rights.'' It calls on Cuba ``to release all human rights activists and other political prisoners'' and ``meet universally recognized standards of human rights and fundamental freedoms.''

DOC.HEAD: Report Says AID Changes Focus of Population Program
DOC.TEXT: The Agency for International Development no longer encourages less-developed nations to control population unless the countries already are committed to such programs, according to a report released Tuesday. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., said the report indicates that AID is ``not receiving the support it needs to meet the pressing demands for contraceptives in the Third World.'' Leahy, chairman of a Senate subcommittee on foreign operations, said exploding populations are putting ``unprecedented pressures on the Earth's environment and threatening to undo everything we are trying to achieve with our foreign aid.'' The report, prepared by the General Accounting Office, a congressional watchdog agency, said reducing population growth is not an AID goal. That, Leahy said, is contrary to laws passed by Congress. The change in AID's policy came during the Reagan administration, when some conservatives objected to giving money to birth-control programs abroad. China, which received money from the U.N. Population Fund, was cited for practicing abusive techniques in enforcing its one-child rule. In the 1980s, AID continued with many of its population programs but no longer ``actively promoted smaller families and lower growth rates,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Arms Summit Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is the preliminary schedule of events for the May 30-June 3 Bush-Gorbachev summit as released by the White House on Tuesday. All times are EDT.

Wednesday May 30: 6:30 p.m.: Gorbachev arrives.
Thursday May 31: 10 a.m.: Arrival ceremony, South Lawn of White House. 10:30 a.m.-noon: First Bush-Gorbachev meeting, White House. Barbara Bush and Raisa Gorbachev meet in White House residence. Noon-4 p.m.: Private time for Gorbachev. 4-5:30 p.m.: Second Bush-Gorbachev meeting, the White House. 7 p.m.: State dinner, the White House.
Friday June 1: 11 a.m.-1 p.m.: Third Bush-Gorbachev meeting, the White House. 1-5 p.m.: Private time for Gorbachev. 5-6 p.m.: Fourth Bush-Gorbachev meeting, the White House. 6 p.m.: Signing Ceremony, the White House. 7:30 p.m.: The Gorbachevs host dinner for the Bushes, Soviet Embassy.
Saturday June 2: 9:30 a.m.: Bush and Gorbachev leave by helicopter from White House lawn for Camp David, Md. 10 a.m.: Arrive Camp David. Late afternoon: Gorbachev leaves for Washington. Bush departure uncertain; he may spend the night at Camp David.
Sunday June 3 10 a.m.: Bush-Gorbachev news conference, East Room, the White House. 11 a.m.: Departure ceremony for Gorbachev, the White House. Noon: Gorbachev leaves for Minneapolis. He flies later in the day to San Francisco.
Monday June 4: Gorbachev returns to the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev to See Minneapolis, San Francisco
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev will visit Minneapolis and San Francisco after summit talks with President Bush, meeting with business executives and agricultural leaders in America's heartland and seeking a California reunion with former President Ronald Reagan. Extending his visit by one day, the Soviet president will spend May 30 to June 4 in the United States, the White House announced Tuesday. Before arriving in Washington, Gorbachev will visit Canada on May 29-30 at the invitation of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, the Tass news agency said. It will be the first extended U.S. visit by a Soviet leader since 1973 when Leonid Brezhnev made a coast-to-coast trip, ranging from the presidential retreat at Camp David to President Nixon's summer home at San Clemente, Calif. Gorbachev has been to the United States twice before but only in New York City and Washington. ``We have a lot of difficult issues to discuss with the Soviets,'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, mentioning disputes over arms control and Soviet pressure on the independence-minded Baltic states. ``I think this summit will demonstrate a new sense of realism about our relationship, one in which both sides can be critical of each other, both sides can raise troublesome and difficult issues and expect to explore them in depth,'' he said. Gorbachev's meetings with Bush will begin with a formal welcoming ceremony at the White House on Wednesday, May 31, and conclude with a joint news conference on Sunday, June 3. In between, there will be four formal rounds of talks at the White House, concluding Friday evening. Bush will be host at a state dinner Thursday for Gorbachev. The Soviet leader will reciprocate with a dinner at the Soviet Embassy for Bush. On Saturday, the two leaders will fly to Camp David, the presidential retreat in Maryland's Catoctin Mountains, for a day of private discussions. Fitzwater said the Camp David talks would focus on political issues such as changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union and challenges facing the NATO alliance. From Washington, Gorbachev will fly to Minneapolis for a six-hour stop. Gov. Rudy Perpich said Gorbachev wants to meet with agricultural and business leaders who are interested in closer ties in high technology and food processing. From Minneapolis, Gorbachev will fly to San Francisco for an overnight stop. The next day, June 4, the Soviet president will visit Stanford University. The university is the home of the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace, which has the world's largest collection of material on the 1917 Russian Revolution, and many scholars unsympathetic to the fruits of that revolution which brought the Communists to power. University officials, who only a day earlier professed ignorance about a Gorbachev visit, said they learned Tuesday that he would spend three hours on campus. U.S. officials in Washington said he might give a speech there. Soviet officials also began exploring the possibility of a reunion between Gorbachev and Reagan, who held five summit meetings when Reagan was president. Staff members in Reagan's Los Angeles office said Soviet officials contacted them Tuesday about a meeting but that no arrangements had been completed. Mark Weinberg, a spokesman for Reagan, said Monday that the former president would be in the state in early June.

DOC.HEAD: 16 Haitians Deported from U.S. Being Held Pending Investigation
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Sixteen of 42 Haitians arrested after they were deported from the United States are being held pending investigation of who organized their trips and provided them with falsified documents, a U.S. Embassy spokeswoman said Tuesday. Susan Clyde said the 16 entered the United States illegally by boat or with falsified papers, and Haitian authorities were questioning them about how they left Haiti and the source of their doctored documents. In a statement last week, the U.S. Embassy said it ``deplored'' the fact that Haitians were being swindled by organizers of trips ``doomed in advance.'' Ms. Clyde said 27 of the Haitians held at the National Penitentiary in Port-au-Prince were deported from the United States on May 7 and 15 others were deported on Saturday. One deportee in the first batch had been serving a five-year sentence in a Florida jail; 10 were stowaways and the remaining 16 were boat people or arrested with falsified entry papers. The deportees in the second batch were serving time in a Texas prison, 14 for drug-related offenses, one for homicide, she said. Three of the drug offenders, having already served their sentences, were released, Maj. Leopold Clerjeune, chief of the Anti-Gang Bureau, told The Associated Press on Tuesday. The other cases had been referred to the courts for judicial decision and most would probably be released soon, Clerjeune said. In Miami, Haitian Refugee Center Director the Rev. Gerard Jean-Juste deplored the arrests of the deported Haitians. ``I think it's a mistake. It's a grave mistake of the Ertha Pascal-Trouillot government, arresting refugees on their return, and we feel some kind of oppression coming from this regime,'' he said. ``At this present moment, we are calling on the government to avoid that mistake and release the refugees who are not criminals.'' He added, ``Most of them have stayed already a year in jail, in detention, here and it's too much. Don't punish these people further.'' Many Haitians try to flee their impoverished Caribbean island in flimsy sailboats and sail for Florida; some of these crafts never make it on the high seas, sinking in bad weather, or are detained by U.S. officials on arrival in Florida or off Haiti. Haiti, one of the poorest countries in the Western Hemisphere, shares the island of Hispaniola with the Dominican Republic.

DOC.HEAD: Slumping `Today' Brings Joe Garagiola Back As Co-Host
LaserPhoto upcoming
DOC.TEXT: NBC, hoping the past of ``Today'' will help its tomorrows, said Tuesday it is bringing back Joe Garagiola as a co-host in a shakeup to help pull the talk show out of a ratings slump. Also Tuesday, NBC hired Faith Daniels as ``Today'' news anchor, and Dick Ebersol, the network executive behind a series of moves that preceded the slump, said he was giving up his job as overseer of the program. Garagiola, the show's host from 1969 to 1973, will work with Bryant Gumbel and Deborah Norville. NBC's surprise announcement comes at a time the once top-rated show has been sliding deeper into second place in ratings after the series of changes, including the replacement of Jane Pauley by Norville in Janary. Since then, ``Today'' has trailed ABC's ``Good Morning America'' in the ratings, with the ``CBS Morning News'' a consistent third. Garagolia, a popular NBC sportscaster until he left the network in 1988, will start work in June, as will Daniels, who has been on maternity leave since the March 25 birth of her second child. Daniels, co-anchor of early-morning newscasts at CBS since 1985, will anchor news segments on ``Today'' and anchor the earlier ``NBC News at Sunrise.'' NBC correspondent Katie Couric also was assigned as the full-time ``Today'' correspondent in Washington, D.C. Ebersol said he was giving up his job as the senior executive in charge of ``Today.'' He'll continue as NBC Sports president and as a senior NBC News vice president. ``Almost all the furor of recent months concerning `Today' has revolved around my decisions of last fall, and I believe I must take the primary responsibility for those decisions,'' said Ebersol. The uproar began in September when Norville displaced veteran correspondent John Palmer, a friend of Pauley, as the ``Today'' news anchor, and was moved to the show's desk to sit alongside Pauley and Gumbel. Pauley, who has refused to blame Norville for anything, reportedly was angered by the moves and finally asked to leave the show. An embarrassed NBC granted her wish. She left in December after 13 years to do prime-time news specials this year and anchor the ``NBC Nightly News'' when Tom Brokaw is on assignment or vacation. Tuesday's ``Today'' shuffle came five days after NBC News president Michael Gartner, also concerned about low ratings for ``NBC Nightly News,'' made another surprise move, hiring Steve Friedman as that program's executive producer. The brash, wise-cracking Friedman was executive producer of ``Today'' when it rose to first in ratings. The ``Today'' and ``Nightly'' changes were made three weeks before NBC affiliates hold their annual convention in Washington. A network executive speaking on condition of anonymity said it's likely that many affiliate executives, while pleased with NBC's prime-time success, will sharply criticize Gartner for the ratings woes of the two news shows. There was no reply by Gartner to a reporter's request for a phone interview. In a statement Tuesday, he admitted that ``it is no secret that in recent months `Today' has been through some troubled times. ``The departure of Jane Pauley left people with a loss of the sense of family which has been valued throughout the years on `Today.' These additions are designed to expand the cast and build on the strengths of the program.'' He also engaged in self-criticism in referring to the way Pauley's exit and Norville's entrance were handled. ``In hindsight,'' he said, ``NBC News management put ... Norville in a difficult position, resulting in a more arduous transition than we had anticipated.''

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: In a battle of wits and knowledge, the final score was Interlake High School Students 33, School Board 16. The five board members accepted a challenge from the school's five-member ``Knowledge Bowl'' team for a contest Monday night in general knowledge of such subjects as art, music, math, science, history and the law. The students never were seriously threatened. Nor had the board members expected them to be. The deal was that if the students lost, they would wash the board members' cars; if they won they'd get certificates of achievement. ``We left our cars at home, and we already have the certificates prepared,'' said board president Phil Noble when it was over. Even on legal issues, Noble and another lawyer on the board took their lumps. The moderator had barely said, ``A person convicted of a minor crime is sometimes ...'' when Noble slapped the buzzer and answered, ``Misdemeanor.'' Wrong. The moderator continued, ``... allowed to go free under suspension of sentence with some form of supervision. Such a person is said to be on ...'' ``Probation,'' a student chimed in. Correct. Last month, the Interlake team won the Puget Sound regional competition in the Knowledge Bowl.

Students at Lake Gibson Senior High better think twice before quitting a club. Their bodies may appear faceless in the yearbook. It's no practical joke. It's school-sanctioned defacing. In the new yearbook, the face of a former cheerleader was scratched out of a varsity squad photo. Two mugs among the Latin Club bodies were whited out. Yearbook photos often are taken in the fall, leaving students months to drop out or change clubs. In years past, club dropouts remained in the picture, but their names weren't listed, said Thomas Winters, school yearbook adviser. Under new rules, Winters said, club teachers and advisers can ask that dropouts be ``eliminated'' from club photos. ``I was hurt. ... That was something I wanted to look back on years from now,'' said the defaced cheerleader, senior Tawana Canady. ``I did quit. I had to. But I didn't know my face was going to get scratched out.'' Principal Richard Lewis conceded, ``it was tacky the way it was done.'' But he said it's not unusual to remove students from club photos if they aren't part of the group. Still, Lewis said he apologized to Canady and her mother.

DOC.HEAD: Hard-line Communist Takes Over Presidency
DOC.TEXT: Hard-line Communist Borisav Jovic of Serbia took over Tuesday as head of Yugoslavia's collective presidency and denounced democratic reforms in two of the nation's republics. The nation is wrapped in political and ethnic tensions, and Jovic said in his inaugural speech that the crisis had brought Yugoslavia to the brink of ``civil war and its breakup.'' He appeared to make conflicting statements about the emerging Western-style democracies in Croatia and Slovenia, criticizing efforts to abandon socialism but also supporting laws for secession. Jovic took over as leader of the eight-member presidency from Janez Drnovsek, a Slovene. Each of the country's six republics and two provinces has a representative on the presidency who holds the top post for one year on a rotating basis. Yugoslavia's founder, Josip Broz Tito, designed the system in what was seen as an attempt to guard against a power struggle in this ethnically mixed country after his death. The presidency is formally Yugoslavia's highest governing body and is in charge of the armed forces. Yugoslavia's Communist Party continues to rule in principle on the federal level, but it has been crippled since January when Slovenian and Croatian members walked out of a national meeting, accusing the Serbians of seeking domination. Slovenia and Croatia later held the first free elections in Yugoslavia in 50 years. Center-right parties won, to the displeasure of the Serbian Communists, who still advocate their party's monopoly of power. ``It is evident that there are forces which, under the cloak of democratic changes, are trying to achieve their strategic goal of abandoning the socialist orientation of our country even at the price of its breakup,'' Jovic said in his inaugural address. ``We will resolutely oppose this.'' However, he added that he would work for laws that would permit peaceful secession of individual states. Jovic, 62, is considered an ally of Serbia's Communist president, Slobodan Milosevic, who also opposes multiparty democracy in Yugoslavia. Both support Yugoslavia's federal system with strong central authority. But that system has been seriously weakened since the free elections in Slovenia and Croatia. Those republics are demanding that Yugoslavia transform itself into a loose confederation. The political conflict is intensifying the deep ethnic rivalries that have existed since the country was united in 1918. The most serious ethnic conflict is in Kosovo, a province that is part of Serbia. Ethnic Albanians make up 90 percent of the province's population, and the region enjoyed broad autonomy until changes last year that gave Serbia control of the police, judiciary and education. Serbian authorities say the changes were necessary to protec the province's Serbian minority from harassment. Delo, the leading Slovenian daily, said in a commentary that Jovic as president will ``strengthen the positions of the orthodox line'' in Yugoslav politics. ``In view of the fact that the presidency controls the armed forces ... this development could dangerously worsen tensions,'' Delo said. Jovic had served as vice president for the past year. Stipe Suvar, Croatia's representative in the presidency, took over that post and formally is next in line for leadership. However, the Croatian Democratic Union won the republic's recent elections and its leader, Franjo Tudjman, said in an interview that the new government may recall Suva, a Communist.

DOC.HEAD: Government Takes Up Issue of Electoral Reform
DOC.TEXT: Israel's Parliament began debate Tuesday on bills calling for direct election of the prime minister, part of electoral reforms demanded during widespread protests. Getting the issue to the floor of the Knesset, or parliament, was seen as a major step for the reformers. Supporters said passage would set the stage for more sweeping electoral reform to would limit political horsetrading. Four separate bills on direct election of the premier were submitted for the first of three readings, needed for the measure to become law. Under the current system, voters chose from a selection of national party lists. The head of the party with the most seats has by tradition become prime minister if he can form a coalition government. Under all proposals submitted Tuesday, the prime minister would be elected separately from the rest of the candidates for Parliament. A premier would no longer be as dependent on the support of small parties to stay in office. The proposals varied as to the length of the premier's term of office and the number of votes in Parliament needed to remove him from office. The idea of directly electing the premier had broad support. A movement for electoral reform began with a small group of hunger strikes shortly after the coalition government _ made up of the right-wing Likud bloc and left-leaning Labor Party _ collapsed March 15. In attempts to form a new government, Likud and Labor tried to lure defectors from each other's camps and from small religious parties with offers of political posts and money. Tens of thousands of people joined demonstrations and 500,000 signatures _ about 10 percent of Israel's 4.7 million citizens _ were gathered in support of electoral reform. If the bills pass, Uriel Lynn, a Likud legislator and head of the Parliament's Law Committee, said his committee would need a month to prepare them for the second and third readings. He said the political situation would determine when they came up for debate. ``I think part of the public will realize and be convinced that a solution for reforming the government lies in the Knesset,'' he said. In a rare move, State Comptroller Miriam Ben Porat announced she had begun a special investigation into government funding of religious bodies. This came as sections of the annual State Comptroller's report were made public. The report said government funds were given to educational organizations affiliated with the ultra-Orthodox Shas party that were simply used as a ``pipeline'' to party coffers. ``It cannot be that those who hold the keys to the public coffers use it as their own private cash register,'' the Jerusalem Post newspaper quoted Ms. Porat as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Unveils Advanced Fighter Drawings
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon unveiled drawings Tuesday of two prototypes of the Advanced Tactical Fighter, a futuristic aircraft designed to replace the F-15 fighter jet. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said the Air Force decided to release the drawings, along with some information about the $63.5 billion classified program, because the two industry teams competing for the contract ``are about to perform air-engine tests.'' ``The ATF is .. the air superiority fighter of the future,'' Williams said. The aircraft, he said, will use stealth technology to evade radar and cruise at supersonic speeds without using afterburners, a capability known as ``supercruise.'' The combat aircraft will have a speed of Mach 1.5, which would double the cruising speed of most present-day fighters. Both prototype airframes are scheduled for flight tests later this year and the winning contractor is expected to be chosen in July 1991, Williams said. The drawings show two versions of a sharp-nosed, single-seat, twin-engine aircraft with sharply angled vertical tails. The aircraft developed by the Northrop and McDonnell Douglas team has smoothed contours reminiscent of the B-2 stealth bomber, while the Lockheed, Boeing and General Dynamics version has a more angled design. No drawings were released for the Navy version of the ATF. Citing changing world conditions and the nation's severe budget crunch, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney announced that he intended to delay the purchases of the ATF two years, until 1996, as a cost-saving measure. The Air Force has said it wants to buy 750 of the jets, but Williams said a purchase of ``something less than 750'' was possible. ``No one knows today how many planes we would build,'' he said. To date, Williams said, $2.8 billion has been spent on the program. Although the cost in 1985 was put at $53.8 billion, current estimates put it at $63.5 billion, Williams said. Those figures include research and development, testing and procurement costs for 750 planes, he said. That translates to a per-plane cost of $84.7 million. ``Air Force leaders believe they need the ATF so future battlefield commanders can count on the umbrella of friendly air superiority and the protection of their forces from devastation by enemy air attacks,'' the Air Force said in a statement. ``It will use a first-look, first-kill capability to detect and destroy enemy fighters of today _ and tomorrow,'' the Air Force said. Williams offered no dimensions for the aircraft, saying they were classified. The aircraft, he said, will carry a full complement of medium and short-range arms, including the AIM-120 Advanced Medium Range Air-to-Air Missile and AIM-9 Sidewinder.

DOC.HEAD: Group Fined for Selling Condoms
DOC.TEXT: A court Tuesday fined the Irish Family Planning Association $750 for selling a packet of condoms in a Dublin record store. Under Irish law, condoms can be sold only in pharmacies, family planning clinics and other health outlets. A police officer testified in Dublin District Court that he saw a packet of condoms sold Jan. 8 at the Family Planning Association's safe sex information counter in Dublin's Virgin Megastore. The officer said he bought a packet for evidence. District Court president Oliver Macklin ordered the fine, saying, ``The law is the law. The offense is not accidental and I take the breach seriously.'' A similar prosecution against the record store eight months ago was thrown out on a technicality. The Irish Family Planning Association, which has been selling condoms at a booth in the store since February 1988, is considering an appeal. The law barring such sales generally has been ignored, but Irish observers said there has been pressure from right-wing Roman Catholics opposed to artificial contraception to prosecute the store. Ireland is overwhelmingly Catholic. Jon O'Brien, the family planning association's spokesman, said the organization was disappointed with the verdict. He said 100 customers a week buy condoms at the record shop booth. The association said in a statement that the sales proved the demand for condoms was not being met, as claimed by government officials. Richard Branson, a spokesman for the record store, said the fine ``seems completely unreal ... in the year 1990, the decade that will see the biggest increase in AIDS.'' Recent figures show there are 140 known cases of acquired immune deficiency syndrome in the Irish Republic. Almost 1,000 people have been diagnosed as carrying the HIV virus, which causes AIDS.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Parliament Approves $77 Billion More in Pensions
DOC.TEXT: Parliament on Tuesday raised pensions for the country's millions of retirees in a move that will cost the government $77 billion a year, the official news agency Tass reported. The Soviet Union has almost 70 million pensioners, many of them barely scraping by on only a few dozen dollars a month. The country has an estimated 290 million residents and is beset by economic difficulties. The new law lowered the retirement age for several types of workers and raised pensions, Tass said without elaborating. Retirement age varies by job but generally is about 60 years old. It quoted Vladimir Shcherbakov, chairman of the committee that worked on the law, as saying the measure would add $77 billion to the state's current annual pension outlay of $108 billion. The law comes at a time when the Soviet government is struggling with a large budget deficit, but also promising aid to low-income groups to ease the coming transition to a market-based economy under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Prices are expected to rise and unemployment to grow. To ease the burden on the state budget, the law will be introduced in stages, coming into full force in three years, Tass said.

DOC.HEAD: 20th Anniversary of Jackson State Slayings Passes Quietly
DOC.TEXT: Twenty years ago Tuesday, Jackson State students and staff swept up broken glass, counted bullet holes and tried to understand why police killed two people and wounded a dozen during a Vietnam War protest. Since students and staff were between semesters, the anniversary of the killings passed quietly on the campus where a dormitory wall remains pockmarked by gunfire. On May 2, about 300 people attended a memorial rally and candlelight vigil. The featured speaker, author and poet Margaret Alexander Walker, chided students for not turning out in greater numbers. School officials blamed the light turnout on the fact that classes weren't dismissed that day, but some students admitted they knew little about the barrage of gunfire aimed at a crowd outside the dorm. ``They had it in the paper, but a lot of students didn't know about it,'' said Tracie Archie, a 20-year-old political science student. ``There wasn't much talk about (the shootings). My mother told me about it.'' Cass Parker, an assistant chemistry professor and former Jackson State student, said there was no observance of the shootings Tuesday partly because of student apathy but mainly because classes ended May 12. ``The students' interest here has changed tremendously,'' said Parker, 36, a student from 1971-1975. ``There seems to be a resurgence in student interest, but it's not the same _ I guess it's a little more subdued.'' At about 12:05 a.m. on May 15, 1970, police opened fire on students at then-Jackson State College during a three-day protest of the Vietnam War and civil rights issues. Killed were Phillip Gibbs, a 21-year-old pre-law major from Ripley, and the 17-year-old James Earl Green, a Jackson high school student. Green had been walking through the college campus on his way home from work. ``It's a part of history that really, I think, was kept quiet,'' Parker said. ``But there are students who will never forget what happened. There are some students that will never let it be forgotten.'' The protesting students were upset about the shooting deaths of four students less than two weeks earlier at Kent State University in Ohio during an anti-war protest. Students also were angry about racial epithets shouted from cars by white Jackson residents driving through the mostly black Jackson State campus. The night Gibbs and Green were killed, 22 policemen in riot gear advanced on the students outside Alexander Residence Center. Some reports counted 75 to 100 students in front of the women's dormitory. Police said there were about 400. The shooting began after police using a bullhorn ordered students to disperse. Police said they then heard a gunshot. Students said it was more likely a bottle dropped on pavement from a dorm window. The ensuing barrage of rifle and shotgun fire lasted less than a minute, but every window on the campus-side of the five-story building was shot out and the FBI counted 275 bullet holes. At dawn, faculty and staff were camped on the front lawn of the dormitory in protest. Family of the dead and injured sued the city of Jackson and the state of Mississippi, but a federal appeals court ruled in 1974 that damages could not be awarded because it was impossible to determine who was to blame. However, the court did say that ``the barrage of gunfire far exceeded the response that was appropriate.'' Today, bullet holes are still visible in the walls. A black stone memorial to Gibbs and Green occupies a spot where people camped that night 20 years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Meat Production Expected to Rise
DOC.TEXT: The combined production of red meat and poultry is expected to increase about 2 percent this year, due entirely to greater output of broilers and turkeys, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. Red meat production is forecast to decline 1 percent from last year, said the department's Economic Research Service, but broiler and turkey output is expected to gain 7 percent each. Beef production may increase slightly from 1989, the report said, but commercial pork production will be down by about 2 percent. Retail beef prices may rise 1 percent to 3 percent from last year, and pork prices may go up 9 percent to 13 percent, the report said. Total egg production is expected to be up 1 percent from last year, after positive returns in 1989 and early 1990, the report said. Prices are declining as a result of the larger production.

DOC.HEAD: China Cancels $550 Million Grumman Contract
DOC.TEXT: China canceled a $550 million contract with a major U.S. defense contractor to update its F-8 jet fighters because of concern over cost overruns and a U.S. export ban, U.S. officials said Tuesday. Under arrangements negotiated in 1986, the Grumman Corp. was to equip the planes with a package of sophisticated electronics, navigation and radar equipment. Richard Boucher, a State Department spokesman, confirmed the cancellation, saying, ``The Chinese government has decided not to proceed beyond the development phase at this time.'' Boucher declined to speculate on the reasons for the decision or the impact it will have on Grumman's work force. He said the development phase of the project will be completed this fall. Defense Department spokesman Pete Williams also confirmed the cancellation and said: ``I can't tell you why. It was a Chinese decision.'' But a U.S. official, who commented on the condition he not be identified, said Chinese officials were concerned about steeply rising costs. The U.S. official said this concern was apparently coupled with uncertainty over when the Chinese Air Force could take delivery of the equipment. The Bush administration suspended military sales and deliveries to China a year ago in the aftermath of the crushing of the pro-democracy movement in Beijing. ``We have not made any deliveries and we will not make any until circumstances change,'' Boucher said. Williams said that two Chinese F-8s are in the United States for the project and will remain here ``until the suspension is lifted.'' Williams said the Pentagon was notified of the decision last month. The Chinese Embassy declined comment. Dubbed Peace Pearl, the agreement ranked among the largest military arrangements between China and the United States in the 1980s and was hailed as a basis for strategic cooperation against the Soviet Union. The arrangement called for the Chinese Air Force and Grumman, based in Bethpage, N.Y., to upgrade 55 planes at $10 million each. One unidentified industry analyst told the Los Angeles Times that cost overruns could boost the price tag to $750 million. The administration not only barred military sales and deliveries but also expelled 40 Chinese military officers assigned to the Peace Pearl project at Grumman in Bethpage and at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base near Dayton, Ohio. But it allowed long-term military programs such as Peace Pearl to continue, and eventually allowed the Chinese officers to return to the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Salute to Levee Living Won't Be Flooded Out
With AM-Floods, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Flooding along the Red River won't wash out this weekend's annual Salute to Levee Living, organizers said Tuesday. ``The levee system we have is completely protecting Alexandria from 40 miles north of the city to 40 miles south of the city,'' said Fred Elsing, festival chairman. ``It's outside the levee that people are having trouble. We think just about everything planned for the festival will go on.'' The stage for the event, which was built on the river bank, was flooded Tuesday, but Elsing said four flatbed trucks were being parked on top of the levee itself and covered with plywood to serve as a new stage. More than 75,000 people attended the three-day event last year. ``We expect more than that this year,'' he said. The water skiing show that was to be held on the river was moved to a lake, Elsing said. The street dances and fireworks would be held as scheduled, he said. The four-mile raft race was still scheduled for Sunday, Elsing said, but some of the smaller rafts might not be allowed to participate.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Discovers Torn Filter on Valve
DOC.TEXT: A faulty cooling valve that forced a delay in the launch of space shuttle Columbia was removed Tuesday and found to have a torn filter. NASA was expected to set a new launch date early next week. The problem prompted the space agency last week to delay Columbia's launch with a $100 million observatory from Wednesday or Thursday to the end of May or the beginning of June. ``We're pretty glad we did find the problem. Now we'll be on the right track of putting everything back together,'' said Lisa Malone, a spokeswoman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Technicians working on a makeshift platform in Columbia's payload bay began draining toxic Freon refrigerant from the shuttle's cooling system Friday. They completed the work late Monday, then cut out the valve, about the length of a hand, and some attached plumbing. It was the first time a cooling valve had ever been removed at the launch pad. The $100 million Astro observatory, Columbia's payload located about 10 feet below the workers' platform, remained safe under protective nets. The bad valve was sent to a nearby Rockwell International service center for analysis. Rockwell built Columbia and the other shuttles. Pieces of the torn metal filter were found on two other filters on the valve, Malone said. Pipes next to the removed valve were being checked for clues as to why the filter may have torn and to assure there are no other problems. After a new valve is installed, probably on Wednesday, the cooling system will be refilled with Freon and the entire system will be tested, Malone said. NASA was expected to set a new launch date early next week, once the work is completed. Columbia's nine- to 10-day flight will be the first Spacelab mission since 1985 and the 36th shuttle mission. The four astronomers who are part of the seven-man crew will operate Astro, which is capable of examining sources of ultraviolet and X-ray radiation.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Journalist Indicted in Chile
DOC.TEXT: A military prosecutor indicted the director of the Communist Party magazine El Siglo on charges of defaming the National Police. Andres Lagos became the first Chilean journalist indicted by a military court since the country returned to civilian rule March 11 after 16{ years of the authoritarian regime of Gen. Augusto Pinochet. The indictment was handed up Monday. Lagos had been in jail since Friday on orders from the prosecutor, Jose Rodriguez. Rodriguez said stories printed by El Siglo about human rights abuse involving police officers under Pinochet's regime were defamatory to the police force. The National Police sued El Siglo earlier this month. Lagos' lawyer said he would appeal the indictment. Under Pinochet, journalists were often prosecuted by military courts, and Rodriguez indicted Lagos based on legislation adopted by the Pinochet regime. The current president, Patricio Aylwin, has sent a bill to Congress to repeal that and other legislation considered restrictive to freedom of the press.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Recommends Honorable Discharge For Army Accused Army Private
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon's inspector general has recommended that an Army private allegedly mistreated by his superiors over a missing rifle receive an honorable discharge, a congresswoman said Tuesday. In a letter to Rep. Helen Bentley, R-Md., the inspector general said the discharge of James Griffin III was ``improperly accomplished'' and should be upgraded. ``Griffin was the victim of a ruse designed by Army officers to extract information from him regarding his missing weapon,'' Inspector General Susan Crawford said in the May 14 letter. Griffin was serving with Task Force Arriba in San Lorenzo, Honduras, in March 1989 when he was charged with loss of his rifle. The enlisted man contended that the rifle had been stolen but his U.S. superiors turned him over to Honduran authorities for interrogation. He was released 18 hours later and eventually returned to Fort Bragg, N.C., where five months later he was thrown out of the Army, Bentley said. The Army Criminal Investigation Command later searched a private house in Fayetteville, N.C., and found the receiver part of Griffin's rifle along with a cache of 16 other semiautomatic rifles. The weapons were part of a cache from a man who had been a soldier in Honduras with the task force at the same time Griffin was there, the congresswoman said. The inspector general said the four Army officers stationed in Honduras with Griffin were found directly involved in the ruse. Three were given letters of reprimand while a fourth received verbal counseling. All officers received outstanding performance evaluations for their time in Honduras, the inspector general said. ``It is accepted by all that Private Griffin was treated unfairly,'' Bentley said. The case was the subject of a recent report on CBS' ``60 Minutes'' television program.

DOC.HEAD: US Provides Food Aid To Haiti, Asks Congress To Act on Other Aid
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said Tuesday that $18 million in food assistance is being provided to Haiti and it called on Congress to approve a bill that includes an additional $13 million for that country. State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher expressed support for the efforts of provisioal President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot to move Haiti toward free and fair elections later this year. The $13 million aid package includes $10 million for short-term needs such as fuel and food and $3 million to enable international observers to monitor the elections and to provide other types of electoral support. ``We encourage and will support her (Mrs. Trouillot's) efforts to overcome the serious obstacles she confronts in bringing genuine democratic reforms and a greater respect for human rights to Haiti,'' Boucher said. The $13 million assistance package is part of a broader aid bill that also includes help for Panama and Nicaragua. President Bush has made numerous appeals to Congress for approval of the legislation. In an interview published in Tuesday's editions of the New York Times, Mrs. Trouillot, who served previously on Haiti's Supreme Court, said she inherited a bankrupt country two months ago. ``I was very surprised to see all of the coffers empty,'' she was quoted as saying. ``Economically, the country is paralyzed. The state can't honor its debts or pay many of its employees.'' The final decision on the food aid was made on Monday. Haiti will receive $6 million of the $18 million over the near term and the remaining $12 will be delivered starting Oct. 1, Boucher said. Haiti has drifted from one political crisis to another since the ouster of President Jean-Claude Duvalier more than four years ago. Mrs. Troiullot, who assumed her duties in mid-March after the ouster of former President Prosper Avril, is Haiti's fifth president since early 1986. Mrs. Trouillot has made clear her intention not to serve as president beyond September, a deadline that some regard as unrealistic in terms of turning over power to an elected successor. For much of the past 2{ years, the United States has not provided government-to-government aid to Haiti but has delivered substantial aid through private voluntary organizations. This has been a reflection of U.S. dissatisfaction with the dictatorial methods of the presidents who preceded Mrs. Trouillot. The total being funneled through voluntary groups this year is $41.4 million, Boucher said.

DOC.HEAD: British Families of Pan Am Victims Oppose Retaliation
With AM-Air Terrorism, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A man whose daughter died in the terrorist bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 spoke out Tuesday against military retaliation for such attacks and said economic and political sanctions should be tried first. A report issued Tuesday by a U.S. presidential commission said the United States should consider military strikes against air terrorists. Dr. Jim Swire, whose 24-year-old daughter was killed when Flight 103 blew up, said: ``We've always been against the idea of military action in response to Lockerbie because we didn't feel that we wanted families in the Middle East to be put in the same position as we're in, that's to say losing those they loved through murder, whether it's organized on a military basis or not.'' Swire spoke to reporters before the report was released in the United States. He is the head of an organization representing families of British victims of the 1988 bombing over Lockerbie, Scotland. His daughter, Flora, was among the 270 people killed. ``Military action should be the last resort, but other forms of pressure have not yet been tried,'' Swire said. The U.S. commission asked the United States to consider military strikes against air terrorists and conduct covert operations if direct action is not possible. The Lockerbie bombing is believed to have been a revenge attack for the July 1988 U.S. downing of an Iranian plane in which 290 people died. The United States said the attack was an accident and offered to pay compensation to Iran. Swire said Syria, Iran and other countries known to harbor terrorists could be forced to cease their activities if the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union would apply pressure. ``They should withhold economic and military exchanges until Syria ejects all terrorist groups,'' he said. Instead, he said, ``America is behaving in a very friendly fashion to Iran and Syria, partly because it wants its hostages back and partly because they want continuing supplies of Mideast oil.'' There are six Americans held hostage in Lebanon, mostly by pro-Iranian groups. Swire condemned the British government for not conducting an inquiry into the Lockerbie incident similar to the one by the U.S. commission. A police investigation into the bombing is under way. The government says no other inquries will be conducted until the police complete their work.

DOC.HEAD: Demjanjuk Attorney Assails Photo Lineups, Judges
