DOC.TEXT: An attorney for retired Ohio autoworker John Demjanjuk on Tuesday challenged the accuracy of photo lineups used to identify his client as a sadistic death camp guard and sentence him to death for Nazi war crimes. Demjanjuk's Israeli defense attorney, Yoram Sheftel, also accused the trial's three judges of failing to halt a spate of negative press coverage and said some of the articles published were tantamount to ``bloodletting.'' The Ukrainian-born Demjanjuk, 70, was pronounced guilty in April 1988 of crimes against humanity after he was identified as a cruel guard known as ``Ivan the Terrible'' at the Treblinka death camp in Poland. More than 850,000 Jews were slaughtered at the camp during World War II. Demjanjuk, who was extradited from Cleveland in February 1986, claims he is the victim of mistaken identity. He said he was captured while serving in the Soviet army and spent the period in question in a German prisoner-of-war camp. On Tuesday, Sheftel challenged two key photograph lineups used to help eight Treblinka survivors identify Demjanjuk as the notorious camp guard. One lineup contains the 1951 picture Demjanjuk used on his application for a U.S. immigration visa. The other picture is from a 1942 identity card the Soviet Union supplied to Israel. It is purported to be from the Trawniki camp in Poland, which trained death camp guards. Sheftel said Demjanjuk was never called for an in-person lineup, despite Israeli and U.S. rulings saying a suspect should participate in person in criminal indentification procedures. Sheftel also said none of the head shots resembled the accused. He said the hair color, shape and size of faces were clearly different. ``It is like putting a photograph of a black suspect among seven white men. Where have you heard of such a thing?'' Sheftel said. Sheftel also noted one of the lineups was deemed inadmissible by the U.S. Southern District Court in Florida in 1978 in a case involving another accused war criminal, Feodor Fedorenko. Demjanjuk's picture appeared alongside Fedorenko's in the display. The U.S. court ruled Fedorenko's picture was ``impermissively suggestive,'' because it was larger and clearer than the others, Sheftel said. ``There's no doubt that Demjanjuk's photograph is 10 times more impermissively suggestive,'' Sheftel added. ``But this court never bothered to rule on whether this picture was suggestive.'' Sheftel also accused the judges of bias. He said Chief Justice Dov Levine told the Cleveland Plain Dealer in an interview published in May 1988 that ``innocence must be proven.'' He noted this contradicted the legal principle that a suspect is innocent unless proven guilty. Sheftel also crticized the judges for the emotional atmosphere surrounding the federal trial. He cited the Dec. 1, 1988, incident in which a Holocaust survivor threw acid in his face at a funeral, injuring an eye. Sheftel, who still wears dark glasses because of the attack, said it followed a series of inciteful press accounts of the trial. He cited an article that questioned his credibility and Jewishness for defending an alleged Nazi war criminal. ``This was a bloodletting report,'' Sheftel said. But, he added, ``the court didn't intercede or say anything.'' Demjanjuk, wearing a brown prison uniform, listened intently to a Ukrainian traslation of the proceedings. His wife Vera and son John Jr. also watched. John Jr. said he believes his father will only walk free if the judges ``have the courage to make a decision based on the facts and the law.''

DOC.HEAD: Feds Reformulate Maternal, Child Health Agency
DOC.TEXT: Federal health officials Tuesday announced the formation of a new agency to highlight efforts to improve the health of mothers and children. In the change, the Department of Health and Human Services abolished the Bureau of Maternal and Child Health and Resources Development and divided its functions among two new bureaus. Creating the Maternal and Child Health Bureau ``should strengthen the visibility of federal programs addressing the special health care and related needs of mothers and children,'' said HHS Secretary Louis Sullivan. Of particular concern, Sullivan said, is the country's ``unacceptably high infant mortality rate.'' The United States ranks 20th among industrialized nations in infant deaths, according to the National Commission to Prevent Infant Mortality. The restructuring also creates a new Bureau of Health Resources Development to administer the rest of the programs in the old bureau, including organ transplantation and some AIDS programs.

DOC.HEAD: Former Ugandan Vice President to Stand Trial
DOC.TEXT: Former Ugandan Vice President Paulo Muwanga, who has been detained on various charges for nearly three years, was ordered Tuesday to stand trial on charges of interfering with the law. The date for Paulo Muwanga's trial before Uganda's High Court will be announced later, said Kampala's chief magistrate, Edward Bamwite. Muwanga asked the magistrate for a speedy trial, arguing his continued detention violated his human rights. Muwanga was a vice president in the government of President Milton Obote, who was overthrown in a military coup in August 1985. He was arrested the following year when President Yoweri Museveni chased from office the generals who had ousted Obote six months earlier. The 69-year-old politician was initially charged with treason, but the state withdrew the case for lack of evidence. Muwanga remained in custody, charged with kidnapping with intent to murder, but was eventually acquitted. He is now charged with the illegally releasing a prisoner while serving as vice president. That case has yet to be heard in court and carries a penalty of five years' imprisonment. Ugandan law requires that a magistrate first hear all criminal cases to determine if they should proceed to the High Court.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms And Too Much Rain
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms battered parts of Missouri and Kansas with heavy rain, hail and high wind Tuesday, causing scattered lowland flooding that closed streets, and rain later fell over much of the Plains and into the Ohio Valley. As much as 7 inches of rain fell overnight at Elgin in extreme southeastern Kansas. Cars were washed from flooded roadways during the morning near Emporia, Kan., and there was local flooding near Concordia, Kan. There were a large number of reports of flooding in and around Kansas City, Mo. ``We're soaked pretty good now,'' said Lyon County, Kan., Emergency Preparedness coordinator Steve Davis, who was watching the Neosho and Cottonwood rivers. ``If we get more, it could be bad. The rivers will rise.'' From midnight until mid-afternoon, thunderstorms produced three-quarter-inch diameter hail near Springfield, Mo.; hail an inch thick at Stover, Mo., and near Norton, Kan., and Colby, Kan.; and hail as big as golf balls near Hutchinson, Kan., and Independence, Mo., the National Weather Service said. Three tornadoes were reported in a thunderstorm over Kansas that hit the Coffeyville and Caney area heavy rain, high wind and brilliant lightning. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT included 3.42 inches at Grandview, Mo.; 2.27 inches at Sedalia, Mo.; and 1.72 inches at Kansas City, Mo. Students at schools in Easton, Kan., were sent home early as Stranger Creek, notorious for flooding, began rising. The river was 2 feet above flood stage by noon. At midday, showers and thunderstorms extended from northern Oklahoma across southeastern and east-central Kansas, central and northern Missouri, southeastern Iowa, southern and central Illinois, Indiana, north-central Kentucky, western Ohio, northwest Iowa, southwestern Minnesota, central and northeastern Nebraska, eastern and north-central South Dakota and western North Dakota. In Kentucky, a report of a funnel cloud over Fort Knox prompted the closure of the military base's aircraft control tower, but no tornado was confirmed. The weather service said a severe thunderstorm in Meade County knocked down trees and power lines; the Meade County Sheriff's Department reported no serious damage. Elsewhere, showers were scattered over northern and central Florida, and from northeastern New York state across central New England. Snow showers were scattered over the mountains of central Montana, changing to rain over western and south-central Montana. snow showers also continued in the northern mountains of Colorado. Boise, Idaho, had a record low of 28 degrees. Tuesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 23 at Truckee, Calif. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 36 at Bozeman, Mont., to 96 at Midland and Wink, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Chad Troops Kill 17, Burn Villages Before Withdrawing from Sudan
DOC.TEXT: Government troops from Chad in pursuit of Chadian rebels killed 17 people and burned down 18 villages in western Sudan before withdrawing from the area, Sudanese officials said Tuesday. Gen. Tiganni Adam al-Tahir, a member of the 15-man ruling military junta, told the official Sudan News Agency Chadian troops that crossed into Sudan's Darfur region last week in pursuit of Libyan-backed Chadian rebels have pulled out of the area but did not say when or give any further details. SUNA said al-Tahir made the statement following a meeting in Khartoum, the Sudanese capital, with a delegation from Darfur. The statement said without elaboration that the Sudanese government would compensate those affected by the Chadian raid. A government statement had earlier demanded compensation from Chad. Ibrahim Idris, head of the Darfur delegation that met al-Tahir, told The Associated Press that Chadian troops torched 18 villages north of Kutum, killed 17 people and kidnapped eight others. The New Horizon, a government English-language weekly, said Monday that 3,000 Chadian troops broke into a hospital and killed and wounded rebel Chadians in Kutum, 150 miles inside Sudan. The Chadian troops had chased rebels across their country's eastern border. ``The wounded men of the opposition were arrested inside the (Kutum) hospital by the Chadian government troops and were executed,'' the paper said. It did not specify how many were killed or when the incident happened. Earlier reports alleged major Chadian troop incursions last week. The newspaper report was the latest in a series of incidents involving Chadian troops and Libyan-backed Chadian rebels in western Sudan following a failed coup attempt in April 1989. The Khartoum government said Saturday that Chadian government troops abducted an unspecified number of Libyan and Sudanese citizens during a raid on western Sudan and called for their release. The New Horizon, however, said the abducted included 10 Libyans and six Sudanese. Chad admitted that incident but said the people kidnapped were Libyan agents on a resupply mission to anti-Chadian rebel missions in Sudan. Libya protested the incident, saying the kidnapped people were Libyan merchants. Sudan's government said it is willing to maintain good relations with its western neighbor but expressed determination to exercise sovereignty over all Sudan, including the desolate and lawless western region of Darfur. The government has virtually no control over Darfur and other frontier areas, which have been used as a base of operations by Chadian rebels and the government in N'djamena. Gen. Hassan Abdul-Rahman, Sudan's deputy chief of staff, told SUNA that Sudan has opted for peaceful means although its army was ``capable of containing the situation.'' Sudan's strongman Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir, who is touring the area, said his government would soon sign a non-aggression and good neighbor pact with Chad similar to one it concluded with Uganda last year. The agreement with Uganda, among other things, calls for extradition of dissidents.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Conclude Some Premature Babies Should Not Be Saved
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Ernle is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Doctors must realize it is often better to let extremely small premature babies die, despite fears of lawsuits or outcries from lobbyists, two researchers say. Medical costs nearing $160,000 per infant and the chance that surviving babies will suffer lifelong health problems led to the conclusion by Dr. David K. Stevenson and Ernle W.D. Young, both of Stanford University. The researchers, writing in the May issue of American Journal of Diseases of Children, said an estimated $2.6 billion annually is spent on neonatal intensive care in the United States. The life-saving efforts result in an average hospital stay of 137 days, at an average cost of $158,800 per infant, the study said. Stevenson and Young said it would be more cost-effective to address ``the root causes of prematurity _ lack of prenatal care, poor nutrition in pregnant women, homelessness, and drug or alcohol addiction.'' But doctors often feel pressured to order aggressive therapy for babies even when the treatment may not be beneficial, the researchers said. ``In part, this is due to the way in which fear of litigation causes medicine to be practiced in a defensive manner in this country,'' they wrote. Special interest groups also may influence doctors' decisions, the article said. ``We appear to have a more vigorous `pro-life' lobby in this country than is evident in either Sweden or Britain,'' they wrote. The researchers said a 1984 study found that the per-capita incidence of extremely premature, underweight infants in Great Britain and Sweden ``was impressively lower than in the United States. Stevenson is a professor of pediatrics at Stanford University Medical Center. Young is a Stanford professor of pediatrics and related ethical issues who also serves as co-director of the school's Center for Biomedical Ethics. Taking issue with the researchers was Dr. Thomas G. Storch, an associate editor of the journal and a member of its editorial board. In an accompanying editorial, he wrote that the technology to achieve good results with the very small infants ``is well within our grasp.'' ``Money should not be a consideration,'' Storch said Tuesday in a telephone interview. ``There is money out there, and we as pediatricians need to become spokesmen to get the money out there rather than throw in the towel and start rationing health care,'' he said. Stevenson and Young said the costs of treating extremely underweight premature babies _ those weighing less than two pounds _ do not take into account the lifelong costs of caring for any resulting disabilities. ``The effects of erring on the side of life are as follows: we save some who would otherwise have died; we do immediate harm and inflict long-term suffering on many who survive; and we expend an enormous amount of money on neonatal intensive care,'' the researchers wrote. They said the decision should be made solely by doctors and parents. ``Once physicians and parents, together, have collaboratively agreed to a strategy for treatment or non-treatment, this ought not to be subject to arbitrary veto by interested third parties, whether pro-life lobbyists or federal bureaucrats.'' In making such decisions doctors must ``confront the inescapable fact that ours is an era of shrinking resources, and ask whether setting limits is not both necessary and inevitable.'' They noted that two respected ethics writers already have advocated ``a rationing of heroic, intensive care for the elderly.'' ``It seems to be only a matter of time before the threshold of eligibility for very costly, high-technology intensive care for the very-low-birth-weight, extremely premature infant will be raised,'' Stevenson and Young wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Still Angry, Victims' Relatives Meet With Bush
With AM-Air Terrorism, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Eight-year-old Elizabeth Marengo lit a candle Tuesday for her father. ``Just for hope,'' said the girl, one of about 200 relatives of victims of the Pan Am 103 bombing who gathered to hear a presidential commission report on how their government had failed them. Still angry over events before and after the terrorist attack, the relatives met with the president and received folded American flags along with official answers they had long sought about the deaths of 270 people on Dec. 21, 1988. ``I just hope this gets President Bush to do something,'' said Kathy Daniels, whose husband, William, was one of the Pan Am 103 victims. ``My fear is that President Bush will put this in a drawer and forget about it,'' said Susan Cohen, who lost her only daughter, 20-year-old Theodora. Relatives of the victims have worked as a group since shortly after the plane blew up over Lockerbie, Scotland. They have bitterly criticized the government for not warning their loved ones of threats that preceded the bombing, and they have been let down since by what they call a government insensitive to their concerns. The relatives said the report, released Tuesday by the President's Commission on Aviation Security and Terrorism, bore out their worst fears about what had happened. They praised the call for change. ``I think the American public, particularly the American traveler, should be outraged'' at the commission's findings, said Victoria Cummock, of Coral Gables, Fla., whose husband, John, died in the explosion. They praised portions of the report calling for warnings to passengers of ``credible'' threats against flights, and many expressed satisfaction at the call for preparations for retaliation against terrorists. ``For many of us, this has been the most satisfying day since Dec. 21, 1988,'' said Bert Ammerman, head of one of the two formal relatives' groups. Ammerman's brother Thomas died on the flight. Many of the relatives went from the White House meeting with Bush to the news conference releasing the report. Almost all wore buttons _ ``Iran Killed Them,'' some said _ and many had pictures of their loved ones pinned to their chest. Some bowed their heads and cried softly as commission Chairman Ann McLaughlin methodically ticked off the findings of bureaucratic failures and described the recommendations. ``There's still a tremendous wound, said Maria Marengo, the mother of three by her late husband, Louis. ``This does not close it.'' Her daughter, Elizabeth, lit one of the three candles the relatives said will burn at Washington's Shrine of the Immaculate Conception in memory of the victims. The candles were labeled ``Justice, Security, Warning,'' _ the three themes the families have stressed. Although they felt vindicated by the findings, the relatives expressed lingering bitterness that the government hasn't come out and said who committed the act and made an attempt to bring perpetrators to justice. ```We have seen since day one a political shell-game going on,'' said Ammerman, pointing to the British, German and American governments. ``There's no question in our minds that the intelligence community knows without a doubt who did this.'' It has been widely reported that investigators believe Iran initiated the act as retribution for the accidental downing in 1987 of a commercial Iranian airliner by the USS Vincennes in the Persian Gulf. The investigators believe the Syrian-based Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, General Command carried it out. ``I'm still very frustrated at the president,'' said Wendy Giebler, the widow of William Giebler. ``I want him (Bush) to make me proud to be an American again. He has the power to do that.''

DOC.HEAD: The White House Haul: From Cowboy Boots To Caviar
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and his wife received at least $26,839 worth of personal gifts last year, from three small tins of caviar to a $995 pair of cowboy boots, the White House disclosed Tuesday. Among the gifts: a box of glass Christmas ornaments and tinsel from the communist president of the U.S.S.R. Vice President Dan Quayle and his wife Marilyn did nearly as well, collecting $23,014 in personal presents, including a pair of hunting knives worth $2,750 and an inaugural medal and charm valued at $3,595. The booty was listed on disclosure forms that all top government executives are required to fill out each year. Not all of the gifts wound up in the presidential closet or attic. Some were doled out to Bush's family and friends, including 11 pairs of boots a Texan sent for the Bush grandchildren. The most expensive Bush gifts were four evening bags valued at $3,102 that Mrs. Bush received from a New York designer, Judith Leiber. The president's haul included a $288 set of baseball cards from Hall of Famer Stan Musial and Edward Stack of Cooperstown, N.Y. The ``three small tins of caviar'' came from Herbert S. Hoffman of Boston and were valued at $255. Bill Humble of Little Rock, Ark., gave Bush 22 neckties worth $396. The disclosure form said Bush's blind trust grew in value in 1989 to $1.28 million million from $998,000. It said the president's home in Kennebunkport, Maine, is worth $892,000 and a lot in Houston worth $81,000. The Bushes have $34,000 in various bank accounts, $32,500 in retirement accounts, and life insurance policies with a cash value of $39,000. They have no mortgage. Their only liabilities are three 5 percent loans totaling $49,000 against their life insurance policies. Bush reported assets totaling $2,352,500 and liabilities of only $49,000. Although Bush lists the value of the Maine home at the $892,000 established by local tax officials, some real estate authorities say it would fetch $3 million to $5 million on the current market. Most of the president's assets were in his blind trust and the seaside home in Kennebunkport. The Aga Khan gave Bush two neckties and a watch worth $300. From designer Ralph Lauren came a $455 sweater. Golfer Lee Trevino's $466 worth of gifts included 11 golf shirts, two caps, one club and six instructional videotapes. Presidential pooch Millie shared in the largesse, including a gingerbread-style Christmas doghouse made from dog biscuits that was valued at $100. It came from public relations executive Robert Gray. The president was required to hand over to the State Department all official gifts worth more than $180 from foreigners _ with some exceptions. He can keep gifts deemed personal presents from friends, as he did with the Aga Khan's neckties and watch. He can keep gifts from Americans of any value but has to report any gifts from a single source totaling $100 or more. The disclosure form did not list the gifts totaling less than $100 that the Bushes kept. It also did not catalogue the gifts the Bushes handed over to the government. ``The president gives away a lot of these gifts,'' said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Included in the presidential gifts were: _A sweatshirt, jogging shoes and tennis shoes from tennis star Bjorn Bjorg: $150. _A pair of ``We the People'' cufflinks from retired Chief Justice Warren Burger, as well as 25 books about the Constitution for the Bush grandchildren: $245. _A $995 pair of cowboy boots from Houston bootmaker Rocky Carroll. _A $100 sterling silver box from Italian President Francesco Cossiga. _Some $331 worth of Mickey and Minnie Mouse dolls and statues from Disney executive Michael Eisner and others. _A $75 shawl for Mrs. Bush from the Gorbachevs, in addition to the $125 worth of children's books and Christmas ornaments. _A pair of boots for Bush and 11 pairs for his grandchildren from Steve Pickens of Nocona, Texas: $700. _A $125 wooden Santa Claus statue from Bety McBee of Dallas. _A cup and saucer worth $800 for Mrs. Bush from Happy Rockefeller, widow of the late vice president. _Two pieces of luggage and a basket for Millie from entertainment mogul Jerry Weintraub of Malibu, Calif.: $725. The gifts to the Quayles included: $1,591 in Izod shorts and slacks from Izod executive Charles J. Smith; a $750 Indy 500 racing helmet from Bill Marvel, an official of the race, which Quayle started last Memorial Day; 10 pairs of ``No Excuses'' bluejeans worth $260; framed letters of Indiana vice presidents worth $1,900, from Jack Smith of South Bend, Ind.; and $1,271 worth of golf equipment from the Ben Hogan Co. Quayle's hunting knives were a gift grom Gilber tHibben of Hibben Enterprises in Louisville. Quayle spokesman David Beckwith said, ``Some of (the gifts) have been given away, either to charity or staff or friends.'' Bush and Quayle do not have to pay taxes on the gifts they keep. Quayle, scion of an Indiana publishing family, listed assets ranging from at least $691,004 to $1,045,000 or more. His tax return, released last month, showed interest and dividend income of $16,430, primarily from stock holdings in Central Newspapers Inc. The Quayles' only liability was the mortgage on their home in McLean, Va., which they rent out. The mortgage is between $100,001 to $250,000. They paid off a promissory note of uner $50,000 to the Huntington Newspapers on Feb. 28, 1990.

DOC.HEAD: George Hamilton Says Imelda Saved His Mother's Life
DOC.TEXT: Actor George Hamilton, testifying Tuesday at Imelda Marcos' fraud trial, said the former Philippines first lady was a ``great friend'' who prevented his mother from committing suicide after his brother's death. ``I think the only reason my mother is alive is because of Mrs. Marcos,'' Hamilton said, his voice breaking with emotion. Hamilton said his mother was so distraught when his brother died of liver and kidney malfunctions that she wanted to commit suicide, but that Mrs. Marcos saved her by inviting her to visit the Philippines. The actor was compelled to testify for the prosecution after being subpoenaed and granted immunity. Hamilton said he sought immunity on advice of his attorneys. Under cross-examination by Mrs. Marcos' defense attorney, Gerry Spence, Hamilton described Mrs. Marcos' kindness to his family and called her ``a great friend of my family and mine.'' Mrs. Marcos, 60, is accused of helping her late husband, former Philippines president Ferdinand E. Marcos, embezzle more than $220 million from their country's treasury to secretly buy four New York properties and artwork. She is charged with racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. Hamilton's testimony for the prosecution dealt with a $5.5 million loan he received in 1983 from Gliceria Tantoco, a friend of Mrs. Marcos who owned Rustans department store in Manila. Mrs. Tantoco was charged along with Mrs. Marcos but is a fugitive. Prosecutors have said Mrs. Tantoco acted as an agent for the Marcoses in the purchase of the New York real estate. Hamilton described the loan as an advance on a contract with Mrs. Tantoco under which he would produce films in the Philippines, including one about Gen. Douglas MacArthur. He said he returned the money to Mrs. Tantoco about eight months later when the deal fell through because of concerns about how the MacArthur movie would affect MacArthur's widow. ``I was able to use a portion of the money for expenses but ultimately paid it all back,'' he said. Hamilton testified that part of the money he returned to Mrs. Tantoco came from another $6 million loan, whose source was not revealed. The actor said he met Mrs. Tantoco in 1979 during a world tour to promote his comedy film, ``Love at First Bite,'' in which he played a vampire. He met Mrs. Marcos through Mrs. Tantoco, he said. Hamilton said he never discussed business with Mrs. Marcos and described their relationship as ``social and great friendship during a crisis.'' Although Hamilton's testimony was expected, his presence late in the afternoon caused a stir in the crowded courtroom in Manhattan's federal court. The tanned actor appeared at ease during his 50 minutes on the witness stand, except for briefly when he spoke of his brother. At one point when the attorneys were discussing a legal point outside the hearing of the jury, Hamilton smiled and waved to a spectator he recognized. He occasionally looked at Mrs. Marcos, but she appeared to avoid making eye contact with him.

DOC.HEAD: Congressmen Call For Federal Assistance In Delta Region
DOC.TEXT: Eight million Americans living like Third World residents along the Mississippi River need attention from the government now, deficit or no deficit, members of Congress said Tuesday. ``We can't use the budget deficit as an excuse for inaction,'' Sen. Dale Bumpers, D-Ark., said at a news conference announcing the findings of the Lower Mississippi Delta Development Commission. Bumpers, one of the powers behind the commission, said the poverty of the region must be addressed cooperatively by the states involved and the federal government. Commission member John Shepherd said health care in the region is worse than some Third World countries. ``If they weren't Americans, the World Bank would come to their aid,'' he said. Shepherd said the kind of attention that has been given to poverty in the Eastern mountain area through the Appalachian Regional Commission ought now be given to the Delta. While the commission's report recommends activities that can help the region without extensive federal spending, Bumpers and others pointed out that the government demonstrates daily it can find money when necessary. ``We spent $5 billion last year for one hurricane that spent 24 hours in the Carolinas,'' Bumpers said. ``If we can spend $50 billion bailing out the S&L's, if we can talk about putting a man on Mars, if can give aid to Eastern Europe, we ought to think about our own people,'' said Arkansas Gov. Bill Clinton, chairman of the commission. ``We're voting this week on $1 billion in foreign aid to strengthen democracies,'' Rep. Mike Espy, D-Miss., said in reference to money going mostly to Panama and Nicaragua. ``I know a region already a democracy that's yearning to be merged.'' Espy said the groundwork already was being laid in the House to carry out recommendations from the commission. ``We are anxious to get started,'' he said of a group of congressmen representing the lower Mississippi area. ``We are positioned across the panorama of congressional committees.'' A hearing on the report has been scheduled for Wednesday by subcommittees of the House Public Works and Transportation and Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs committees. The commission spent 18 months studying the problems of the poorest region in the United States and developed a 10-year economic development plan. The area includes 219 counties in Arkansas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Missouri, Illinois, Tennessee and Kentucky. The commission's 186-page report was touted as a ``handbook for action'' by its authors. It offers specific recommendations for improving health, education, housing, community development, agriculture, natural resources, utilities, roads, business opportunities and tourism. For example, the region is one of the most naturally rich agricultural areas of the country but has experienced setbacks due to the trend away from family farming and technological changes that displace workers. The report suggests specific action that can be addressed by the federal government, states, educational institutions or agribusiness to revitalize that part of the region's economy.

DOC.HEAD: Parents Ask Publicity for Vaccine Compensation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf: ``Hugo estimated,'' with two grafs bgng: ``The program to clarify, add balancing estimate on injuries and note that DTP vaccine is also known as DPT
DOC.TEXT: A Boston lawyer and a parents' group asked a federal court Tuesday to force federal health officials to publicize a compensation program for vaccine-related injuries. Attorney Michael Hugo and Dissatisfied Parents Together, a group of parents whose children have been injured or killed by vaccines, say the federal government has failed to get word of the program to other parents. Hugo, a Boston lawyer who represents people injured by vaccines, and the parents' group asked the U.S. District Court to order the Department of Health and Human Services to put out information about the program in public service announcements to television and radio stations, in fliers mailed with Social Security notices and in ads in major newspapers. Of particular concern is an Oct. 1 deadline for claims to be filed for children injured by vaccinations before Oct. 1, 1988. But Robert Harmon, head of the Health Resources and Services Administration, the arm of the department overseeing the program, said, ``We feel that reasonable efforts to publicize the program have occurred.'' Harmon said officials have conducted press interviews, printed articles in the Health Resources and Services Administration's weekly newsletter, notified national and all state bar associations and sent information to professional organizations, journals and newsletters. Also, the agency plans to have a toll-free hotline working by the end of the week, he said. As of May 11, the National Vaccine Injury Compensation Program had paid $32 million in 62 cases. The program is financed by an excise tax on the sale of vaccines and congressional appropriations. The program covers injuries from vaccines protecting against diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis or whooping cough, measles, mumps, rubella and polio. Hugo estimated that up to 40,000 children have serious though not necessarily permanent reactions to the vaccine for diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis, called DTP or sometimes DPT. But Kenneth Bart, deputy director of the Vaccine Injury Compensation Program, said serious injuries from childhood immunizations are rare and that Hugo's estimate was far too high. Dissatisfied Parents Together, in a separate action Tuesday, asked Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan to withdraw financing for a vaccine study because of an alleged conflict of interest involving a member of the study committee. The group says Dr. Marie Griffin, a member of the committee appointed by the Institute of Medicine, receives financial support from Burroughs Wellcome, one of the leading makers of the pertussis vaccine. The panel is reviewing medical evidence on possible adverse reactions to the pertussis and rubella vaccines, including brain damage and death. In a statement, the institute said the Burroughs Wellcome Scholar Award that Griffin received does not pose a conflict of interest. The grant program is administered by the American College of Preventive Medicine and money for it comes from the Burroughs Wellcome Fund, a nonprofit foundation, the institute said. Griffin, who is on leave from her job at Vanderbilt University School of Medicine, was attending an out-of-town conference and could not be reached for comment, her secretary said. About a month after the committee began its work in January, one member was removed from the panel because of a conflict of interest. Dr. Floyd Denny, a pediatrics professor at the University of North Carolina, had testified on behalf of a physician in a malpractice case involving the pertussis vaccine.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Protest Hearing Held in DC as Atlanta Demonstrators Defy Ban
DOC.TEXT: Anti-abortion activists from Operation Rescue should be found in contempt of court for blockading medical clinics in the District of Columbia, abortion-rights proponents told a federal judge Tuesday. The arguments came as five members of Operation Rescue defied a U.S. Supreme Court ban on protests within 50 feet of Atlanta abortion clinics, chaining themselves together inside the Atlanta Surgi-Center. Police and firefighters pried the protesters loose from clinic property before arresting them Tuesday, but two were still chained at the feet and neck when carried to jail. They were held on charges of criminal trespass. In U.S. District Court in Washington, pro-abortion advocates from the National Organization for Women and other groups testified that Operation Rescue members violated a court order in November that prohibited them from blocking entrances to clinics in the District of Columbia. U.S. District Court Judge Louis Oberdorfer issued the preliminary injunction Nov. 8 in a lawsuit filed by NOW and Planned Parenthood that anticipated Operation Rescue protests in the District. More than 700 protesters were arrested in one day of demonstrations in November on charges of violating a new District of Columbia law barring them from gathering within 100 feet of an abortion clinic. At a day-long hearing, witnesses said they had seen Patrick Mahoney of Boca Raton, Fla., and other members of Operation Rescue direct demonstrators to trespass on the property of clinics. John Bates, who assisted the abortion-rights groups, testified that Mahoney directed the actions of the protesters sitting within 40 feet of the back and front doors of a clinic in the Nov. 17 demonstrations. Under questioning by Mahoney, Bates said he hadn't seen Mahoney cross the police line. Bates said he saw Mahoney give media interviews, but couldn't recall precisely what he said. Operation Rescue spent ``well in excess of $50,000 and maybe well more than $100,000'' on the November protests, said Larry Eisenstein, who represents NOW and Planned Parenthood. Eisenstein said 1989 donations exceeded $700,000 and that $1.1 million was deposited in bank accounts. Eisenstein asked that Operation Rescue and its leaders be fined ``a large enough figure to deter them from returning in the future.'' Operation Rescue contends it is in debt. In Atlanta, Operation Rescue spokeswoman Jane Shepherd denied that Tuesday's protest was in response to the Supreme Court decision to prohibit the anti-abortion group from protesting within 50 feet of any Atlanta abortion clinic. She acknowledged, however, that it violated that ban. ``When we do a rescue in the city, it does not matter whether there's an injunction or not,'' she said. Clinic director Beth Petzelt said protesters pushed their way into the clinic about 8:30 a.m. as patients were being admitted and then scuffled with the four or five staff members who tried to keep them out. Some demonstrators sat in the waiting room singing hymns, Ms. Petzelt said, while the five men went to the back and chained themselves together, fastening the chains with half-inch-thick steel locks. They attached some of the chains to door hinges or knobs, but were not able to enter the clinic's operating and recovery rooms, she said. Seven other protesters quietly demonstrated on a sidewalk across the five-lane street from the clinic. They appeared to be outside the 50-foot limit and were not arrested. Monday's Supreme Court decision came on Operation Rescue's emergency appeal of the lower court ruling. The appeal was rejected on a 5-4 vote. Operation Rescue members said the injunction violated their free speech rights.

DOC.HEAD: Nintendo Gives MIT $3 Million to Make Games More Educational
DOC.TEXT: The nimble little Nintendo men who dodge bad guys to rescue the princess now have a bigger prize to capture: the approval of wary parents exhausted by the video game craze. As an inducement, the Japanese toymaker has given $3 million to the Media Lab at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for its ongoing research into how children can learn while they play, the school announced Tuesday. The gift to establish the Nintendo Fund will back the work of Seymour Papert, a mathematician and pioneer in artificial intelligence who directs learning research at the Media Lab. Making more-educational models of Nintendo could ease parents' worries about the intense attraction the games hold for their children and a tendency to dismiss them as useless diversions. ``Kids do just love (Nintendo),'' said Gordon Cawelti of the Association for Supervision and Curriculum Development in Alexandria, Va., which examines the use of computers in education. ``But they consume an enormous amount of time. Something like Nintendo is captivating but not very educating, and it's addicting.'' What underlies Papert's approach to work-plus-play equals learning is a phrase he learned from children, Papert said in an interview: ``Children say: `I like that because it's hard fun.''' ``Fun does not have to be easy. Real play can be painful, but it also has this element of fun and engagement and it's something you want to do.'' ``One of the criticisms of school I've made is that it's not connected to children's real lives, what they're really interested in.'' Papert is widely known for his invention of a computer language called Logo. Used in about a third of the country's elementary schools, Logo lets children program computers. The new grant does not require MIT researchers to devise new Nintendo games, though Papert did not rule out the possibility. Nintendo games already are played in 40 million homes worldwide, half of them in the United States. With an estimated 90 percent of children of video-game age playing Nintendo, the market seems about saturated. A new angle could boost sales. But so far, intentionally educational software for kids doesn't seem to sell as well as the sort regarded as pure fun. Educational software rang up sales of about $350 million last year, compared with $3.5 billion in video games. Video games are to computer technology what soap operas are to drama, Cawelti said: ``Power-gripping soap operas have no theatrical merit, but they could have.'' But Papert believes video games already teach children about learning, about complex systems and strategy and about communicating with others. ``Parents need to be reeducated to think that fun is the most important element of good learning,'' he said. Papert wants the new research to expand on the use of video games to teach children about their physical and social environment. ``I'm not against books, but computers open up new routes into these subject matters,'' he said. Spokespeople at Nintendo's U.S. offices in Redmont, Wash., were away for the day Tuesday and other officials said they could not comment. Nintendo is headquartered in Kyoto, Japan. In a statement released by MIT, Nintendo President Hiroshi Yamauchi said, ``We have long felt that we ... owe a responsibility to develop our hard- and software to enhance the educational opportunities through our machines. I am confident ... this program will contribute to a smarter generation than ever existed before.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Hiding in Furniture Truck Shoot on Crowd, Kill Two
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 8-9 `Police said... black groups' to clarify. Pickup 10th pvs, `The black...'
DOC.TEXT: Police hiding in a furniture truck opened fire on a crowd of black stone-throwers Tuesday, killing two, a spokesman for a human rights group said. Police confirmed the deaths and said five other blacks were killed Monday and Tuesday in factional fighting. The dead included three blacks who were burned to death, one stabbed with a spear and one black policeman killed by unknown assailants with automatic rifles. Police spokesman Maj. Reg Crewe said a police patrol in the black township of Maokeng, south of Johannesburg, began shooting when blacks in a crowd of 1,000 protesters threw stones and a gasoline bomb at the vehicle. He confirmed police were patrolling in a private vehicle, but gave no further details. A spokesman for the Detainees Parents Support Committee, Niza Makhete, said witnesses told him the police were hiding in a furniture truck and that several people were also injured in the incident. The incident was similar to the October 1985 ``Trojan Horse'' shootings in the mixed-race township of Athlone near Cape Town. In that case, police hid behind boxes in an unmarked freight truck. When the vehicle was attacked, police opened fire, killing three blacks, including a young child, and injuring several others. The African National Congress, the nation's most powerful black political organization, has accused police of using excessive violence in dealing with disturbances in black townships. The organization has also blamed police for firing at non-violent crowds of protestors. Police said Tuesday a 52-year-old black man and his 22-year-old daughter were locked in their hut and burned to death by a group of men in southern Natal. In the past few weeks almost 20 people have been burned to death as land and water feuds between black groups have escalated into power struggles between rival gangs and political groups. Police said another black man was burned to death in Pietermaritzburg, the capital of Natal province, when a gasoline-soaked tire was placed around his neck and set afire. This brutal method of killing, known as ``necklacing,'' is common among some black groups. The black policeman was killed in Crossroads township near Cape Town, and another man was stabbed to death with a spear in Ixopo township in Natal, police said. Police say almost 600 people have been killed in fighting between black factions since Jan. 1.

DOC.HEAD: South African President Flies to Belgium Seeking Support
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk of South Africa came to Belgium Tuesday on his European tour to seek support for his government's new racial policy. He confirmed he will soon visit the United States. Before leaving Lisbon, Portugal, de Klerk said he was not pleading for an end to Western economic sanctions on his white minority-dominated nation, but ``to bring about a fundamental reappraisal of the situation in South Africa and furnish full and unbiased information.'' ``It won't be a mission where South Africa says, `Please, we want sanctions lifted,''' de Klerk told a final news conference in the Portuguese capital on the third stop of a nine-nation European tour. He said the U.S. trip will have the same aims as the European swing. The 12 European Community countries have banned imports of iron, steel and gold coins from South Africa for more than three years and also banned new investments in South Africa. U.S. officials said Tuesday in Washington that de Klerk will meet President Bush on June 18 in the first official call by a South African president in more than 30 years. De Klerk said he could not confirm the date. Black South African opposition leader Nelson Mandela is due to arrive in the United States June 20, and officials of his African National Congress called the reported timing of the des to aid anti-government insurgents in the two countries, insisting, ``All our efforts are concerned with promoting reconciliation.'' Portuguese President Mario Soares joined de Klerk at Tuesday's news conference and praised his reform efforts, saying, ``We're convinced that the reforms are really under way, and we think the time has come to support the policies of President de Klerk.'' Soares said Portugal, ``has never been very enthusiastic about sanctions. ... We must show the EC sanctions applied to South Africa are no longer relevant.'' Since becoming president last September, de Klerk has released Mandela and some other anti-apartheid activists and legalized opposition groups, including the ANC. He met Mandela this month and reached broad agreement with the ANC to work to end political violence and prepare the way to black entry into government. De Klerk said Tuesday reforms would continue, but warned, ``Reform always carries with it the risk of destabilization.'' De Klerk was welcomed at Brussels airport by Development Aid Minister Andre Geens. He will be received by King Baudouin, meet with Belgian political and business leaders and have talks with Jacques Delors, president of the Brussels-based European Community. ``We will talk about the rising interest of the business community in South Africa,'' said Urbain Devoldere, president of the Belgian Employers Federation. About 250 people demonstrated elsewhere in Brussels for continued sanctions on South Africa. Anti-apartheid organizations announced a demonstration in front of EC headquarters Thursday. South Africa has 5 million whites, 28 million blacks, about 3 million people of mixed race, and 850,000 Asians and Indians. Apartheid establishes a racially segregated society in which South Africa's blacks have no vote in national afairs. The whites control the economy and maintain separate residential districts, schools and health services.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Seize Jungle Town, Free 35 Suspected Guerrillas, Rob Banks
DOC.TEXT: About 300 leftist rebels stormed the jungle town of Saposoa, freed 35 suspected guerrillas and drug traffickers and robbed its three banks, police said Tuesday. One civilian was killed by a stray bullet and two policemen were wounded in the ensuing three-hour battle between police and rebels belonging to the Cuban-inspired Tupac Amaru movement, police said. Ten policemen were also captured by the guerrillas and tried in a ``people's court'' in the main plaza of Saposoa. The 10, stripped to their underwear, were freed at the request of the townspeople. Saposoa is 60 miles southeast of Tarapoto, the biggest town in the Huallaga Valley, and 340 miles north of Lima. The 35 freed prisoners had been convicted of drug trafficking or guerrilla activities, police said. Two other prisoners, each with less than a month to serve, chose to stay behind in the jail. Police said the rebels had guns and carried five shoulder-held anti-aircraft missiles. Police and military in the region often use helicopter gunships in their battles with guerrillas and drug traffickers. Before leaving Saposoa, the rebels destroyed the police post and distributed 300 sacks of government rice to residents. The rebels also robbed the town's three banks, stole four trucks and headed south out of town, police said. The Tupac Amaru group began operating in Lima in 1984 and concentrated its attacks on U.S. installations and organizations they accused of exploitation of the poor. The rebels later began fighting in the Huallaga Valley, but were quickly suppressed by the army. Small columns have continued to operate in the jungle but have not carried out major attacks. The valley is the world's main source of coca leaves, the raw material for cocaine. The rebel group and the larger Maoist-inspired Shinning Path guerrillas receive weapons and money from drug dealers and in return allow them to operate freely in the region. In September the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration and the Peruvian police began operating an anti-drug airbase in the Huallaga Valley. The U.S. government is also seeking Peru's approval to set up a camp in the area to train Peruvian soldiers in anti-guerrilla warfare.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Independence Crowds Demonstrate in Latvia and Estonia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with details of encounters. Picks up 9th graf, `Aris Jansons' with minor editing to trim
DOC.TEXT: Soviet loyalists converged on the secessionist parliaments of Estonia and Latvia on Tuesday, and one Baltic premier broadcast an appeal to stave off a ``coup attempt'' as protesters raised the hammer-and-sickle flag over his office building. ``People, come here to save Estonia!'' Prime Minister Edgar Savisaar said in a Tallinn radio address as a crowd estimated at up to 6,000 took over parts of the Toompea Palace government building and a square outside. ``There is a coup attempt here,'' he said in the broadcast, monitored in Moscow and transcribed by the Estonian news agency ETA. Tallinn and the Latvian capital of Riga were described as peaceful Tuesday night, although Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze warned of ``anarchy'' in the Baltic states as he prepared for a round of meetings in Moscow with U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III. After Savisaar's evening broadcast, thousands of Tallinn residents rushed to the palace and hoisted the pre-Soviet blue, white and black banner that was raised last week when Parliament restored a 1937 independence charter. Pro-independence demonstrators formed two human chains through which Soviet loyalists were allowed to leave the area, ETA reported. Calm returned to the city by 7:50 p.m., Estonian reports said. Finnish television said pro-independence crowds guarded government broadcasting stations during the night to block any takeover attempt. Popular Front security guards were also assigned around the clock to other government buildings, ETA reported. ETA estimated the Moscow loyalists at 2,500, with a core of about 400 who tried to overturn a police truck in the palace courtyard. It put pro-independence forces at 3,000. Finnish TV estimated the anti-independence crowd at 5,000 to 6,000 and secessionist demonstrators at 20,000. The incident lasted two hours. A similar confrontation occurred in the Latvian capital of Riga, where for the second day whistling and jeering Soviet soldiers tried to muscle into the parliament building but were blocked by pro-independence crowds. About two dozen Interior Ministry troops, wielding truncheons, helped drive back the soldiers and their civilian supporters, said Ivars Embrekts, an American working at the Latvian parliament. Soviet helicopters scattered leaflets the day before, urging residents to storm the building. Aris Jansons, top aide to Latvian President Anatoly Gorbunov, said unarmed soldiers and military cadets aged 18-22 gathered outside the building of the Latvian Supreme Soviet, or parliament, and 100 yards away on another square. ``The whole street is full of people. ... thousands of people, and thanks only to special militia units has the situation normalized,'' Jansons said in a telephone interview. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis, in a radio interview broadcast as Secretary Baker flew to Moscow, appealed to the Americans to raise the issue of Baltic independence with Soviet leaders. The steep rise in tension came the day after Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev invoked new presidential powers to decree that Latvia and Estonia violated the Soviet constitution by declaring independence and that the declarations were invalid. One speaker at the Tallinn rally appealed to Gorbachev to declare direct presidential rule in Estonia, according to a report from the Estonian news service. It was not clear whether the anti-independence rallies were planned with Gorbachev's knowledge or were organized solely by pro-Moscow forces in the republics. Shevardnadze made ominous statements in an interview with CBS-TV. ``The right to self-determination has to be implimented within the framework of our constitution. If this principle is violated, then it will mean anarchy, I am sure,'' he said. ``The mistake of our friends in the Baltic republics is that first they decide and then they want dialogue ... but dialogue is necessary before a decision is passed.'' The Soviet parliament in March voted that Lithuania violated the constitution when its legislature declared immediate independence on March 11. Gorbachev imposed economic sanctions on Lithuania, blocking deliveries of oil and natural gas. Latvia declared May 4 that it was passing through a transition period to independence. Estonia had taken a similar step March 30. All three republics were independent until the Soviet Union annexed them in 1940. Second Secretary Vladislav Shved said the Lithuanian Communist Party faction loyal to Moscow planned anti-independence rallies Tuesday in factories in the capital of Vilnius, but managers and workers interviewed at two major plants said they knew nothing of such rallies. The state Tass news agency reported, however, that ``political actions were undertaken in organizations and businesses ... to demonstrate solidarity with the striking collectives in the Latvian Soviet Socialist Republic.'' Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene and President Landsbergis have said they are prepared to back away from immediate independence, but have been unable to open negotiations with Gorbachev. Mrs. Prunskiene said in an interview broadcast on central Soviet television that talks between Moscow and Vilnius ``should start immediately.'' Lithuanians has 3.7 million people; Latvia, 2.7 million, and Estonia, 1.6 million.

DOC.HEAD: Mubarak Meets Gorbachev in Moscow, Speaks of Soviet Jews Issue
DOC.TEXT: Hosni Mubarak met in the Kremlin on Tuesday with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. He was the first Egyptian president to visit the Soviet Union in 18 years. The two leaders signed a declaration ``laying the groundwork for developing relations between the two countries'' and an agreement for economic and scientific cooperation through the year 2000, the Soviet news agency tTass reported. Mubarak also told Gorbachev the Arab states were angered by the possibility the growing wave of Soviet Jews emigrating to Israel could be settled in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. ``Gorbachev declared he understood the serious nature of the problem, and informed (Mubarak) that the proper government agencies already have the task of resolving it, taking into account the deep concern of Arabs,'' Tass reported. Speaking at a dinner in Mubarak's honor, Gorbachev said influencing the emigrants to settle in the occupied territories ``amounts to dangerously and immorally playing with their fates,'' Tass reported. ``We also see it as infringing on the rights of the Palestinian people.'' Israel has been accused of encouraging Soviet Jews to move to the occupied territories. About 200 of the emigrants have settled in the occupied lands. Egypt's state-run Middle East News Agency reported from Moscow that Mubarak invited Gorbachev to visit Egypt. They said no date has been set for the visit. Mubarak was also scheduled to meet with Secretary of State James A. Baker III on Wednesday. Baker arrived Tuesday for talks that will precede the Washington summit meeting between Gorbachev and President Bush. Mubarak's predecessor, Anwar Sadat, was the last head of state to visit the Soviet Union. He came to Moscow in 1972 before relations soured over Soviet refusals to meet Egypt's arms requests.

DOC.HEAD: Shotgun Blasts at University Dorm Leave Two Dead, Fellow Student Arrested
DOC.TEXT: A Montana State University freshman described by a classmate as ``kind of different'' allegedly opened fire with a sawed-off shotgun inside his dormitory early Tuesday, killing two students. The motive for the early morning attack was unknown and investigators were not even sure the accused killer knew his victims, Police Chief Dick Boyer said. Brett D. Byers, 19, of Great Falls was arrested about 90 miles northwest of Bozeman after a highway chase and crash into a convenience store gas pump. He was charged in Helena Justice Court with two counts of deliberate homicide, felony criminal mischief and reckless driving. The teen-ager said nothing Tuesday morning as the charges were read. He was later returned to Bozeman. The shootings occurred shortly before 2:20 a.m. Tuesday in Langford Hall, an all-male dormitory. The two victims, James Clevenger, of Billings, Mont., and Brian Boeder, of Plymouth, Minn., both 19, died later at a Bozeman hospital. Some fellow students described Byers, a freshman majoring in business management, as overly quiet; others recalled him being sometimes oddly talkative. ``He talked too much, maybe,'' said Scott Adams, a dormitory resident. ``He was kind of different. He didn't have many friends.'' Shaken students and officials at the dormitory also said they did not know what might have provoked the shootings. ``It was the scariest experience I'll ever have in my entire life,'' said Jim Collins, director of the dormitory. ``It was so scattered and happened so fast. It was just so traumatic.'' The killings were the first ever on the 97-year-old campus, which has 10,000 students, Boyer said. Classes scheduled for Wednesday were canceled and a memorial service was planned, MSU Dean of Student Affairs John O'Connell said. The shootings occurred in Boeder's room on the first floor of the dormitory. Clevenger was staying in the room only because he had had ``some sort of a conflict'' with his regular roommate in the same dorm, Boyer said. Clevenger and Boeder were shot at close range with a sawed-off shotgun that had a home-made pistol grip, Boyer said, adding that the gun would be illegal if the barrel were one inch shorter. Lewis and Clark County Attorney Mike McGrath said Byers allegedly fired four shotgun blasts before fleeing. A witness identified Byers in the hallway after the shooting, McGrath said. Bozeman authorities obtained a description of Byers' vehicle and notified Helena authorities that Byers might be headed through there for Great Falls. Lewis and Clark County sheriff's deputies spotted Byers on U.S. Highway 12 several miles east of Helena about 4:50 a.m., Sheriff Chuck O'Reilly said. The suspect was arrested about two miles down the highway after he crashed through a highway fence and into a gas pump and a power pole at a Circle K convenience store, the sheriff said.

DOC.HEAD: Company Agrees To $3.5 Million Sex Discrimination Settlement
DOC.TEXT: A company has agreed to pay $3.5 million in back pay to women employees in what Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole on Tuesday called one of the largest equal-employment opportunity settlements in U.S. history. Precision Castparts Corp. of Portland will pay about 1,000 women ``who were steered into traditionally female jobs when they were hired,'' the Labor Department said in announcing the settlement Tuesday. The money will be paid to women who worked in hourly, non-clerical jobs at the company's plants in Portland at any time from 1978 through 1988, according to Roy Marvin, the company's vice president of administration. Precision Castparts, which manufactures jet engine parts and other metal components for the aerospace industry, will send notices to women eligible for benefits within 45 days, Marvin said. Women who do not receive notices within 45 days and who believe they are eligible should contact the Department of Labor, he said. The settlement is the result of a compliance review conducted by the Labor Department's Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs after a complaint was filed in March 1987. The complaint alleged that the company had violated an executive order that prohibits federal contractors from discriminating on the basis of race, sex, religion, color or national origin. The order also requires contractors to take affirmative action measures in hiring women and minorities. ``Women represent an important and growing part of today's labor force,'' Dole said in a prepared statement. ``If America is to remain competitive, it is no longer just an option for companies to employ and promote qualified women and minorities into non-traditional jobs. It is a business and legal necessity. ``This settlement is one of the largest equal opportunity agreements in Labor Department history and further demonstrates the department's commitment to eliminating discrimination in the workplace.'' As part of the settlement, the company agreed to provide more opportunities for women to transfer to higher-paying jobs within the company. The Labor Department said its investigation revealed that Precision Castparts ushered women into traditionally female jobs that were lower-paying and provided less opportunity to compete or train for higher-paying jobs, which traditionally have been filled by men at the three plants. The company said it was denying the allegations but decided to negotiate a settlement anyway. Precision said in a news release that it has taken steps to increase the percentage of women in its blue-collar workforce and in traditional male jobs in particular. ``Our efforts to increase opportunities for women are already showing results,'' Marvin said. ``The number of women in blue-collar jobs has doubled since 1980, a period when our overall employment levels have increased dramatically. In percentage terms, women are now 33 percent of the blue-collar workforce, compared to 26 percent in 1980.''

DOC.HEAD: Beef Off School Menus in British Mad Cow Disease Alarm
DOC.TEXT: The government sought to quell national concern over mad cow disease on Tuesday, but local government officials removed beef from the menu in more than 1,000 schools. While Agriculture Minister John Gummer insisted that British beef is perfectly safe to eat, the publicized death of one of Britain's 7 million pet cats from the disease grabbed the headlines. Gummer said he was letting his four children eat beef and beef products. ``I would not dream of either allowing that or the public to eat beef unless I was wholly and absolutely confident,'' he said in a statement. Britain's 11 European Economic Community partners and the Soviet Union earlier banned British beef imports after reports of cattle having to be destroyed because they had the disease, scientifically named bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or BSE. The mysterious disease affects the brain and central nervous system in cattle. They foam at the mouth and their legs splay out. Last month, Humberside in eastern England banned all British beef products from its school canteens. Tuesday was the blackest day yet for the $3.3 billion a year cattle industry. Staffordshire banned beef sausages, beefburgers and minced beef in the county's 570 schools. It said it was satisfied solid beef cuts are safe. Derbyshire stopped beef servings in more than 600 schools ``as a precaution.'' Richmond upon Thames took beef off the menus of its primary and junior schools. Liverpool banned British and foreign beef from all its kitchens in more than 300 schools and 100 old people's homes and other institutions. Government officials said there was no chance of BSE passing from beef to humans but the death of Jacqueline Stone's Siamese cat, Max, aroused widespread alarm. Blood tests and X-rays did not indicate what made Max ill so it was destroyed in April for an autopsy, which showed it probably had a feline version of BSE. Mrs. Stone said Max was the only one of her five Siamese cats affected and they all had the same food: canned meat, dried food and cooked meat from pet shops and butchers. She said the cat showed the first sign of illness in January when it held up a paw and lost its sense of balance. It did not go mad, she insisted. BSE has a long incubation period, perhaps four to six years. It was first identified among Britain's 16 million cattle in 1984 and more than 13,000 of them have been destroyed since then. Only 22 were bulls. The Daily Telegraph said Tuesday only a single animal had the disease in 63 percent of the affected herds and 90 percent of dairy herds are unaffected. What causes the disease is unknown. Autopsied brains examined through electron microscopes are holed and fibrous, indicative of a rotting process. A sheep disease called scrapie that most resembles BSE has been known for 200 years and is still not identified. The government said people have been eating meat from scrapie-affected sheep for generations without being harmed. It was thought that cattle with BSE got the disease from feed containing protein from the remains of scrapie-infected sheep and such feed has now been banned. Last year, the Agriculture Ministry forecast about 350 cases of BSE would appear each month. But in the first week of May the rate was up to about 1,000 a month. The ministry is giving 100 percent compensation to farmers slaughtering their affected animals and has pledged $20 million over three years for research on the disease. The Vegetarian Society advised: ``The only logical approach for the human population is to avoid beef products altogether.''

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Police Hold Jewish Suspect in Cemetery Desecration
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli court held over in custody Tuesday a 41-year-old Jewish man suspected of spray-painting about 300 graves in the northern port of Haifa with slogans in Hebrew calling on Arabs to ``Kill the Jews.'' The Magistrates Court in Haifa agreed to a police request to hold David Goldner for 15 days for further investigation. Police described Goldner as an ``eccentric.'' A Haifa journalist who is personally acquainted with Goldner said the suspect was a former military scientist who became religious and engaged in Jewish mysticism. The journalist spoke on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Arizona Senate Passes Bill; House To Vote Wednesday
DOC.TEXT: Arizona's Senate voted 16-14 Tuesday to create a paid Martin Luther King holiday and wipe out a public referendum on the long-controversial issue, despite polls showing most Arizonans want it put to a statewide vote. The measure, which also restores a paid Columbus Day holiday, now goes to the House. Legislative leaders said it would be passed Wednesday. Opponents of the measure say a referendum should be automatic because the new bill would knock out a scheduled public vote on a bill lawmakers passed last year. That bill created a King Day while eliminating Columbus Day from the list of paid holidays for state employees. Last year's King-for-Columbus bill so angered King opponents and Columbus supporters that they joined forces and gathered nearly twice the 43,350 needed signatures to put the measure into legal limbo pending a referendum this November. If the newest King holiday bill is passed and signed by Gov. Rose Mofford, who called the legislature into special session to consider the measure, opponents would have 90 days to gather signatures to call a referendum. Polls suggest that more than 80 percent of Arizonans believe the issue should be decided by the voters. Opponents of the bill, including impeached Gov. Evan Mecham, have promised a new referendum drive to get the issue back on this November's ballot. ``It was my impression we were supposed to be servants,'' said Republican Sen. Wayne Stump. ``It was never, never my idea that we were supposed to be the masters.'' ``Rightly or wrongly, this bill won't go away,'' Republican Sen. Leo Corbet warned as he pleaded with his fellow senators to amend Tuesday's bill and condition it on public vote. ``My opposition isn't to a King holiday,'' he added. ``My opposition is to giving another paid holiday to state employees'' at a time when the state faces a potential deficit of at least $250 million. Controversy over a King holiday has dogged the state for years. Democratic Gov. Bruce Babbitt declared a holiday by executive proclamation as he was about to start a presidential bid in 1986. But Republican Attorney General Bob Corbin called it an illegal usurpation of the Legislature's role and Mecham rescinded it days before it would have taken effect. Mecham's action sparked protest marches, tourist boycotts and convention cancellations by national organizations. It also fueled a recall drive against Mecham, but a Senate Court of Impeachment ousted him on other grounds before the recall vote could be held. Mecham, who is running for governor again, has promised to put up to 4,000 of his volunteers into the field to help gather signatures for a referendum, and organizers predict they'll get the signatures within two months. The chief sponsor of the latest legislation, Democratic Sen. Carolyn Walker, said there was no need to let the voters have a say in what could become a racially divisive referendum. ``I know there are those who say we are taking this away from the people,'' she said. ``I would like to remind them that ... the people elected us in the state of Arizona as leaders.'' The bill's impact on the referendum caused one long-time holiday supporter, Democratic Sen. Gus Arzberger, to switch sides. ``I can't vote to take the vote away from the people,'' Arzberger said. ``I vote no.'' But Republican Sen. Bill De Long, who has voted against the bill in the past, reversed field Tuesday, saying a recent poll showed his constituents now favor the holiday. He refused to release the poll results. Republican Sen. Doug Todd, who opposed early King bills before voting for last year's measure, also voted for Tuesday's bill, saying his past votes had helped to build ``a Berlin Wall ... of fear, bigotry and hatred.''

DOC.HEAD: Norway's Brundtland Tries New Tactic in Global Environment Effort
DOC.TEXT: Three years ago Gro Harlem Brundtland, then Norway's prime minister, became an environmental champion with her acclaimed report on preserving the world's ecology without stifling development. Mrs. Brundtland can now add another innovation to her green politics: she has brought decision-makers from 34 industrial countries together for a three-day meeting with a broad range of non-government groups, in what is becoming known as ``the Bergen Process.'' Mrs. Brundtland said Tuesday it was important to bring ``the labor unions, youth, scientists and the industry in the process, because they had more affect in pressuring the governments.'' Mrs. Brundtland serves as leader of the opposition Labor Party and chairs Parliament's foreign affairs committee. But the conference, which began Monday, has failed to pass the toughly worded declaration Mrs. Brundtland backed. This enraged a group of radical environmentalists who gathered in Bergen to protest the three-day meeting. On Tuesday, hundreds of the demonstrators forced delegates to abandon two tour buses and flee on foot under police protection. The demonstrators jeered, tore down barricades and scuffled with police as they tried to reach the roughly 60 visibly frightened delegates. None of the 34 delegates, including Iceland's prime minister and Norway's foreign minister, were injured, said the conference secretariat. ``They were all talk and no action,'' said Jan Heiret, a representative of the protesters. The conference ends Wednesday and delegates are trying to work out a compromise declaration that will take into account U.S. objections. The U.S. delegation has objected to some recommendations, particularly those on setting binding agreements to limit emissions of gases and on establishing a new fund for environmental aid to developing countries. Mrs. Brundtland criticized the U.S. stance, saying, ``We can pay, or pay later.'' Tom Burke, of Britain's Green Alliance and a spokesman for the environmental groups represented, praised the meeting: ``It may not get us the result we wanted but it got us a lot further in contacting governments.'' Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov joined in the praise. ``The environment requires urgent joint action to save civilization on earth,'' he said in a cable to the meeting. Mrs. Brundtland's headed the 1987 U.N.-sponsored Commission that issued a report entitled ``Our Common Future,'' outlining paths toward development that would allow Third World countries to progress while taking environmental precautions.

DOC.HEAD: Mondello Jury: We're Stuck Again
DOC.TEXT: A jury weighing the fate of a young white man accused of murdering a black youth in a Brooklyn neighborhood said Tuesday it was hung up for the second time in four days, but the judge ordered them to keep talking. ``If you can make any progress at all, I want you to continue your deliberations,'' state Supreme Court Justice Thaddeus Owens told the panel. ``I want you to go and try it again.'' At about 5 p.m., the jury sent out a note saying it was unable to come to a unanimous decision on six of the 16 counts against Keith Mondello, 19, the alleged ringleader of the white gang that killed 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins in Bensonhurst on Aug. 23. The jury, in its eighth day of deliberations, did not say which of the counts were involved. The most serious charges against Mondello, 19, are two counts of murder and two counts of manslaughter. He also is charged with discrimination, which means the crime allegedly was racially motivated. ``We are at a standstill,'' jury forewoman Mimi Snowdon told the judge. The jury had sent Owens a similar message on Saturday, when he also sent them back to resume deliberations. Nearly 90 minutes after being sent back Tuesday, the jurors sent out another note requesting definitions, ``in layman's terms,'' of intent, reasonable doubt and acting in concert. Meanwhile, a second jury deliberated for a ninth day on murder and other charges against Joseph Fama, also 19, the accused triggerman in the case. Both juries recessed for the day around 7:30 p.m. and were to resume deliberations at 11 a.m. Wednesday. ``My guess is they're hung up on the tougher charges,'' Assistant District Attorney Paul Burns said of the Mondello jury after its first note Tuesday. Based on notes from the jury, Burns speculated that the panel was at an impasse over the discrimination and homicide charges. He predicted the judge would give the jurors a so-called Allen charge Wednesday if they continued to report a deadlock. Under an Allen charge, a judge formally admonishes deadlocked jurors to persist and listen to each other with an open mind. Prosecutors say that if the panel is unable to decide all counts, the judge would have to accept a verdict on whatever charges it did agree on. The defendant then would be retried on the charges on which the jury was deadlocked. Mondello's lawyer, Stephen Murphy, said the jury's deadlock was ``hard to read. ... I'd just as soon take whatever they have and leave.'' Earlier, the two panels listened to readbacks of testimony from several residents of the Bensonhurst neighborhood in south Brooklyn where the shooting occurred. Prior to its standstill note, the Mondello jury sent word that they would need fresh clothes if their deliberations went into Wednesday. Prosecutors allege Fama shot Hawkins after a mob of whites organized by Mondello surrounded the black youth, who had come into Bensonhurst with three black friends to look at a used car.

DOC.HEAD: Baker in Moscow, Trying to Resolve Pre-Summit Missile Differences
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 10-11: ``Interviewed by,
DOC.TEXT: '' with Shevardnadze interview

Secretary of State James A. Baker III, backed by three dozen advisers, arrived in the Soviet capital Tuesday to try to overcome deep differences over missile reductions that could impede success at the Washington summit. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is due to see President Bush in only two weeks, and senior Baker aides said on the flight to Moscow that at least four key issues were unresolved. Already, the two sides have decided to resume negotiations in Geneva right after Baker concludes his visit on Saturday, take a break for the May 30-June 3 summit, and then work through the summer. This suggests there is little hope that Baker, in his talks with Gorbachev and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, can settle all the remaining issues in time for a summit declaration. The differences are over restrictions to be placed on cruise missiles aboard fighter planes and warships, on mobile missiles with multiple warheads and on heavy land-based missiles. Also, in more than 400 pages of proposed treaty text compiled in Geneva, the two sides have not fixed on a scheme for verifying compliance with the reductions in strategic nuclear weapons. Gorbachev is to arrive in Washington May 30 after visiting Canada the previous day. After his summit meetings with Bush, at the White House and at the presidential retreat at Camp David, Md., he is to fly to Minneapolis on June 3, to visit with business and agricultural leaders, and then on to San Francisco for a speech at nearby Stanford University. Two U.S. officials, who spoke to reporters traveling with Baker on condition they would not be identified, said the Soviets had backtracked in talks in Washington last month after considerable headway was made in February talks in Moscow. ``There has been some movement to try to pick up the pieces,'' one of the officials said of the continuing talks in Geneva. But he declined to venture a prediction of Baker success or describe recent headway as substantial. Interviewed by CBS News, Shevardnadze denied any significant ``backtracking'' in the talks, or undue influence by the Soviet military. ``There is a team effort to formulate our arms control positions and I wouldn't say that at any point there was any significant backtracking on our part.
