It is part of a normal negotiating process,'' Shevardnadze said in the interview broadcast Tuesday evening. On two other arms control fronts the outlook also is cloudy. Completion of a U.S.-Soviet accord at the summit pledging to cease production of chemical weapons depends on the Soviets agreeing to a schedule to destroy their stockpiles. And differences over verification methods and limiting aircraft stand in the way of an accord between NATO and the Warsaw Pact to reduce troops and tanks in Europe. As Baker arrived in Moscow, Gorbachev's difficulties in the breakaway Baltic republics deepened. His domestic troubles might seem likely to impair preparations for the summit meeting with Bush, although some administration analysts suggested this week Gorbachev might be impelled to push for a foreign policy success to balance his political problems. Thousands of whistling and Soviet soldiers tried to break into the Latvian parliament in Riga, the Latvian capital, a day after Gorbachev declared independence movements in Latvia and Estonia null and void. In Lithuania, he is maintaining a partial economic blockade. Bush and Baker, while voicing support for self-determination, have withheld any U.S. economic retaliation against Moscow. However, Baker has informed Moscow that the administration is under pressure from Congress and Bush has said there are limits to U.S. patience. Baker is due to see Gorbachev on Friday after talks Wednesday and Thursday with Shevardnadze. Saturday morning has been set aside for further discussions with the Soviet foreign minister. While both sides have said heavy emphasis would be put on arms control measures, Baker and his aides also would like to prepare agreements on space cooperation, the environment and trade for announcement at the summit. And Baker intends to make a special point about human rights. Before his first round with Shevardnadze, he scheduled a meeting with Jewish ``refuseniks'' who have been long denied exit permits.

DOC.HEAD: Two Pro-Democracy Activists Arrested in Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: Security forces on Tuesday arrested two pro-democracy activists for holding an illegal meeting in a private residence, officials said. Officials said Jassem al-Qotami, a politician, and Abdullah al-Nafisi, a former university professor, were arrested under a law making it illegal to hold political rallies in a home. Opposition sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said al-Qotami was arrested while delivering an address to about 200 men at his house. The two are part of a group that has been campaigning for the restoration of Parliament, which was was suspended in 1986 because of its vitriolic criticisms of government ministers. Two other activists, including former parliament deputy Ahmed al-Rabei, have been in detention since Sunday night. Eleven activists, including three former legislators, were arrested last week but have since been released on bail.

DOC.HEAD: Arkansas Declared Disaster Area
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Tuesday declared a major disaster in the state of Arkansas from the severe storms and flooding that struck on May 1. The disaster declaration makes individual residents and businesses eligible for federal assistance, including temporary housing, grants and low-interest loans. The areas covered are in the counties of Craford, Faulkner, Jefferson, Little River, Perry, Pulaski and Sebastian. Robert B. Broussard of the Federal Emergency Management Agency's regional office in Denton, Texas, was named to coordinate the federal recovery activities. The federal government pays 75 percent of the eligible costs for repairing or replacing roads, bridges, utilities and other public facilities.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Auction Record
DOC.TEXT: Following is a list of the top 15 prices paid for paintings at the world's major auction houses: 1. ``Portrait of Dr. Gachet'' by Vincent van Gogh; $82.5 million, sold by Christie's, New York, May 15, 1990. 2. ``Irises'' by Vincent van Gogh; $53.9 million, sold by Sotheby's, New York, Nov. 11, 1987. 3. ``Les Noches de Pierrette'' (Pierrette's Wedding) by Pablo Picasso, $48.9 million, sold by Drouot-Montaigne, Paris (bid from the Bunkamura Shibuya auction house in Toyko in a televised satellite hook-up), Nov. 30, 1989. 4. ``Yo Picasso'' by Pablo Picasso; $47.85 million, sold by Sotheby's, New York, May 9, 1989. 5. ``Au Lapin Agile'' by Pablo Picasso; $40.7 million, sold by Sotheby's, New York, Nov. 15, 1989. 6. ``Sunflowers'' by Vincent van Gogh; $39.9 million, sold by Christie's, London, March 30, 1987. 7. ``Acrobat and Young Harlequin'' by Pablo Picasso; $38.46 million, sold by Christie's, London, November 28, 1988. 8. ``The Mirror'' by Pablo Picasso; $26.4 million, sold by Sotheby's, New York, Nov. 15, 1989. 9. ``Maternity'' by Pablo Picasso; $24.75 million, sold by Christie's, New York, Nov. 14, 1988. 10. ``Dans La Prairie'' (``In the Meadow'') by Claude Monet; $24.59 million, sold by Sotheby's, London, June 28, 1988. 10. ``Mata Mua (In Olden Times)'' by Paul Gauguin; $24.2 million, sold by Sotheby's, New York, May 9, 1989. 11. ``Interchange'' by Willem de Kooning; $20.6 million, sold by Sotheby's, New York, Nov. 8, 1989. 12. ``The Trinquetaille Bridge'' by Vincent van Gogh; $20.24 million, sold by Christie's, London, June 29, 1987. 13. ``Mere et Enfant'' by Pablo Picasso; $18.7 million, sold by Sotheby's, New York, Nov. 15, 1989. 14. ``La Promenade'' by Pierre-Auguste Renoir, $17.6 million, sold by Sotheby's, London, April 3, 1989. 15. ``False Start'' by Jasper Johns; $17.05 million, sold by Sotheby's, New York, Nov. 10, 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Prince Calls for Society to Utilize Retired People
DOC.TEXT: Prince Charles called on society Tuesday to make greater use of the ``skills and energies'' of retired people. ``People tend to take retirement seriously; they withdraw into the anterooms of society and often do little or nothing, stagnating and wilting visibly. They act out the role in which society has cast them,'' he said. The 41-year-old heir to the British throne said greater initiatives were needed to tap the skills, experience, enthusiasm and time of retired people. To retired people he said: ``Look about your community, ask yourselves how your talents and those of your friends could be used to benefit not only others, but yourselves too.'' Addressing the annual meeting of the Abbeyfield Society, a charity that has more than 1,000 homes for the elderly, the prince said a majority of the almost 13 million elderly Britons _ a third of the adult population _ were active, independent and reasonably fit. ``By this definition, old age is not the postscript to the long letter of life. It is, or could be, the final, glorious concluding paragraph,'' he said. ``And the challenge is, in part, how do we offer these millions some opportunity to find the right mix of leisure with constructive and worthwhile activity?'' he said. The prince also noted it was ``a harsh and terrible fact'' that so many old people were lonely. ``It is one of the sad paradoxes of this earthly life that alongside the advantages of an industrial society we have witnessed the parallel degradation of the wider family circle and an expansion of the kind of loneliness which is still less common in other parts of Europe.''

DOC.HEAD: Church Council Unveils Restructuring
DOC.TEXT: The nation's largest ecumenical body, faced with dwindling contributions from member churches, on Tuesday unveiled a reorganization plan designed to cut costs and weaken its governing board. ``We refer to it as a leaner, kindlier council,'' said the Rev. J. Martin Bailey, spokesman for the National Council of Churches. The council represents 32 Christian denominations with 42 million members. Most major Protestant, Orthodox and Anglican religions sponsor the council to help further education, missionary work and other projects around the world. The reorganization plan was presented on the first day of the semi-annual meeting of the council's 250-member governing board. Bailey said President Bush ``and his thousand points of light'' led to tight finances and forced the reorganization. Member churches are contributing less to the council because of inflation and the need to fund social programs once backed by the federal government, he said. Under the plan, the council would combine into four units 11 divisions responsible for subjects ranging from overseas ministry to sacred music. Bailey said the reorganization would remove most decision-making power from the governing board and give it to smaller boards overseeing the new units. The governing board, however, still will set policy, elect officers and approve the council's budget, which in 1989 totaled $44.6 million. Church leaders said the restructuring will make the council more efficient. ``We found that a lot of our costs, too many of them, were going for meetings and other administrative functions,'' Bailey said. The council's Stewardship Commission, which develops fund-raising programs and helps local churches manage their finances, opposes the reorganization for fear it will lose power, said the Rev. E. Wayne Antworth of the Reformed Church of America, the commission's co-chairman. The governing board is to vote on the plan Thursday. If approved, it will go into effect in 1991. Also Thursday, the board is scheduled to vote on a resolution that would urge the Defense Department to withdraw troops from the Philippines by 1996. Another would ask U.S. coffee producers to stop buying coffee from El Salvador, where six Jesuit priests were gunned down in November 1989. Nine Salvadoran soldiers are awaiting trial for the killings. On Wednesday, copies of the New Revised Standard Version of the Bible are to be distributed. The revised Bible is partly based on the Dead Sea Scrolls, which predate the Greek and Hebrew texts used to write the King James Bible, said Bruce Metzger, chairman of the revision committee. The council has licensed six publishers to print the new Bible, last revised in 1952. It is to appear in bookstores this summer.

DOC.HEAD: Detained American Publisher Released by Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: An American publisher detained three weeks for unknown reasons has been released by the Vietnamese government, a U.S. Embassy spokesman said Tuesday. Mike Morrow arrived Monday in Bangkok from Ho Chi Minh City, said Embassy spokesman Jim Williams. He had no other details, and Morrow could not be reached immediately. Friends said Morrow, a longtime resident of Hong Kong, was in Vietnam looking into investment possibilities. They said he was arrested April 23 in the central city of Da Nang, then taken to Ho Chi Minh City. A companion who was also arrested, French businessman Terry Rodzynk, was released earlier. Vietnam has not revealed the reasons for the arrests. An American who said she was recently detained for five days in Vietnam said Morrow may have been held because of contacts with dissidents in the country. The American, who said the reason for her detention was never made clear, spoke on condition of anonymity. Morrow started a private news service in Vietnam during the Vietnam War. He was held briefly by Communist forces during the war. Morrow is the publisher of Petroleum News, an industry journal. He also heads Asia 2000 Ltd., a publishing house, and a trading company in Hong Kong.

DOC.HEAD: Presidential Candidate Fujimori May Face Tax Evasion Charges
DOC.TEXT: A court is investigating charges that leading presidential candidate Alberto Fujimori under-reported the money he made on the sale of a home in Lima, the chief criminal prosecutor said Tuesday. The prosecutor, Pedro Mendez Jurado, said the court has not decided whether to file formal charges of tax evasion against the candidate. Fujimori could face a maximum six years in prison if convicted. A centrist political newcomer, Fujimori is favored to win the mid-June runoff elections against center-right novelist Mario Vargas Llosa. Fujimori was accused by Fernando Olivera, head of a small center-right party, the Independent Moralizing Front, of paying taxes on only the first $18,000 he made when he sold a home in December for $55,000. Olivera said Saturday that Fujimori received a payment of $25,000 and then one of $30,000, for the December sale of a house in Lima's exclusive Monterrico suburb. In reporting the sale to tax authorities in January, Fujimori listed the sale price of the house at $18,000, Olivera says. Fujimori has not commented on Olivera's accusations. The candidate owns at least six properties in Lima, including houses, apartment buildings and stores. Before first-round presidential elections in April, leftist candidates accused Vargas Llosa of tax evasion but no charges were filed.

DOC.HEAD: Shift To Unleaded Gas Causes Lead in Forest Soil To Decline
DOC.TEXT: Fifteen years of unleaded gas in the tank is helping clean up more than smoggy city air. Dramatic lead decreases also have been reported in forest soil far from urban areas. Scientists had feared that toxic lead emissions wafting from vehicle tail pipes threatened trees and other forest life, but a recent study credits the Clean Air Act with bringing relatively speedy relief. ``It's beautiful, the curve showing the decline of lead,'' said Thomas G. Siccama, a forest ecologist at the Yale University School of Forestry and Environmental Studies. ``It has left the forest floor faster than the general community of ecologists thought,'' he said. In 1980 Siccama and two other scientists, William H. Smith of Yale and Donald L. Mader of the University of Massachusetts, documented that lead levels in Massachusetts forest soil had jumped significantly between 1962 and 1978. The amount of lead per square meter had increased from 682 milligrams to 1160. Siccama, Smith and others, including Andrew J. Friedland of Dartmouth College and Arthur H. Johnson of the University of Pennsylvania, began looking more closely at forest surface soil, typically a mat of organic matter 2 to 4 inches deep. They took samples in forests extending from Pennsylvania through New Hampshire. Over the past year, they and other researchers reviewed the data. Their work has not yet been published, but Siccama said clear trends were apparent. At a Cathedral Pines forest test site near Cornwall, Conn., Yale graduate student Julie Tritschler found lead had fallen 26 percent since 1980, down from 1,275 milligrams per square meter to 940. At Hubbard Brook in West Thornton, N.H., lead levels in 1975 were approaching 1,100 milligrams per square meter. By 1988, they had fallen to under 800 milligrams per square meter, Siccama said. Michael J. Kellett, Northeast regional director for the Wilderness Society, was encouraged by the lead decreases, but cautioned that it is important to learn where the lead is going because it might end up in underground water supplies. Siccama and others say the decline in soil lead levels is almost certainly because of mandated unleaded gasoline use in new cars that began in 1975. ``That was the whole point of the law,'' Siccama said. ``It is a one-on-one connection. We know it has gone down in the rain, and we've followed it going down in the soil where we knew it was accumulating.''

DOC.HEAD: Gay Family Support Group Receives `Kind Word' from Barbara Bush
DOC.TEXT: A letter Barbara Bush sent to a support group will help parents of homosexual men and lesbians accept their children, the group's leader said Tuesday. Paulette Goodman, president of the Federation of Parents and Friends of Lesbians and Gays, asked Mrs. Bush for an expression of support during a White House visit last month. Mrs. Goodman asked the first lady to ``speak kind words to some 24 million gay Americans and their families to help heal the wounds and to keep these families in loving relationships.'' Last week, Mrs. Bush sent a letter to Mrs. Goodman praising the federation and reaffirming her belief that discrimination cannot be tolerated. ``I appreciated so much ... your encouraging me to help change attitudes,'' Mrs. Bush wrote. ``Such treatment always brings with it pain and perpetuates hate and intolerance,'' Mrs. Bush wrote, according to the letter released by Mrs. Goodman. Mrs. Bush frequently has made clear her distate for discrimination based on sexual preference. ``I was filled to tears when I got this letter,'' said Mrs. Goodman, who received it in Monday's mail. ``It will help families better accept and deal with the situation.'' Tim McFeeley, executive director of Human Rights Campaign Fund, a supporter of causes favored by gay men and lesbian women, said, ``I think it's a beautiful letter and I think it's a powerful letter because it's sincere and reinforces values that American mothers and American families are all about.'' The federation has about 200 chapters of volunteers nationwide and has a part-time staff in a Washington, D.C., suburb, Mrs. Goodman said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Meets With President Of Tunisia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 8: ``Ben Ali,'' with 4 grafs to update with toasts
DOC.TEXT:
President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali of Tunisia on Tuesday told President Bush of the Arab world's alarm over the settlement of Soviet Jews in Israel. Bush agreed that Israel should not settle Jews in the territories it occupies. But he also supported the flow of Jews allowed out of the Soviet Union to Israel in recent months, said Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly. Bush ``stated our position of opposition to the settlement of people in the occupied territories,'' Kelly said, briefing reporters about the Oval Office talks, which included a 20-minute one-on-one meeting after which aides were brought in. ``The president did reiterate our support for emigration from the Soviet Union and the right of Soviet Jews to settle in Israel within the boundaries that existed'' before Israel captured the West Bank from Jordan in 1967, he added. Kelly said Bush took the opportunity to discuss with Ben Ali next week's summit of Arab leaders in Baghdad, Iraq. The summit is expected to focus on concerns about the Soviet emigres to Israel and on recent accusations by the United States and Britain that Iraq is developing nuclear weapons and threatening to attack Israel.
in 1970 ran unsuccessfully for the Arizona House of Representatives.

DOC.HEAD: Four Texans Sentenced in Deaths of Five Aliens on Train
DOC.TEXT: Four Texans arrested in the deaths of five would-be immigrants in a fumigated railroad car last year were sentenced in federal court Tuesday. Five people from Mexico, Honduras and El Salvador died last October after being locked inside a trailer that was loaded onto a train and filled with fumigated tortilla flour. The flour had been treated with Phostoxin, a poisonous insecticide. The defendants, all from Victoria, asked U.S. District Judge Filemon Vela for mercy Tuesday, saying their families need them. They originally were indicted on alien smuggling charges, but later pleaded guilty to lesser offenses in plea-bargain agreements. Vela sentenced Magdaleno Arcos Soriano, 34, to 18 months in prison, to be served when he finishes a 14-month sentence handed down Nov. 3, 1989, in connection with another alien smuggling case. The judge handed a 16-month sentence to Eleutorio Amaya Torres, 35, who received probation in connection with the same previous smuggling case. Vela sentenced Amaya's wife, Jane Amaya, 39, to six months. ``I need an opportunity. I'm very sorry for what happened. ... My kids need me,'' the woman told the judge. Mary Ann Martinez, 24, was given three years' probation. The Amayas and Arcos Soriano were indicted Jan. 23 on 13 counts of alien smuggling and witness tampering. Ms. Martinez was named in six counts for alien smuggling. She pleaded guilty to misprision, or knowing that a crime was taking place and failing to report it to authorities. Eleutorio Amaya Torres pleaded guilty to one count of witness tampering, as did Arcos Soriano. Jane Amaya pleaded guilty to one count of conspiring to smuggle aliens. Upon questioning from U.S. District Judge Filemon Vela, Assistant U.S. Attorney John G. Crews said he had no proof that the four people actually had put the aliens in the trailer.

DOC.HEAD: Last Minute Appeals and Protests Over Prejean Execution
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers turned to the U.S. Supreme Court on Tuesday in what they called their last hope of heading off Friday's execution of a man convicted as a teen-ager of killing a Louisiana state trooper. ``If they turn us down, I don't think we'll have time for anything else,'' said Sam Dalton, the lawyer for Dalton Prejean. Prejean, a two-time killer, was sentenced to death 12 years ago for the 1977 murder of state Trooper Donald Cleveland. Now 30, he has been on death row longer than any inmate in Louisiana. His case has been championed by death penalty opponents who say he should be spared because he is nearly retarded, with an IQ of 76, and because he was a teen-ager when Cleveland was killed. Successful appeals have staved off 10 dates with the electric chair, but Dalton acknowledged he is not optimistic about chances for an 11th. ``Hopeful,'' he said. ``Not optimistic.'' Gov. Buddy Roemer reiterated Tuesday that he will not intervene, despite public protests. ``I've reviewed this case personally now on two occasions,'' Roemer said. ``With his killing in cold-blooded murder a police officer, the law is clear in Louisiana: he shall die from execution.'' Cleveland was killed after stopping a car in which Prejean was a passenger for a broken taillight. Prejean acknowledges that he shot Cleveland in the face. But he maintains that he should be sentenced to life in jail, not executed, because he suffered emotional problems and brain damage from childhood. The killing came shortly after Prejean was released from a reform school, where he served time for killing a cab driver when he was 14. Dalton said he asked the U.S. Supreme Court for a stay this time on the basis of remarks by state Supreme Court Justice James L. Dennis, who dissented Monday when that court refused to block the execution. The court rejected 5-2 Dalton's argument that a psychiatric evaluation administered before Prejean's 1978 trial was inadequate. Some justices saw it as rehashing an old issue, but Dennis said the appeal raised some questions that should be decided in court. Dalton said those questions include whether it would have affected the jurors if they had known Prejean was brain-damaged and consequently not totally responsible for his acts. The U.S. Supreme Court last summer rejected the argument that Prejean should be spared because of his age at the time of the crime. Other appeals have been based on Prejean's mental capacity, his conviction by an all-white jury (Prejean is black, Cleveland was white), and the fact that the jury was not told he had been abused as a child. The State Pardon Board has recommended that Prejean's sentence be reduced to irrevocable life in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Rehnquist Urges Streamlining of Death Penalty Appeals
DOC.TEXT: The chief justice of the United States called on Congress Tuesday to limit death penalty defendants to just two appeals, one in their state court and one in the federal system. There is no limit to such appeals now, and generally each case sees several appeals filed in each court system. As a result, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist said in an address to the American Law Institute, ``The result is that at no point until a death sentence is actually carried out can it be said that litigation concerning the sentence has run its course ... The system at present verges on the chaotic.'' A committee appointed by Rehnquist last fall, headed by retired Supreme Court Justice Lewis F. Powell, recommended the two-appeal limit. Rehnquist sent the report directly to Congress, bypassing the U.S. Judicial Conference, the policy-making body for the federal courts he heads. Fourteen of the 27 members of the conference wrote Congress to request hearings on the conference's recommendations _ which differ significantly from those of the Powell committee. Civil liberties lawyers generally criticized the Powell Committee recommendations. There are now more than 2,200 prisoners under sentence of death around the United States. During the 1980s, there have been at most 25 executions a year. Noting that the average time between sentencing and execution is seven or eight years, Rehnquist said, ``The eight years ... is consumed not by structured review ... but in fits of frantic action followed by periods of inaction.''

DOC.HEAD: Bailiff Wounded, Suspect Grazed in Courtroom Shooting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead, INSERTS 1 graf after penultimate to UPDATE with bailiff saying gun was aimed at judge. Ptomey is cq
DOC.TEXT: A drunken driving defendant pulled a gun and shot a courtroom bailiff who tried to grab the weapon from him as he aimed it at a judge Tuesday, authorities said. The shot hit two of the bailiff's fingers and grazed the face of the suspect, but neither man suffered life-threatening wounds, said Monroe County sheriff's spokeswoman Becky Herrin. Charges against Peter Anderson, 22, of Miami, included attempted murder, aggravated battery and bringing the weapon into a courtroom, Ms. Herrin said. The trouble began as Judge William Ptomey conducted a traffic session in the small courtroom, which was crowded with about 50 people. The judge called Anderson on charges of drunken driving, not having a valid driver's license and refusal to sign his citation. Anderson approached the podium and handed Assistant State Attorney Leo Bueno a dead white flower, said Ms. Herrin. When the judge asked what the flower was for, Anderson replied that the charges against him were ridiculous, Ms. Herrin said. Ptomey ordered a bailiff to sit Anderson in the jury box to allow him to cool down, she said. But as the bailiff approached, Anderson allegedly pulled a .38-caliber revolver from his waistband. The judge yelled out a warning, and bailiff Ron Dowmond, 62, walked up to Anderson. ``He grabbed the gun with his right hand, and at that point the gun went off,'' said Ms. Herrin. ``The bullet grazed his middle finger and entered and exited his index finder. It also grazed the defendant on the left neck and cheek.'' The bullet then hit a wall and bounced off a ceiling beam, ``showering particles down and causing a considerable amount of confusion and panic,'' she said. A spectator ran to a sheriff's substation and deputies entered the courtroom and helped subdue Anderson, she said. Anderson was treated for superficial wounds and released to sheriff's deputies. Dowmond was taken to Cedars Hospital in Miami for evaluation. Dowmond, speaking later from his hospital bed, said he ``got ahold of the gun and turned it away from the judge. There's no doubt in my mind, the judge was the target.'' After the shooting, Sheriff Allison DeFoor ordered that either physical searches or portable metal detectors be used to check people entering the building, Ms. Herrin said.

DOC.HEAD: Operator of Children's Home Sentenced to Five Months in Jail
DOC.TEXT: A fundamentalist minister who operates an unlicensed church boarding home for troubled teen-agers was sentenced Tuesday to five months in jail for violating a court order barring him from housing minors. The Rev. Herman Fountain was forcibly brought to court Tuesday afternoon after failing to appear at the contempt of court hearing. Fountain had said earlier that he would ignore the summons because he answers only to God. ``I feel that this is pure persecution and that the court is completely out of line,'' he said Tuesday. Fountain was jailed pending posting of a $1,000 appeal bond. He said he would not post the bond and would serve the five months. A January chancery court order prohibited Fountain from operating the Bethel Children's Home here because he refused to submit to a new state law requiring registration of such institutions. The law was adopted last year after a youth court ordered the state to take custody of Bethel's almost 100 juvenile residents because it had found several incidents of abuse and neglect. On May 4, state officials again searched the 28-acre church compound for illegally housed juveniles, but found none. The investigators believe Fountain was tipped off and moved the youths. That order to remove children was issued by youth court Chancellor Robert Oswald after a 16-year-old boy who ran away from the home testified that during his 13 days there, Fountain forced more than a dozen children to work nine or ten hours a day on various chores. The teen-ager said he ran away because he was going to be beaten. Fountain disputed the accusations. On Tuesday, Fountain told Oswald, ``You are biased against Bethel and the attorney general's staff who lobbied for passage of this law shouldn't be allowed to prosecute me under this law.'' Oswald said he has an obligation to uphold the law, and appointed a lawyer for Fountain although the minister said he did not want one.

DOC.HEAD: A `Striking' Scene in Muggy Managua
DOC.TEXT: The strike of government workers Tuesday was a day of music, pushcart food and tear gas; of frustration, poetry readings and slogans; in all, a very Nicaraguan affair. The lighter aspects were a thin gloss on the crisis the walkouts represent: A life-or-death challenge by the ousted leftist Sandinistas to the 3-week-old, pro-American government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. It was like this Tuesday in this muggy lakeside capital: Culture Ministry workers sent ``morale brigades'' to government buildings occupied by strikers. Guitar players and singers broke into popular songs and ballads from the Sandinista revolution. At the Finance Ministry, a crowd of passers-by, barefoot kids and ubiquitous food vendors quickly gathered. High-powered loudspeakers blasted the musical messages throughout Managua's desolate downtown sector, still largely vacant or in ruins from a 1972 earthquake. Police relaxed under shade trees in their jeeps outside striker-occupied government buildings, enjoying paper cones of flavored, shaved ice and chatting with strikers. The army was nowhere to be seen.

At the Ruben Dario theater, artists, musicians, and perfomers lounged about in the theater's gardens, which they have occupied since Friday. A few turned cartwheels under the trees, some painted revolutionary banners and, in a country that calls itself a nation of poets, there were plenty of readings. Red-and-black banners reading ``Art-Revolution'' and ``Viva El Frente,'' a reference to the Sandinistas, were draped over the theater's four-story facade. Hours earlier, at the occupied Foreign Ministry, people were wheezing from tear gas thrown by police.

At the airport, a wizened, old man selling cigarettes one at a time and candy said four flights came in that morning and striking customs workers just waived the passengers through. No bags were checked. He said it must have been paradise for smugglers. Most doors were tied or locked shut. Newspaper was pasted over the windows. Maria Mayorga, 31, housewife from near the Pacific town of Corinto, sat on two large boxes outside the closed terminal and looked resigned. She had arrived on the last flight allowed to land, a LACSA plane from Miami. Because of the phone strike, she could not call her relatives to come and get her. Because of the transportation strike, she could not take a bus. She lacked the 15 million cordobas, about $45, the two-hour taxi ride would cost. What to do? ``I guess I'll just sleep here tonight,'' she sighed.

Luisa Amanda Perez is 25, has five children and has sold pork rinds with boiled yucca in front of the Finance Ministry for eight years. ``(The Sandinistas) neither work nor allow people to work,'' she said. ``They say they are so very much for the poor people. Well, I'm poor and they're not doing me any good.'' She said she normally sells about 100 helpings a day, mostly to people who come to pay their taxes. But now the tax collectors are among the strikers, and she says she is lucky to sell 20.

DOC.HEAD: Austrian Student Survives Shove Under Train
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf to fix typo in `trough'
DOC.TEXT: An Austrian student was shoved from a subway platform into the path of an oncoming train by an unknown assailant Tuesday morning, but she escaped death when the train passed right over her without hitting her. ``If you can be lucky and unlucky at the same time, this woman was,'' said Al O'Leary, a Transit Authority police spokesman. Christa Neumann-Spallart, 26, of Vienna, Austria, was in stable condition at Elmhurst Hospital Center with a broken right leg, a fractured right ankle and a possibly fractured pelvis, said hospital spokeswoman Daphne Prior. She underwent surgery on the right leg Tuesday afternoon but Prior said no further information was available. The woman, a second-semester freshman at New York City Technical College in Brooklyn, had been out with friends Monday evening and was on her way alone to another friend's home, O'Leary said. About 2:30 a.m., she realized she had missed her stop and got off to catch a different train. A man she saw but hadn't paid much attention to was sitting on a bench as the train came in, O'Leary said. ``He jumped out and pushed her. She fell on the platform first, then tumbled onto the track area,'' O'Leary said. She wound up in the trough between the running rails. The motorman saw the unidentified man push the woman and braked the train. Part of the first car passed over her but did not hit her. Neumann-Spallart crawled out from underneath and was taken to the hospital. ``The combination of the clearance at the center of the train and the depression, the trough, those two factors worked together in saving this woman's life,'' O'Leary said. Police are working ``full bore'' on trying to track down the suspect, O'Leary said.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Locked Down After Inmates Refuse To Return To Cells
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with inmates returning to cells. Picks up penultimate graf pvs. ^By DEB RIECHMANN
DOC.TEXT: About 500 inmates at the Maryland Correctional Institution returned voluntarily to their cells Tuesday night after refusing to leave a courtyard during an eight-hour standoff, officials said. Greg Shipley, a corrections division spokesman, said prisoners began returning to their cells shortly before 10 p.m. Earlier, state police who had been waiting outside the prison were seen entering the grounds about 9 p.m. Shouts could be heard from prison cellblocks, but activities inside the prison could not be confirmed. The prison was locked down after about 500 inmates gathered in a yard during a recreation period and refused to return to their cells about at 2 p.m., said Greg Shipley, a corrections division spokesman. ``They are simply milling about in the middle of the courtyard,'' Shipley said earlier. ``At this point, we don't know what they want.'' After a brief scuffle, three guards were taken to a hospital for treatment of bruises and then returned to the prison, he said. Shipley said overcrowding was not determined to be the cause of the disturbance. The prison's designed capacity is 1,086 inmates, based on one inmate per cell. Tuesday's count was 1,657 inmates. Additional correctional officers and about 65 state troopers and six canine units were called in as a precaution, Shipley said. The Maryland Correctional Institution is located about five miles south of Hagerstown.The medium-security prison was opened in 1931 as the Maryland Penal Farm. Two housing units have been added to the prison since 1980 _ a 128-bed facility in 1980 and second emergency housing unit of 420 bed in 1983.

DOC.HEAD: HUD To Begin Evicting Public Housing Tenants Accused Of Drug Dealing
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 3rd graf: ``The program,'' with grafs 3-6 bgng: ``Kemp's proposal,'' with INS proposal, followed by original 3rd graf, now 7th graf bgng: ``The housing,'' edited for transition
DOC.TEXT: People conducting drug deals in their public housing units could lose their leases without being charged with a crime under a program Housing Secretary Jack Kemp unveiled Tuesday. ``A judicial order for forfeiture of assets is a very powerful weapon,'' Kemp told several hundred state and local drug war officials at a conference called by the Office of National Drug Control Policy. ``It allows the public housing authority to take over the trafficker's unit immediately.'' Kemp's proposal was announced as officials elsewhere in the Bush administration were readying a package of other anti-drug measures to be sent to Congress on Wednesday. A provision of that package would give the Immigration and Naturalization Service greater authority to deport non-citizens without hearings. Duke Austin, chief spokesman for the service, said it would add a small number of serious drug offenses such as trafficking or possession with intent to distribute to the list of serious crimes for which conviction can bring deportation without hearings. Those hearings and subsequent appeals can take two years. The housing program, which Kemp said will start next month, drew immediate criticism from the American Civil Liberties Union. Kemp said it targeted serious drug traffickers ``because the standard of proof for a forfeiture order is evidence beyond a reasonable doubt that the apartment has been used for the commission of a drug felony.'' Congress specifically identified leases as forfeitable assets in the 1988 Anti-Drug Act, said Bud Albright Jr., deputy general counsel for the Department of Housing and Urban Development. The Public Housing Asset Forfeiture Demonstration Project, to be launched by HUD and the Justice Department and carried out by local housing authorities with local U.S. attorneys, will be conducted in 23 cities nationwide. Kemp declined to identify them. In addition, Kemp said, HUD is proposing new regulations for Section 8 rent subsidies. Those, he said, will ensure that persons convicted of drug-related or violent crimes and evicted from public housing will not be allowed to use Section 8 vouchers for other rental property. Albright said the regulations should be sent to the Office of Management and Budget on Wednesday and should be published in the Federal Register next month. The ACLU said the proposal ``takes a solid principle of American jurisprudence _ which is that you are innocent until proven guilty _ and turns it on its head.'' ``It suggests the government can punish people in advance of a conviction,'' ACLU spokeswoman Colleen O'Connor said. It also ``discriminates against people who are poor and dependent on federal programs'' and turns a program designed to help people into ``a means of enforcing the drug laws,'' she added. Albright said some individual public housing authorities already have seized leases from drug traffickers, but the program announced by Kemp will be ``a nationwide hit to raise the consciousness of drug dealers and of the public that this is something we can use and we intend to use.''

DOC.HEAD: Oil Spill Hits Devon Holiday Beaches
DOC.TEXT: Oil from a damaged Liberian-registered tanker began washing ashore on the holiday beaches of south Devon on Tuesday, despite four days of dispersal efforts. Ken Reynolds, Devon county emergency officer, said crews would begin cleaning the beaches Wednesday when the bulk of the oil that had spread six miles east of Plymouth was expected to come ashore. ``It would have been time-wasting to start today,'' he said Tuesday night. ``Tomorrow will be a day of action.'' Government anti-pollution officials said half the 294,000 gallons of oil had been dealt with, either by chemicals dropped from aircraft or by ships sucking it up from the sea. The oil leaked Saturday from the 275,000-ton tanker Rosebay after it collided with a British trawler 14 miles from the Devon coast.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Delays Ruling in Obscenity Case
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for 2 Live Crew produced a Rhodes scholar and a music critic Tuesday to support their claim that the rap group's million-selling recording isn't obscene _ just misunderstood. U.S. District Judge Jose Gonzalez Jr. issued no ruling Tuesday after a two-day hearing on a lawsuit by the group to have its sexually explicit album, ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be,'' restored to Broward County store shelves. The judge did not indicate when he would rule. Lawyers for both sides said they expected it would be within a week. Expert witnesses for the Miami group talked about musical, cultural, literary and political values to the album, which Gonzalez and the rest of a packed courtroom heard played in its entirety on Monday. John Jolly, representing Broward County Sheriff Nick Navarro and his department, didn't put on any witnesses, saying earlier that the group's album spoke for itself and was ``smut.'' ``It's got a good beat; you can dance to it, but you should give it a zero. It has no value,'' Jolly told the judge in final arguments Tuesday. The rap group's attorney said those who may be offended by 2 Live Crew's music need to see it is a product of the inner city, which is unfamiliar to the majority culture in the United States. ``You have to see anything new and understand where it has come from and what it is,'' attorney Bruce Rogow said in his closing arguments. The rappers sued after a Broward County circuit court judge found their album was probably obscene and a sheriff's detective visited stores around the county warning retailers they could be prosecuted for obscenity violations. Carlton Long, a Rhodes scholar from Gary, Ind., spoke about African-American historical and cultural significance and political importance in the album, which has drawn the criticism of Gov. Bob Martinez and authorities in several other Florida counties and in other states. ``The music is political simply in that you have a group of artists who are saying `I'm going to express myself the way I express myself,' '' said Long, who said he will teach political science at Columbia University this year. Long said he did a cultural analysis of the album at the group's request. He detailed the cultural background in which ``making self-aggrandizing statements,'' boasting about sexual prowess and trading insults are common. He said people outside the culture should work to understand what's being expressed. ``Then you discover what they're saying isn't all that dissimilar to what other people are saying,'' Long said. He called the 2 Live Crew music ``one slice of the pie ... one aspect of black culture.'' John Leland, music critic for Newsday of New York, testified about ``hip-hop,'' from which rap developed. His descriptive testimony, with his own sound effects such as ``boom-boom-bah-boom'' and ``wikka-wikka,'' drew laughter from the judge and spectators. ``This is a new music,'' Leland said. ``It's difficult to explain in terms other than that. I think it's a whole new way of looking at music.'' The group's use of profanity tells its audience the rappers ``are in leisure mode,'' Leland said. The album ``As Nasty as They Wanna Be'' has sold nearly 2 million copies, while sales of a toned-down version, ``As Clean As They Wanna Be,'' lag far behind at about 300,000.

DOC.HEAD: Nazi Graffiti in France Day After Desecration Protest March
DOC.TEXT: One day after a huge march in Paris against anti-Semitism, police reported Tuesday that swastikas were painted on buildings in two towns and four youths were arrested elsewhere for spray-painting neo-Nazi slogans. On Monday, President Francois Mitterrand and Holocaust survivors joined up to 200,000 people in a silent march. They were protesting last week's desecration of a Jewish cemetery in Carpentras, south-central France, where 34 graves were violated and a 81-year-old man's body was dug up and mutilated. It was the first time since World War II that a French president joined a public demonstration. In Montreal on Tuesday, Charles Germon, 74, brother of Felix Germon, the man whose corpse was exhumed, sat sobbing at a ceremony held there in solidarity with the French Jewish community. ``You wouldn't do this to a dog!'' exclaimed Germon, who emigrated to Montreal 31 years ago. ``God will punish them.'' He was among about 300 people who gathered in the Canadian Jewish Congress building to condemn recent desecrations. On Monday, swastikas were found painted on Jewish graves in suburban Clichy-sous-Bois. Police in Seclin, in far-northern France, said swastikas and six-pointed stars were painted in red overnight on the town library, the tax collector's office, a reception hall and several monuments. In Gardenne, near Marseille, swastikas and racist slogans were painted on the local office of the French Communist Party, police said. Four youths were arrested Monday in Perigueux, southwestern France, in connection with recent incidents in which neo-Nazi slogans were spray-painted on a World War II monument in Perigueux and a synagogue in Bordeaux. One slogan read, in German, ``We will return and conquer.'' Authorities also said Tuesday that two Roman Catholic cemeteries were vandalized recently. In one case, a mentally disturbed young man was taken into custody. No leads were reported in the other case. Authorities took the violated body from Carpentras to Nimes to be examined for possible clues that would aid the police investigation. All major political parties except the far-right National Front supported the protest march in Paris.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Tells Carson's First Wife Her Case Has a `Glitch'
DOC.TEXT: A judge Tuesday told the first of comedian Johnny Carson's four wives that her petition to get more money out of the Tonight Show host has ``a little glitch'' in it _ she married another man after divorcing Carson. State Supreme Court Justice Phyllis Gangel-Jacob noted that Joan ``Jody'' Carson, mother of the star's three sons, was married to Donald Buckley, an ad executive, for about six years after she divorced Carson. Carson's lawyer, Stanley Arkin, called the suit ``extortion'' and ``a bald-faced holdup.'' He told the judge, ``There is no basis for this lawsuit.'' Mrs. Carson, who married the comic in 1949 and divorced him in 1963, entered into a 1970 deal with Carson in which he would pay her $13,500 a year until 1999 whether she remarried or not. That deal superseded an agreement that would have given her 15 percent of Carson's income for life _ unless she remarried. Mrs. Carson married Buckley 15 days after signing the 1970 agreement. She says she can't live on $13,500 and needs more. ``I don't have enough money to buy a house,'' Mrs. Carson said, even though she and her lawyer, Raoul Felder, admit she has almost $400,000 in the bank. ``Look at (Carson's) other wives,'' she said. ``They have dresses that I see in the magazines that cost more than I earn in five years.'' Mrs. Carson, who hasn't spoken to her first husband in more than 30 years, said she brought this action against him now because ``I may not be able to do this later when I'm really in need.'' Felder called Carson an ``economic mugger'' who makes $40 million a year and could easily afford the $120,000 a year that his first wife is asking. Arkin said she is entitled to nothing more than the $13,500. He noted that Buckley, now an antiques dealer, gave Mrs. Carson a lump sum of about $200,000 in a divorce settlement. Felder questions whether his client was competent to understand and sign the 1970 agreement. He pointed out in court that she had been in mental hospitals at least four times. The judge asked Felder whether ``support should survive remarriage. She was remarrying three weeks later. It's a little glitch in the case.'' Felder never answered the question. The judge reserved decision.

DOC.HEAD: Wallace Says He Suffered from Clinical Depression
DOC.TEXT: CBS News correspondent Mike Wallace says he was treated for clinical depression during the Westmoreland libel trial five years ago, and that he thought about suicide. ``You feel like a fraud and a fake,'' he said in an interview that aired Tuesday on WNYW-TV Fox News. ``There was pain in my arms and in my legs and a sense that life was not worth living.'' He said he kept it a secret from his colleagues. ``Depression is something you do not want to talk about,'' he said. ``The reason I'm talking about it now is so people who are looking in will be aware of the kind of thing that can happen. It is a sickness,'' he added. Asked if he thought about suicide, Wallace responded, ``Sure.'' But he said he never made plans to take his own life. Wallace, 71, was a co-defendant in Gen. William Westmoreland's 1985 libel suit against CBS, which had reported that the general deliberately falsified estimates of enemy troop strength during the Vietnam War. Westmoreland settled the case out of court after hearing trial testimony by his former chief of military intelligence that backed charges made by a witness cited in the CBS documentary.

DOC.HEAD: Dam Releases Record Amounts of Water, Downstream Areas Brace for Worst
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf to UPDATE with release reaching 88,000 cfs; INSERTS two grafs after 7th with Army Corps of Engineers saying dam working as planned, governor asking to add four counties to federal disaster list.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Engineers opened floodgates wider Tuesday to release a record flow of water from a flood-burdened reservoir, and some downstream residents who had not already evacuated called for help. Parts of Arkansas flooded since May 1 were declared a federal disaster area by President Bush as National Guardsmen labored to shore up a weakened levee protecting a small town from the Red River, which continued its steady climb toward a 45-year high. In neighboring Louisiana, residents stacked sandbags around homes near the Red River and some evacuated. ``It's bad,'' said Rep. Jim McCrery, R-La., who toured the flooded regions. ``It's the worst flood we've had here in my lifetime.'' Elsewhere, creeks and rivers rose sharply in western and central Missouri, including the Kansas City area, as thunderstorms continued to dump heavy rain throughout the region. Many streets were flooded and more rain was expected. Residents of low-lying areas along the Trinity River in southeastern Texas braced for the worst as engineers at Lake Livingston Dam cranked open the taps to release a record flow of 88,000 cubic feet per second to protect the dam from a record flood. Releases of more than 20,000 cfs cause at least some flooding below the dam. The river's crest was expected to reach the dam by Wednesday, and releases could reach 100,000 cfs that day or Thursday, causing the worst flooding in 80 years in the small communities downstream. Lt. Gen. Henry Hatch of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers flew over the area Tuesday and said the Lake Livingston Dam appeared to be working as planned. Meanwhile, Gov. Bill Clements asked federal officials to add four more Texas counties to the 29 listed in a presidential disaster declaration issued earlier this month because of flooding and storm damage. Many residents of communities south of the dam heeded early warnings and moved to higher ground, although there were last minute stragglers who called for help as water covered the roads out of their subdivisions. ``They chose to stay ... now they've become frightened and they want out,'' said Jim Mitchum, Liberty County emergency management coordinator, adding that people were helped by the early warnings. Flooding along the Trinity began two weeks ago in the Dallas-Fort Worth area, forcing hundreds of people from their homes. The flooding and storms that caused the flooding killed 12 people in Texas and one in Oklahoma, and could cause up to $700 million in agricultural damage in Texas alone, officials estimate. In Arkansas, agencies differed on the numbers of houses affected by flooding on the Arkansas and Red rivers. The state Office of Emergency Services estimated 493 houses sustained some kind of flood damage, said spokesman Gary Talley. Red Cross spokesman David Threkelsen said their count stood at 337 but that surveys were continuing. The president's disaster declaration makes federal funding available through the Federal Emergency Management Agency to supplement the recovery of residents and businesses in Crawford, Faulkner, Jefferson, Little River, Perry, Pulaski and Sebastian counties. The disaster declaration was requested last week by Gov. Bill Clinton, who renewed the requested Tuesday, saying, ``devastating flooding unprecedented in recent history continues to this day.'' Clinton estimated that losses to public and private property will exceed $20 million. Sandbagging continued in earnest on a weakened levee protecting the town of Garland, Ark., from the Red River, said Talley. The river had crested in the area, he said, but it probably will be late Wednesday before it receded. National Guard Maj. David Lively said sandbagging along the Red River could continue until the weekend. If the levee breaks near an Army Corps of Engineers' command post at Garland, a town of about 600 people, ``we'll have time to sound a horn and tell people to get out,'' said Lt. Bob Page of the Miller County sheriff's office. In Louisiana, about 300 homes have been evacuated along the Red River from Shreveport southward as the river climbed toward a 45-year high. Emergency workers ringed homes with sandbags in a low-lying area of Shreveport, where the Red was expected to crest Wednesday at 34.8 feet, about 5 feet above flood stage. That will be higher than a 1957 flood, but not a record. Water is expected to cover 600 square miles, including 200 square miles of cropland, said Maj. Jack Scherer of the Corps of Engineers in Shreveport. Water continued to recede in southern and eastern Oklahoma but additional localized flooding threatened an area of northern Oklahoma after thunderstorms dumped more than 7 inches of rain overnight on Elgin, Kan., a small town just across the Kansas-Oklahoma line. That much water ``means some rises on some of the local creeks and rivers but it's a situation where the rainfall is very localized, so we really don't expect any widespread flooding,'' said David Andra of the National Weather Service in Norman, Okla. In Mississippi, the National Weather Service said the Leaf and Bowie rivers should drop below flood stage by Wednesday, allowing 37 people who went to a Red Cross Shelter Monday at the University of Southern Mississippi Sports Arena at Hattiesburg to return home. Hattiesburg received 7.97 inches of rain from Saturday night through Tuesday morning.

DOC.HEAD: Court Lifts Ban on Building of Squirrel-Threatening Telescope
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court on Tuesday lifted a lower-court ban on construction of an observatory imposed out of fear for the survival of an endangered species of squirrel. The order by the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals was praised by the University of Arizona, which wants to build the telescope. One environmental group, however, said it would head to Congress immediately to try to stop the project. ``At 8 a.m. Washington time we go to Congress and we ask them whether the Endangered Species Act still exists,'' said Robin Silver, a Phoenix physician and spokesman for the Maricopa Audubon Society. Environmental groups have fought the construction on Mount Graham, near Safford in southeastern Arizona, contending it would lead to extinction of the Mount Graham red squirrel. The university denies the project would harm the squirrel. Two House subcommittees have scheduled a hearing in Washington June 26 on the observatory. They are to consider environmental groups' allegations that high-level coercion was behind a report by U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service biologists, which found no danger to the squirrel's survival and led to congressional authorization for the project. U.S. District Judge Alfredo Marquez cited those allegations, and concerns about the red squirrel, in explaining the 120-day injunction against the observatory that he issued March 26. But the appeals court panel, Judges Jerome Farris and Harry Pregerson, said it did not appear that the evidence presented to Marquez ``constituted new information that revealed effects of the proposed telescope project not previously considered by Congress'' when it authorized the project. As a result, the panel said, it appeared that opponents' claims of violations of the Endangered Species Act and another law, the Arizona-Idaho Conservation Act, ``do not raise a serious question.'' The court lifted Marquez's orders blocking construction, specifying that Marquez could reinstate the ban ``should subsequent proceedings reveal effects of the project not previously considered.'' Marquez has scheduled a hearing on the suit July 16. ``We're very pleased that the appellate court thought the project should proceed,'' University of Arizona spokesman Steve Emerine said in a statement. ``We'll have to study the order to see exactly what's required of us. We would hope to begin construction in perhaps four to six weeks.'' The observatory dispute prompted recent comments by Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan that he saw no difference between various kinds of squirrels and thought the Endangered Species Act was too strict. President Bush disavowed Lujan's suggestion for relaxation of the act.

Secretary of State James A. Baker III is on his way to Moscow to try to work out arms control agreements with the Soviet Union for signing at the fast-approaching Washington summit. Baker's aides are not predicting success. ``By the end of the week we should know a lot more,'' a senior U.S. official said before takeoff Monday. The four days of talks are Baker's last chance to work out agreements with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze for signing during the May 30-June 3 visit of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The two sides are in disagreement on several key issues. Gorbachev's problems at home also could get in the way.

Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev may turn into a tourist after summit talks with President Bush, hopscotching to Minnesota and California from Washington early next month. Gorbachev's most likely destinations are Minneapolis and San Francisco or Palo Alto, Calif., U.S. officials said Monday. However, they cautioned that his schedule was tentative and subject to change. ``It's almost too good to be true yet,'' said Minnesota Gov. Rudy Perpich, who said the White House notified him Monday that Gorbachev is considering a visit to Minnesota and California. ``I didn't believe it at first. The Russians are coming.'' The Soviet president is interested in speaking with businessmen in both states and may deliver a speech at Stanford University, said the U.S. officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

Chancellor Helmut Kohl is suggesting an all-Germany vote as early as December as he encounters growing resistance and an eroding political base in his drive for rapid German unification. Kohl met with East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere on Monday and noted that in East Germany ``there are discussions'' about having all-German elections this year. Kohl said West German federal elections are still planned for Dec. 2 but added that his party would have ``good chances'' if elections were held throughout Germany. De Maiziere leads Kohl's sister party in East Germany. The chancellor conceded a ``bitter defeat'' in Sunday's elections in two West German states. The opposition Social Democrats defeated his conservative Christian Democratic Party and won control of the upper house of Parliament, the Bundesrat.

The United States could turn several small military facilities over to the Philippines government in negotiations under way in Manila, a senior U.S. defense official suggests. ``It's in our interest to be forthcoming,'' said the official, who spoke with reporters Monday on condition of anonymity. ``We're prepared to talk about anything.'' Exploratory talks between the two governments opened on Monday. After a largely ceremonial opening session, the two delegations began the first day of substantive discussions today. At issue are the future of six U.S. military facilities, including Clark Air Base and Subic Bay naval base. The lease on the installations expires in 1991.

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Joseph Biden says he'll have a flag-protection constitutional amendment ready if the Supreme Court strikes down a law Congress passed last year. But Rep. Don Edwards, head of the House constitutional rights subcommittee, vowed just as fiercely to resist House passage of such an amendment. ``Let's say no to weakening the Bill of Rights,'' he said Monday. These divergent views from two key Democratic players on judicial issues set the stage for what lawmakers in both parties agreed could be a divisive new election-year battle over Old Glory. The Supreme Court holds the key to whether there will be a 1990 flag fight on Capitol Hill. It is expected to rule in late June or early July on whether to uphold the Flag Protection Amendment of 1989. That's the law Congress passed _ and President Bush signed _ in the wake of the high court's decision in a Texas case that flag desecration is protected by the First Amendment.

DOC.HEAD: Cablers Convene Amid Worries About Future
DOC.TEXT: This Sunday, the still-growing cable industry will gather in Atlanta, home of Ted Turner and CNN, to start the National Cable Television Association's annual four-day convention. But hovering over the usual convention exhibits, panel discussions, deal-making and whoopee will be the specter of a possible return to federal regulation that cable systems largely shucked six years ago. It's a big concern for the industry, says NCTA President James P. Mooney, one he thinks may not be fully warranted. If there is action by Congress or the Federal Communications Commission, he says, ``Increasingly, I'm convinced that it will be modest in scope.'' Cable operators may particularly worry about a return to regulations giving cities power over the rates cable systems charge customers, Mooney says. But he says he doubts either Congress or the FCC will do anything that would hamper the continued growth of cable. And, says Thomas S. Rogers, president of NBC Cable and Business Development, ``It's a good bet there won't be any bill enacted this year,'' despite more than a dozen reregulation proposals pending in Congress. Once just a means of getting a clear broadcast signal into homes, cable now also is a programming giant and a collective rival of NBC, ABC and CBS. NBC and ABC themselves are active in cable _ notably NBC's new CNBC channel and ABC's 80 percent ownership of the ESPN sports channel. Once a minor player on the TV scene, cable now is in nearly 58 percent of the nation's 92.1 million homes with televisions, according to Nielsen estimates. But with its growth has come criticism that includes consumer complaints to Congress over increases that have occurred in cable rates since cable was broadly deregulated and cable systems generally allowed to set their own rates. The NCTA contends the worst is over. Mooney agrees, noting that a General Accounting Office study shows that in the two years after deregulation began, basic cable rates rose 29 percent and the overall customer bill went up 14 percent. But in the 14 years before deregulation, cable rates lagged far behind the U.S. Consumer Price Index, he says, and cable wasn't allowed ``to develop as a programming medium because we didn't have the money to do it.'' It has that now. But consumer grumbles continue, according to a Wall Street Journal-NBC poll in March. It found that 62 percent of those surveyed generally like what their cable systems offer. But 37 percent, it said, are dissatisfied with cable's cost and question whether the rates are reasonable. The survey, of 1,003 registered voters, had a 3 percent margin of error, NBC says. The rate issue provokes much of the Capitol Hill action, yet it's ``an enormously difficult one for Congress to confront, particularly given the policy reversal that it represents,'' says NBC's Rogers. He refers to the 1984 cable deregulation act he helped draft as a staff member of a House telecommunications subcommittee. Two reports expected soon in Washington may have some impact on the legislative front. One, due in July from the FCC, concerns the state of the cable industry today and what, if any, changes are needed. The other, to come at the end of June from the GAO, is an update on cable rate increases. ``What cable offers today is light-years from what it was five years ago,'' says Kay Koplovitz, president of the USA Network, which says it serves 53 million homes. ``Now the question is, can it stabilize without regulation? And will it stabilize without regulation?''

Elsewhere in television ... SALUTE TO COMPOSER: Keep an eye and ear for a lovely PBS special, ``Sing: Sesame Street Celebrates Joe Raposo and His Music.'' Scheduled for tonight by PBS, it's a fine tribute to the late composer of the familiar ``Sesame Street'' theme and more than 1,000 songs for the series, including the memorable ``Bein' Green'' and ``Sing!'' Those taking part in the Raposo retrospective include a wide range of his friends, including former CBS anchorman Walter Cronkite and ``60 Minutes'' correspondent Morley Safer.

DOC.HEAD: Warfare In The Real Estate Market
DOC.TEXT: War has broken out in the housing market, and some innocent buyers and sellers are walking right onto the battlefield without knowing it. While the alleged goal of the combatants is the right to serve homebuyers, which they assert is a privilege, a right and a duty, the underlying reasons clearly involve their own self-interest. It began when real estate agents sought to offer computerized menus of mortgages and rates available in their areas and then seek a second fee for what they claimed was an additional service. The Mortgage Bankers Association of America, whose members do not sell houses but who arrange financing for a fee, usually paid by the lender, say the practice is illegal _ that to accept a second fee was in effect a kickback. The battle has now reached a rather bombastic level, with the National Association of Realtors declaring the issue ``full-scale war,'' and blaming the MBA of publicly tossing about distortions, red herrings and untruths. Some Realtors seem to think the MBA is also slurring their image as Americans. The Realtor News quotes one as saying,``The MBA is effectively telling you `Don't Be Americans. Don't be innovators. Don't be entrepreneurs.''' According to the Realtors, the MBA is ``trying desperately to wrap itself in the flag of pro-consumerism,'' and has ``succeeded in planting many articles in the general news media.'' Those articles, it states, ``allege that you and your fellow brokers and agents are ripping off the consuming public when you are compensated for services in addition to brokerage.'' The MBA has done a lot more. It has been contacting federal lawmakers and state officials, and has succeeded in enacting restrictions in Connecticut, Illinois, New York, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island and Virginia. The mortgage bankers maintain that when real estate agents accept a fee for helping a homebuyer choose a mortgage, they are violating the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act, which outlaws referral fees and kickbacks. The Realtors are outraged that their actions should be tainted with such terminology. As they see it, they perform two services: the first is finding a house for the buyer, and the second is finding a mortgage for the buyer. Two different services, two different fees, they say, adding that everyone prefers the high level of comfort accorded by one-stop shopping. Just a minute, say MBA members: What is this talk about a commitment to the buyer? Real estate agents, they point out, have a commitment to serve the seller, who pays their commission. Are they claiming a dual commitment? And, by the way, some add, how does the buyer, who pays the extra fee, know that the agent's commitment isn't to a particular lender instead of to him? The cloud that hung over the Department of Housing and Urban Development has cast a shadow on the issue. Twice HUD issued informal opinions saying it was permissable to charge the borrower an extra fee for extra services. But, it seems, HUD has issued no regulation _ as opposed to an opinion. One limiting the practice was composed but never signed, the MBA says, because outgoing HUD Secretary Samuel Pierce thought it should be left for incoming Secretary Jack Kemp. Jacki Grumbacher, MBA vice president for communications, says war with the Realtors is mainly in their minds. The MBA has not declared war, she says, and it is not out to deny the Realtors or their customers anything. ``Our goal is just to get a stricter interpretation of the act on the books,'' she says.

DOC.HEAD: Eritrean Separatists Fighting Africa's Longest War
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: A 29-year-old Eritrean battle for independence from Ethiopia has become the longest war in Africa and one of the world's most obscure, fought in a region where travel is difficult and dangerous. An Associated Press correspondent spent nine days in Eritrea. This is his report.

Just south of this neat town built of rock and adobe are towers of sandstone boulders hundreds of feet high, where the people take cover during daylight in case of bombing raids. ``We cannot stay down there during the day,'' said Mariam Teglest, 32, a soldier's widow with three children. ``It is much too dangerous when the planes fly.'' She was speaking of Soviet-built MiG fighter-bombers of the Ethiopian air force, which had bombed the town of about 20,000 people twice in a few months. Afabet is one of a dozen or so major towns in Eritrea, Ethiopia's northernmost province, where rebels have fought for independence since 1961. Rebel forces captured the town in February, early in their biggest offensive of the war. The conflict began 29 years ago as a small uprising by scattered guerrilla bands and has grown into a toe-to-toe slugging match by armies of thousands of soldiers armed with heavy artillery, tanks and other modern weapons. It is a war the Eritreans appear on the verge of winning, despite the Ethiopian military's total dominance of the sky and its vast superiority in manpower. The government has a military force of about 320,000 men, largest in black Africa. The Eritreans do not divulge the size of their army. The International Institute for Strategic Studies in London says 30,000, but some recent visitors to the region believe the true strength is double that or more. In three decades, the war has touched almost every part of this barren, mountainous province the size of England. Afabet is tucked into a desert valley that evokes the American Southwest. Here and elsewhere, people hide by day and work by night in caves or camouflaged stone buildings and under the spreading branches of the ubiquitous African thorn tree. ``We've created the world's largest underground economy,'' said Haile Menkerios, a Harvard-educated economist, grinning at his play on words. He is on the Central Committee of the rebel Eritrea People's Liberation Front. ``We've learned not to expose ourselves,'' he said, with a sweep of the arm that covered hills dotted with cave mouths and stone huts almost undiscernible from a few yards. Eighty miles north of Afabet is Orota, the main rebel base camp. It sprawls through a deep, narrow valley cross-hatched by canyons and surrounded by rugged peaks so high the sun reaches in for only a few hours a day. Enemy planes fly into this maze at great peril. Orota is a supply and military training base, site of a detention center for thousands of prisoners of war, a civilian and an army hospital, schools for children of soldiers, manufacturing plants and repair shops for trucks, tanks and other military vehicles. The hospitals stretch for three miles down the main valley, to reduce the threat from bombing. Wards and operating theaters are hidden in tents under thorn trees, in caves and in nearly invisible buildings hewn from the same sandstone as the surrounding mountains. ``I think Frank Lloyd Wright would be proud of us,'' said Menkerios, grinning again at his reference to the architect who believed buildings should harmonize with their natural surroundings. A pharmaceutical factory, hidden in caves, makes everything from saline solutions to malaria pills and sanitary pads for women. One in four rebel soldiers is a woman, many of them commanders in an army with no ranks or sex discrimination. Everything in Orota is powered by electrical generators, most of which are cranked up only after sundown, when the vast camp stirs to life. Soviet-made field telephones captured from the Ethiopians connect the scattered complex. They look like early Edison models, but they work. Nearly everything is captured, scavenged, donated or handmade by a people used to getting by on next to nothing. This province on the Red Sea is one of the poorest in one of the world's poorest nations. Nothing is thrown away. Artillery shell casings filled with sand and welded together form the supporting pillars of a new school. Disposable hypodermic syringes become light switches. Old tractor and truck tires are turned into wash troughs. The Eritreans claim that they do not have the support of foreign governments and that all their military hardware, from tanks to Kalashnikov assault rifles, has been captured from the Ethiopian army. Officials and some diplomats in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia's capital, say the Eritreans have received arms and money from several Arab countries around the Red Sea that oppose the Soviet-supplied government of President Mengistu Haile Mariam. Eritrea's population is split about 50-50 between Moslems and Christians. A few reporters allowed behind rebel lines in recent months saw nothing but old and often battered Soviet-made military equipment. Nothing in Orota except the crowded hospitals suggests the huge battles being waged around Asmara, the Eritrean capital, a 16-hour drive south over rutted trails even experienced drivers can lose in the dark. On a roughly north-south line running nearly 100 miles betweem Asmara and the sea, the rebels are fighting more than a third of Ethiopia's armed forces, mostly conscripted and poorly trained young men. At the beginning of their February offensive, the rebels surrounded and cut off Asmara, including an estimated 1 million civilians and the government's 120,000-man 2nd Revolutionary Army. Three times since early April, the 2nd Army pushed eastward in an attempt to recapture its nearest outlet to safety, the Red Sea port of Massawa. Each time, an Eritrean force no more than half the size stopped it cold. Reporters who visited Massawa in late April could hear the thunder of artillery and tank barrages day and night at the front 40 miles away. The fierce exchanges often made windows rattle. The rebels claim they killed, wounded or captured 30,000 Ethiopian soldiers when they took Massawa in a three-day battle in early February and have inflicted similar casualties along the Ghinda front. Journalists who have seen the remains of Massawa, been guided near the front by the rebels and talked with deserters from Mengistu's army believe the numbers are not greatly exaggerated. Whatever the number of dead and wounded on either side, the Ethiopian 2nd Army's inability to break out of Asmara illustrates the rebels' military prowess. Most of Mengistu's other forces are occupied far to the south in the neighboring provinces of Tigre, Wollo and Gonder with an uprising by the smaller Tigre People's Liberation Front. The Tigreans, known to coordinate military moves with the Eritreans, have spent 15 years fighting to overthrow Mengistu and establish a new national government. Eritrean fighters and their leaders predict the long war will end in a few months. ``Come back soon,'' said Asmellash Abraha, who was detached from other duties to play host to three visting journalists. ``I'll show you Asmara. I am anxious to see it myself. It's been a long, long time since I was last there.''

DOC.HEAD: Mengistu Changes Course in Midst of Setbacks ^With AM-The 30-Year War, b0437
DOC.TEXT: President Mengistu Haile Mariam, who built a Marxist regime on the ashes of a feudal empire he helped bring down in 1974, is a man with many problems and, some predict, a limited future. His army has suffered battlefield setbacks in recent months, particularly in the northernmost province of Eritrea, where rebels appear on the verge of winning a 29-year-old war for independence. Another insurgent group swept out of its stronghold in Tigre Province, just south of Eritrea, 10 months ago and has pressed its fight to overthrow Mengistu's government to within 50 miles of the capital. The Soviet Union, preoccupied with its own economic and political problems, has threatened to close the tap that has poured billions of dollars worth of military hardware into Ethiopia since 1977. Mengistu spurned the United States and its Western allies when he achieved power 13 years ago, and they are in no hurry to improve relations. Major elements of Mengistu's own army attempted a coup last year. He said in a recent speech he had survived nine assassination attempts. With all those problems, and burdened by a collapsing economy that has never been robust, Mengistu signaled a change of course two months ago. From now on, Ethiopia will favor free-market economics and welcome foreign investment, he said. Giant posters of Marx and Lenin came down in Addis Ababa, but those showing Mengistu in various poses as a revered leader remain. ``It looks like a deathbed conversion,'' a Western diplomat in Addis Ababa said, on condition of anonymity. ``If you believe that Mengistu has had a true change of heart, you probably also believe in the Easter bunny.'' Mengistu joined other army officers in 1974, when he was a major, in overthrowing Emperor Haile Selassie. Three years later, he reigned supreme. He created the Marxist-Leninist Workers Party of Ethiopia in 1984. In 1987, Mengistu established the People's Democratic Republic of Ethiopia, formally dropping his military rank of lieutenant colonel to become a civilian president. Ethiopia is ruled by a small group agreeable to Mengistu's every plan, according to the memoirs of Dawit Wolde Giorgis, a former member of the party Central Committee who defected to the West. Dawit, major human rights groups and other critics accuse Mengistu of ordering or participating in the executions of dozens of rivals and of imprisoning thousands. Mengistu has denied the claims.
