DOC.HEAD: Peace Talks Falter in Africa's Oldest War
With AM-The 30-Year War, b0437
DOC.TEXT: Peace talks aimed at ending nearly three decades of war between Eritrean rebels and the Ethiopian government are stalled and unlikely to resume. Preliminary discussions, with former President Jimmy Carter as chairman, began in Atlanta last September and moved to Nairobi, the capital of Kenya, two months later. Negotiations in Nairobi ended with the government and rebel delegations clearly at odds, but agreeing to continue talks under the joint mediation of Carter and Julius Nyerere, former president of Tanzania. A third round was tentatively scheduled for early March in Nairobi, but foundered on a dispute over whether the United Nations should send an observer. Eritrean rebels see U.N. participation as de facto recognition of their movement, which controls 80 percent of the Eritrean countryside. President Mengistu Haile Mariam's government opposes it for the same reason. Carter invited the United Nations to take part, on behalf of the rebels, and said his offer was rejected. Rebel leaders said the invitation should have been sent jointly by them and the representatives of Mengistu's government and accused Carter of double-dealing, which the former president denied. ``The issue will ultimately go to the United Nations,'' Ali Sayed Abdalla, foreign minister of the Eritrean People's Liberation Front, said in an interview. ``The U.N. must guarantee any accord, so why not agree to have it represented as an observer at the peace talks?'' A Western diplomat in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia's capital, said: ``I see absolutely no chance for a resumption. The military situation has changed radically since September and the government seems to be reeling. I suspect the EPLF feels it can stand pat on its demands.''

DOC.HEAD: Can the Church Be Democratic? Critics and Pope Disagree
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II watched with satisfaction as the democratic spirit triumphed over communism in Eastern Europe. But the winds of change that swept the world, which the pontiff so encouraged, have made some Roman Catholics wonder when the revolution will touch their own church. John Paul, for his part, wonders what the winds blowing from the West hold for his newly liberated flock in the East. It is a moment of great joy for the church, and also poses new challenges. Critics like the Rev. Hans Kung, the Swiss theologian punished for his liberal views, have said the triumph of pro-democracy movements in Eastern Europe left the Vatican as a last bastion of totalitarianism. Several liberal Catholic groups in the United States have drawn up a statement urging the pope to share his power. The call to reform was signed by one bishop and some prominent theologians, nuns and priests. Calls for drastic change are nothing new in the papacy of John Paul, a native of Poland, where open Catholic dissent in the long communist era was unthinkable. During a historic visit last month, the pope hailed the strength of the faith in Czechoslovakia, which he said was ``deepened and purified by lengthy suffering.'' He also warned of ``dangers'' inherent in renewed contacts with the West. ``Unfortunately, not everything the West proposes as a theoretical vision or as a concrete life practice reflects Gospel values,'' John Paul told his bishops. He urged them to prepare ``immunizing defenses'' against such Western ``viruses'' as secularism and ``hedonistic consumerism.'' John Paul, who was 70 on May 18, is in the 11th year of his papacy and Vatican insiders believe those hoping for radical reforms will be disappointed. ``I don't feel such changes will happen under this pope,'' a senior Vatican official said, invoking the usual ground rule of anonymity. For example, the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, the guardian of doctrinal orthodoxy, is preparing a document on the church's moral teaching expected to be an answer to criticism from theologians. Much of such criticism has come in the past year from theologians in Western Europe concerned about the church ban on contraception and the pope's exercise of power, particularly his choice of bishops. For the pope and Vatican, there is no contradiction in seeking democracy in civil society while not applying it to the church. On his flight to the United States in 1987, a reporter told John Paul some American Catholics felt the church was not democratic enough. ``The Catholic church is not a democratic institution,'' he replied. ``It is an institution governed by Jesus Christ, a theocratic one.'' While the imperial trappings of the papacy have been removed _ popes are ``installed'' now, not crowned _ John Paul reminded Brazilian bishops earlier this year that power in the church comes from above, not below. To the pope, Christian teaching has been entrusted to the church by Christ, to be accepted in its entirety. He has said repeatedly that people who accept only what they want cannot consider themselves good Catholics. John Paul is not responsible for the teachings most frequently criticized _the ban on artificial birth control and divorce, mandatory priestly celibacy and the prohibition on women in the priesthood _ but he has not tolerated dissent or doubts about them. For him, the reforms of the Second Vatican Council in the 1960s were the church's revolution, and now it is a matter of containing their excesses. Kung, who has questioned papal infallibility, the celibacy rule and other church teachings, was stripped of his right to teach as an official Catholic theologian in December 1979, little more than a year into John Paul's reign. Pope Paul VI, who died in 1978, had merely warned Kung. In an interview with the Swiss newspaper Basler Zeitung in December, Kung said, ``The last diehards sit today in the Vatican, the last ones who have not yet realized that the world no longer tolerates authoritarian and totalitarian systems.'' The new U.S. statement, published in March as an advertisement in The New York Times, said the church was ``crippled by its failure to address fundamental justice issues within its own structures.'' Among the signatories was Emerson Moore, an auxiliary bishop in the New York archdiocese. These are the voices from the West. An important question for the pope is whether there will be voices of dissent from the East now that the church's long trial under communism is over. Moving quickly to keep pace with the political changes, John Paul, while in Czechoslovakia, called bishops from Eastern and Western Europe to an unprecedented synod to be held next year.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Video View: Home Video News and Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``The Little Mermaid'' (Disney. VHS-Beta, $26.99. Rated G)
The best video news these days is the availability of Walt Disney's ``The Little Mermaid'' for the home screen. This rhapsody of animated excellence has been sharply transferred to video, losing none of its richness and texture. And it's been priced at $26.99, making it accessible to just about all families. It's a movie that's worth embracing dozens of times, and you'll want to add it to your video library. Based on the Hans Christian Andersen story, the musical is the first animated feature based on a fairy tale from Walt Disney Pictures since ``Sleeping Beauty'' reached theaters on Jan. 29, 1959. No one does it like Disney, and Disney truly does it best. The drawings and backgrounds are full and brilliantly colored and tinted. Animation techniques incorporate the smallest and most insignificant nuance and detail, breathing life to both the sea world creatures and the humans above. The Disney characters move not with the plodding awkwardness of cartoon creatures, but with all the alacrity of live actors. When the mermaid Ariel moves through the sea there is an actual sense of water motion, of flotation. Her ruby hair fans out as she bobs in place; her tail eases through currents and actually propels. Sebastian the crab skitters sideways on tiny claws and shoots through the water with tiny legs moving like crazy. A storm at sea moves with the slashing ferocity of a real-life squall. Evening is misty and gray; the amber glow of lanterns illuminates the deck and crew at night; diamond-like fireworks sparkle in the midnight blue sky. The Disney animators, led by Mark Henn, Glen Keane, Duncan Marjoribanks, Ruben Aquino, Andreas Deja and Matthew O'Callaghan, really did their homework and understand the physics of swimming, floating, flying. The team of more than 400 artists and technicians spent more than three years on the project, with 150,000 painted cels and 1,100 backgrounds utilizing more than 1,000 colors. In the end, they produced 7,000 feet of hand-drawn film. If there's a scene stealer in ``The Little Mermaid,'' it's Sebastian, the kingdom's musical leader, who conducts two of the movie's most energetic and imaginative production numbers by Alan Menken and Howard Ashman: ``Kiss the Girl'' and ``Under the Sea.'' This a video for pure family fun and entertainment. ``The Little Mermaid'' is magic and joy for everyone, and teaches us all to never lose sight of dreams and hope.

``Thomas the Tank Engine & Friends'' (Strand VCI Entertainment. VHS, $14.95)
This set of videos based on ``The Railway Series'' by the Rev. W. Awdry and first published in 1945 might be a little esoteric for American children. The stories are very British, and entirely take place on the railroad tracks. With Ringo Starr as narrator, the stories include ``Thomas Gets Tricked'' and ``James Learns a Lesson,'' and feature live action animation. There are moral messages galore about friendship, believing in oneself and honesty _ all very good values for youngsters, and oldsters as well. But they are not presented in an entertaining fashion. If your child adores trains, let him or her check out the Thomas stories. Otherwise, you're much better off with mermaids under the sea.

``Harlem Nights'' (Paramount Home Video. VHS-Beta. Priced for rental market. Rated R).
Paramount Home Video wisely priced this Eddie Murphy disaster for the rental market rather than for sales. It's hardly worth the low cost of rental, let alone the $90 or so you'd have to spend if it were for sale. Murphy, who directed and wrote and was executive producer of ``Harlem Nights,'' has set his movie in the perfect era for interesting characters, situations, music and nuances _ 1938. His cast includes some of the jewels of vaudeville, film and television, including Richard Pryor, Della Reese, Redd Foxx, Danny Aiello and Arsenio Hall. But the movie is largely uninteresting and a turn off. The direction is tentative in spots, the pacing is as slow as molasses, and the dialogue, when not peppered with obscenities, is filled with lengthy explanations about what action the characters may or may not wish to take. Murphy's writing is about as snappy as a Sunday school lesson. The constant obscenities become a distraction and an eventual turnoff, and seem to be used when the writer and director can't invent something more creative. Surprisingly, it's not the two foul-mouthed bad boys of comedy who steal the show (Pryor and Murphy), but the women. Reese is fierce as Vera, the madam at Pryor's club. She's not just heavy, she's huge. And she literally swings her weight around as a cursing, tough, evil mama with a heart of gold. And then there's Sunshine (Lela Rochon), Vera's No. 1 whore. Sunshine's charms are so magnificent, one character says, she can make a man change his religion from Catholic to Baptist. It's worth suffering through this film just to catch Rochon, who has appeared in dozens of TV commercials and done guest stints on various sitcoms. She's a natural beauty and a comedic joy who has some of Judy Holliday's timing and Carole Lombard's sauciness. She's an actress to watch in the future.

Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian. X _ No one under 17 admitted. Some states may have higher age restrictions.

DOC.TEXT: Stock prices climbed to a record high Monday, building on their rally of the last two weeks as interest rates continued to ease. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 19.95 to 2,821.53, extending its gain since April 27 to 176.48 points. It surpassed its previous closing peak of 2,810.15, reached last Jan. 2. Most other, broader market measures remained below their former highs, however. The rally has been attributed to a sudden favorable swing in economic statistics of late, which has reduced worries about inflation and the interest-rate outlook.

Congressional Republicans say they hope to use budget negotiations to force domestic spending cuts, while all sides insisted they would not be the first to broach a possible tax hike. At the White House, where the talks open Tuesday, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Monday that President Bush would not make specific proposals to lawmakers but rather lay down his goals for the talks. The budget summit is designed to find $50 billion or more in savings _ either through spending cuts, tax increases or a combination of the two.

Economists say Federal Reserve policymakers likely will vote to leave interest rate policy unchanged. The policymakers are to meet on Tuesday. Analysts said Monday that most recent economic figures point to a weaker economy than earlier believed. As May began, nearly all signs suggested an economic rebound and rapid inflation and many of thse enalysts expected a credit-tightening move.

Businesses held inventories steady while increasing sales in March, the government said. The Commerce Department reported Monday that shelf and backlot inventories were unchanged at a seasonally adjusted $794 billion. Backlogs rose a revised 0.4 percent in February, originally reported to have fallen 0.4 percent. Sales rose 0.6 percent to a seasonally adjusted $539.1 billion following gains of 1.4 percent in February.

Shares of electronics giant NV Philips rebounded after a dramatic shakeup that saw its president and the head of its computer business resign due to a ``crisis of confidence'' among shareholders. News Monday President Cor van der Klugt would resign on July 1, a year before his scheduled retirement, pushed NV Philips Gloeilampenfabrieken up the equivalent of $1.05 to close at $17.57 a share in Amsterdam. The company's stock had plummeted 16.7 percent since the May 3 disclosure that Philips, a flagship of Dutch industry, had barely broken even during the first quarter of the year.

Jury selection in the securities fraud trial of Ivan Boesky associate John A. Mulheren Jr. began with questions about key players in Wall Street's insider trading scandal. About 100 citizens on the panel of potential jurors were asked in a questionnaire Monday whether they had ever heard of Michael Milken, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and Boesky, the convicted stock speculator who was Mulheren's one-time friend and business associate. Mulheren, 40, is on trial in U.S. District Court on 41 counts of conspiracy, securities fraud, mail fraud and record-keeping violations involving his relationship with Boesky.

Closing the United States to competition from foreign banks would be ineffective and prompt retaliation against U.S. banks, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan told a congressional panel. U.S. banks need less regulation, not protection from overseas financial institutions, to compete in a rapidly changing international marketplace, Greenspan and other witnesses told a subcommittee of the House Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs Committee on Monday.

Price-cutting schemes do not necessarily violate federal antitrust laws, even if they hurt a competitor's business, the Supreme Court ruled. The justices voted 7-2 on Monday to end a lawsuit against Atlantic Richfield Co. brought by independent gas stations in California and Washington state. The court said that only when a company's price-cutting can be proved to be ``predatory'' and harmful does it violate the federal Sherman Act, a major antitrust law.

The Gannett Foundation said it has had ``numerous expressions of interest'' from potential buyers since announcing it was exploring the sale of its 10 percent stake in media giant Gannett Co. Inc. The foundation disclosed April 25 that its trustees had voted to hire an investment banking firm to negotiate the possible sale of its 15.94 million shares of Gannett stock. On Monday, the foundation said it had hired the investment banking firm Salomon Brothers Inc. for the job.

Bond prices extended last week's rally in moderate actvity. The dollar finished mixed against other major currencies. Cocoa futures prices roared to their highest levels in more than year; oil futures rose sharply; soybeans plunged while grains were mixed; livestock and meat futures were mixed; and precious metals were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Rates Reach Three-Month Low
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities fell at the latest auction to their lowest level in three months. The Treasury Department on Monday sold $8.4 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.67 percent, down from 7.79 percent last week. The Treasury also sold $8.4 billion in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.68 percent, down from 7.84 percent last week. The rates were the lowest since Feb. 12, when both three-month and six-month bills sold for 7.65 percent. The discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 7.93 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,806.10 and 8.10 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,611.70. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, fell to 8.36 percent last week, down from 8.56 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Hachette Puts Woman's Day Up For Sale
DOC.TEXT: Woman's Day, one of the seven major women's service magazines, is being put up for sale so Hachette SA's U.S. publishing business can trim its debt and concentrate on magazines with international potential. The proposed sale comes amid sluggishness bordering on recession in the advertising environment for magazines that has been keenly felt at Woman's Day, the nation's 10th largest magazine by circulation last year. Industry analysts said Hachette's decision to abandon the fiercely competitive women's service segment illustrates the difficulty facing a company that owns only one title in competing against companies that each own two titles in the same category. The New York Times Co., Hearst Corp. and Meredith Corp. each own two of the so-called seven sisters publications. Hachette's Diamandis Communications Inc. said Monday it has hired the investment banker Veronis Suhler & Associates Inc. to conduct an auction for Woman's Day over the next several weeks. Circulation at Woman's Day fell 15.5 percent to 4.7 million last year, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations. That knocked it to sixth from third place among the seven sisters, leading only Redbook at 3.9 million. Advertising pages were down at four of the seven magazines in the first quarter of the year, with Woman's Day suffering the deepest drop at 22.1 percent. That was followed by a 19.1 percent decline at Family Circle, according to Publishers Information Bureau. The decision to sell Woman's Day, which was founded in 1937 and is sold mainly at the supermarket checkout counter, marks an abrupt reversal for Hachette. A year ago, Diamandis Communications was reported to have been close to an agreement to purchase McCall's magazine, another leading women's service magazine. But McCall's was sold instead for a reported more than $80 million to The New York Times Co., which also publishes Family Circle. Hearst owns Redbook and Good Housekeeping while Meredith owns Ladies Home Journal and Better Homes & Gardens. ``Hachette was finding it hard to compete on a stand-alone basis,'' said Peter Appert, who follows the media industry for C.J. Lawrence Morgan Grenfell. He said the other owners were able to attract advertisers by offering them package deals in both of their magazines. In doing so, he said owners of two magazines can often get more ad revenue overall than if the magazines were sold separately to advertisers. Richard Kostyra, who oversees evaluation of media for the ad agency J. Walter Thompson, said the women's service magazine field ``is one of the most competitive categories'' for attracting advertising. ``These magazines are oftentimes viewed interchangably. There is tremendous pressure'' on publishers to compete by offering ad rate discounts or other deals to advertisers, he said. Early speculation about who might be interested in Woman's Day included each of the current owners of women's magazines and Bauer Publishing Co. LP, the German company that brought out First for Women magazine last year. In announcing the proposed sale, Peter Diamandis, president and chief executive of Diamandis Communications, said the company wants to concentrate on creating or buying special interest magazines with an international appeal. The company already publishes 18 special interest magazines including Road & Track, Popular Photography and Boating. It also publishes the fashion magazine Elle, which is published in 17 countries. Didier Guerin, president of Hachette Publishing Inc., which oversees Diamandis Communications, said Woman's Day was not a good candidate for international expansion. He said the magazine ``is very American because of the way it is sold.'' Supermarket checkout sales are not popular outside the United States, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Campaign Planned to Fill Thousands of Manufacturing Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Manufacturing employment may be on the decline nationwide, but business leaders in Illinois are struggling to attract people to highly skilled, well-paying jobs in the precision metalworking and plastics industries. State business and government leaders launched a campaign Monday to attract workers into the industries, which need to fill an estimated 24,000 jobs in Illinois over the next five years. Businessmen say a shortage of young entrants to the labor market, a lack of knowledge about the field and a stigma against manufacturing work are hampering efforts to fill the jobs. ``The industry has had a chronic problem for many years in being able to attract and train skilled metal workers. Right now we're finding the shortage is getting even more severe,'' said Bruce Braker, executive vice president of the Chicago-area Tooling & Manufacturing Association. ``There simply are fewer young people coming into the labor market,'' he explained. ``The baby boomers are working. Right now, we've got the birth dearth.'' Association members were joined Monday by Gov. James R. Thompson, who outlined a statewide effort to help the group attract and train the new workers. Of the estimated 24,000 openings, 8,000 would be for skilled precision metalworkers and 16,000 for machine tool set-up and operating positions. ``Tool-and-die makers and machinists create the tooling that makes possible mass production of products, ranging from computers and satellites to automobiles and appliances,'' Thompson said in a statement. The state's departments of Commerce and Community Affairs, Employment Security and the Board of Education along with the mayor's Office of Economic Development will work with the association to recruit high school graduates and displaced workers into training programs operated by the association and community colleges. Precision metalworking jobs pay apprentices $15,000 to $20,000 a year and $25,000 to $55,000 with overtime for trained workers. The work involves fabricating parts that fit precisely, sometimes as accurately as within a micron, or 40-millionth of an inch, Braker explained. Braker said the group has created a special foundation to fund recruitment and training efforts. He said between 1,000 and 2,000 new workers are needed each year just to maintain overall employment, but so far the group is graduating only about 200 workers a year from its training program. ``You can't become a tool-and-die maker unless you can work with trigonometry'' and can read at the 11th- or 12th-grade level, he said. Precision metalworking has been primarily a white male industry, Braker said, so the industry must seek to attract more females and minorities. One problem, he said, is that upwardly mobile young people, white and black, usually want to go to college rather than into manufacturing. ``There's a generally negative perception of working in manufacturing or with your hands,'' Braker said. Many young people think of a factory as ``a traditionally dirty, noisy place to work. That's not the way it is anymore. These factories look like science laboratories.''

DOC.HEAD: Gannett Foundation Hires Salomon Brothers, Reports Interest in Gannett Stake
DOC.TEXT: The Gannett Foundation said it has had ``numerous expressions of interest'' from potential buyers since announcing its intention to sell its 10 percent stake in Gannett Co. Inc. The foundation disclosed April 25 that its trustees had voted to hire an investment banking firm to negotiate the possible sale of its 15.94 million shares of stock in the media company. On Monday, the foundation said it had hired Salomon Brothers Inc. for the job. The foundation's chairman, retired Gannett Co. boss Allen H. Neuharth, and its chief executive, Charles L. Overby, repeated their preference for selling the stock to the company or to an employee stock-option plan. ``But we have had numerous expressions of interest from other potential buyers and Salomon will explore all of those,'' they said in a statement. In trading Monday on the New York Stock Exchange, Gannett rose 12{ cents a share to $38.62{, making the foundation's stake worth about $616 million. The foundation is Gannett's largest shareholder. The proposed sale of the stake has raised questions about whether the newspaper, outdoor advertising and broadcasting company has been put into play as a possible takeover target. Shortly after the April 25 announcement by the foundation, Gannett Co. said the company reaffirmed its continuing interest in buying back its stock, subject to market prices, and noted it could buy more than 4.5 million shares under an existing repurchase program. But it added that the company had not by then decided whether it would be in a position to buy the stock being sold by the foundation. A Gannett spokeswoman said Monday the company still had not determined whether it will be a buyer of the stock. The foundation, established in 1935 and separate from the media company, said it was considering selling its stake because it had to seek higher income than paid by common stock dividends to meet the obligation imposed on foundations to pay out 5 percent of their assets annually. Gannett Foundation, based in Arlington, Va., had assets of nearly $650 million at the end of 1989 and spent $30 million on grants for journalism education, adult literacy, community projects and other philanthropic programs last year. Gannett Co., also based in Arlington, earned $397.5 million, or $2.47 share, on revenue of $3.52 billion in 1989. It owns 83 daily newspapers including USA Today and 52 non-daily publications, 10 television stations, 16 radio stations, Gannett News Services and the largest outdoor advertising companmy in North America.

DOC.HEAD: Union Hopes NLRB's Greyhound Decision Reopens Bargaining Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A federal investigator says Greyhound engaged in unfair labor practices in the 10-week-old drivers' walkout _ a potential victory for the union because it could force the company to give the drivers their jobs back. Jerry Hunter, the general counsel for the National Labor Relations Board, authorized the board's regional office in Milwaukee on Monday to file an unfair labor practice complaint against Greyhound, sources said. If the NLRB files the complaint and it is eventually upheld, it could force Greyhound to give back to union members the 3,000 jobs that the company gave to strikebreakers since the walkout began March 2. Union president Edward M. Strait said he considered Hunter's ruling a major victory because if upheld, ``it protects the seniority of our drivers.'' ``I'm so doggone happy ... I just hope that this will get the company back to the table and make them do some good-faith bargaining,'' Strait said. Greyhound said it would appeal any such complaint and predicted it would eventually win the issue. It noted that Hunter's ruling rejected a claim that the company had failed to bargain in good faith and instead focused on a more narrow issue. ``The replacement drivers we have hired have permanent jobs. That has not changed. ... We are confident we will prevail, and we will appeal all the way to the U.S. Supreme Court, should that be necessary,'' said Greyhound Vice President Anthony Lannie. Hunter concluded that Greyhound unlawfully put into effect certain bargaining proposals before an impasse was reached in negotiations, said sources who demanded anonymity. The decision was expected to be announced today. Both sides in the dispute, which involves 6,300 strikers who walked out over wages and job security, filed unfair labor complaints with the NLRB. While rejecting the union's contention that Greyhound had engaged in overall bad-faith bargaining, Hunter found merit with a union complaint over the illegal implementation of bargaining proposals before an impasse, said the sources, who declined to identify the proposals at issue. The union also had complained it was illegal for Greyhound to refuse to negotiate until a week passed without violence, but Hunter rejected the claim, calling the stall legal under the circumstances. There were dozens of shootings and bomb threats in the first several weeks of the strike. The union lost on one front _ Hunter asked the NLRB to seek an injunction against the union to stop alleged picket line misconduct and violence. Hunter's decision could have a huge impact because under federal law, it would make the Greyhound dispute an unfair labor practice strike rather than a dispute over economic issues. That is relevant because when a strike is determined to be an unfair labor practice dispute, employers who hire permanent replacements must fill all jobs on a seniority basis, essentially giving preference to union members who were employed there before the strike. The victory is especially key in the Greyhound dispute because the company just last week declared the strike over, from a practical standpoint, since it has hired about 3,000 replacement drivers and said it can get by without union drivers. The company offered the union only about 620 immediate jobs back _ an offer the union called an insult _ and vowed to give remaining jobs to replacement drivers if the union did not accept its offer for a four-year wage freeze and eliminating 4,500 union jobs. That offer followed a company announcement that Greyhound lost $56 million in the first quarter of 1990.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls, Stocks Slip
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against the Japanese yen for the fifth consecutive trading day today, while the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index slipped moderately. The dollar closed at 151.30 yen, down 2.05 yen from Monday's close of 153.35 yen. After opening at 151.82 yen, it ranged between 150.85 yen and 152.15 yen. The dollar has declined 6.75 yen in five days. Its close today was its lowest since 151.15 on March 9. Kozo Yoshida, a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank, said the yen's strength was a ``reaction to its slide against the dollar'' over the past several weeks. ``A couple of recent U.S. economic indicators showing a slowdown in the American economy also contributed to dollar-selling,'' Yoshida said. Further U.S. indicators are to be released this week in Washington. They include the consumer price index and housing starts in April, both to be announced on Wednesday, and the nation's trade figures for March, due out Thursday. Yoshida said the dollar's direction will become clearer after those reports. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues lost 45.61 points, or 0.14 percent, closing at 31,997.04 points. The index started slightly lower, but was up 73.34 points at the end of the morning session. It declined in the afternoon, partly on profit-taking, said Yu Yoshida, an equity analyst with Yamaichi Securities. Today's decline followed a 530.51-point gain on Monday and a 531.88-point gain Friday. The decline was a technical adjustment after a rise that the market considered too rapid, said Yoshida. But he said the market environment remains favorable to investors, with the yen stronger against the dollar and interest rates declining. Their yield declined to 6.920 percent from the previous day's 6.985 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Newspapers Publish Controversial Pickens Advertisement
DOC.TEXT: Major Japanese newspapers published ads Tuesday from Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens that accuse the country's biggest automakers of colluding to keep consumer prices high and some shareholder dividends low. Pickens accused Toyota Motor Co. and its powerful advertising agency Dentsu last week of attempting to block publication of the ads, which contend that collusive business practices force higher prices on consumers. Toyota and Dentsu denied the allegations. The takeover strategist charged that Toyota intervened because of his battle to exercise ownership rights in Koito Manufacturing Co., an auto lighting equipment maker close to Toyota. Pickens is the largest stockholder in Koito. The Asahi Shimbun, the Nihon Keizai Shimbun and the Yomiuri Shimbun, all major dailies, published identical ads from Pickens in their Tuesday morning editions. None of the ads, which also blame Japan's big automakers for low returns to shareholders of auto parts companies, mentioned any automaker by name. Pickens' lawyer, Kanji Ishizumi, said the ad as originally submitted named Toyota, Honda and Nissan Motor Co. as leaders of separate automobile keiretsu, or business groups, that force their auto parts makers to sell parts at low prices. However, Ishizumi said, he was forced to drop their names because it was the only way to get the ads published. Ishizumi said the fact that all three newspapers ran the same ad on the same day illustrates the degree to which the move was calculated after Pickens made his charges public. ``After media coverage of the issue, the newspapers compromised and printed the ads,'' Ishizumi said. Pickens' laywer said he was disappointed the newspapers did not comply with his request to run the ad on staggered days. ``It's like fireworks, everyone will read the ad and forget about it at once,'' he said. ``The auto industry is booming, but because of the keiretsu we believe auto parts makers are forced to sell their parts at inappropriately low prices to the makers,'' the published ads said. ``We think the automakers, as a group, damage the profits of auto parts makers and reduce the dividends of shareholders by beating down the prices of auto parts,'' the ad said. Last week, a representive of the Yomiuri Shimbun said the ad had been rejected twice, but that the daily paper was considering using the ad if it dropped references to Toyota and Honda, two of the newspaper's biggest advertising clients. The paper was concerned the ad might confuse consumers, added Ikuo Terai of the Yomiuri's advertising department. The Nihon Keizai Shimbun denied five days ago that any representative of Pickens had approached the paper to publish the ad. Pickens has said he tried to place the ads in an effort to motivate the Japanese public to complain about how the big business cartels force higher prices on consumers. The ad requests that Japanese consumers with any information on ``unfair practices'' among carmakers to send it to Pickens in Dallas, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Planning Corvette Competitor
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. will begin limited production of a two-seat, high-performance Dodge Viper car that reportedly will rival the Chevrolet Corvette, a Chrysler source said today. The source, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said an announcement that the No. 3 automaker will begin production of the car in late 1991 would be made Friday in Los Angeles. Such an announcement seems unusual for a company battling shrinking profits and market share, and working to cut $1.5 billion from its standing costs by the end of this year. The source declined to say where the car would be built, but that all major components would be made by Chrysler. The price of the car will not be announced until just before it becomes available, the source said. The car will be powered by a V-10 engine, according to the source. There have been reports that the car may carry a V-8, but the source said a major aim of the Viper project was development of the V-10, originally conceived for truck use. According to next Monday's edition of AutoWeek magazine, the V-10 engine is capable of reaching 100 mph from a standing start in less than 10 seconds. A Corvette ZR-1 takes about 11.5 seconds, according to a road test in Road & Track magazine. The announcement of Viper's production will be during the last of a six-city road show Chrysler has been conducting since March. The program is aimed at boosting interest in Chrysler products and quality. A concept version of the Viper made its debut in January 1989 at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit. Chrysler Motors President Robert Lutz, design Vice President Thomas Gale and other executives have backed efforts to make Viper. Gale said last year the Viper was the first project to result from Chrysler's conceptual design and rendering system. The computer-driven system could cut by 25 percent the amount of time needed to bring a totally new car to market, Gale said.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 440.61 down 1.00 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: IBM To Expand Software That Links Phones and Computers
DOC.TEXT: IBM said Tuesday it would enhance its CallPath software, which links corporate phone systems with computer data bases, so that the software will work with many brands of phone systems. Currently, CallPath only works with phone systems made by Rolm, the telephone equipment maker owned jointly by International Business Machines Corp. and Siemens AG of West Germany. CallPath allows a company such as a mail order house to link an incoming phone call from a customer with that customer's records in the company's IBM computer. The system displays the customer's records on a computer screen in front of a customer service representative as the employee answers the phone. CallPath also allows a company to transfer both a telephone call from a customer and that customer's computerized records from one employee to another, such as from a customer service representative to a supervisor. CallPath works through corporate phone systems called private branch exchanges, or PBXs. IBM said two additional telephone equipment makers, Siemens and Northern Telecom Inc., have announced their PBXs will have the capability to be linked to the enhanced CallPath. IBM also said it has reached an agreement with American Telephone & Telegraph Co. to work on making CallPath compatibrgi-Center, said a clinic spokeswoman who declined to give her name. Oberdorfer, Eisenstein showed videotapes of three November demonstrations in an effort to prove that Operation Rescue, Project Rescue and their leaders violated Oberdorfer's injunction. If we were homosexuals, does anyone really think that we would be denied access to a public sidewalk?'' Terry said.

DOC.HEAD: Surge to Record High Persuades Many Investors Rally Will Persist
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 6th graf pvs with noon Dow average level down about 3 points.
DOC.TEXT: A surge in the Dow Jones industrial average to a new record high is persuading many investors that the two-week-old stock market rally is far from over. The optimism about stocks reflects a growing belief that inflation and interest rates are headed lower, a sharp turnaround in sentiment from just last month. ``You can almost hear the opinion change,'' said John Connolly, head of the investment policy committee at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``Money that's frozen out of this market wants to get in.'' ``I think it's a big bull market,'' said Michael Metz, managing director and investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Co. ``Nobody's in the market. Everybody's underinvested.'' The widely followed Dow Jones average of 30 blue-chip industrial stocks rose 19.95 Monday to 2,821.53, topping the previous record close of 2,810.15 set on Jan. 2. The Dow average retreated about 3 points by noon today to the 2,818 level in what brokers called a brief respite from ``profit-takers,'' investors who cash in their stock to lock in a gain. The average has risen by more than 170 points or about 7 percent since April 27. Broader market indicators also advanced strongly Monday, and about two issues rose in price for every one that declined on the New York Stock Exchange. The turnaround in sentiment has been so swift that many investors have missed the rally, analysts said. Cautious individuals and institutional investors have built up big cash positions, and they should propel stocks to new highs in coming weeks and months as they put that cash to work, they said. Stock market activity had been very light and prices had traded within a modest range earlier this year because of concerns about prices and interest rates. Inflation ran at a rate of more than 8 percent in the first quarter, the highest rate since the early 1980s, and other indicators suggested the economy was growing at a too-fast pace that would only worsen price pressures. Economic indicators for April released in the last two weeks have alleviated many of those concerns, however. The unemployment rate ticked up to 5.2 percent, wages rose only modestly despite a hike in the minimum wage and prices at the wholesale level declined. Most economists believe the Federal Reserve's policy-making body will leave its interest rate stance unchanged at its meeting today. Two weeks ago, many analysts were predicting the fed would boost rates to combat inflation. Reflecting that belief, interest rates kept falling Monday after plunging on Friday. Yields on long-term government bonds, which topped 9 percent at the start of the month, fell to 8.58 percent. Falling rates are seen as stimulating business activity, which would be good for corporate profits. And by reducing the returns on interest-bearing investments, lower rates can prompt investors to switch funds to the stock market. High rates on safe, short-term debt instruments like Treasury bills had been ``irresistible'' and kept many investors out of stocks, Metz said. Individual investors now have less than 20 percent of their funds in the stock market, the lowest level in 20 years, he said. Mutual funds also have been wary of stocks, letting cash and short-term debt securities rise to 12 percent of their portfolios, the highest level since the 1982 bear market, he said. A slowdown in inflation and credit demand and an increase in savings should push rates on three-month T-bills down to 6{ percent this summer from 7.87 percent Monday, Metz predicted. That should send money into stocks and drive the Dow industrials toward 3,000, he added. Connolly said the Dow could hit 3,200 in the next year if the scenario of sluggish economic growth and slower inflation holds. The upside for stocks could be even bigger, he added, if Congress and the Bush administration reach an agreement to cut the budget deficit significantly, which should drive interest rates lower still. Stocks should gain even without a notable improvement in corporate earnings because the market today is driven mostly by the outlook for interest rates, Connolly said. Norm Wolff, technical market analyst at A.G. Edwards & Sons, Inc. in St. Louis, said there is some resistance to further declines in bond yields, which could hurt stocks. Also, the stock market is likely to give up some of its gains in the next few days as investors take profits on the rally. Nevertheless, the market's surge Friday and Monday was broadly based, affecting smaller stocks as well as the big blue chips that started the rally, Wolff noted. That bodes well for coming weeks, he said. ``As long as the breadth continues, you've got to play it from the long side,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Sony Introduces Compact Disc-Based Electronic Books
DOC.TEXT: Sony Corp., the brains behind the ubiquitous Walkman stereo, said Tuesday it will introduce an ``electronic book'' system that uses a palm-sized player for reading books recorded on 3-inch compact discs. Sony's ``Data Discman'' player has a screen that displays text recorded on CDs called Electronic Books that each can store about 100,000 pages of text _ more than 300 paperback books, Sony officials said. ``The purpose of this product is to create an entirely new market. Instead of having to go to a library or bookshelf for information, people can have access to it anytime and anywhere,'' said Sunobu Horigome, head of Sony's General Audio Group. He said Sony hopes the product will create a ``new culture'' and approach to information access, with an impact similar to its Walkman portable stereos. If successful, Sony's reward could be big. In two years, the Japanese market alone for CD information discs, including the new CD books, is expected to grow to about $2.6 billion, according to Hideo Nishikawa, general manager of new media development for the publishing house Iwanami Shoten. Sony said it plans to begin marketing the machine in Japan on July 1 for about $380. Overseas sales are expected to begin in less than a year, after arrangements with local publishers are made, officials said. The Data Discman comes with a CD containing five different English- and Japanese-language dictionaries, and can be plugged into a regular television screen to create a larger display. Users also can listen to regular 3-inch audio CDs with an earphone. A small typewriter-like keyboard allows a user to select particular entries or portions of the text. Twenty-eight Japanese publishing companies have formed an Electronic Book committee that cooperated with Sony in developing the format, said Nishikawa. Eighteen CD Electronic Book titles will be released at the same time as the Data Discman. Titles will include reference books and guides to medicine, movies, travel and entertainment, he said. Electronic Books are likely to cost an average $20 to $33, Nishikawa said. ``Novels are certainly possible, but the question is how successful they will be because of the small screen,'' a Sony official said. The screen can display only 10 lines at a time, but can be ``scrolled'' up or down. Both the CDs and player will be sold through regular bookstores. The player's built-in software allows it to display indexes and quickly find particular portions of the text. In an Electronic Book containing thousands of song lyrics, for example, it can search for those from different time periods or with different styles, or those with particular themes or words in their titles. Other companies also will be able to obtain licenses to produce Electronic Books and players, Sony officials said. Compact discs use digital codes to record information ranging from music to computer programs or databases. Those that contain data used by computers are called CD-ROM, or CD read only memory, because they generally cannot be altered or re-recorded. The Electronic Books use a technical standard similar to CD-ROM, Sony officials said.

With movement in London shares closely tied to Wall Street's performance, a weak opening in New York didn't leave much room for gains, traders said. Although there were indications earlier in the day that London might be consolidating from its 38.6-point advance Monday before moving higher, dealers turned skeptical by the end of the session. ``The market is tired,'' said one trader. ``It's had a big rally up and there's nothing behind it.'' Amid fundamentally bearish tidings for the British economy and uncertainty about the economic direction of the United States, dealers said they saw no good reason for players to jump into the London market.

DOC.HEAD: White House-Congressional Budget Talks Begin
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs talks under way; picks up 2nd graf pvs, `If everybody ...'. Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and leaders of Congress began negotiations today aimed at finding a way to break a political deadlock over next year's federal deficit. Bush, Vice President Dan Quayle, and top administration officials were joined by congressional leaders of both parties in the White House Cabinet Room. They sat at a long table adorned with plates of pastries but answered no questions about where their talks would head. Earlier in the day, House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, who heads Democratic participants in the negotiations, predicted the talks will fail if participants use them to seek political gains. ``If everybody tries to politicize this, nothing will be accomplished,'' said Gephardt, D-Mo. He spoke several hours before Bush and congressional leaders were to begin negotiations over next year's $1.2 trillion spending plan. At the White House, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said that, while President Bush would not put forth any administration proposals at today's opening session, ``we'll make proposals'' in later meetings. Fitzwater called the summit a ``feet on the floor and hands on the table'' session. And, reiterating administration assertions that nothing was off the bargaining table, Fitzwater told reporters: ``No preconditions, no preconditions, no preconditions.'' Many Democrats have said they want Bush to lead the way in proposing any eletion-year taxes or spending cuts. ``We have one goal,'' Gephardt said. ``That's to do this as fast as we can and see if any good can result for the fiscal policy of this country.'' The goal is to shrink next year's federal deficit, a task the administration says means coming up with $50 billion or more in savings. Fiscal 1991 begins Oct. 1. Stung by the ``tax and spend'' label President Reagan attached to them in the 1980s, Democrats say they want Bush to detail the size of the deficit problem and to lay out his suggested solutions. They point out that in the 1991 budget he proposed in January, he put the needed savings at $36 billion. Democrats promised Monday that little will happen at the talks until the president describes why the problem has worsened. They also demanded that Bush help build congressional support by explaining to the public why unpopular, painful measures may be necessary. ``I want to hear what more do we need, why do we need it, and what are the choices the president will accept,'' said Rep. William H. Gray III, D-Pa., the No. 3 House Democrat and one of the negotiators. ``Failure to say those things will mean a deadlocked summit. ``If those things are only said within the closed door of the summit, I think that means a failure to put together a meaningful package, because we won't be able to pass it,'' Gray said. White House officials said Bush had no plans to lay out his own ideas about reducing the deficit. ``He'll have general goals about getting the deficit down,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Republicans say they will focus on spending cuts as a way to reduce the budget gap. They are particularly concerned about benefit programs _ referred to as entitlements _ such as Medicare and federal employee retirement payments, which account for about half of all federal spending each year. They also want to tighten the budget law to ensure that any spending cuts end up as savings and are not simply transferred to other programs. ``Whatever we agree upon _ expenditure reductions, entitlement reforms, revenues _ you have to be able to say they won't be spent, but they have to go as designed to deficit reduction,'' said Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico, the ranking Republican on the Senate Budget Committee and one of the bargainers. Democrats will focus more on cutting the defense budget. As for taxes, members of both parties say they will wait for the other side to bring them up. ``If there are going to be revenues, they'll have to propose them,'' said Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., the Senate Budget Committee chairman and another negotiator. The talks were announced last week, with both sides saying all options were negotiable. This represented a departure from Bush's 1988 campaign pledge not to raise taxes. Democrats began worrying that they might be heading toward a trap, however, after White House chief of staff John Sununu said last Wednesday that the president would never seriously consider tax increases. The White House quickly disavowed Sununu's comment, but Democratic feelings have remained bruised. One administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said budget director Richard Darman would explain why the administration feels the deficit has taken a turn for the worse. The reasons include the growing costs of the savings and loan industry bailout, fears of higher interest rates and tax collections that have been lower than projected. After that, the official said, opening statements and other preliminary remarks could last until next week. There will be 21 congressional negotiators and four administration bargainers, not including Bush. Administration officials and lawmakers have said the talks could last weeks or months. The Gramm-Rudman budget-balancing law requires a deficit of no more than $64 billion next year.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel OKs Assistant Treasury Secretary to Federal Reserve Board
DOC.TEXT: The nomination of Assistant Treasury Secretary David W. Mullins Jr. to a vacant seat on the seven-member Federal Reserve Board was endorsed Tuesday by the Senate Banking Committee. The committee voted 18-0 to forward the nomination to the full Senate, which was expected to approve it. Mullins, 44, is one of the architect's of President Bush's savings and loan bailout. He was a Harvard business professor before moving to the Treasury in October 1988. He was nominated to fill the six years remaining in the term of H. Robert Heller, who resigned.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Credit System Reports Earnings Rise in First Qtr
DOC.TEXT: The Farm Credit System said Tuesday its net income rose 8.5 percent in the first quarter, reflecting the retirement of higher-cost debt and continued improvement in the quality of its loan portfolio. The system said it earned $191 million in the three months ended March 31 compared with $176 million a year earlier. The Farm Credit System is a nationwide network of federally-chartered agricultural lending institutions that are cooperatively owned by their borrowers. The system is the biggest lender to the nation's farms. ``The improvement in net income resulted in large part from the system's continuing efforts to enhance credit quality and to emphasize asset and liability management,'' said James A. Brickley, president and chief executive of the Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corp., the system's financing arm. The system said its net interest income rose to $321 million in the latest quarter from $239 million in the same period a year ago. The rise stemmed mainly from the retirement of higher-cost debt that matured over the past year, the system said. In addition, it said the improvement reflected higher credit quality of the loan portfolio, reflected mainly by a reduction in nonaccrual loans to $2.51 billion on March 31 from $2.55 billion on Dec. 31. Loans placed on nonaccrual status are accounted for only as payments are made, rather than when they are due.

The stock market paused today, with prices mostly lower following powerful rallies during the previous two sessions that propelled the Dow Jones average to unprecedented levels. ``We're resting right now,'' said Robert O'Toole, manager of over-the-counter trading at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in New York. ``People are saying, `Hey this is nice, let's sell some stock.''' The Dow Jones industrial average, the best-known barometer on Wall Street, was up a scant 0.23 to 2,821.76 as of 3 p.m. EDT after having fallen earlier in the session. On Monday, the average rose 19.95 to a record high of 2,821.53, bringing its gain since April 27 to 176.48 points. The broader market remained in negative territory. Declining issues had a lead of about 7 to 6 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 609 up, 866 down and 502 unchanged. Brokers said they believed the respite was temporary and the market would inevitably turn higher again on the strength of optimism over lower interest rates, which would makes stocks a more attractive investment. Volume on the Big Board came to 137.37 million shares with one hour of trading left. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks was down 0.32 to 193.33. On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 1.00 to 355.54. Philip Morris, topping the NYSE's most active list, was off [ at 44|. Among other blue chips, American Express was up 1 to 30\, General Motors was up \ to 48[ and Exxon was down ] to 47|. The stock market's rally in the last two weeks has been attributed to evidence that inflation is easing, which has sent interest rates plunging. The market also has been bolstered by the perception that the Bush administration and Congress are willing to negotiate to reduce the nation's budget deficit.

DOC.HEAD: Manufacturers Hanover Announces Organizational Restructuring
DOC.TEXT: Manufacturers Hanover Corp. said Tuesday it was revamping its organizational structure so that the nation's eighth-largest banking concern will be split into four key groups, effectively removing a layer of management. The bank also announced the resignation of 22-year veteran David Ebert, who once headed the company's retail division and most recently served as sector exective vice president for investment banking. Manufacturers Hanover established divisions in global banking, regional banking, operating services and developing markets, with the office of the chairman overseeing those operations. Chairman John F. McGillicuddy will oversee the developing markets group, which is responsible for managing the bank's Third World debt portfolio, the bank said. President Thomas S. Johnson will oversee the global banking group. Edward D. Miller will oversee operating services, which includes its processing center, and regional banking, which includes real estate lending and the credit-card franchise. ``By removing a layer of management, we are deploying our most experienced people to where they can be closer to our wholesale clients,'' Johnson said. ``We will be lighter on our feet, able to marshall quickly a wide range of capabilities to custom-tailor what a client requries.'' James J. McDermott Jr., a banking analyst with Keefe Bruyette & Woods in New York, said there were little surprises in the announced changes. ``They formalize a process of reorganization under way for a period of time that give the corporation a better business focus,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean, Corn Futures Plunge
DOC.TEXT: Corn and soybean futures prices closed sharply lower Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade, leading a general decline that reflected profit-taking and aggressive liquidation of bullish positions, analysts said. The drop in soybean prices extended losses that now total about 35 cents a bushel since Thursday in the contract for May delivery. The soybean sell-off began Friday after the Agriculture Department released a higher-than-expected 1990 soybean crop estimate. The corn market posted its steepest one-day decline this year after recently advancing amid concerns about rain-delayed planting activity. The sudden drop in crop futures may have been linked to market talk of turmoil in the Soviet Union and fears of a change in Soviet leadership that could potentially reduce grain sales to Moscow. The Memphis-based analytical firm Sparks Commodities Inc. released new projections of corn and soybean plantings Tuesday. The soybean estimate of 58.9 million acres was below the USDA's latest forecast of 59.4 million while Sparks' corn estimate of 75.5 million acres was above the USDA's projection of 74.8 million. ``The Sparks numbers were bullish on beans and bearish on corn but that's not the way the market acted,'' said John Frazier, director of agricultural commodities trading for Gerald Inc. in Chicago. At the close, wheat futres were 1 cent to 2 cents lower with the contract for delivery in May at $3.83 a bushel; corn was 4{ cents to 6} cents lower with May at $2.84\ a bushel; oats were 1{ cents lower to \ cent higher with May at $1.55 a bushel; soybeans were 8 cents to 11} cents lower with May at $6.13 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Reports Decline in Nine-Month Earnings
DOC.TEXT: News Corp. Ltd., the multinational media and entertainment concern headed by Rupert Murdoch, said Tuesday its earnings tumbled 74.1 percent for the first nine months of its fiscal year. The Australian company said it had a strong performance in the United States, especially from its television stations and its Fox Broadcasting Co. It said profits from U.S. magazines, which include TV Guide, Seventeen, New York and Soap Opera Digest, remained strong despite a soft advertising market. The company said its overall earnings would have exceeded last year's results except for losses associated with its Sky Television service in Great Britain and its investment in Ansett Airlines, an Australian carrier whose results have been hurt by a dispute with pilots. News Corp. reported a profit of 121.2 million Australian dollars, or about $93 million, in the nine months ended March 31 compared with 467.1 million Australian dollars, or $384.8 million, in the same period a year earlier. The company said its earnings amounted to 74 cents per American Depositary Receipt, down from $2.41 per ADR a year earlier. Each of its ADRs, which are traded on the New York Stock Exchange, represent two ordinary shares. Nine-month revenue rose 14.4 percent to 6.28 billion Australian dollars, or $4.8 billion, from 5.50 billion Australian dollars a year earlier. Operating profits were up for operations in Australia and the Pacific Basin because of improved newspaper and commercial printing operations, the company said, while operating results fell in the United Kingdom because of the impact of the Sky Television startup as newspaper results there held steady. The company said it has lost 179 million Australian dollars on Sky Television since September 1989, but said the pace of the losses are declining with accelerated installation of receivers and dishes. The four-channel, satellite-delivered service claims 1.4 million viewing households, including 526,000 subscribers to its premium network, Sky Movie Channel. In the United States, News Corp. owns three newspapers and 11 magazines and has a 50 percent stake in the book concern Harper & Row Publishers. It owns the Twentieth Century Fox Film Corp., six TV stations and the Fox TV network.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Ready To Announce New, Pumped-Up Sports Car
LaserPhoto DT4
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. has decided to produce its proposed Viper sports car featuring a 10-cylinder engine, a source said Tuesday, a move apparently designed to polish the image of the struggling carmaker. The Dodge Viper, equipped with an engine originally designed for truck use, will go into extremely low-volume production late next year for the 1992 model year, said a company source speaking on condition of anonymity. ``Anything that shows people that Dodge is back in the performance business is good news,'' said David Slone, general sales manager of Lynn Hickey Dodge in Oklahoma City. A Viper prototype was introduced last year at an annual auto show in Detroit and drew huge crowds. The two-seat convertible is a throwback to the era of sleek, muscular sports cars with few electronic gadgets. The prototype has been part of a six-city tour this spring during which Chrysler executives have touted the quality of the company's vehicles, comparing them favorably with those made by Japanese automakers. The tour winds up Friday in Los Angeles, where Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca is expected to announce that the Viper will go into production. Such an announcement would come as Chrysler car sales and profits slip and as the company struggles to carve $1.5 billion from its annual $26 billion budget. The cost of the Viper project hasn't been pinpointed. Despite that expense at a time when the company is trimming back, analysts and dealers on Tuesday were enthusiastic about the project, not only because of the exotic nature of the car, but because of the traffic it can draw to dealerships. Slone said he already has noticed an increase in traffic through his showroom just because of media attention the Viper has received. ``We've had people wanting to put deposits down on it,'' he said. The car's price won't be announced until just before it hits the showrooms. AutoWeek magazine said it could be in the $40,000 range. The Viper would be entering the exotic sports-car market, broadly comprised of the Corvette ZR-1, some BMWs and Porsches. No firm performance statistics were available, but AutoWeek magazine reported that with the V-10 engine, the Viper could go from a standing start to 100 mph in less than 10 seconds. The ZR-1, the hottest Corvette ever, takes 11.5 seconds to get to 100 mph, according to a Road & Track magazine road test. ``There is an enthusiasts' market out there,'' said auto analyst Mary Anne Sudol of Fitch Investors Service Inc. in New York. ``I think there is room in the market for it (Viper). I think the hot cars carry fairly nice (profit) margins and you wouldn't have to put an incentive on them. ``I think it will make people sit up and notice Chrysler even though there aren't many (Vipers) around. It's what they can do in styling and performance.'' The prototype has distinctive door panels with chrome-plated exhaust pipes running below them. A spy photo appearing in the June issue of Car and Driver magazine shows a Viper without the side-mounted pipes. The source said all major components of the car would be made by Chrysler. The source declined to reveal the final assembly site, but said it would be an existing Chrysler factory. Production figures weren't available, but it could be as low as a few hundred a year. By contrast, General Motors Corp. sold about 24,000 Corvettes last year, before the introduction of the ZR-1 model. Chrysler has said that the Viper was the first project to result from the carmaker's conceptual design and rendering system. The computer-driven system could cut by 25 percent the amount of time needed to bring a totally new car to market, Chrysler officials said.
The stock market took a breather today after sharp gains the previous two sessions. Five minutes before the close, the Dow Jones industrial average was up 1.16 to 2,822.69.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Pause, But Dow Jones Average Reaches New High
DOC.TEXT: Wall Street took a breather today, with the Dow Jones industrial average inching its way up to a new closing high but the prices of most stocks ending lower. The Dow Jones average, which reflects the performance of 30 blue chip stocks, rose 0.92 to 2,822.45, just eclipsing the record high of 2,821.53 set on Monday. Today's advance brought to 177.40 points the surge in Wall Street's best-known barometer since April 27. The broader market remained in negative territory today. ``We're resting right now,'' said Robert O'Toole, manager of over-the-counter trading at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in New York. ``People are saying, `Hey this is nice, let's sell some stock.''' Brokers said they believed the respite was temporary and the market would inevitably turn higher again on the strength of optimism over lower interest rates, which would makes stocks a more attractive investment. The stock market's rally in the last two weeks has been attributed to evidence that inflation is easing, which has sent interest rates plunging. The market also has been bolstered by the perception that the Bush administration and Congress are willing to negotiate to reduce the nation's budget deficit.
