DOC.TEXT: Declining issues outnumbered advancers by about 4 to 3 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 641 up, 847 down and 514 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 165.73 million shares, down sharply from 225.41 million in the previous session. The NYSE's composite index fell 0.34 to 193.31.. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index slipped 0.78 to 353.56.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Retreats on Profit-Taking, Gasoline Rises
DOC.TEXT: Crude and heating-oil pricesfell slightly Tuesday, weakened by speculators cashing in the market's gains, but gasoline strengthened because of impending higher demand from summer vacationers. Energy brokers said most of the movement in prices was predictable and didn't reflect any particular outside news or sudden shift in market psychology. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the next-month delivery price of West Texas Intermediate, the key grade of U.S. crude, closed at $19.59 a barrel, down from $19.71 Monday. Later-month contracts were mixed. On Monday, WTI for June delivery jumped 79 cents a barrel, largely because of word that Saudi Arabia, a leading producer and the most important member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, had cut production as promised in an earlier OPEC agreement aimed at reducing a worldwide glut. Among refined products traded on the exchange, wholesale heating oil for June delivery fell to 51.72 cents a gallon from 52.43 cents Monday. Later contract months also declined. Natural gas for June delivery fell to $1.552 per 1,000 cubic feet from $1.556 Monday. Later contract months were mixed. Wholesale unleaded gasoline for June delivery rallied to 63.51 cents a gallon from 62.97 cents Monday. Market strategists attributed the strength to expectations of higher demand as of Memorial Day weekend starting May 26, regarded by the recreation industry as the beginning of summer. ``We're getting closer to the official start of gasoline season,'' said Peter Beutel, assistant director of the energy group at Elders Futures Inc. in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Higher, Gold Ends Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar firmed Tuesday against most major currencies in light trading. Gold prices rebounded after falling overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $370.90 a troy ounce, up $2.50 from late Monday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $370.25 an ounce, up $2.15. The currency market seemed to shrug off the latest economic report by the Federal Reserve on Tuesday, which showed industrial production fell 0.4 percent in April, its first decline since January, dealers said. They said attention is turned toward the release Wednesday of April consumer prices and Thursday's March trade data for further indications of the direction of the U.S. economy and interest rates. Earl Johnson, a currency dealer with Harris Trust & Co. in Chicago, said the market is predicting higher inflation and a further worsening of the nation's trade deficit. ``We're in a bearish climate right now,'' he said. For Tuesday, dealers said the dollar's strength came partly at the expense of other currencies, particularly the West German mark and British pound. The mark remained under pressure, they said, following the surprisingly weak showing in recent state elections by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's conservative party. Those results brought some uncertainty about the pending reunification with East Germany, dealers said. The British pound fell against the dollar after Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said she supported efforts by Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major to lower the current official interest rate of 15 percent by year's end. In Tokyo, where the global trading day begins, the dollar fell against the Japanese yen to close at 151.30 yen from 153.35 yen Monday. The dollar traded at 151.37 yen in London, and closed at 150.83 yen in New York, down from 152.50 yen Monday. The dollar was stronger against the British pound. Sterling cost $1.6775 in London, less than the $1.6817 Monday, and $1.6725 in New York, down from $1.6825. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's quotes, included: 1.6465 West German marks, up from 1.6428; 1.3980 Swiss francs, up from 1.3915; 5.5540 French francs, up from 5.5360; 1,211.25 Italian lire, up from 1,208.00; and 1.17695 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17715. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with Monday: 1.6467 West German marks, up from 1.6443; 1.3977 Swiss francs, up from 1.3952; 5.5480 French francs, up from 5.5430; 1.8476 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8472; 1,210.50 Italian lire, up from 1,209.75; and 1.1808 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1767. Gold fell in London to $367.75 an ounce from $369.75, and in Zurich to $367.50 an ounce from $368.75. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at $368.05 an ounce, down from $368.35. Silver prices declined. Silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.012 a troy ounce, down from $5.066 Monday. Silver fell in London to $5.07 an ounce from $5.09.

DOC.HEAD: Broadcaster Reports Loss in 1st Qtr
DOC.TEXT: Great American Communications Co., which owns 23 radio and television stations and Hanna-Barbera Productions, on Tuesday reported a loss of $35.2 million for the three months ending March 31. Meanwhile, the company denied a report published in The Wall Street Journal that it is negotiating to sell Hanna-Barbera to MCA Inc. to raise cash. ``Hanna-Barbera has not been put up for sale,'' spokeswoman Sandra Heimann said. She declined to say whether Great American has received any offers to buy the division. MCA, a California-based entertainment company, declined comment on the story which said the talks were said to be very preliminary. The loss of $1 a share compared with a loss of $24 million, or 76 cents per share, in the same period in 1989. Revenue for the first quarter was virtually flat at $61.5 million compared with $61.4 million in 1989. Great American cited slack advertising demand in the first quarter, which the company said is normally its weakest period of the year. The company said it expects to continue to report large losses for the next several years because of substantial interest charges and significant non-cash charges for depreciation and amortization of intangible assets. Great American said it is continuing to sell assets outside its core businesses to reduce debt. The company has put up for sale its 46 percent stake in Spelling Entertainment Inc., which has a library containing the TV shows ``Dynasty'' and ``Charlie's Angels.'' Great American and its subsidiaries own five network-affiliated television stations and twelve FM and six AM radio stations in the nation's top 50 markets. Hanna-Barbera is involved in animated film and video production, distribution and marketing worldwide. American Financial Corp. owns 65 percent of Great American.

DOC.HEAD: Quality Inn Owners Interested In Buying Ramada, Howard Johnson
DOC.TEXT: The parent company of the Quality Inn motel chain wants to buy the Ramada and Howard Johnson franchise systems, officials of the company said Tuesday. If successful, the acquisition would create the largest lodging operation in the country. However, Prime Motor Inns, the current owner of Ramada and Howard Johnson, already has reached a preliminary agreement with a New York-based investment group to sell 65 percent of the two franchise systems in a $200 million deal. ``We have told them we're interested in making a proposal for a comparable package or for outright acquisition,'' said Jim MacCutcheon, chief financial officer of Manor Care Inc., the Silver Spring, Md., company that owns Quality Inns. Manor Care officials said they had not made a formal offer for the franchises. MacCutcheon refused to comment on how much his company would offer or when negotiations might begin. The Washington Post reported Tuesday that under a preliminary agreement reached Friday, Blackstone Capital Partners of New York would pay $140 million in cash and $60 million in notes for the 65 percent chunk of the two lodging chains. Blackstone is an affiliate of the merchant banking firm Blackstone Group. That agreement covers the rights to franchise the Howard Johnson and Ramada names, but no motels, which are owned by individual franchisees. Manor Care operates a franchise system through its Quality International subsidiary for 1,077 properties. If successful in acquiring Ramada and Howard Johnson franchises, the Manor Care system would include more than 1,900 inns, representing the largest chain in the United States. Holiday Inns now has the largest chain with 1,450 locations. Last Friday, Manor Care Chairman Stewart Bainum Jr. sent a letter to Prime Chairman Peter E. Simon saying Manor Care was ``extremely interested'' in making a deal with Prime ``superior to the transaction'' with Blackstone. Officials at Prime Motor Inns, based in Fairfield, N.J., refused comment on the offers.

DOC.HEAD: Penney, Limited Quarterly Earnings Up, TJX Profit Fell
DOC.TEXT: J.C. Penney Co. Inc. reported Tuesday its first-quarter earnings rose 20.5 percent, while Limited Inc. posted a 37.9 percent gain during the period. Another retailer, TJX Cos. Inc., said its earnings fell 40 percent from a year earlier, when the company's income was inflated by one-time gains. Penney, the nation's fourth-largest retailer, said it earned $154 million, or $1.21 per share, in the quarter ended April 28, up from $128 million, or 97 cents, a year earlier. The company's total revenue rose 6.3 percent to $3.8 billion from $3.58 billion, while retail sales revenue increased to $3.53 billion from $3.34 billion. Penney Chairman William R. Howell said in a statement that the company's recent sales levels have been disappointing, but ``our expenses are under control and inventories are in line with sales expectations.'' Dallas-based Penney has shifted its emphasis to high-fashion apparel and family wear, dropping hardware and related lines from its stores. Limited, the nation's largest specialty apparel retailer, said it earned $62.3 million, or 34 cents per share, up from $45.2 million, or 25 cents per share, a year earlier. Sales rose 14.8 percent to $1.1 billion from $964.6 million. Apparel retailers such as Limited, which is based in Columbus, Ohio, have been faring better than other store companies as consumers shy away from expensive purchases like appliances. Limited's holdings include its flagship Limited stores; the Limited Express, Victoria's Secret, Lerner and Lane Bryant chains; and several catalog operations. Meanwhile, TJX said it earned $14.6 million, or 21 cents a share, compared with $24.3 million, or 34 cents a share, a year ago. TJX, based in Framingham, Mass., reported sales of $513.8 million, up from $466.4 million. In the 1989 quarter, TJX had more than $5.1 million in gains from its restructuring, which included the sale of its Zayre discount stores. Without those gains, its income would have fallen 23.9 percent this year. TJX said it had strong gains at its Chadwick's of Boston and T.J. Maxx divisions, but that the performance of its Hit or Miss stores was disappointing.

DOC.HEAD: Wall Street Takes A Breather, But Dow Jones Industrials Reach New High
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Wall Street took some time out Tuesday after running up a string of sharp gains, but its retreat was milder than expected and the Dow Jones industrial average still managed to reach a new closing high. Market watchers had anticipated heavy profit-taking after the Dow Jones average surged more than 176 points in less than two weeks. But with relatively light selling, ``we had a constructive day,'' said Dennis Jarrett, an analyst with Kidder Peabody & Co. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials inched up 0.92 to 2,822.45, just eclipsing the record high of 2,821.53 set on Monday. The advance brought to 177.40 points the surge in Wall Street's best-known barometer since April 27. The average fluctuated during the day, but the broader market stayed in negative territory. At the close, declining issues outnumbered advancers by about 4 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 654 up, 856 down and 505 unchanged. Analysts said Wall Street showed continuing signs of strength. Tuesday's selling was an extension of profit-taking that began Monday, when the Dow Jones industrials rose 50 points and then fell back, closing with a 19.95 point gain. While Monday's performance raised the specter of heavier losses Tuesday, ``volume dried up on the downside,'' Jarrett said. The stock market's rally in the last two weeks has been attributed to evidence that inflation is easing, which has sent interest rates plunging. Last Friday's announcement of the second straight monthly decline in wholesale prices fed a 91.22 point gain in the Dow Jones industrial average. The market also has been bolstered by the perception that the Bush administration and Congress are willing to negotiate to reduce the nation's budget deficit. Analysts said the market ignored a government report Tuesday that industrial production fell 0.4 percent in April, the first decline since January, but they said there was some concern on Wall Street about Wednesday's scheduled release of consumer price figures for April. Technology stocks helped lead the market Tuesday. Compaq Computer jumped 2[ to 114{, IBM picked up 1] to close at 115|, and Texas Instruments rose 2\ to 39~. Retailing stocks were among those hardest hit by profit-takers. J.C. Penney, which announced a big earnings increase, fell 1] to 65\. American Express was up 1] to 30| amid speculation it was negotiating to sell its troubled Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. brokerage subsidiary to Primerica. Among other blue chip stocks, Philip Morris rose [ to 44~, AT&T fell | to 41}, and Boeing slipped 1 to 77. Alcan Aluminum, unchanged at 21{, led the NYSE most active list. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 165.73 million shares, down from 225.41 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 207.26 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market fell $3.714 billion, or 0.11 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 0.34 to 193.31. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 0.76 to 411.86, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was off 0.47 at 354.28. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 0.89 to 442.50. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 353.56, down 0.78.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Price Slide Steepens As Supply Tightness Eases
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices fell sharply Tuesday for the third straight day amid profit-taking and speculative fund-selling prompted in part by signs that Brazilian soybean exports are closing the gap between world supply and demand. On other commodity markets, grain futures fell; cocoa futures retreated; oil futures were mixed; precious metals were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Soybean futures settled 8 cents to 11{ cents lower on the Chicago Board of Trade with the contract for delivery in May down 10\ cents at $6.13\ a bushel. The decline extended to about 35 cents the drop in the May soybean contract's price since Thursday, when the Agriculture Department released a report projecting rising U.S. soybean stocks. Some analysts attributed the weakness to increased soybean exports, especially from Brazil, the world's second-largest producer after the United States. Brazilian shipments have risen in the past 10 days after a month-long period in which exports of newly harvested soybeans were stalled by confusion over President Fernando Collor de Mello's harsh economic reforms. USDA figures released Monday showed inspections of U.S. soybeans earmarked for export last week were up nearly 20 percent over a year ago. The soybean rally of the past three months ``was a case where shipments around the world did not equal demand requirements,'' said Mickey Luth, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ``Now, until you create a deficit problem again, you've lost your support for the market,'' he said. William Biedermann, research director for the brokerage firm Allendale Inc., also said the supply picture has improved. ``There are 14 vessels en route from South America right now,'' he said. ``The reality of those supplies hitting world markets is causing users to back off and pull their bids.'' Corn futures posted their steepest one-day decline this year after recently advancing on concerns about rain-delayed planting activity. Biedermann said there is a growing belief among grain traders that the Soviet Union does not intend to buy any more old-crop U.S. corn, a bearish factor in the market Tuesday. Wheat futures settled 1\ cents to 2 cents lower in Chicago with the contract for delivery in May at $3.83 a bushel; corn was 4{ cents to 6 cents lower with May at $2.84} a bushel; oats were { cent lower to \ cent higher with May at $1.56 a bushel. Cocoa futures settled mostly lower on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange amid profit-taking after Monday's dramatic gains. Cocoa settled $14 lower to $6 higher with May at $1,375 per ton. Crude and heating-oil futures fell slightly Tuesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, weakened by speculators cashing in the market's gains. Gasoline futures strengthened because of impending higher demand from summer vacationers, analysts said. After the close the American Petroleum Institute released its weekly stocks report, which showed an unexpected increase of 4.3 million barrels in U.S. crude-oil stocks and an unexpected decline of 4.2 million barrels of gasoline. Distillate stocks were down 66,000 barrels, which was within market expectations. Crude-oil futures settled 12 cents lower to 7 cents higher with June at $19.59 a barrel; heating oil was .10 cent to .28 cent lower with June at 51.72 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .54 cent to .88 cent higher with June at 63.51 cents a gallon. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold futures settled $2.40 to $2.50 higher with June at $372.30 a troy ounce; silver was 5.4 cents to 6.2 cents lower with May at $5.012 a troy ounce. Livestock and meat futures finished narrowly mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in quiet trading ahead of Thursday's monthly USDA cattle-on-feed report. Live cattle settled unchanged to .25 cent lower with June at 73.70 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent lower to .17 cent higher with May at 84.75 cents a pound; hogs were unchanged to .38 cent higher with June at 63.50 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1 cent lower to .22 cent higher with May at 62.22 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Executive Named Head of Black & Decker Power Tools Division
DOC.TEXT: A Chrysler Corp. executive has been named head of Black & Decker Corp.'s power tools division, which has annual revenues of more than $2 billion, Black & Decker announced Tuesday. Michael N. Hammes, 48, has been Chrysler's vice president for international operations since 1986, with responsibility for sales and marketing of North American vehicles around the world, manufacturing operations in Europe, Latin America and the far East, and joint ventures with other auto makers. Hammes replaces George M. Sherman, who resigned in February to become president and chief executive officer of Danaher Corp. Meanwhile, Chrysler named its brand development vice president, Joseph Cappy, the former president of American Motors Corp., to succeed Hammes. Cappy, 56, worked for Ford Motor Co. for 26 years before becoming marketing group vice president at AMC, which Chrysler bought in August 1987. He was AMC's last president and chief executive officer, a post he took a year and a half before Chrysler purchased AMC. For 20 years Hammes also worked for Ford, serving as vice president of European truck operations from 1983 to 1986. At Chrysler, international revenues grew from just over $1 billion in 1986 to $4 billion in 1989 under his direction. Black & Decker's power tools group makes consumer and professional power tools and accessories, outdoor products and automotive products. Black & Decker has reported losses for the past four quarters. The losses were attributed to the toolmaker's April 1989 $2.8 billion acquisition of Emhart Corp. of Farmington, Conn., which makes locks, tools, sporting goods, faucets, staplers and other products. Analysts said at the time that Black & Decker probably would not turn a profit for a year and a half after the takeover. Before purchasing Emhart, Black & Decker failed in attempts to acquire American Standard Inc. and Oster-Sunbeam.

DOC.HEAD: Three CBOT Traders Settle Charges; One Pays $250,000
DOC.TEXT: Three Chicago Board of Trade bond futures traders have agreed to pay a total of $260,000 to settle charges of non-competitive trading brought against them by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. Keith M. Rudman, who trades contracts for future deliveries of U.S. Treasury bonds, agreed Monday to a $250,000 settlement just as he, 20 other bond traders and a broker were about to begin defending themselves against the federal regulatory agency. Rudman also agreed to testify against the 21 others if asked, and he agreed not to try to return to trading for two years. Two other bond traders also settled just before a hearing in Chicago before the CFTC. George D. Leventis agreed to a $5,000 fine and a two-week suspension from the exchange, and Roy E. Erickson agreed to a $5,000 fine and a five-day suspension.

DOC.HEAD: President of Douglas Helicopter Division To Resign
DOC.TEXT: William P. Brown, president of the McDonnell Douglas Helicopter Co. for the past four years, will resign and serve as a consultant to the company, a spokesman said Tuesday. Jim Reed, a spokesman St. Louis-based McDonnell Douglas Corp., parent of the helicopter subsidiary, declined to reveal the reasons for Brown's resignation. A successor will be named in the next few weeks, the company said. In an announcement to helicopter company employees, John McDonnell, chairman and chief executive officer of McDonnell Douglas Corp., praised Brown's ``valued leadership,'' but offered no explanation. Some stock analysts said the resignation might be linked to the subsidiary's poor performance last year when inventory and audit troubles required $137 million in writeoffs. Earnings for the subsidiary in the first quarter of this year were down, when compared to the first quarter of 1989, but company officials did not provide any other details. During the transition, William Ross, president of McDonnell Aircraft Co., will assume the additional responsibility of heading the helicopter subsidiary, the company said. The helicopter company, based in Mesa, Ariz., makes the Apache helicopter for the Army and the MD-500, a commercial and military helicopter. It also operates a plant in Culver City, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Subsidiary Placed in Bankruptcy; Yugoslavian Bank Sues for $70 Million
DOC.TEXT: A Polish bank on Tuesday sought to place a Drexel Burnham Lambert financing subsidiary into involuntary bankruptcy proceedings for failing to pay back a $5 million loan. The move came one day after Yugoslavia's central bank sued the collapsed Wall Street firm for more than $70 million in investment losses it claims were part a scheme to funnel money into Drexel's parent company. The parent, Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors in February after failing to meet debt payments due to a weakening financial condition following its securities fraud guilty plea. In a petition filed Tuesday in U.S. Bankruptcy Court, Bank Polska Kasa Opieki asked a judge to assign a trustee to liquidate Drexel Burnham Trade Finance Inc. A Drexel spokesman said the firm would exercise its right to convert the case from a Chapter 7 liquidation to a Chapter 11 case, where the debtor would continue managing the company. DBL Trade Finance is the second Drexel unit creditors have tossed into bankruptcy court alongside the parent company, indicating frustration with progress in resolving payments to creditors. The unit has assets of $88 million and liabilities of $94 million. Jon Arnason, an attorney for Bank Polska, said it is owed $5 million plus $76,000 in interest from a 30-day loan placed with one of Drexel's European entities in December. The money was due Feb. 20. Other creditors include the National Bank of Poland, which the petition said is owed $12 million, and a Drexel subsidiary in Britain, said to be owed $28 million. The subsidiary is owed $28 million from the parent company and $20.5 million from Drexel Burnham Lambert Trading Inc., a commodities trading unit now in Chapter 11 proceedings, according to the filing. DBL Trade Finance engaged in foreign currency trading and handled loans in connection with commodities-based transactions. Separately, the National Bank of Yugoslavia charged that Drexel failed to disclose that it used money borrowed from that nation last year to help raise cash for Drexel's parent company. The central bank claims it lost about $71 million in the scheme _ more than 1 percent of the country's federal budget. It is seeking to recover the losses plus $10 million in punitive damages. ``We dispute the premise of the complaint, but beyond that we don't have any comment,'' Drexel said in a statement. The Yugoslavian bank was one of four large unsecured creditors that last week pushed DBL Trading into involuntary bankruptcy proceedings. The bank claims Drexel failed to disclose its intended use of the borrowed money as well as information about the parent company's deteriorating financial condition. It claims that Yugoslavian law requires the bank to make ``safety'' the primary concern for investing its reserves. It said investments are restricted to the 100 largest commerical banks worldwide and high-quality debt securities issued or guaranteed by developed nations. The bank said it had never before lost money in an investment transaction. According to the lawsuit, filed late Monday in U.S. District Court in Manhattan, Drexel contacted central bank officials last June to discuss investing some of its funds. The bank said it had not done business with Drexel previously. The bank said it bought a total of $80 million in time deposit investments in U.S. dollars and West German marks in September and rolled them over in December. The investments were placed in banks in the name of the commodities trading unit. The lawsuit states that Drexel did not invest the money as required but instead transferred it to the parent company. The bank claims Drexel never informed it how it was investing the money. On Feb. 13, when Drexel's parent filed for Chapter 11, it sent a telex to the Yugoslavian bank saying: ``We have been trying to reach you urgently. Our parent company has some liquidity problems which we would like to explain to you over the telephone.'' When it made the bankruptcy filing, Drexel's parent owed its commodities unit $645 million. The Yugoslavian bank claims its investments were part of money ``upstreamed'' from the commodities unit to Drexel's parent.

DOC.HEAD: Miller to Test Market New Barley Brew
DOC.TEXT: Miller Brewing Co. said Tuesday it will test a new barley-only beer in four markets, under a strategy to grab a bigger share of the shrinking market for superpremium beers. The all-malt beer, to be called Miller Reserve, will be tested in Rhode Island, Connecticut, Richmond, Va., and Atlanta starting Wednesday, Miller spokesman David Fogelson said. In brewing the product with only barley and no corn or other grain fillers, the company is using the same approach as for some products made by smaller breweries that have grown rapidly in recent years. Miller Reserve is brewed using a cold-filtered process, in which contaminants are removed from the beer using a filtration system rather than heat pasteurization. ``In Miller Reserve, we've brought back the tradition of an all-barley beer and gone a step further by using our unique draft-brewing process,'' said David Krishock, new products category director for the Milwaukee-based brewery. As light beers have continued growing in popularity, the market share held by superpremium and import beers has slipped markedly in recent years. Miller hopes Miller Reserve will seize a portion of the shrinking market, which averages about 16 million to 18 million barrels a year. Miller Reserve is being brewed and shipped from the Miller brewery at Eden, N.C. Milwaukee-based Frankenberry, Laughlin & Constable is to handle advertising for the brand. The beer packaging includes a 20-sided bottle and a six-pack carrier with high sides, Miller said. Miller is the nation's second-largest brewer behind St. Louis-based Anheuser-Busch Inc. Miller's principal brands include Miller High Life, Miller Lite, Miller Genuine Draft, Lowenbrau, Magnum, Meister Brau and Milwaukee's Best. Miller also produces Sharp's, a non-alcoholic brew.

DOC.HEAD: Earnings Decline as Gains From Asset Sales Tumble
DOC.TEXT: Hanson PLC said its net income fell nearly 12 percent in the first three months of 1990 compared with a year earlier, when the British conglomerate's profits were boosted by one-time gains on asset sales. Without the gains, earnings were up 36 percent in the quarter, Hanson said Tuesday. Earnings included a first-time contribution from Consolidated Gold Fields, the British-based mining company Hanson acquired last August in a $5.4 billion takeover. Hanson's U.S. businesses include SCM Chemicals, Jacuzzi whirlpools, Kaiser Cement and Faberware cookware. Its British operations include Imperial Tobacco and several building supply companies. Net income in the company's fiscal second quarter totalled $414 million, or 39 cents, for each of Hanson's American depositary receipts, down from $469 million, or 40 cents an ADR, in the same quarter a year earlier. The latest quarter's results included a one-time loss of $16 million from asset sales and currency adjustments. In the year-earlier quarter, Hanson reported a one-time gain of $153 million by selling some of its businesses. Sales declined to $2.98 billion in the latest quarter from $3.03 billion. Hanson said it had taken in $1.81 billion by selling parts of Consolidated Gold Fields since it purchased the company. ``At March 31, we had cash balances of $10.49 billion, no net gearing (borrowing) and substantial borrowing capacity,'' Lord Hanson, the company's chairman, said in a statement. ``We remain in a strong position to continue the future development of the company, both by acquisition and internal investment.'' For the first six months of the company's fiscal year, net income rose 1 percent to $995 million, or 74 cents an ADR, from $985 million, or 71 cents, a year earlier. One-time gains from asset sales fell to $283 million in the latest six months from $425 million a year earlier. Without the gains, its profit was up 27 percent to $712 million. Sales declined to $5.97 billion from $6.21 billion. Hanson declared a dividend of 17 pence an ADR, or about 28 cents, for the first half, up 20 percent from a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: U S West Announces `Self-Healing' Telephone Services
DOC.TEXT: U S West Inc. said Tuesday it will build new fiber optic phone lines for businesses in five cities that will ``heal'' themselves in the event of a failure. The regional phone company also said it will offer a similar service to link various plants and buildings of a corporation or government agency. The first service is aimed at improving the reliability of phone service to customers with medium to large amounts of data, voice and video traffic by providing backup electronics and two separate fiber-optic lines through two telephone central offices. Several fiber-optic rings will be placed in each city, with an average of 37 miles of fiber optics per city, said Hawk. An average of 40 buildings in each city will be targeted for installation, he said. The service, called Alternate Route Protection, will be offered in Denver, Minneapolis-St. Paul, Portland, Seattle and Phoenix, U S West said. The service will be available starting in September in Minneapolis, with Phoenix the last city on the company's installation schedule, in July 1991. ``With the convergence of data processing and telecommunications, our customers' networks carry traffic often representing millions of dollars. They can't afford even one minute of downtime,'' said Bob Hawk, president of U S West Communications' Carrier and Information Provider division. ``With an availability rate of 99.99 percent, these new services virtually guarantee the highest reliability technically possible.'' U S West said it will offer one month of free service if a customer suffers downtime while using the new services. The second service, the Self-Healing Network Service, is aimed at companies and government agencies with multiple locations. U S West said two concentric fiber-optic rings will be installed linking the locations, each employing devices that detect problems. In the event of a failure, the system would ``heal'' itself instantly by sending the transmission in the opposite direction around the ring, U S West said.

DOC.HEAD: Merv Griffin's Troubled Company Posts Quarterly Loss
DOC.TEXT: Merv Griffin's Resorts International Inc. said it continued to lose money in the first quarter but at a much slower rate than before the company filed for bankruptcy protection. The company lost $3.1 million on revenues of $107.5 million in the first three months of 1990 compared with a loss of $18.7 million on revenues of $113.5 million in the first quarter of 1989. The improvement was a result of not having to make interest payments on the company's outstanding bonds. In the first quarter of 1989, those interest payments amounted to $32.7 million. The company said Griffin Resorts Inc., a Bahamian subsidiary put up for sale last month, posted a profit of $2.1 million on revenues of $50.1 million in the quarter compared with a $5.2 million profit on revenues of $50.5 million a year earlier. The company did not release figures on Merv Griffin Resorts Casino Hotel in Atlantic City. However, the Casino Association of New Jersey reported that the casino lost $5.8 million on revenues of $51.5 million in the first quarter. Six months ago, Resort filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code. Griffin has proposed giving bondholders 78 percent of his full ownership of the company in exchange for about $400 million of the $927 million in bonds outstanding. The reorganization plan is subject to the approval of the bankruptcy court, the N.J. Casino Control Commission and bondholders. The Atlantic City property, which was the first to open here 12 years ago, has fallen on hard times, consistently placing among the bottom of the city's 12 casinos.

Trans World Airlines Inc. said its loss ballooned to $143 million in the first quarter because of a sharp rise in fuel costs and other operating expenses. The private carrier, controlled by investor Carl Icahn, said the results compared with a loss of $83.1 million in the first three months of 1989. On an operating basis, which excludes interest and tax payments, TWA's loss widened to $100.7 million from $30.9 million. Revenues increased by $25.1 million to $1.01 billion in the quarter, but expenses outpaced that, rising by $94.8 million to $1.12 billion. A 36 percent jump in average fuel prices compared with the 1989 quarter boosted expenses by $52.9 million, the airline said. The remaining increase of $41.9 million in expenses reflected the cost of adding capacity and improving service, it said. Revenue passenger miles, a key indicator of health in the airline industry, rose less than a tenth of one percent to 7.11 billion. TWA filled 53.2 percent of its seats in the latest quarter, down slightly from 53.9 percent a year earlier. Icahn has said he needs wage concessions of 10 percent from pilots in order to buy up to 100 new jets and modernize the carrier. Without concessions, he has threatened to shrink TWA and has suggested turning over its domestic routes to America West. TWA said the results didn't include $106 million in unrealized gains on its investment portfolio.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Bans Hughes Division From New Contracts
DOC.TEXT: A Hughes Aircraft Co. research center has been suspended from bidding on government contracts after the company admitted that executives trafficked in secret Pentagon documents, government and company officials said. The suspension prevents the research and development center of Hughes' missile systems group from bidding on new government business but doesn't affect outstanding contracts. The center is located in the San Fernando Valley suburb of Canoga Park and employs 2,100 workers, mostly scientists and engineers. The missile group accounted for $1.3 billion of Hughes' $7.4 billion in 1988 sales, the last year for which sales were broken down by division. Overally, Hughes has about 68,000 workers. ``Obviously we are very concerned about it,'' said Hughes spokesman Richard Dore. ``It doesn't really have an impact on current programs.'' Hughes received notice of the ban last Thursday and has 30 days to present its case, said Capt. Jack Giese, an Air Force spokesman. The Air Force has proposed a three-year suspension for the research center, Dore said. The actual length of the suspension will be decided after the government reviews operations at the center, he said. The suspension was imposed after Hughes entered guilty pleas on two felony counts of using classified Pentagon documents to gain a competitive advantage. Hughes executives said they acquired classified documents between 1978 and 1985. The guilty pleas were entered in March.

DOC.HEAD: Bargain Hunters Check Out Braniff Auction
DOC.TEXT: Bargain hunters from across the nation bid on everything from baggage tractors to office equipment Tuesday at a bankruptcy auction of Braniff Inc. assets. ``I would say it was a success,'' said Brian Hayes, auction coordinator for Rabin Brothers, the San Francisco firm that handled the sale. ``We had about 260 registered bidders. We had people come from all over the country, from South America, from Canada,'' Hayes said. Nearly 2,000 items that had been appraised at between $10 million and $11 million in total were auctioned, Hayes said. ``I'm not at liberty to say how much money was made, but the prices were good,'' he said. ``Some of the stuff went for what it almost cost new.'' Tractors that push airplanes, the jetways that connect planes to terminals and office machinery all were included in the auction. Braniff also has a Boeing 737 for sale, but it was not included in the auction, Hayes said. Other bankruptcy auctions are scheduled for Thursday in Orlanda, Fla., and on May 22 in Dallas, Hayes said. The auction was held at Braniff's old reservations center near Kansas City International Airport and lasted about nine hours. Braniff had been building a hub in Kansas City until it collapsed last year.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Opens Lower, Share Prices Slip
DOC.TEXT: The dollar opened lower against the yen Wednesday morning, while share prices eased slightly on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The dollar started trading at 150.90 yen, down 0.40 yen from Tuesday's 151.30-yen close. The dollar has declined 6.75 yen over the previous five sessions. Dealers said the dollar's lower opening followed its overnight decline in New York, where the currency closed at 150.83 yen, down from 152.50 yen Monday. ``After its lower opening, the dollar has been moving narrowly, and it is unlikely to fall as low as 150 yen because some market players are buying back the currency whenever it moves lower,'' said Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co. The 150-yen level is a major psychological barrier for many investors, so trading is likely to be mixed before the market establishes a firm direction, Kanai said. He said the majority of participants were sitting on the sidelines ahead of the release Wednesday in Washington of April U.S. consumer prices and Thursday of March trade data. The reports are expected to provide further indications of the direction of the U.S. economy and interest rates. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average slipped 15.7 points, or 0.05 percent, to 31,981.34 in the first 30 minutes of morning trading. The Nikkei lost 45.61 points Tuesday. Traders said the index fell in a continued reaction to the rapid increases posted last week. The price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond fell to 88.18 from Tuesday's close at 88.63. That boosted the yield to 6.95 percent from 6.92 percent.

DOC.HEAD: New `Development Pool' to Push US Sales in Far East
DOC.TEXT: U.S. agencies have announced the creation of a $500 million aid pool to help promote sales by American business in the Far East against government-subsidized competition from Japan, France and Britain. The money initially will go largely for loans to Indonesia, Pakistan, the Philippines and Thailand, the U.S. Agency for International Development said Tuesday. AID will provide $100 million of the money from its Economic Support Fund, most of which goes to Israel and Egypt. ``The program will be limited to markets where other governments already are engaging in extensive, trade-distorting tied-aid finance activities,'' AID said in a statement. ``Tied aid'' typically requires a Third World country to spend the aid on products made in the donor country. Tied aid usually takes the form of a loan at a low rate of interest, subsidized by the donor government. Jeni Falkiewicz of the U.S. Export-Import Bank, which also is contributing to the aid pool, said the money would help businesses compete especially against tied aid provided by Japan, France and Britain. Successive U.S. governments have opposed tied aid because American businesses say its often prevents them from getting lucrative contracts overseas. U.S. negotiators have failed to win agreements outlawing tied aid, though. Last week John D. Macomber, president of the Export-Import Bank, said he would try to get tied aid outlawed for some categories of products, including power plants and communications system. AID said the new pool will support projects in telecommunications, transportation, power and construction equipment. Projects helped by the pool will meet AID criteria and will be in line with the priorities of the recipient country. AID said none of the money will come from its funds marked for development assistance. AID has cooperated with the Ex-Im bank on some projects, but the new pool is the first large-scale effort of its kind. Its formation follows statements in Congress suggesting that the United States reconsider its aid programs to take into account its impact on American businesses and jobs. In addition to the $100 million from AID, the Export-Import Bank will provide guarantees on $300 million worth of loans from private banks. The guarantees enable banks to charge borrowing countries lower rates of interest. The bank also will contribute $100 million from its Tied-Aid Credit Fund. This is usually called the ``war chest,'' used to match offers of tied aid from competing governments. The Bush administration has asked for another $114 million for this fund. Many members of Congress would like to appropriate more. One bill recently introduced would add $1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Van Gogh's `Portrait of Dr. Gachet' Sells For $82.5 Million
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT to Kobayashi. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese gallery bought Vincent van Gogh's ``Portrait of Dr. Gachet'' for $82.5 million Tuesday, a record auction price for any art work and double the price estimated by Christie's, a spokeswoman for the auction house said. ``This is by far the world's most expensive painting,'' surpassing the $53.9 million price bid for Van Gogh's ``Irises'' in November 1987 at Sotheby's auction house, Christie's spokeswoman Susan Britman said. The buyer, a representative for the Kobayashi Gallery in Tokyo, was in the room during the approximately 10 minutes of bidding that opened at $20 million, Britman said. Toward the end of bidding, only the Kobayshi representative and a telephone bidder whose identity wasn't disclosed were vying for the painting, she said. ``Portrait of Dr. Gachet,'' an image of the physician who tended Van Gogh during the last weeks before his suicide, was painted 100 years ago. It had been expected to fetch between $40 million and $50 million at a sale of major works by impressionist and modern artists. The auction has been anticipated as a key test of the strength of the art market. Prices boomed in the mid- to late 1980s but the 1987 stock market crash and unusual circumstances surrounding the sale of ``Irises'' had cast doubt on whether prices would continue to rise. Australian entrepreneur Alan Bond bought ``Irises'' largely with money borrowed from Sotheby's, the house that handled the auction. Bond's business empire became swamped in debt after the stock market crash, and he was forced to sell the painting for an undisclosed price to the J. Paul Getty Museum in March. ``Dr. Gachet'' was lent to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1984. It is from the collection of Siegfried Kramarsky, a German-born New York banker who died in 1961. It was put on the block by a trust created under his will. The portrait of Dr. Paul-Ferdinand Gachet was painted six weeks before van Gogh committed suicide in 1890. In a letter to artist Paul Gauguin, van Gogh wrote that he had painted Gachet ``with the heart-broken expression of our time'' and that it was ``not destined to be understood.'' Gachet, a practitioner of homeopathic medicine, was van Gogh's friend and physician. He was also close to other impressionist painters of the time. In the painting, Gachet is shown seated at a table, head in hand. Van Gogh painted a second, slightly larger version of the portrait, which hangs in the Musee d'Orsay in Paris. It lacks the details of the Kramarsky painting and its colors are flatter. Another van Gogh from the Kramarsky collection was auctioned in 1987 for $20.24 million. It too had been lent to the Metropolitan.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Judges Say They Might Reopen Manville Bankruptcy
DOC.TEXT: Two judges supervising hundreds of asbestos damage cases said they might seek to reopen the bankruptcy proceeding of the Manville Corp., a newspaper reported. The judges also suggested that the multibillion dollar trust set up by Manville to compensate victims of asbestos-related diseases had been mismanaged, The New York Times reported in Wednesday's paper. At a hearing Tuesday, Federal District Judge Jack B. Weinstein and state Supreme Court Justice Helen E. Freedman ordered the Manville Personal Injury Settlement Trust to explain why it had been depleted of cash so soon and why it recently decided that tens of thousands of asbestos victims, many with fatal diseases, would not be compensated until well beyond the year 2000, the newspaper said. Representatives for other asbestos companies named in lawsuits and lawyers for some plaintiffs have said that hundreds of millions of dollars were paid as fees to only a handful of plaintiffs' lawyers, helping to create the cash shortage, the Times said. The two judges said they might seek to have the bankruptcy plan amended so Manville, which won protection from lawsuits in exchange for establishing the trust, could lose that protection. They also said the corporation might be forced to contribute more money to the trust. In a veiled reference to the management of the trust, the Times said the judges reminded one of the trust's lawyers that they had the authority to seize the trust's assets and appoint a receiver. As of March 31, the Times said the $2.5 billion trust had received about 152,000 claims. It has made payments or promised to pay more than $935 million to settle 22,204 claims, the newspaper said. Lawyers involved in the Manville bankruptcy and litigation said more than $200 million had been disbursed to fewer than three dozen lawyers who represent plaintiffs, the Times said. Last month, trust lawyers filed bankruptcy papers saying that an asbestos plaintiff who filed a claim now would receive 40 percent of the claim in 2015 and the remaining 60 percent in 2020. Payments would be without interest. The judges gave the trust until June 1 to respond to their questions and hinted they would take action then, the Times said.
